HEADLINE: Gold Miners Eager for Bush To Roll Back Clinton Rules 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CRESCENT VALLEY, Nev. 

 BODY:
These are the hills that gold built, acres and acres of rubble piled more than 200 feet high, the detritus of mining operations that require the removal of 80 tons of rock to produce a single ounce of gold.
 If Nevada were a country, it would be the third-largest producer of gold in the world, thanks largely to a 129-year-old federal law that gives mining companies broad license to scrape and otherwise reshape public lands to get at elusive ores. And mining operations like the giant Cortez complex here are among the most profitable anywhere, in part because the law does not require mining companies to share their gains with federal taxpayers. 
 But the industry has come to see itself as under siege, a target of rule changes by the Clinton administration that scaled back some of those old prerogatives. Now, in places like Crescent Valley, hopes are running fervent that the tide will turn again. 
The Bush administration is widely expected to roll back the bulk of the major Clinton-era regulations governing mining on public lands, in an action anticipated by next month -- one that could not come too soon for Nevada's gold mining industry. 
The anticipated shifts are not only portrayed as further evidence that the pendulum has swung significantly toward positions advocated by industry, but also a demonstration of how administrative rule changes, which do not require Congressional approval, can have a profound effect on the ground.
The changes would scrap most of the rules that took effect on Jan. 20, President Bill Clinton's last day in office, leaving in place a set of weaker regulations imposed in 1980. One measure that would be set aside gives federal officials the power to block mining operations likely to cause "substantial irreparable harm" to resources on public lands. In addition, the Interior Department is expected to undo a 1997 regulatory interpretation that imposed a strict limit on how much land could be used for dumping, milling and other activities to support future mining operations.
"We were dealt a devious, malicious hook," Tony A. Jensen, the Cortez mine general manager, said of the stricter regulations. "And until something changes, we will have a tremendous amount of concern about our future."
The dumping rules, which would probably have greater overall impact, would have little effect on existing mines. But they could greatly restrict future operations. 
Valuable minerals like gold and copper generally are found only in quantities invisible to the naked eye, so mining companies extract them by sifting through vast quantities of rock and soil, usually gouged from an open pit. Most of the waste is simply piled in dumps, and even what is deemed to be viable ore must be milled or stacked in heaps and then bathed in a cyanide solution to disgorge tiny flecks of precious metal. 
The process is so land intensive that the largest pit at Cortez is nearly a mile across, and the area used for milling, dumping and support exceeds that used for mining by five to one.
Mining critics have welcomed the Clinton land-use limit as a novel way to rein in operations they see as having overstepped their bounds. But it has been regarded within the industry and among its allies in Congress as a sneaky, backdoor substitute for the Clinton administration's earlier efforts to rewrite the mining law itself, which failed to win Congressional approval.
Already, members of Congress, including Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, have enacted legislation exempting existing mining operations from the new land-use rules. But the industry has been pushing the Bush administration to draft a legal opinion of its own that would also spare new operations. People on both sides of the debate expect the administration to accede.
The Interior Department said in June that it would retain one provision of the environmental rules that the Clinton administration enacted in January, which toughens rules requiring mining companies to put up bonds against the potential cost of environmental harm. But that idea was never strongly opposed by mining officials, and with a decision on the rest of the package expected soon, the industry's main critics say they are pessimistic.
"On mining, the difference between Bush and Clinton is the difference between night and day," said Alan Septoff, research director for the Center for Mineral Policy, an advocacy group. 
Indeed, Bruce Babbitt, the interior secretary under President Clinton, often criticized regulations that allowed industry to extract billions of dollars of minerals from public land while paying what Mr. Babbitt said was too little in taxes. He described the mining law as "one of the most outrageous corporate subsidies" in American history.
But under Gale A. Norton, Mr. Babbitt's successor, the Interior Department has been far friendlier. Its proposal to roll back the environmental regulations for public-lands mining was one of the department's first actions, and its new No. 2 official, J. Steven Griles, a former mining lobbyist, is respected by the industry as a sympathetic expert.
"It was a tough eight years, and now we are doing triage," said Joe Danni, a vice president and director of Placer Dome America, one of the country's largest mining companies and the majority owner of the Cortez mine. (Like most big mining companies operating in the United States, Placer Dome is foreign owned; it is a subsidiary of Placer Dome Inc. of Vancouver, British Columbia.)
Opponents of hard-rock mining point to an Environmental Protection Agency finding that the mining industry produces more toxic waste than any other. In addition, taxpayer watchdog groups have attacked the terms enjoyed by producers of gold, silver and copper on public lands -- rules that are far more generous than those offered to the oil, gas or timber industries.
But people on both sides of the fight say the atmosphere is volatile now because the price of gold and copper has fallen sharply. 
In Nevada, which produces 70 percent of the country's gold, gold mining is still a $3 billion a year industry, second only to gambling in the state's economy. But since 1997, the number of people in Nevada directly employed by mining has dropped to 11,000 from 15,000, said Russ A. Fields, president of the Nevada Mining Association. 
Some of the jobs were cut because of falling gold prices, Mr. Fields said. But he contended that others were the result of "a chilling effect on new exploration" caused by both sets of the Clinton rules, which encouraged some companies to look overseas for new supplies. 
The industry says it fears that the veto power granted to the government under the latest Clinton rules could be used capriciously to block mining operations, even at the last minute, on the ground that they would cause "substantial irreparable harm." The industry prefers the previous rule, which prohibits only environmental disturbances "greater than what would normally result when an activity is being accomplished by a prudent operator in usual, customary, and proficient operations of similar character."
The Cortez mines lie in a "area of control" covering 250 square miles in which Placer Dome and its partner, Kennecott, control mining rights under laws that allow companies to stake claims on public lands for nothing more than filing fees.
The operation is enormously profitable, with Cortez producing more than one million ounces of gold a year at an average cost of $160 an ounce; even with the depressed price of gold, that amounts to a profit of more than $100 per ounce. Under the 1872 law, mining companies pay no federal royalties. By contrast, producers of oil, gas and coal pay up to 12.5 percent in royalties for mining on public land.
Cortez's center of operations, an open pit known as Pipeline, stretches nearly a mile across and will ultimately be 1,000 feet deep, while piles of waste rock nearby will eventually tower more than 400 feet above the natural terrain. Both the pit and the hills will become permanent features of the land, under rules more forgiving than, for example, those requiring that surface coal mines be returned to their original state. 
A cyanide solution is used to separate the microscopic flecks of gold from the surrounding ore -- a process that at the Cortez mines alone consumes more than 2 million pounds a year of cyanide, a highly toxic chemical, posing what environmentalists say are potential risks to groundwater.
"We're going to see impacts out there for hundreds of years," said Tom Myers, director of the Great Basin Mine Watch, an environmental group. 
But in a tour of the mine, Mr. Jensen and other senior managers painted a very different picture.
Active mining operations, they noted, cover just a tiny fraction of the "area of control;" only when gold is found in economically viable quantities is the land disturbed. Five percent of the mine's net proceeds, or about $10 million a year, is paid in state taxes. 
The use of cyanide is governed by strict environmental regulations, enforced by the federal Bureau of Land Management and the state, which require that pits be lined to prevent toxic seepage. The piles of waste rock, though visible from miles away, are being reshaped to more closely replicate natural contours.
Even industry critics concede that the Clinton land-use limits -- allowing just one acre of milling and dumping areas for every four acres of mining claims -- will be all but impossible for many mines to heed. They say companies in need of more land for their operations could always buy it from the federal government, at market prices, but they say the real lesson that mining officials should draw is that the 1872 law is unworkable, for all sides, and is in need of a major overhaul.
"If the multinational mining industry wants the subsidies that it has enjoyed for 129 years, namely billions of dollars in publicly owned minerals for free, and exclusive, essentially free use of publicly owned lands for mining, they must comply with the whole law," said Mr. Septoff of the Center for Mineral Policy. 
That is not a message that sits well in Crescent Valley, where miners point to the bleak surrounding terrain and say they doubt it could be put to better use.
"Just remember," said one employee, Jason Lowe, 33, a heavy equipment operator, "agriculture, mining and lumber -- that's what built America."

HEADLINE: When All Roads Lead to Wall Street 

BYLINE:  By Charles R. Morris; Charles R. Morris is the author, most recently, of "Money, Greed and Risk."

 BODY:
Get thee glass eyes," King Lear says to Gloucester, "and like a scurvy politician, seem to see the things thou dost not."
 Wall Street is cutting jobs by the tens of thousands, and big banks and investment banks are privately predicting a dire downturn in the financial services business. But city politicians, according to news reports, foresee only minor speed bumps on the highway of prosperity. Shakespeare would not have been surprised. 
 Wall Street's fortunes and city finance have been inextricably linked since New York's manufacturing economy dried up in the 1950's. During Mayor John Lindsay's first term, New York enjoyed one of the fastest-growing economies and lowest unemployment rates in the country because the stock market was at the peak of its 60's go-go years. But when the market tumbled in 1968 and 1969 and again in the early 1970's, the city careered toward insolvency and disgrace.
There was another go-go period in the 1980's. Wall Street's leveraged buyout boom swept away sour memories of default and "Drop Dead!" missives from Washington. Mayor Ed Koch metamorphosed from the tight-fisted fiscal disciplinarian of the late 1970's to the good-times free spender of the mid-1980's.
What economists call the FIRE sector of the economy -- finance, insurance and real estate -- accounts for half or even more of city employment, counting the rippling impact on all the law firms and accountants, restaurants and taxicabs, florists, financial printers and other businesses that feed from Wall Street's table leavings. The prices of co-op apartments in upscale buildings generally follow the Dow Jones average but lag behind by a year or two when the direction is down. It takes that long to figure out that moving up to a terrace view of the park is a set-up for a big loss when the best price you can get won't cover your mortgage.
As the long boom of the 90's made giddy excess the norm, wise men convinced themselves that this time would be different. After all, they said, New York was no longer so dependent on the fortunes of Wall Street. We were becoming a high-tech media center -- just look at the new Web-based companies in Manhattan's Silicon Alley. Long a technology laggard, New York City suddenly became a magnet for venture capital, trailing only San Francisco in attracting technology venture financing.
But the Silicon Alley phenomenon was mostly froth from the stock market boom. Few of the Web companies were real businesses with real earnings. They depended on a stream of new money from bursting coffers of investment banks and private equity funds. Now Web entrepreneurs rub shoulders with tech-stock brokers in the unemployment lines.
To his credit, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has not lapsed into the lavish spending that marred the last term of Mayor Koch. Over the past few years percentage increases in city spending have been in the low single digits, and this year projections are for a relatively flat budget. When tax revenues turn down, as they must this year, the city is likely to be facing yawning deficits and painful service cutbacks once again.
Are New Yorkers doomed to repeat the cycle of stock-market-driven boom and bust forever? The great hopes for a more diversified economy have faded with the dreams of the dot-com entrepreneurs. If that's a harbinger of what's to come, our next mayor will be dispensing bitter medicine. And we'd better get used to it, because this market downturn could well be a long one.

HEADLINE: Japan's Budget Deficit Has Soared. It's Time for a Tax Cut. 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
NEARLY two decades ago, when almost everyone knew that Japan's all-powerful economic machine was vastly superior to ours, Russell Baker offered a modest proposal in these pages: In return for Japan's sending cars to us, we should export our lawyers.
 It was a brilliant idea, and one that needs to be revived, with but one change. We should send them supply-side economists instead. 
 Let me make it clear that I think more highly of such economists than Mr. Baker seemed to think of lawyers. Two decades ago, the supply-siders performed a valuable service. They persuaded a popular new president, who had been elected as a fiscal conservative, to slash taxes and claim that no budget deficit would result. Lower tax rates, they said, would miraculously bring higher tax revenues.
That proved to be wrong. But it was a good idea nonetheless. The United States was going through painful economic times, and the tax cut provided relief for the majority who were not to be victims of the cutbacks that were needed to make American business more competitive. The economic stimulus helped to end a severe recession.
Japan's prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, now needs all the help he can get to turn around an economy that is viewed as hopeless by the same people who once deemed it omnipotent. He has promised reforms that will clean up the balance sheets of banks and restructure the economy. Longer term, such reforms are necessary. But their immediate effect will be to raise unemployment and restrain economic activity.
It is good news that Japan's central bank moved this week to print money, after making the belated discovery that, as Masaru Hayami, the Bank of Japan's governor, said, "the downside risks to the economy are becoming a reality."
But more is needed. Consumers in Japan these days are the mirror image of those in this country. The last decade has taught many Japanese that economic growth is ephemeral at best, and saving is the most prudent course. Their caution depresses growth, while consumer optimism here has so far kept this country out of recession.
There will be more pain from restructuring in Japan. Getting the banks in shape will mean some borrowers are forced into bankruptcy, putting people out of work. But most people will not lose their jobs, and a tax cut could encourage them to spend. "You have a shot at breaking the logjam in Japan," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company. "For the vast majority, the tax burden would go down substantially, and the purchasing power of their income would go up substantially."
Japan has tried fiscal stimulus before, building roads and bridges that kept the construction industry happy but accomplished little else. Some money from tax cuts would vanish into savings accounts, but the rest would be spent on things people want. Consumer confidence might rise.
The previous spending sent Japan's debt soaring, leading Mr. Koizumi to run on a budget-balancing platform, just as Mr. Reagan once did. He needs a way out of that promise without having to admit he is breaking it. That is where the supply-siders come in.
Japan's domestic policies are all the more important because it is on its own as it has not been in recent years. Without strong American growth, there is little hope for a weak yen to produce an export-led revival. And with the dollar looking shaky, Mr. Koizumi may even have to cope with a rising yen. Tax cuts are a gamble worth taking.

HEADLINE: Ford Weighs Plans to Cut White-Collar Work Force 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 16 

 BODY:
Alarmed by the slowing economy and a slumping market share, executives of Ford Motor have approved an early-retirement program for up to 10 percent of its white-collar employees in the United States, or 4,600 workers, people close to the company said today.
 Ford's management has also begun reviewing the possible delay of some planned vehicle models, which would lower the company's design and engineering costs, and has even started considering whether to shut down an assembly plant, these people said. But only the early-retirement plan appears imminent, they said, partly because Ford has only just installed a new group vice president for North American operations, Nick Scheele, who has begun a comprehensive review of the automaker's activities in the region. 
 The American auto market has been slowing steadily this summer, and Ford has fared worst of all. Sales tumbled 12.7 percent last month while the overall market slipped 5 percent, so Ford finds itself in the unenviable position of holding a shrinking share of a shrinking market. 
Shares of Ford, which is also facing the likelihood of a downgraded credit rating, have been steadily declining, producing pressure from Wall Street for the company to cut costs quickly.
"There is a whole list of actions being considered, some of which will be announced very shortly," said a person close to the company who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The Street is concerned, and obviously we are concerned about that as well." Ford's stock rallied somewhat yesterday, rising 92 cents, to $23.47 a share, as the falling dollar improved its competitiveness, especially against Japanese automakers, whose stocks fell.
Nick Sharkey, a Ford spokesman, declined to comment on the company's plans.
As in at least two other early retirement programs in recent years, Ford is offering to add three years to employees' years of service with the company and three years to their ages for the purpose of calculating pensions, a second person close to the company said. Because Ford has hired fairly few workers since its heyday in the late 1970's, it has many engineers and managers in their 50's, so retirement incentives have been effective in reducing the number of employees.
Ford had 45,822 white-collar employees in the United States as of Dec. 31. The buyout program might be extended to Ford engineers and managers in other countries, although this would require tailoring it to other nations' laws, two people close to the company said. Ford has almost 200,000 employees outside the United States but does not release the proportion who are in white-collar jobs; comparable statistics for other automakers would suggest Ford has 25,000 to 35,000 white-collar employees outside the United States.
A concern for Ford's leaders is that credit agencies will lower the company's credit rating. Rod Lache, an auto analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, warned in a research note today that "a rating downgrade for Ford appears imminent" while adding that the company appeared to have insulated itself from the effects of a downgrade by rebalancing its credit exposure in recent months.
Scott Sprinzen, the managing director for automotive credit at Standard & Poor's, a big rating agency, said the agency had put a "negative outlook" on Ford's credit rating in February and had been warning actively since May that the rating "could possibly be lowered within a few quarters." The agency is concerned that price competition and a proliferation of sport utility models will hurt the profitability of Ford's North American operations even as Ford's foreign operations are struggling and its cash reserves are declining, Mr. Sprinzen said, while refusing to discuss when any downgrade might take place.
Ford has been struggling with quality problems that have forced repeated recalls and slowed the introduction of new models. The new Ford Thunderbird, a convertible that has won rave reviews, has been delayed until the end of this summer because of problems with overheating engines, two people close to the company said today.
Sales of the Ford Explorer sport utility vehicle, the company's best-selling family vehicle excluding pickup trucks, have still not recovered from the recall of Firestone tires on Explorers a year ago despite costly discounting. Sales of Ford's larger sport utilities and pickups, once the cornerstone of its profits, have slowed even more as General Motors and Toyota Motor have stepped up their production and marketing of competitive models.
A person close to the company said one factory that could be closed is Ford's 53-year-old operation on the outskirts of St. Louis, which makes about one-third of the Explorers; the rest are assembled at a larger, 46-year-old factory in Louisville. But any closing of factories will probably not happen soon because Ford's current labor contract runs through September 2003 and bars factory closings except with the permission of the United Automobile Workers, which is very hard to obtain.

PERSON: Gale Cincotta 

HEADLINE: Gale Cincotta, 72, Opponent Of Biased Banking Policies 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Gale Cincotta, a plainspoken mother of six who became a neighborhood activist and went on to help ignite the national debate over bank lending policies that discriminated against minority home buyers, died Wednesday at a hospital in Maywood, Ill. She was 72.
 The cause was gall bladder cancer, said Tracy Van Slyke, spokeswoman for the National Training and Information Center, of which Ms. Cincotta was executive director. 
 Ms. Cincotta, who lived in Oak Park, a Chicago suburb, achieved fame for her spirited fights for residents of the neighborhood of Austin, on Chicago's West Side, where she lived most of her life. In a 1996 article in Illinois Issues, she told of nailing a rat to the door of the alderman for Austin in 1970 after he refused to attack rodents. The next day, the city's rat patrol was on the job.
She moved on to national issues, especially her challenge to the banking industry and the federal bureaucracy over the practice called redlining, refusing to lend to residents of minority neighborhoods. As part of this fight, she once threatened to nail a "Loan Shark" sign over the door of the Federal Reserve in Washington.
After redlining was outlawed in the 1970's, she kept fighting to make sure the law was enforced.
Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago said she "was instrumental in helping the city formulate its campaign against predatory lending." 
Last year, she successfully lobbied for a Chicago ordinance to ban such lending practices, like offering very high mortgage rates and other confiscatory financial terms to minority members and the poor, often resulting in the loss of homes through foreclosures. In April, the Illinois Legislature followed suit.
Gail Angeles was born on Dec. 28, 1929, in Chicago. Her father ran a Greek restaurant. She married a gas station owner and they had six sons. She became politically active in the 1960's because of school crowding.
In the late 1960's, Ms. Cincotta became president of the Organization for a Better Austin. The school battle expanded into other concerns, as Ms. Cincotta fought real estate agents' encouragement of panic selling by white homeowners as minorities began looking for homes.
People in other cities began turning to Ms. Cincotta and her colleagues for advice, and she became head of National People's Action, a network of 30 groups from 110 cities. The umbrella group held a housing conference in Chicago in 1972 and a protest in Baltimore the next year.
The strategy was extended to other issues, including consumer protection. "Coalitions are forming all over the place," Ms. Cincotta said in an interview with The New York Times in 1982.
Her group was one of those that successfully pressed Congress to pass the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act of 1975, which requires lending institutions to disclose where they make home loans. It also was an advocate in the winning fight to persuade Congress to pass the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, which required banks to invest in neighborhoods where they did business.
National People's Action combined with other neighborhood groups to persuade three large Chicago banks to commit themselves to making $173 million in low-interest loans for housing and industrial development in poor neighborhoods. In return, the groups agreed not to challenge the banks' merger plans. 
Colleagues remembered her war cry: "We want it. They've got it. Let's go get it."
Ms. Cincotta is survived by five sons, George and Charles of Delray Beach, Fla.; James of Ottawa, Canada; Theodore of Phoenix and Richard of Oak Park, Ill., eight grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren. No information was available on the sixth son.

SUBJECT: DEATHS & OBITUARIES (92%); RODENTS (90%); REAL ESTATE (90%); BANKING & FINANCE (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); DISCRIMINATION (90%); CREDIT REGULATION (89%); MORTGAGE BANKING & FINANCE (89%); COMMUNITY ACTIVISM (89%); FAIR LENDING (89%); FORECLOSURE (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); POLITICAL DEBATES (78%); CONSUMER LENDING (78%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (78%); HOMEOWNERS (77%); MORTGAGE LOANS (77%); INTERVIEWS (76%); ORDINANCES (75%); MAYORS (74%); PREDATORY LENDING (73%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (72%); REAL ESTATE AGENTS (72%); EXECUTIVES (71%); LOBBYING (67%); CONSUMER LAW (65%); INTEREST RATES (64%); ECONOMIC NEWS (64%); CONSUMER PROTECTION (64%); MORTGAGE RATES (64%); CANCER (57%) DEATHS (OBITUARIES); BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION

HEADLINE: U.S. Consumer Prices Decline At Steepest Rate Since 1986 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
The prices that American consumers paid for goods and services fell in July at the steepest rate in 15 years as gasoline prices plummeted, the Labor Department said yesterday.
 The report provided further evidence that inflation remains under control, even though the Federal Reserve has reduced interest rates six times this year to reinvigorate the economy. 
 A separate report, meanwhile, showed that the housing market remained strong in the weakened economy as new construction surged in July. 
"There's still a lot of question marks about the economy," said Joel Prakken, the chairman of Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting firm in St. Louis. Still, he said, it appeared that the year's "second half is going to be a heck of a lot better than the first."
The Consumer Price Index slid a surprising 0.3 percent, well exceeding economists' forecasts of a drop of 0.1 percent. It was the first decline since April 2000 and the largest since one of 0.4 percent in April 1986.
Excluding food and energy prices, the core inflation rate was only 0.2 percent, even with a large spike in tobacco prices.
The negligible inflation in July appears to give the Fed's policy makers further room to reduce short-term interest rates again when they meet on Tuesday. Several economists said they expected the Fed to reduce its benchmark rate by another quarter of a percentage point, to 3.5 percent.
"Inflation is not an issue, in the short term, for Fed policy," said Jade Zelnik, chief economist at Greenwich Capital Markets.
Overall transportation prices fell 2.3 percent, offsetting increases in the costs of many other services, including education, communication, medical care and recreation.
The cost of food and beverages increased 0.3 percent, while apparel costs fell 0.6 percent and housing costs were unchanged.
For the 12 months ended in July, consumer prices rose 2.7 percent, compared with a rate of 3.6 percent in the 12 months ended in July 2000. By the same measure for the same time periods, prices of services rose 4.2 percent, compared with 3.6 percent a year earlier.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said the housing market remained strong in July, with starts of new construction rising 2.8 percent, to an estimated rate of 1.67 million, from a revised 1.63 million in June.
"With housing activity a good leading indicator for durable consumption, and the economy balanced two to three quarters since the start of monetary easing, housing gains may point to stronger consumption ahead," Peter Kretzmer, senior economist at Banc of America Securities, wrote to clients.
The Labor Department also reported that the number of people filing initial claims for unemployment benefits in the week of Aug. 11 fell by 8,000, to a seasonally adjusted 380,000.

HEADLINE: THE CENSUS: Economics; 
Mixed Findings on Poverty in Survey of Bronx

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The economic boom that changed the face of New York City in the 1990's appears to have had no impact on the median income of families in the city's poorest borough, according to the results of an experimental Census Bureau survey of Bronx households released yesterday.
 The survey data suggest that the median household income and median family income may even have dropped slightly in the Bronx between 1990 and 2000. The numbers also show that the percentage of Bronx residents living in poverty remained unchanged over the decade, stuck at 29 percent. 
 The numbers come from the American Community Survey, a new approach to census data collection that the bureau has been testing in 31 counties nationwide. The findings were based on a survey of an average of 1,340 Bronx households done each month during 2000. 
The results offer a rare glimpse at important trends involving income, education and employment a year before comparable data from the more comprehensive 2000 census are scheduled to be released. But the survey's findings are not without limitations, the bureau and others point out.
Census officials say some of the numbers are not strictly comparable to figures from the 1990 census, against which they will inevitably be measured. For one thing, there are differences in the way the bureau collects information for the census as opposed to the survey, and whom it is collected from.
An examination of some of the 1990 census and 2000 survey numbers that are considered relatively comparable suggests a mixed picture in the Bronx. Estimated median household income dropped from about $30,000, adjusted for inflation, to $27,551. The estimated median family income dropped from about $35,200 in 1989, adjusted for inflation, to $30,791 in 2000.
A median is not an average; it is the number in the middle. Median income means that half of all the incomes are below that number and half are above.
At the same time, employment levels in the Bronx remained constant, according to a comparison of the 1990 and 2000 numbers. And the percentage of Bronx residents over age 25 with high school and college diplomas went up. The 1990 census found that 58.5 percent of Bronx residents were high school graduates. That figure rose to nearly 65 percent in the 2000 survey. Residents with a bachelor's degree or higher went from 12.2 percent in 1990 to 15.6 percent in 2000.
Also on the rise was the percentage of Bronx housing units occupied by their owners, instead of renters. That figure rose from about 18 percent in the 1990 census to nearly 21 percent in the survey. Owner occupancy is considered an indicator of community stability.
Meanwhile, the percentage of Bronx households in which a language other than English was spoken jumped from 48 percent in 1990 to 54 percent in 2000, a comparison of the numbers showed. That reflected the large number of immigrants, many of them from Latin America, who poured into the Bronx in the 1990's.
The survey data raised several questions. Why did the estimated median incomes in the Bronx fail to rise, and apparently even decline, during a period of affluence in the city and nationwide? And why did the percentage of Bronx residents living in poverty remain stable if median incomes went down?
Though surprising, the income numbers were not entirely inconsistent with recent data from the federal Bureau of Economic Analysis, which found that per capita personal income in the Bronx increased barely, if at all, between 1989 and 1999. Those figures, however, are based on tax returns and do not include people who do not report their income.
Andrew A. Beveridge, a sociology professor at Queens College who did the income comparisons for The New York Times, said the incomes of middle-class and upper-middle-class residents of the Bronx appeared to have increased while the large numbers of poor people in the borough held the median income down.
"This could mean that those better off in the Bronx are now quite a lot better off while those who are poor in the Bronx are poorer now than they were 10 years ago," he said. "In other words, those in the bottom half could have lost ground and those in the top half could have gained ground."
William Bosworth, director of the Bronx Data Center at Lehman College and a retired professor of political science, suggested the influx of immigrants, many of them poor and unable to speak English, might have counterbalanced any improvement in income and education levels among those already in the Bronx.
"What you have is this constant influx," he said. "It's absolutely clear that the vast majority came from Latin America and of those, the vast majority speak English poorly. If you came from Latin America and speak English poorly, what are your chances of being in poverty?"

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Hewlett-Packard Profit Falls but Beats Wall St. Estimates

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company reported fiscal third-quarter earnings today that fell 78 percent from the period last year, as the company, a computer industry bellwether, continues to struggle with a slowing worldwide economy.
 In spite of slowing sales in all parts of the world, the company's profits nearly tripled the expectations from Wall Street, which were sharply lowered after the company warned last month that it foresaw a revenue shortfall. 
 "While we can't control what's going on," Robert P. Wayman, the chief financial officer, said in speaking about the economy, "at least we've made some important progress on what we can handle here."
The company's shares closed up 3 cents at $24.13 today before the earnings announcement. In after-hours trading, shares rose to $24.90. 
Among other technology companies, Dell Computer reported earnings today in line with expectations but lost $101 million, largely because of charges related to job cuts and other expenses. Shares for Ciena, a maker of fiber optic equipment, fell sharply after the company said profits for 2001 and 2002 would not meet estimates.
Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., reported earnings, excluding one-time items, of $218 million, or 11 cents a diluted share. Pricing wars and sluggish demand, particularly in the company's consumer printer and personal computer businesses, dragged earnings down from $1.04 billion, or 50 cents a share, during the third quarter last year.
As recently as June 6, the company said it was comfortable with analysts' profit expectations of 23 cents a share. But on July 26, five days before the quarter's end, Hewlett-Packard warned that its revenue would decline 14 to 16 percent, twice as sharp a drop as expected. The company also announced that it would cut its work force by 6,000 employees.
Analysts cut their estimates to 4 cents a share, according to a survey by Thomson Financial/First Call. Hewlett-Packard today beat those expectations by 7 cents by reporting higher-than-expected revenues, cost reductions and gross margins.
Including special items, the company earned 5 cents a share. The special items included a $131 million loss from the sale of the company's VeriFone business and $49 million for amortization of good will and other intangibles.
Carleton S. Fiorina, the company's chief executive, said today that although sales may improve slightly during the current quarter as back-to-school shopping begins, she saw no immediate end to the dreary economic times.
"We don't see any signs of change in the market before 2002," Ms. Fiorina said in a conference call with analysts. She was referring to the company's fiscal year, which ends in October.
Revenue declined 14 percent, to $10.1 billion, from $11.8 billion in the period last year. The company said that it lost money in its consumer PC and software businesses and that revenue for its "crown jewel" printers and imaging devices declined 10 percent because of economic weakness and falling average selling prices. Over all, the consumer business fell 23 percent from the second quarter and 21 percent from the third quarter last year.
More than most computer makers, Hewlett-Packard is vulnerable to an economic slowdown because of its wide range of products, which include computers, printers and digital cameras, as well as server and storage systems. The company is also focusing more effort on information technology services, mainly through acquisitions.
Trying to quiet speculation that Hewlett-Packard might shut down its PC business, where year-to-year sales declined 36 percent to homes and 23 percent to corporations, Ms. Fiorina reaffirmed her commitment to selling those products.
In the conference call with Hewlett-Packard management today, Andrew J. Neff, an analyst with Bear Sterns & Company who has predicted that at least one of the major PC manufacturers will be forced out of the shrinking market, pressed her to explain her reasons for remaining in the industry.
Ms. Fiorina said Hewlett-Packard needed to use PC's to sell its printers to consumers and its profitable services packages to corporations.
"It has been a good performer for us," Ms. Fiorina said. "We think in more normal times it will continue to be a good performer for us."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Dell Loses $101 Million For Quarter

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
Dell Computer lost $101 million in the second quarter of its fiscal year, largely because of charges related to job cuts and other expenses, the company said yesterday.
 In the same quarter of last year, Dell reported net profit of $603 million, or 22 cents a share. When the charges are excluded from this year's figures, the company posted a profit of $433 million, or 16 cents a share, in the second quarter, which ended Aug. 3. That figure matched forecasts of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. 
 Sales from the computer giant, which is based in Austin, Tex., were $7.61 billion, down slightly from $7.67 billion the year before. Analysts predicted slightly higher sales of $7.7 billion. Before the company released its earnings after the market closed, Dell shares had dropped 12 cents a share, closing at $25.38. Shares fell as low as $24.60 in after-hours trading.
Dell executives said that layoffs and sharp reductions in inventory had helped the company cut costs and weather the weakness in the economy, while lower costs for computer components had permitted it to reduce prices and to continue a price war with rivals.
"We increased shipments strongly in a down market, particularly in enterprise products," Michael S. Dell, the company's founder and chief executive, said. The company, he said, "gained more than two points of overall market share."
Outside of the United States, the company's product shipments rose 30 percent over the previous quarter and increased 19 percent from the year before as sales for most of its competitors fell. In the United States, shipments increased 13 percent over the previous quarter, the company said.
In a conference call with reporters, Mr. Dell said, "We think we're very, very well positioned for a bounce-back in demand that we think is likely to occur in the spring of next year." 
The company, which is the biggest seller of computers for the laptop and the desktop markets, had a 33 percent increase in global sales of servers, large computers for running networks. 
Dell executives said that sales in the third quarter would probably be flat, or could drop 5 percent. That would translate into earnings of 15 cents or 16 cents a share. Mr. Dell suggested that the forecasts might be conservative, but said, "If our forecasts are conservative, that will be good for us and the rest of the industry."
One market analyst said that Dell's earnings were not a surprise. Ashok Kumar, an analyst with U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray, said, "In this tough environment, you have a single company that has executed remarkably well."
Mr. Kumar said the hard times would continue. "It's highly likely we won't see any sequential growth for the company," he said, "and especially for the industry, until the December quarter at the earliest."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Despite Good Market, Mortgage Problems Inch Up

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Even as the real estate market remains strong in the New York metropolitan region and across the country -- in fact, national sales of existing homes are on track to make this year the second-best year ever, surpassing last year -- some housing observers point to a hairline fracture in the foundation: mortgage delinquencies and foreclosure rates have risen slightly.
 "The numbers are small, but quite meaningful," said Rae Rosen, the senior regional economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. 
 Douglas Duncan, the senior economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said, "It's not cause for concern, but for attention."
There are approximately 47 million existing mortgage loans in the country, 31 million of them regularly surveyed by the Mortgage Bankers Association. It tracks mortgage payments that are 90 or more days late and mortgages that have entered the foreclosure process. 
Nationally, the percentage of mortgages that were 90 or more days past due in the first quarter of 2001 (the latest data available) was 0.63, up from 0.52 in the first quarter of 2000. For foreclosures initiated in the first quarter, the percentage was 0.32, compared with 0.30 in the corresponding period last year.
"We didn't get the kind of decline in foreclosures you would have expected during a strong expansion," Ms. Rosen said. "Now we see that 90-day late payments and foreclosures have ticked up, and that was for the first quarter of 2001, before the recent spate of large layoffs."
In New York, the percentage of mortgage payments that were 90 or more days late in the first quarter was 0.55, up from 0.49 in the first quarter of 2000. For foreclosure proceedings initiated, the percentage was 0.34, up from 0.31.
For New Jersey, 0.77 percent of all mortgages were 90 or more days late at the end of the first quarter, up from 0.65 in the first quarter of 2000. For foreclosures started, the percentage was 0.38, up from 0.33.
And in Connecticut, 0.42 percent of mortgages were at least 90 days late, up from 0.37 percent. However, foreclosure proceedings initiated during the first quarter stood at 0.23 percent, down from 0.24 percent.
"Two factors are driving the increases," Mr. Duncan said. One is that unemployment has increased nationally to 4.5 percent from 3.9 percent in October. "The second is that lots of loans were originated in 1998 and early 1999," he said. "They are now three years old and, historically, the peak delinquency period in the life of a loan is Years 3 through 5."
That is because home buyers make sure their finances are in order before they purchase, and because they have had the house inspected to be certain it is in good condition. "Three years later, maybe the furnace breaks down," Mr. Duncan said, "but you're not as flexible financially because you used your resources to get the house. Or now there's a baby and Mom is staying home or working part time."
Mr. Duncan also pointed out that energy prices soared in the fourth quarter of 2000. "For households that were less flexible and all of a sudden their heating bill increases 50 percent, that stretches the budget," he said.
Although the New York region has been somewhat insulated from the national economic slowdown because it is less dependent on manufacturing, Ms. Rosen expressed concern about recent job losses in that sector, particularly in New Jersey. "There's a potential for more layoffs, so there could be an additional rise in foreclosures," she said.
George McCarthy, a housing economist at the Ford Foundation, says the poor are most vulnerable. "When you look at the numbers for the market as a whole, it doesn't reveal the cancer that's spreading from the low end," he said.
"The real story behind these numbers is the rapid expansion of predatory lending," Dr. McCarthy continued. "There is a two-tiered lending market, and increasingly the lower tier is being served by subprime lenders" -- those that lend to people with less than pristine credit and often charge considerably higher rates.
As an indicator that the poor are particularly affected, Dr. McCarthy pointed to statistics from the Federal Housing Administration, which insures prime loans in low-income neighborhoods. "Defaults on F.H.A. mortgages jumped 30 percent within the last year," he said. "And the 30-day delinquency rate on F.H.A. mortgages crossed the 10 percent mark for the first time ever at the end of 2000."
If F.H.A.-backed loans have been hit hard, then subprime loans must be even more vulnerable, Dr. McCarthy said. "What we do know is that the default rates on these subprime loans are at least three times the rate of prime loans," he said. "And the share of the market that's covered by subprime lenders has increased dramatically since 1997."

HEADLINE: Industry Standard Says It Will Cease Publication 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER and ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
The Industry Standard, a magazine that rose with the dot-com boom it was founded to chronicle but suffered when the bubble burst, has published its last issue barring a last-minute rescue by some unexpected savior, according to a statement released yesterday.
 The magazine's parent company, Standard Media International, is expected to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection soon. 
 In the statement, Alissa Neil, a spokeswoman for the magazine, said: "The Standard will be suspending publication of its weekly print magazine, The Industry Standard, while the company continues to look for a buyer. It is quite possible that during that time we will file Chapter 11. We're very disappointed that our short-term financial situation requires this, but we remain hopeful that our assets will be sold." 
Word began to spread earlier this week among the handful of employees who were not taking a company-required vacation, and executives scrambled to reach the rest of the 200 or so remaining employees. In its heyday a little more than a year ago, the company, based in San Francisco, employed about 400 people, including 130 journalists. Company executives said that a flood of dot-com ads brought in $140 million last year, allowing the magazine to turn a profit in its third year of existence -- a rare feat in the magazine business.
But advertising declined 75 percent in the first half of this year, and the magazine was on track to lose $50 million on revenue of $40 million, these executives said. International Data Group, the Boston-based trade magazine publisher that once dominated the board of Standard Media, let its partners know this week that it would not seek or provide a bridge loan of about $10 million, according to a person who participated in the discussions.
Until a few days ago, several members of the company's board thought that as cash ran out, bridge financing would give the magazine enough breathing room to organize a sale, perhaps to a publishing company like Dow Jones & Company or McGraw Hill or even one of its investors, Pearson P.L.C. 
Although no new issue of the magazine is expected -- the final copy was published last week, three and a half years after the first issue -- the magazine's Web site, www.thestandard.com, is expected to continue in the immediate future, operating with a skeleton crew of journalists and technicians.
Over the last two years, the magazine rode to unexpected revenue heights, quadrupling its 1999 revenue in 2000. But in January, the bottom dropped out of the advertising market.
All the magazines devoted to the Internet and to investing in the technology sector have been hurt by the economic downturn, but The Industry Standard was the hardest hit. From January to June, for example, the magazine's ad pages were down 75 percent, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. By contrast, ad pages at Business 2.0 declined 60 percent during the same period, Red Herring was down 49 percent and Fast Company was down 47 percent.
The news of impending bankruptcy came less than a month after The Industry Standard sponsored a conference in Carlsbad, Calif., that attracted industry chiefs from Steven A. Ballmer of Microsoft to Scott G. McNealy of Sun Microsystems. It came only a few months after the magazine, regarded by many as the best of a new crop of news-oriented new-economy publications, won a Gerald Loeb award, the highest award in financial journalism.
The likelihood that a spirited magazine tailored to a new economic and journalistic landscape is coming to an abrupt end left staff members angry and resentful at their financial backers. "We had never fit into the I.D.G. culture," one staff member said of International Data Group. "They do trade magazines. We're just culturally different. It was an uneasy relationship."
During the flush times of late 1999, Standard Media sought out new investors that would dilute the role of International Data. The first step, in January 2000, was to take on an outside loan of $30 million from sources that included Flatiron Partners and Pearson. 
But to attract those investors, the company promised to undertake a rapid expansion built on optimistic assumptions. It created a costly infrastructure, starting back-office legal and auditing departments separate from those of International Data and developing its own software. 
The company also signed leases for office space for up to 600 employees in San Francisco and New York, with some leases negotiated to last as long as 10 years.
In January 2000, the company was valued by its new investors at about $200 million. The investors, who together paid $30 million for a stake of about 15 percent, according to one person close to the transaction, were Flatiron Partners, Chase Capital Partners, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter Venture Partners, Pearson, Europ@Web, J.& W. Seligman and Chase H&Q.

HEADLINE: Big Stakes In Small Errors; 
Manufacturers Fight Retailer 'Discounts' In Shipping Disputes

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Earlier this year, Sega of America Dreamcast, which makes computer games and the machines to play them, went to court, suing one of its biggest customers over a $2.2 million unpaid bill.
 Sega contended that although it had delivered some $25 million worth of Dreamcast consoles and other items ordered by Kmart buyers to its stores around the country, the Kmart front office had refused to pay for $2.2 million of them because of "numerous credits and deductions which were not authorized" and were disputed by Sega. Kmart declined to comment on the dispute because of the pending legal matter. 
 The deliveries were made in 1999 and last year, according to the lawsuit, and by June 2000 Sega had halted further shipments to Kmart over the unpaid amount.
Sega's lawsuit was a rare public eruption of what those in the retail business say is a broadening undercurrent in their industry: stores charging their suppliers for all kinds of supposed infractions on the receiving end, ranging from late-arriving trucks to wrongly placed bar-code labels to incorrectly dangling tags on clothing and boxes that are unloaded out of order. By some estimates, retailers charge back as much as 10 to 15 percent of certain types of purchases, which can make a huge difference in the bottom line of suppliers affected by the practice. 
Manufacturers are reluctant to discuss specific charges because they usually are still doing business with the retailers in question. But now, with most businesses suffering from the slowing economy, manufacturers large and small say they are being squeezed harder than ever. And new charge-back permutations have emerged, like the reopening of old accounts to claim fresh deductions.
"Doing business with the department stores has gotten worse over time, and I think it's in correlation to their balance sheets," one clothing manufacturer said. "It is a major, major thing. From the hangers to how it's hung to the placement of the tags, it just goes on and on and on, and there are penalties if you don't do it right."
At first glance, consumers would seem to benefit from the practice because it keeps retailers' costs down, giving them flexibility to keep prices low. The stores, for their part, say the charges, which are perfectly legal, are an attempt to improve the efficiency of their operations, starting at the mammoth warehouses where all kinds of goods are delivered.
But when retailers are charging back as much as they are today, manufacturers say they sometimes end up raising prices to offset their losses. Some may even stop dealing with particularly troublesome retailers, as Sega did, reducing the choices available to shoppers.
"Sometimes retailers find themselves being penny-wise and pound- foolish, by nitpicking with a vendor and then finding themselves without product," said Darrell Rigby, a retail specialist at Bain & Company. 
The practice, generally referred to as charge backs and deductions, dates to the 1970's in the apparel business, where it started small. But in the last few years, industry experts say, chain stores and department stores have spread the practice to packaged food, cosmetics, toys and other products. Consolidation among the stores has left fewer players, and they have more power over their suppliers than in the past. Many stores have information technology that is superior to that of the manufacturers, giving them another edge in the disputes over money owed.
"It's more aggressive lately because business is tough," said Walter Levy, a consultant with Kurt Salmon Associates in Manhattan, which advises retailers all over the country. "It is capitalism run amok."
The problems begin after products ordered by a store have been delivered. A store might claim that cartons arrived with less than the promised amount of, say, compact discs, rubber sandals, blenders, cashmere sweaters and the like. Or they might have held too much. Or the cartons were not delivered the way the store prescribed, perhaps landing on the loading dock in the wrong order or arriving on a truck that was too late or too early. 
Increasingly, stores want products packaged in ways that cut the amount of time required to set them up on shelves or racks. And they will deduct a certain amount for each aspect of product delivery that does not fit specifications, which can quickly add up to thousands of dollars.
The stores serve notice that they expect things to be done a certain way, issuing thick binders of "vendor compliance" regulations. But manufacturers say that the demands have become increasingly onerous, and differ from store to store.
One store even introduces its policy with the following: "When dealing with a major retailer, things will go wrong. So, be prepared, and the journey through charge back and deduction land will be as painless as possible."
For many of the manufacturers, painless is not the word that springs to mind. "You might have an invoice due for $1 million, but then you get paid $100,000, because $900,000 is in charge backs," the credit manager for a California company said. "You then have to identify what the charge back is for, and that could take anywhere from one week to three months. If you think about the cost of capital, you see that they finance their operations on chargebacks."
For the manufacturer, "it affects cash flow," he added. "If you are expecting a million dollars and you get just $100,000, then you have to go out and borrow that missing $900,000."
Steven Parks, director of deductions management at Dun & Bradstreet Receivable Management Services, told of seeing a check representing the net payment to a manufacturer from a $1.5 million invoice. "With all the deductions, the net effect for the manufacturer was 94 cents," he said.
Charge backs have become so pervasive this year that trade groups like the Fashion Association in New York started holding seminars to discuss the problem. On the Internet, various companies advertise their recovery services, intended for both retailers and manufacturers. Agencies have sprung up, like the Vendor Compliance Federation, also based in New York, which tries to bring the two sides together.
"There's no doubt in my mind that there's abuse," said Kim Zablocky, secretary to the federation, which has 150 large companies as members. "It's all subjective. Some manufacturers won't have any issues at all. Others are getting their brains handed to them."
He says that 85 percent of all the charges are the fault of the manufacturers, and most of those stem from shipping problems.
Stores of all sizes and types are using charge backs. At Sears, Roebuck & Company, executives say they are not interested in collecting money, but in improving the logistics of their business. Still, suppliers are fined for not fulfilling orders and other problems.
Each of Sears' 3,000 suppliers also gets a monthly report card -- with grades of A through F -- on how well they perform. "It's just like being back in school," said Charles Izzo, the company's director of vendor performance management. Filling orders counts for the most, followed by operational compliance, or how the orders are delivered to Sears. Poor grades usually generate a call from someone at the manufacturer, asking how it can improve, Mr. Izzo added. "You are changing their behavior," he said. 
If a company fails to ship a product on time, it is fined 5 percent of the cost of each product that was supposed to be in the shipment and did not arrive promptly, Mr. Izzo said.
Some stores have begun charging for what are called unidentified deductions, in which retailers deduct part of their payments for problems they do not specify. Others even forecast deductions as a certain percentage of an order, based on past experience. Post-audit deductions, in which closed accounts are reopened and challenged by the retailers, are another recent development. In effect, an increasing number of deals are just never done. Instead, they are subject to endless negotiation.
"A lot of them will try to get away with just about anything," said Judy Palilla, vice president for business development for Internal Audit Bureau Inc., which recovers unpaid bills for manufacturers from its headquarters in Clarks Summit, Pa. "They throw it up to see what will stick."
Much of what is charged as noncompliance can be difficult, if not impossible, to prove, Mr. Garuba of Dun & Bradstreet said. "The box arrives on the loading dock, and someone at the store signs for it," he said. "But when they open it up, there's only three-quarters of the order inside. So they take a one-quarter deduction for the missing part of the order." Some manufacturers have begun photographing their cartons as they leave the factory, in order to escape certain kinds of chargebacks.
Once a claim is made, many manufacturers do not have time to research it or otherwise defend themselves, Ms. Palilla said. She estimated that the retailers are wrong at least 25 percent of the time, and as much as 50 percent.
"I had one situation where a retailer deducted $200,000 from my account for perfume," said Andy Kahn, president of the children's wear division of the American Apparel and Footwear Association. Mr. Kahn's company made clothing, not perfume. Even so, it took him a year to get his money.
The effect is also felt by companies that lend money to the manufacturers, since the payments become more difficult for manufacturers to make. "We never know if we're going to get a dollar bill for a dollar bill," said Jerry Sandak, a principal with Rosenthal & Rosenthal, a Manhattan company that finances manufacturers, "or 67 cents for a dollar bill because the store didn't get it at the right time with the right label."
Wayne Hood, a retail analyst with Prudential Securities in Atlanta, said Wal-Mart was the first discount store to begin charging its manufacturers for noncompliance about five years ago. Wal-Mart declined to comment.
Mr. Hood said that better collaboration between the stores and the manufacturers will ultimately cut down on charge backs. More stores are working with their suppliers to plan what will be on the shelves and when, a development that has improved the sales of many products, he added.
But for now, the penalties are escalating.
"You used to be charged a dollar, or five dollars," said Mr. Zablocky of the Vendor Compliance Federation. "Nowadays, the penalty could be as high as $25,000. If you want to get your goods sold, it's the cost of doing business. The customer is always right."

HEADLINE: Hollywood, an Eye on Piracy, Plans Movies for a Fee Online 

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 

 BODY:
Five major movie studios, including some of Hollywood's top players, unveiled plans today for a joint venture that would allow computer users to download rental copies of feature films over the Internet.
 The service, which will be available only to those with high-speed Internet connections, is an attempt to get ahead of piracy problems that have plagued the music industry through services like Napster and which were beginning to be felt in the film industry with newer file-swapping services. 
 "I think the majority of consumers believe that copyright has value and that if they have a pay vehicle to watch movies on the Internet, they will pay for it," said Yair Landau, president of Sony Pictures Digital Entertainment. "We want to give honest people an honest alternative."
The venture is also seen by many studio executives as a first step toward true video-on-demand, when consumers will be able to watch any movie they want, whenever they want. Initially, the films will be available for download only onto personal computers, or television monitors linked to an Internet connection, but eventually video-on-demand service is expected to include cable television and other delivery systems. 
"I think anybody who is in the movie business wants to reach the day when you can watch any movie you want, any time you want," Mr. Landau said. "I personally believe that launching an Internet service like this is a necessary first step in that regard."
The studios that will be partners in the service are MGM, Paramount Pictures, Sony Pictures, Warner Brothers and Universal Pictures. Noticeably absent were Disney and 20th Century Fox, although sources close to Disney said that it intended to announce its own video-on-demand service within 10 days. Fox issued a statement late this afternoon saying that it, too, would announce plans soon for such a service.
Executives at Sony's Moviefly, an Internet movies-on-demand effort that will provide the technical backbone for the venture, had been saying since early this year that they intended to go online as soon as they could. 
They delayed the move, the executives said, in hopes of persuading as many Hollywood studios as possible to join the effort, a process that took longer than expected as each studio brought its concerns about pricing, security and competition with other outlets like cable television.
"It's very expensive to create something like this, so economics plays a role in bringing so many studios together," said Jack Waterman, president of worldwide pay television for the Paramount Television Group. "And this allows a lot of companies to come together to create a common viewpoint on the technology and security behind the system."
In the coming months, a chief executive will be hired for the new venture, which will have an equal number of representatives from each studio on its board; a name will be chosen; and the site will be tested extensively to make sure its security system works as promised. Then, the first 100 or so films, a mix of recent releases and films from studio libraries, will become available, either late this year or early next.
The selection of films, and how much it will cost to download them, will be left to the individual studios. Studios that are not part of the venture will also be allowed to post films on the site.
The average feature film is about 500 megabytes in digitized form and will take 20 minutes to 40 minutes to download, Mr. Landau said, depending on the type of broadband connection. Download times would be untenable for those with slower Internet connections. Studio officials estimate that there are 10 million households with broadband connections, a number they expect to increase significantly, as well as 35 million screens in offices and colleges.
A film will remain on a computer's hard drive for 30 days but will erase itself 24 hours after it is first run. In that 24 hours, consumers will be able to watch the film as many times as they wish -- pause, fast forward and perform other functions typical of a videocassette or DVD.
Studios traditionally release movies in a series of so-called windows, starting with theatrical release, followed by videocassette, DVD, pay-per-view, pay-cable networks and, eventually, broadcast networks. Executives at several studios said films would be released on this new system, initially at least, only when they entered their pay-per-view window, usually months after the theatrical release. The rental cost will be about the same as a pay-per-view film, the executives said. 
"We are not looking to undermine DVD, which is a great business," Mr. Landau said.
The new venture will be neither the first video-on-demand service (cable operators in a few markets have offered such a service to some customers, though the movie selection has been limited) nor the first time that feature films have been available for download on the Internet (companies like CinemaNow and SightSound Technologies have offered a limited roster of films for download). But it is the first effort involving Hollywood studios and offers the promise of thousands of potential films.
"This announcement confirms that film producers are eager for the Internet to enlarge and flourish," said Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America. "For the first time, in the very near future, a broad selection of motion pictures will be available online, protected by encryption, and delivered directly to consumers at a reasonable price."
In general, the studios have been hesitant to allow the distribution of digital copies of their films on the Internet, fearing they would be too easy to copy and share through unauthorized sites. What has made studio executives agree to this venture has been a growing confidence that the necessary security is in place to prevent copying of the downloaded files.
However, since almost all film pirating has involved the latest releases and this service will make movies available only months later, it is unclear what effect it would have on illegal copying.
"That remains to be seen," said Ric Dube, an analyst for Webnoize, a research company that focuses on digital entertainment industries. 
"What this does is to compete with piracy more effectively than the movie industry has in the past," Mr. Dube said. "And the real issue isn't whether it will affect piracy, but whether the movie industry is willing to tolerate the amount of piracy that's going on in order to grow their market."
The music industry, which shares parentage with many of the studios involved in today's announcement, has also fought against file-sharing sites like Napster, and had a harder time because of the relative ease of downloading a piece of music. 
But movie studios have also been faced with file-sharing sites like Aimster, which allows swapping of both audio and video files. 
"The film industry does have a better history of coming through on plans like this than does the music industry," Mr. Dube said. "So when five major film companies say they will use an online channel to distribute their films, that means a lot more than a similar statement coming from five music companies."
The real question, though, is how many people really want to download movies onto their personal computers.
"To be really honest, we have no idea," Mr. Waterman said.

HEADLINE: White House Sees Economic Growth Doubling in 2002, but Democrats Voice Disbelief 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WACO, Tex., Aug. 16 

 BODY:
The White House estimated today that economic growth would rebound to 3.2 percent next year from a projected 1.7 percent this year and that the current year would bring a small surplus in the non-Social Security part of the budget. Democrats immediately denounced the estimates as overly optimistic and politically self-serving.
 As Democrats intensified their charges that President Bush's tax cut was already draining the budget surplus and putting Social Security funds at risk of being spent for general purposes, Ari Fleischer, the president's press secretary, gave reporters a preview of figures to be issued by the White House Office of Management and Budget next week. 
 Those figures painted a rosier picture than the one provided by many private economists, and presage an intense battle over what is affordable and what is not when Congress hammers out the details of the 2002 federal budget in the coming months. 
Mr. Fleischer used the numbers to counter Democratic charges that the administration would return to deficit spending this year, not counting the revenue set aside for Social Security. "Even with the economic slowdown," he said, "the budget will have the second-largest surplus in history, and the only way the Social Security surplus will be spent is if Congress breaks the budget."
He said the overall surplus for this fiscal year, ending Sept. 30, would be about $160 billion. Virtually all that money is attributable to Social Security, leaving a small remaining surplus of several billion dollars. That cushion, Mr. Fleischer said, will keep the government from having to tap excess Social Security funds for current non-Social Security spending.
But Democrats and some budget experts said the White House was able to make its claim of a non-Social Security surplus only because it had changed an accounting method that had been used for the last 65 years. Under the new method, the non-Social Security surplus this year is increased by $4.3 billion.
In addition, the 3.2 percent growth estimate for 2002 is markedly higher than the projection of 2.8 percent in the most recent survey of private economists conducted by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a leading financial newsletter. While that discrepancy has no relevance to this year's budget, the White House's use of a higher figure could have an impact on how much money Congress calculates that it can spend within Mr. Bush's budget for 2002. It will also be used to underpin White House estimates of budget surpluses for 2002 and the years beyond.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, said the figures showed that the Bush administration "will twist and turn the numbers in an effort to hide the reality, which is that Bush's tax cut has put him on a path headed straight for the Medicare and Social Security surpluses."
Gene Sperling, who was President Bill Clinton's top economic adviser, said he detected in the Bush administration "a disturbing pattern of using budget numbers that are compelled more by politics than fiscal prudence, more by convenience than by consistency."
The conflicting calculations and contentions reflect a broader political battle between the administration and its critics, including many Democrats, over whether Mr. Bush's tax cut was affordable and why Congress may feel a pinch when a 2002 budget is forged this fall.
Administration officials have said any budgetary constraints arise from an economic slowdown that began before Mr. Bush took office. And Mr. Fleisher said the threat to Social Security revenue came from lawmakers' appetite for spending.
Mr. Fleischer said the surplus in the current fiscal year, the budget for which was signed by President Clinton, was turning out to be $34.5 billion smaller than it should have been because Congress and Mr. Clinton "spent more than they promised." Mr. Bush's tax cut, he said, was an insurance policy against that sort of extravagance, because it put money out of reach of lawmakers.
The Office of Management and Budget's midyear report, to be released next Wednesday, will come a week before a similar report by the Congressional Budget Office, and many lawmakers expect the C.B.O. forecast to be more conservative.
Several Democrats and budget experts said they were less troubled by the O.M.B.'s optimistic forecast for economic growth, which they said was only slightly out of line with other projections, than by a sudden budget accounting change that the White House recently adopted.
The change involves payroll taxes that go to Social Security. In the past, this revenue was estimated in one year and then reconciled in a future year with the actual money collected. The reconciliation was reflected in the future year's budget.
But the Bush administration is attributing the actual amounts for 1998, 1999 and 2000 to those years instead of 2001. As a result, it will not have to deduct what is essentially a back payment to Social Security from non-Social Security revenue in this year's budget, and the non-Social Security surplus will be $4.3 billion higher. By the administration's own calculations, that amount could be the difference between a surplus and a deficit this year in the non-Social Security part of the budget. The accounting change does not, however, affect the amount of money in the Social Security trust fund, or Social Security benefits. 
Mr. Fleischer said the change was an effort by an administration in its first year to start keeping the books more accurately and coherently.
But many Democrats said it was obviously intended to help offset the effects of Mr. Bush's tax cut and a provision that moved the deadline for about $33 billion in corporate tax payments into the next fiscal year. The moving of the deadline made those payments available as revenue for the 2002 budget, the Bush administration's first, but also lowered revenue this year, depressing the non-Social Security surplus.
"Political budget gimmicks create a negative cycle that creates the need for more political budget gimmicks," Mr. Sperling said.
"Their first $33 billion gimmick," he added, "has now forced them to go back to the gimmick well a second time," to make the Social Security accounting change.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
AMES TO CLOSE 47 STORES AND LAY OFF 2,000 WORKERS

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Ames Department Stores said yesterday that it would close 47 stores and lay off about 2,000 employees, or 6 percent of its work force, the second time the company has shut stores because of the slowing economy. Ames will close 15 stores in Ohio; 12 in Pennsylvania; 6 in Indiana; 4 in Virginia; 3 in Illinois; 3 in New York; and one each in Maine, Maryland, North Carolina and West Virginia. The stores will begin liquidation immediately and are expected to close by the end of October, Ames said. The company operates more than 400 stores and employs 35,300 people. In November, Ames announced plans to close 32 stores and cut about 2,000 jobs. Shares of Ames, which is based in Rocky Hill, Conn., fell 5 cents, to 73 cents a share.

WEYERHAEUSER EXTENDS OFFER FOR WILLAMETTE SHARES

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The Weyerhaeuser Company, still trying to win a hostile takeover of a rival, Willamette Industries, extended by a month its offer to buy Willamette shares.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing State Jobless Rate 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 New York State's unemployment rate remains flat, state officials announced yesterday, but analysts said that was an improvement over the national jobs picture. The state's joblessness in July was 4.4 percent, as was the rate in June and in July 2000. 
The national rate for July was 4.5 percent, also the same as in June, but 0.5 percentage points higher than in July 2000. New York City's unemployment rate in July was 5 percent, down 0.3 percentage points since June. Joblessness in July 2000 in the city was 5.6 percent. The figures are based on monthly surveys of 20,000 businesses and include both full- and part-time jobs, except agricultural workers, the self-employed and domestic workers in private households.
