HEADLINE: ABN Amro Shifts Focus Back to Traditional Banking 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 16 

 BODY:
ABN Amro said today that it would concentrate on traditional Main Street retail banking and rein in its corporate and investment banking -- a business, analysts say, where the Dutch bank is not big enough to compete on a global stage dominated by Wall Street giants.
 In the effort to increase its retail business, ABN Amro is expected to look for a merger or an alliance. But the bank has been coy about identifying a likely partner, despite speculation that it may be considering Fortis, a Belgian-Dutch company. 
 "We have not drawn up a list of merger partners," ABN Amro's chief executive, Rijkman Groenink, told reporters in Amsterdam. "If we were to draw up a short list of candidates, then Fortis would fit the criteria."
The planned shift in corporate focus was announced as ABN Amro reported a 21 percent decline in second-quarter profit. Excluding a one-time gain from the sale of the European American Bank to Citigroup Inc., ABN Amro's second-quarter profit fell to 671 million euros, or $614 million, from 851 million euros in the quarter a year earlier.
The bank said earnings from corporate and investment banking fell 65 percent. Like other big international banks, ABN Amro has sought to cut costs in the face of dwindling fees for mergers and equity sales, as the slowdown in the global economy forces corporate clients to curb their expansionary ambitions. 
But Mr Groenink insisted that the bank was not planning to move out of this area. "We are by no means going to leave this business," he said, even as he acknowledged that economic and market conditions were unlikely to improve this year.
ABN Amro also reported a 35 percent decline in profit from private banking and asset management, to 64 million euros.
In retail banking, which is more resistant to recession, according to Mr. Groenink, profit rose 7.2 percent, to 400 million euros -- the only main business line to show an increase in profits. Despite a sharp decline in net income in the Netherlands, where ABN Amro is the biggest, profit from the retail business in the United States surged 63 percent, following the $2.75 billion purchase of the Michigan National Corporation, which was completed earlier this year.
ABN Amro has said that it planned to cut almost 9,000 jobs -- 6,250 of them at Dutch bank branches -- to generate savings of nearly $1 billion by 2004. Today, it said that it would also shed 3 of its 10 management board members by the end of the year and reduce capital invested in wholesale banking by 20 percent. But the cost-cutting has failed to take effect, while the slump in corporate and investment banking continues to push down profits.
Mr. Groenink's ambition is to reach the top five of a group of 20 big banks by 2004. At the end of the second quarter, it was 15th, based on return to investors.
In trading in Amsterdam, shares of ABN Amro rose 2.7 percent.

HEADLINE: San Francisco Museum Director Resigns Suddenly 

BYLINE:  By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

 BODY:
David A. Ross, the former director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, resigned suddenly yesterday as director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, where he had spent three heady years and $140 million building up the museum's collection of contemporary art.
 His sudden departure caught the Bay Area art world off guard, including some members of the museum's 60-seat board of trustees. But Elaine McKeon, the chairman, said the executive committee and Mr. Ross had concluded several weeks ago that their paths had diverged at a time when a slow economy was forcing the museum to keep a tighter rein on its resources. 
 "Our focus in the museum is on internal management, and David Ross is focused on external matters, which he is a genius at," Ms. McKeon said in a telephone interview. "What is good for the museum is not necessarily in his best interests. And we thought it was mutually beneficial if we parted."
Mr. Ross was not available for comment yesterday.
Ms. McKeon praised Mr. Ross's tenure at SFMOMA, as it is called, where, she said, "he created so much excitement." 
Since 1998 the museum's membership has risen to 44,000 from 24,000, and its acquisitions of works by Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Mark Rothko, Francis Bacon, Alexander Calder, Chuck Close and Frank Stella put the institution in the top ranks of American museums of modern art.
Before going to San Francisco Mr. Ross had been director of the Whitney for seven years, where he had also created waves by his embrace of the trendy downtown art scene. In interviews later Leonard Lauder, the chairman of the Whitney's board of trustees, said he had tried to dissuade Mr. Ross from leaving New York and had offered to match San Francisco's handsome package.
But Mr. Ross was determined to move West, in part for personal reasons but also out of the belief that the energy -- and the money -- behind the American art market was shifting to the Pacific Coast.
"The idea of modernity is congruent with San Francisco," he said at the time.
Once he arrived, Mr. Ross led the museum on a buying spree that riveted the attention of dealers and artists around the country. "The trustees around here do not bargain," Mr. Ross said then. "They recognize that one of the reasons great pictures are being offered to us is because our trustees are willing to pay. They know what a great picture is worth."
Ms. McKeon said the different approaches of Mr. Ross and the board had surfaced only in the last year or so, with a downward shift in the national economy, in particular among the high-tech companies that are the backbone of Bay Area philanthropy.
"We are in a period, in an economy that puts the focus on management, on being fiscally responsible, financially responsible," she said. "It was a mutual parting of the ways, which was very friendly. So now David can get on with his life, and he can go do for somebody else what he did for us. But I have to think of our responsibilities."
Ms. McKeon said that she would begin a search for a new director next week. "When I get back Monday, I will immediately start interviewing search firms," she said. "We will do that right away."

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit For the U.S. Grew in June 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit widened in June as slower growth abroad and a strengthening dollar pushed exports to their lowest level in 16 months, the government said today.
 Imports fell a third consecutive month as companies spent less on oil, machinery and equipment. 
 The gap in trade of goods and services grew to $29.4 billion in June from $28.5 billion in May, the Commerce Department said. The drop in exports was larger than that for imports. 
The numbers "point to the bleak state of the global economy," said Avery Shenfeld, an economist at CIBC World Markets in Toronto. "America's problems have spread to the rest of the world."
Through June, the trade deficit totaled $184.9 billion, compared with $178.1 billion during the first six months of last year. The trade deficit in 2000 was a record $375.7 billion.
Optimistic consumers may bolster the economy in the current quarter, now in its second month. The University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment rose to 93.5 in August from 92.4 in July. The increase was the third in four months, and the level is the highest since January.
"There is no consumer collapse here at all," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. Rising consumer sentiment about current conditions probably reflects the mailing of tax rebate checks, he said.
Exports fell 2 percent in June, to $86 billion, the lowest level since February 2000. The decline was the third in four months. Exports of industrial supplies and materials, which include chemicals and pulpwood, totaled $13.5 billion, the lowest level since October 1999.
There were two bright spots. Exports of services rose to a record $25.1 billion. Exports of automobiles, parts and engines rose to $6.6 billion, the highest level in almost a year.
Imports fell 0.7 percent in June, to $115.4 billion, the lowest level since February 2000. The decline was the third straight, led by reduced demand for capital goods, as well as industrial supplies and materials, which include oil and natural gas.

HEADLINE: Economic Tombstones; 
The Industry Standard, Unplugged

 BODY:
In Silicon Valley, it may well go down as the day the buzz died. On Thursday The Industry Standard magazine, launched three years ago to serve as the "newsweekly of the Internet economy," announced that it would cease publication and may have to seek bankruptcy protection. It is a dizzying reversal of fortune for a publication whose meteoric rise and fall mirrors the euphoric, then harrowing times lived by the dot-com entrepreneurs it covered. 
 From its inception in 1998, The Standard was a must-read in Silicon Valley thanks to the emphasis by its editor, Jonathan Weber, on journalism over boosterism. In 2000 The Standard broke the publishing industry's all-time single-year record with 7,440 ad pages, as hundreds of start-ups spent their venture capital on glossy ads to build brand awareness in anticipation of an initial public offering. 
 Readers often groused about The Standard's telephone-directory thickness, and the irony that an old-fashioned magazine had become an indispensable medium for the new economy was not lost on anyone. But The Standard, based in San Francisco, always strove to be far more than just a magazine. 
John Battelle, its founder and chairman, wanted to build an information conglomerate for the new economy that investors would value more as a high-tech company than as an old-line media company. The backers who are now refusing to provide more financing bought into this vision, and in its first two years The Standard, much like the companies it covered, raised and lavishly spent millions in venture capital -- all with an eye toward the big I.P.O. at the end of the rainbow. 
The promise of all those stock-option riches allowed its journalists to feel like entrepreneurs themselves, real players in a generation's hottest story, much like Rolling Stone writers must have felt in the heyday of rock 'n' roll.
The Nasdaq bubble popped, of course, and The Standard's revenues plummeted along with the index, from $140 million in 2000 to a projected $40 million this year. What's more, the company found itself faced with high fixed costs, reminders of its past ambitions, and investors who had lost their patience. 
As the dot-coms fell, The Standard's Layoff Tracker replaced its I.P.O. Tracker as one of the most avidly followed indices in Silicon Valley. Ironically, the magazine produced some of its best journalism in its last few months, albeit in a much slimmer package. The abrupt slowdown in the technology sector, with its tales of angst and its implications for the economy as a whole, has provided a gripping story, and The Standard did not sugar-coat it. But like the real player it set out to be, it has now fallen victim to its own story.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Luxury Fleet Grows Nimble

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: CHALLANS, France 

 BODY:
Yachts are no Model-T's. Yet Joseph Brethome heads a team of a dozen workers -- joiners, plumbers, electricians -- who scramble over 30- to 50-foot sailboats as they inch along eight assembly lines in a sprawling factory in this provincial French town six miles from the Atlantic.
 "We generally work on two at a time," said Mr. Brethome, a 12-year veteran of Beneteau, the French sailboat builder. And while sales are strong in Europe, as prosperity and abundant leisure time promote sailing, Beneteau is leading other European boat makers in looking farther afield. 
 Borrowing a chapter from luxury goods makers like Louis Vuitton or Gucci, and blending it with the production techniques of automakers, which modify basic models into dozens of variations, these boat builders have branched out to new markets, notably the United States. 
"Our main challenge is to meet demand," said Annette Roux, 59, the chairwoman and chief executive of Beneteau, who has run the company, founded by her grandfather in 1884, since she was 22. Beneteau, which started as a builder of boats for local fishermen, has grown more than 25 percent a year for five years and invested $80 million in the last two years to increase capacity at its yards in France and in Marion, S.C.
But the challenge may soon change. Competition is growing just as slowing economies and the global stock market slump dry up some of the extra income of the well-to-do, who buy most boats.
Still, Beneteau may be better situated to weather the coming storm, for the company provides a textbook example of how impressive design and modern production methods can overcome many obstacles. This combination has produced sailboats with price tags low enough to attract customers who may never have thought of themselves as yacht owners before. In the United States the pleasure boat industry, including sailboats and powerboats, had a record year in 2000, with revenue rising to $25.5 billion. Sales are expected to fall as much as 9 percent this year, the first decline since the mid-1990's, said Thom Dammrich, president of the National Marine Manufacturers Association. 
That has left many investors and analysts wary. Shares of Beneteau, which is 57 percent family-owned, with the rest traded on the Paris bourse, are down 33 percent this year. Ferretti, a big Italian yacht builder that has been an investor favorite, is off 15 percent.
European yacht builders have made their deepest mark in the American market for sailboats, which is a small fraction of the huge market for powerboats. And the Europeans run against strong American rivals, like Catalina Yachts of California and the Hunter Marine unit of the Luhrs Marine Group in Florida, the leaders in the $1 billion market.
Yet attractive European designs and low prices, thanks to automation and the strong dollar, which makes imports less expensive, have enabled the Europeans to carve out a larger niche in North America. Last year, imports of European sailboats were more than $124 million, up from $79 million five years earlier.
Beneteau's gains have drawn other Europeans, including fast-growing German yards like Dehler International and Bavaria Yachts. It has also opened marketing tie-ins with luxury goods producers. Patrizio Bertelli, owner of the Prada fashion house in Italy, parlayed a passion for sailing into a global marketing pitch by investing $50 million in Luna Rossa, a boat that reached the finals of last year's America's Cup.
Earlier, Leonardo Ferragamo, of the family that controls the Ferragamo fashion group, acquired Swan, the Finnish yard that had fallen on hard times despite specializing in yachts that are to sailing what Porsches are to driving. Wally Yachts, an upstart boat builder in Monaco, has had such success with its sailboats that it plans a line of accessories to go with them.
But Beneteau, whose biggest boats -- about 50 feet -- cost up to $378,000, has had the most success in the United States. It now holds 16 percent of the American sailboat market, placing it third behind Hunter and Catalina, up from 6 percent when it opened its South Carolina yard in 1986.
If a downturn hits the global economy, Mrs. Roux says Beneteau is armed to weather it. In the early 1990's, during the last recession, Mrs. Roux, a short, tanned woman whose charm is combined with self-assurance, refused to follow the industry wisdom and lay off workers on a large scale. While big French rivals like Jeanneau let go half their workers, Beneteau hung on. When sales rebounded in the late 1990's, she said, "we were in position to take opportunities."
Though criticized by analysts who thought she should have done more to prop up profits, she said, "We had not decapitated the company." In 1994, Beneteau acquired the ailing Jeanneau and nursed it back to health.
As rising wealth in the 1990's made sailing accessible to more people, Beneteau's revenue exploded. In its latest fiscal year, which ended last month, the company generated sales of 543 million euros, or $475 million, up 22 percent from last year and 59 percent over 1999's sales of 342 million euros.
If Beneteau has mastered the art of mass-producing sailboats, in factories that turn out 4,000 a year with little or no customizing, some of its rivals have taken an opposite tack. The owners of Wally Yachts invented a kind of virtual corporation, with teams responsible for design and marketing, farming out construction to specialized yards in Europe, the United States and Tunisia. To assure quality, Wally's owners, including Luca Bassani, the chief executive, have begun taking stakes in the companies that build its boats, and are contemplating taking Wally public.
Wally, whose boats average about $4 million, just launched an 88-foot yacht, its biggest ever, and has four more under construction. It is diversifying from sailboats to powerboats. And to expand its presence in the United States, where it gets 8 percent of its revenue, it will show the new models at the Fort Lauderdale boat show in October.
Wally put itself at the high end to try to be more recession-proof. It pioneered some innovations, featuring hydraulic keels and automated furling systems operated by remote control. Mr. Bassani, 44, who sold his family business in Italy making electrical equipment to start Wally in 1994, said the company's peculiar structure, with only about 60 employees, was intended to insulate it from market volatility.
"Historically, yards were always hit when markets contracted," he said. "We control only design and development, since design is essential, and marketing and sales, with which you manage your image."
If Beneteau, with its assembly-line approach, wants to be the Toyota of sailing, Wally clearly wants to be the Ferrari.
Domenico De Sole, a longtime sailor, is impressed. "For me, it's a passion, not a business," said Mr. De Sole, the Italian-born chief executive of the Gucci Group. "But Bassani really changed the industry. He created a class. He is the big news of the last few years."
Mr. De Sole became hooked on sailing, he explained, while living in the United States, where he studied and practiced law, and sailed his first boat in Chesapeake Bay. In 1998, after moving to Europe, he bought a Wally and sailed it in the Mediterranean, but sold it a year and a half later because he had so little time to use it. If he bought another boat, he said, it would be a Wally. "They're big, modern boats -- beautiful, fast," he said.
John Peterson, director of sales and marketing at Hunter Marine, whose 24 percent of United States sailboat sales makes it the market leader, said the combination of mass producers and niche players gave the Europeans their edge.
"Beneteau is a very formidable competitor," he said. "In 10 years they came from scratch."
But niche players, like Bavaria and Dehler, which may sell fewer than a hundred vessels a year in the United States, make a difference, too. "That's a share that someone else doesn't get a chance to sell," he said.
The Americans, scrambling to prevent the Europeans from expanding, are carrying the battle into the Europeans' own backyard. In July, the Brunswick Corporation paid $68 million to acquire Sealine International, one of Britain's most profitable boat builders; in September, Luhrs began building Hunter Marine's line of mid-size sailboats, ranging from 29 to 38 feet, at a new yard in Dorset, England.
"The Europeans build nice boats, but they're not better than American boats," said Walter Schulz, the owner and president of Shannon Yachts, in Bristol, R.I. Mr. Schulz is fighting back with custom-built yachts, including a high-end range of 43- to 47-footers that cost up to $800,000, because sailboats 40 feet long and up have been the fastest-growing part of the market. "That is the niche that everybody is eyeing," he said.
Europeans face two challenges, said Tibor Sillinger, managing director of the Federation of French Nautical Industries: keeping the affluent market rolling and expanding from sail- into powerboating. "On the world market, motorboats are 85 percent," he said. "We are first in the last segment."
Beneteau is certainly expanding. Its catamaran unit, Lagoon, launched a 43-foot power catamaran last year and showed it earlier this year at boat shows in Florida. In Italy, Ferretti, which expects revenue of about $227 million this fiscal year, compared with $165 million a year ago, sells about 30 percent of its luxury yachts, which cost up to $16 million, in the United States. To push into the lucrative market for sport fishing boats, in 1998 Ferretti acquired Bertram Yachts of Miami, a leader in the field.
Still, sail remains the European passion. And while delivery times for Beneteau's yachts remain backed up six months to a year, that could change quickly if potential buyers start getting nervous about the economy.
"It's not financial, but psychological," Mrs. Roux said, "The customer says, 'I'll wait.' "

HEADLINE: Certicom Plans Job Cuts 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HAYWARD, Calif., Aug. 17 

 BODY:
 The Certicom Corporation, a maker of security software, said today that it planned to cut about 70 employees, or one-quarter of its staff, to trim costs. 
It was the second round of layoffs at the company in less than three months. The latest cuts will leave the company with about 200 employees by the end of the October. On June 4, Certicom said it would dismiss 30 percent of its workers. Certicom, based in Hayward, has been scaling back staff as customers spend less in a weak economy. The company makes software to protect people's identities when they make purchases over wireless devices.

HEADLINE: Poor Profit Outlook Sends Stocks Down 

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply and broadly as companies as varied as Dell Computer, Ford Motor and Gap provided Wall Street with further evidence that corporate profits appear unlikely to recover soon. Heavy selling in Microsoft also put pressure on the stock market. 
 The Nasdaq dropped more than 3 percent, bringing the week's loss to 4.6 percent. The S.& P. 500 was down 1.7 percent for the day and 2.4 percent for the week. The Dow Jones industrials dropped 1.5 percent, ending the week down 1.7 percent. 
 Analysts said the latest bleak messages from corporate America further unnerved investors, many of whom were already reluctant to buy stocks ahead of Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy makers. Economists expect the Fed to cut short-term interest rates for the seventh time this year, reducing them at least one-quarter of a percentage point.
Business Day, Page C1.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Ford to Cut 5,000 Workers And Reduce Output This Fall
Ford Motor said it was eliminating 5,000 salaried jobs in North America and planned to reduce production this fall, the latest signs that the auto industry may no longer be able to prop up the stumbling American economy.
 The Standard & Poor's credit agency said it was preparing to downgrade the credit ratings of both Ford and General Motors -- a reflection of Wall Street's worries about the domestic carmakers' high costs and the growing market share of import brands. Page A1. 

Trade Deficit Widens as Exports Fall
The United States trade deficit widened in June as slower growth abroad and a strengthening dollar pushed exports to their lowest level in 16 months, the government said. The gap in trade of goods and services grew to $29.4 billion in June from $28.5 billion in May. Imports fell a third consecutive month, but the drop in exports was larger. C2.

Court Rejects Microsoft Request
A federal appeals court rejected the effort by Microsoft to delay the antitrust case against it, setting the stage for the selection of a new trial court judge soon to consider the appropriate penalties against the company. The decision was a procedural setback for Microsoft. A1.

Bush Fills Last Major Economic Post
The Bush administration acted to fill the last significant slot on its economic team by naming Richard H. Clarida, chairman of the economics department at Columbia University, to be assistant secretary of the Treasury for economic policy. C2.

F.D.A. Warns About Candy Hazard
The Food and Drug Administration warned consumers that bite-sized, jelly cup candies, popular treats in Asia that have begun to catch on with American children, may pose a choking hazard. The candies may have caused the deaths of three children in the United States and more overseas, the agency said. C4.

Europe Ends Compact Disc Inquiry
The European Commission said it was ending an investigation into whether the world's five largest music companies were colluding with retailers over the price of compact discs in the European Union. Competition authorities in Germany and Italy, however, can start their own investigations. C14.

Sotheby's Ex-Chief Plans Defense
Lawyers for A. Alfred Taubman, Sotheby's chief shareholder and former chairman, outlined central elements of the defense he is expected to make against charges that he colluded with a counterpart at Christie's to fix commission rates governing tens of thousands of transactions. A17.

Electronics Downturn Hurts Taiwan
Taiwan's economy shrank for the first time in 26 years as a slide in electronics exports sapped investment and consumer spending, prompting the central bank to cut interest rates for the eighth time since December. Gross domestic product contracted 2.4 percent in the second quarter from a year ago. C3.

A Russian Tries to Polish His Image
Mikhail Khodorkovsky, chairman of Yukos, Russia's second-largest oil company, and by some estimates the nation's richest man, is now working to right past wrongs. Two years ago, Mr. Khodorkovsky orchestrated a series of flagrant corporate abuses of minority shareholders unparalleled in the short history of modern Russian capitalism. C3.

Accenture to Eliminate 1,500 Jobs
Accenture, the consulting firm that recently changed its name from Andersen Consulting, said it would lay off 1,500 employees, including 1,000 consultants, because of the weak economy and the low rate of employee turnover. Accenture also said that it would expand to Europe and Asia its sabbatical program. C4.

AMR Cuts Travel Agents' Payments
AMR plans to lower its maximum commissions to travel agents in the United States and Canada for domestic travel on its American Airlines or Trans World Airlines units. C14.

 INTERNATIONAL A3-7

British Arrive in Macedonia To Start NATO Campaign
Forty-one British troops arrived in the Macedonian capital as part of an advance NATO team that will help decide when and if Macedonia is safe and stable enough for a full contingent of 3,500 NATO troops to come in and disarm ethnic Albanian guerrillas. In Brussels, the alliance's leaders decided to wait until next week before making a decision on whether to deploy all 3,500 soldiers. A4

Rift in Serbian Coalition
The party of Yugoslavia's president, Vojislav Kostunica, pulled out of Serbia's coalition government in what could become a final split in the governing pro-democracy camp. A4

U.S. Mideast Monitors Sought
Egypt's top foreign policy official, Osama el-Baz, asked the Bush administration to send American monitors to the Middle East to help defuse the violence between Israelis and Palestinians, officials said. A3

Not Quite Around the World
The fifth attempt by Steve Fossett, an American millionaire, to become the first person to complete an around-the-world solo balloon trip came to an abrupt end when a prediction of bad weather forced him to land near Brazil's southern border. A4

Chinese Protesters Convicted
A Beijing court convicted four people of murder for organizing the self-immolation in January by followers of the Falun Gong movement. A7

F.A.A. Limits Korean Flights
The Federal Aviation Administration told South Korea that its regulation of aviation safety fell short of international standards. As a result, Korean carriers flying to the United States will not be allowed to expand their service, use American partner airlines or even change the airplanes they use. A5

Investigators Trace Trail Of Diluted Cancer Drugs
Investigators examining the records of Robert R. Courtney, a retail pharmacist charged with diluting the cancer medicine he dispensed, believe that at least 10 doctors could have received diluted drugs for potentially hundreds of patients. Mr. Courtney told investigators he cut the drugs' strength "out of greed," according to court papers. A1

Rumsfeld described his vision of military transformation as one that might not even challenge current weapons programs or involve more than a "modest fraction" of the Pentagon's forces. He said changes would focus on new technology, especially communications networks. A10

Luck and Money Fight Fires
Federal officials say fewer lightning strikes and the approval of additional firefighters by Congress have made a big difference in limiting the number of acres burned to well below that of previous big fire years. A8

HEADLINE: Dollar's Slow Slide Indicates Foreign Investors May Be Wary of U.S. 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The dollar's slow tumble against the euro continued yesterday and analysts are not sure where it will stop, given the concern that the American economy may not begin to rebound as soon as many had expected. The dollar has also been slipping against the Japanese yen.
 "There is a change in the mood," said Larry Kantor, the head of foreign exchange strategy in New York for J. P. Morgan. "We are in mid-August now, we are in the second half of the year and people are nervous that it is not here," he said of the economic rebound. 
 Mr. Kantor added that the pace of the flow of capital into American markets from abroad might also be slowing a little, which would put downward pressure on the dollar.
For the yen, he said the rally seemed to reflect a decision by many investors to pull out of trades in which they had borrowed in yen at nearly zero interest rates and then invested that in securities in other currencies that paid much higher interest rates. He said this shift in strategy was a reflection of a move by investors to be more cautious and was overwhelming the economic fundamentals in Japan, which he said favored a stronger dollar.
Since its high in July against the euro, the dollar has fallen 8.8 percent. In New York yesterday, the value of the euro settled at 91.74 cents, a move up from 91.35 cents on Thursday that pushed the value of the dollar 0.4 percent lower. Against the yen, the dollar is down 5 percent from its 2001 high in April. Yesterday, the dollar was up slightly, to 120.40 yen from 119.93 on Thursday.
Yet by any measure, the dollar is still strong. Since the inception of the euro in 1999, the dollar is up 21 percent and it is still up 2.7 percent for this year. Against the yen, the dollar is up 5.2 percent this year and well above its record low in the early 1990's.
One key for the dollar's outlook is how the Bush administration handles its recent slide. Currency traders are looking for any hint from the administration that it is backing off from the strong-dollar policy of the Clinton administration under Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary. If traders hear one -- or even think they do -- the dollar ought to fall further.
While the current Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, has said the strong dollar policy is intact and that he would hire out Yankee Stadium to announce any change, there have been some confusing signals. In July, President Bush spoke about both the benefits and drawbacks of a strong dollar and said that markets should set its value. Some currency traders interpreted those remarks as a hint of a weaker dollar policy and sent the currency sharply lower. Then Mr. O'Neill asserted that he was the administration's sole spokesman on the dollar and reiterated support for a strong dollar.
At the same time, there is growing pressure on the administration from many manufacturers, who have complained that the strong dollar is hurting their business. John M. Devine, the chief financial officer of General Motors, said recently that G.M. had asked the Bush administration to rethink its currency policy. "The strong dollar is frankly destroying the manufacturing capability and the manufacturing competitiveness of this country," he said.
The strengthening dollar has made the rebound of the economy much more difficult. A stronger dollar makes American exports less competitive abroad, hurting sales. In addition, a stronger dollar makes imports cheaper for Americans, hurting sales of domestic competitors.
But at the same time, the strong dollar has been a boon to Americans traveling abroad. In some parts of Europe, the exchange rate has not been this favorable since the 1980's.
The report yesterday that the trade deficit in June grew to $29.4 billion was another reminder of the impact of the strength of the dollar, as American exports fell to their lowest level in 16 months. The widening trade deficit also reflects a long-term problem for the dollar. As it and the broader current account deficit widens, America needs to attract more investment from abroad to balance its books. But if this flow slows, one consequence will be a weakening dollar.
Before the dollar tumble against the euro began, it had managed a surprising rally this year against the single European currency that now covers 12 nations, even though the American stock market was plunging and the United States economy was slowing quickly.
One reason was that Europeans still seemed to have a preference for investing in America. This preference was heightened by the fact that the Federal Reserve began to cut short-term interest rates aggressively in January, which made many believe, at the time, that the slowdown in the American economy would be over in the second half of the year.
But now that the Fed has cut interest rates six times and the economy is still struggling, "it is a scarier environment than it was in January," Mr. Kantor said.
The flow of foreign investment into the United States, which is now going into bonds instead of stocks and mergers and acquisitions, is still positive. But Mr. Kantor said it could slow suddenly. He noted that foreigners did not have to begin selling American assets to put downward pressure on the dollar. All they have to do, he said, is buy at a slower pace than in the past.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA DROPS ON REPORT OF WEAK DEMAND

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Shares of Scientific-Atlanta Inc. declined 15 percent after the company, a leading maker of set-top boxes for cable television, withdrew previous earnings and sales forecasts as demand fell. 
Shares of the company, which is based in Lawrenceville, Ga., fell $3.77, to $21.24, The company said Thursday it could not predict sales for the first fiscal quarter ending in September or for fiscal 2002. It blamed slowing customer growth for digital TV, which uses a set-top box to get hundreds of cable channels. Cable operators are ordering fewer of the devices as economic growth slows and customers spend less.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Fall Broadly on Poor Profit News From Big Names

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply and broadly yesterday, as companies as varied as Dell Computer, Ford Motor and Gap provided Wall Street with further evidence that corporate profits appear unlikely to recover soon.
 Heavy selling in Microsoft also put pressure on the stock market, after a federal appeals court ruled against the company's request to delay the government antitrust case against it. 
 "That's enough on a summer Friday to give the market a pause, and this is exactly what happens under these circumstances," said Arthur Hogan, the chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "We're seeing literally a handful of negative stories from some pretty marquee companies, and that's sort of outweighing anything we can focus on." 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 151.75 points, or 1.46 percent, to close at 10,240.78. For the week, the Dow lost 1.68 percent.
The technology-weighted Nasdaq composite index, meanwhile, dropped 63.31 points, or 3.28 percent, to 1,867.01, bringing the week's loss to 4.57 percent. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 19.69 points, or 1.67 percent, to 1,161.97, for a weekly loss of 2.37 percent.
Analysts said the latest bleak messages from corporate America further unnerved investors, many of whom were already reluctant to buy stocks ahead of Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy makers. Economists expect the Fed to cut short-term interest rates for the seventh time this year, reducing them at least one-quarter of a percentage point.
"It's a virtual certainty there will be an easing next Tuesday," said Rory Robertson, an interest-rate strategist at Macquarie Equities in New York. "The only real outstanding question," he said, is whether it will be another quarter-point or whether the Fed will see a need to go for a half-point increase. "The ongoing weakness in equities is a clear signal that equity investors are basically giving up on a quick rebound in growth," he added.
Dell was among those hit hard yesterday, falling $2.38, to $23. Dell reported a loss of $101 million in its second fiscal quarter and warned that it would not meet Wall Street's forecasts for its earnings and sales in the current quarter because of weak demand.
The prospect of slumping demand for personal computers sent shares of other computer makers and related companies downward. I.B.M. fell $1.16, to $104.59; Cisco Systems lost 87 cents, to $16.61; and Intel tumbled $2.09, to $28.07.
Semiconductor issues were among yesterday's most battered technology stocks. Shares of Linear Technology fell $2.74, to $41.37; Texas Instruments fell $1.58, to $33.14; Applied Materials fell $2.13, to $42.57; and Xilinx fell $2.01, to $37.53. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index dropped 27.49 points, or 4.7 percent, to close at 555.54.
Ford fell $1.77, to $21.70, after it cut its earnings forecast for all of 2001 because of slowing sales and said it would eliminate 4,000 to 5,000 white-collar jobs by the end of the year. General Motors, one of the 30 Dow components, dropped $3.10, to $59.47; Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service said they might cut the credit ratings of G.M. and Ford.
Gap lost $1.92, to $21.43, after warning that its profits in its latest quarter would miss analysts' expectations. In response, Merrill Lynch, Credit Suisse First Boston and Prudential Securities cut their ratings on Gap's stock.
Microsoft lost $2.74, to $61.88, after the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied the company's bid to delay lower-court proceedings against it while it pursues an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.
Scientific-Atlanta was the biggest loser on the Big Board yesterday, plunging $3.77, to $21.24, after the company, a maker of cable television equipment, withdrew its forecasts for its first fiscal quarter and for all of fiscal 2002, saying there was a slowdown in customer demand for new digital equipment.
PeopleSoft, a software maker, fell $2.34, to $35.85, after a judge ruled in favor of a former employee who sued the company because she was dismissed for calling attention to the company's failure to comply with affirmative action regulations.
Investors largely ignored yesterday's mixed economic data.
The Commerce Department reported that the United States trade deficit widened 3.3 percent in June, to $29.4 billion. But that figure was largely in line with analysts' estimates.
On a positive note, consumer confidence remains a bright spot in what is otherwise a sluggish economic environment. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index rose to 93.5 in August from 92.4 in July. The current-conditions index also rose to 101.7 from 98.6 in July.
Treasury prices rose yesterday as investors moved out of stocks and anticipated that the Fed would cut interest rates further to revive the economy. The 10-year Treasury note rose 27/32, to 100 10/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.83 percent from 4.94 percent on Thursday. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 28/32, to 99 11/32, while its yield fell to 5.42 percent from 5.48 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: FORD TO CURTAIL AUTO PRODUCTION AND CUT 5,000 JOBS 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 17 

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it was eliminating 5,000 salaried jobs in North America and planned to reduce production this fall, the latest signs that the auto industry may no longer be able to prop up the stumbling American economy.
 The Standard & Poor's credit agency responded to Ford's moves by warning that even more drastic measures were needed. S.& P. said it was preparing to downgrade the credit ratings of both Ford and General Motors -- a reflection of Wall Street's worries about the domestic carmakers' high costs and the growing market share of import brands. 
 Even with strong sales earlier this summer, G.M., Ford and Chrysler have had trouble earning profits because of the persistent strength of the dollar, which allows foreign makers to undercut their prices. And lately, sales have been gradually slowing at dealerships across the country despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate reductions that had been sustaining car purchases. 
Economists said today that the auto industry, rather than pulling the American economy along, is turning into a brake on growth that could help drag the nation into a recession. 
"Sales and ultimately production are going to go down another notch, and if that happens it might be another weight on the economy that's just too much for the economy to bear," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
Ford projected today that it would make 8 percent fewer cars and light trucks during the fourth quarter of this year than during the period last year. Such a reduction would require Ford to temporarily furlough thousands of workers across the Midwest, further damaging confidence in the economy. 
"At that level of production, that would imply some facilities would have to be temporarily idled," said George Pipas, a market analyst at Ford.
Even so, S.& P. said Ford's "efforts to reduce costs have been inadequate."
Martin Inglis, Ford's chief financial officer, confirmed today that the company had begun a broad review of its North American operations with an eye to further cutbacks by year's end.
In its announcement today, Ford said it planned to reduce its salaried work force of 50,000 managers and engineers by 10 percent through an offer of early-retirement incentives, mainly to those 50 or older with 10 or more years of service. While the great bulk of the job losses will be in the Detroit area, there will also be 200 in Canada and an unspecified number at Ford operations in Chicago and the Los Angeles area.
The company said the program's one-time cost would be $700 million, but that it would save $300 million a year in salaries and benefits. 
Ford also warned Wall Street today that even without the buyout program's cost, it expected to earn just 70 cents a share this year, instead of the $1.25 to $1.35 it predicted just a month ago. Ford shares fell $1.77, to close at $21.70. Shares of General Motors dropped $3.10, closing at $59.47.
Other automakers have not yet completed their fall production forecasts, but they are concerned about sales. "The market's not so strong this month," said an executive at one of Ford's rivals. Ford, though, is struggling more than other automakers because it has a shrinking share of the shrinking auto market. Its sales this year are down 11.6 percent, versus a drop of 4.7 percent for the market as a whole.
When sales briefly slowed last winter, auto executives made deep production cuts in January and February, and both Chrysler and G.M. rolled out early-retirement programs to reduce labor costs. But sales proved surprisingly strong in the spring as lower interest rates helped auto sales, and automakers began to schedule longer hours at factories again. 
Now, though, showrooms and factory parking lots are beginning to fill up with unsold sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans, as sales of these vehicles have slowed sharply -- except for car-based sport utilities, many of which are imported. Foreign-owned and domestic automakers are now planning to cut production of so-called light trucks in North America by 3.4 percent in September, according to Ward's Communications, an automotive data service in Southfield, Mich.
Production cuts could be even sharper, if manufacturers are being too optimistic in their projections of fairly vigorous sales as the new model year begins this autumn. 
Inventories of traditional cars are not a problem, because automakers have been more conservative about building large numbers of them. But because automakers earn almost all of their profits on light trucks, difficulties in that half of the market can quickly lead to cost cuts and job losses.
At the same time, the startling strength of the dollar in currency markets this summer has made it very hard for G.M., Ford and Chrysler to price their cars at profitable levels, even when auto sales have been fairly strong.
Foreign and domestic automakers have been engaged in a frenzy of discounting, with zero-percent loans available on many models. Foreign automakers have been able to absorb the discounts, because weak currencies have kept their costs down. This month, for example, Toyota announced that it would cut the price of its Camry sedan by $600. The cars are assembled in the United States, but many of the transmissions and other parts come from Japan.
Detroit automakers, by contrast, have watched their profits largely evaporate -- or turn into huge losses, in the case of the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler A. G. The combined after-tax earnings of Detroit's Big Three fell 61 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, to $2.04 billion, excluding one-time items and the cost of Ford's Firestone tire replacement program. The dollar has edged down in the last few weeks against the euro in particular, but remains far above the levels of two years ago.
As a result, all three Detroit automakers are under fierce pressure from Wall Street and credit ratings agencies to adopt cost-cutting measures, including job cuts. And cost reductions by automakers ripple quickly through the American economy, because the automakers are so enormous.
G.M. and Ford are still the only companies that each account for about a full percentage point of the nation's economic output; each is eight times the size of the Microsoft Corporation, for example. The auto industry is not just the biggest user of steel in the United States but the second-biggest user of glass and the third-largest buyer of textiles.
Sung Won Sohn, executive vice president and chief economist of Wells Fargo & Company, said that brisk auto sales had added half a percentage point to the nation's economic growth in the second quarter. Slowing sales, he projects, will subtract about three-tenths of a percentage point in the third quarter. "It's a big, pervasive impact," he said.
But Mr. Sohn and other experts cautioned that the industry is not struggling nearly as much as it had during the last recession, in 1991, which cost hundreds of thousands of workers their jobs as manufacturers shut assembly plants and auto parts factories. 
The sharp production cuts in the first quarter of this year allowed automakers to reduce inventories much more swiftly than in previous economic slowdowns. Supplies of unsold cars and light trucks have not rebounded to anywhere near the levels they reached last December.
Moreover, the economic effects of Detroit's production cutbacks and a strong dollar have been muted somewhat by the construction and expansion of numerous foreign-owned assembly plants in states like Indiana, Alabama and South Carolina. Japanese and European automakers have been gaining market share at Detroit's expense, but half their vehicles are assembled in the United States, where they provide tens of thousands of jobs.
Still, the strong dollar has clearly damaged Detroit's financial position, and the dollar's incremental retreat over the last six weeks -- it has lost 8.8 percent of its value against the euro -- has done nothing to reassure executives here. Trade figures released by the Commerce Department today showed that the nation's trade deficit in autos and auto parts widened in June, as $16.09 billion worth of automotive imports swamped the nation's $6.63 billion in automotive exports.
Stephen J. Collins, the president of the Automotive Trade Policy Council, a Washington lobbying group composed of Ford, G.M. and DaimlerChrysler, said that manufacturers from many industries had opened discussions in Washington with farm groups and labor unions about forming a lobbying coalition in favor of a weaker dollar. 
"The impact of the dollar as a competitive factor causing real harm has been the subject of discussions for the last three or four months," he said.
Detroit is also suffering because foreign automakers have been building new factories in the United States to enter market segments that used to be high-profit American preserves, like full-size sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. 
Toyota dealerships, for example, have been selling the new full-size Sequoia sport utility and Tundra pickup truck as fast as they arrive on lots, even as Ford dealerships become cluttered with unsold Expeditions and Excursions. 
And while Toyota is building its vehicles at a new plant in Princeton, Ind., both models were designed and engineered in Japan, so those costs were incurred in inexpensive yen.

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal; 
Red Square Is Suddenly Catching Up With Times

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 17 

 BODY:
Red Square is such a vast affair, a sprawling stretch of windswept cobblestone and towering cathedrals, that it is easy for summer's swarms of tourists to miss its small charms, like the round dais from which czars addressed the masses. No one, on the other hand, will miss the skin cream ad.
 No one can. An immense photograph of a joyous family and its exceptionally clean pores, the billboard dominates the square's northern entrance, covering much of the breadth and four-story height of the State Historical Museum. 
 Visitors will find the sight arresting, as if someone had concealed the Treasury Building next to the White House with a gigantic banner peddling, say, yogurt.
Muscovites long ago stopped noticing. Thanks to a lucky confluence of events -- or a sad one, depending on one's point of view -- Russia's rococo old capital has become Europe's hothouse of billboards, an absolute thicket of signs beseeching the people to gamble, smoke, drink, wear skimpy underwear and expensive watches and visit strip joints, among other things.
One can gauge the explosion by the numbers. There are more than 14,000 standard-size billboards -- the 10-by-20-footers that line most streets -- up 20 percent last year alone, according to the Espar-Analytik market research firm. There are another 10,000 billboards, building-size banners and rooftop signs of other stripes.
The better measure, though, may be this one: Moscow today has roughly as many billboards as does London, and it has put up virtually all of them in the last 10 years.
As Andrei V. Beryozkin, the general director of Espar-Analytik, points out, these are the fruits of capitalism. There was a perception common across the old Soviet bloc that the presence of such luscious billboards was as sure a sign of arrival in the market economy as the old Communist slogans were of being ruled by the rigors of Marx.
The explosion of street advertising here and in other Russian cities also belies the old saw that Russians were rendered destitute by the country's two fiscal collapses during the 1990's.
Enough people are buying what the boards sell that outdoor advertising has become a $150-million-a-year business here, and big American and European companies have begun to invade the market. The most notable is the News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's media conglomerate, which has bought Russia's largest outdoor advertising company, APR City.
But even Adam Smith might be forced, after surveying the glut of cheesy ads that blot out Moscow's once graceful avenues, to agree that this city was at least more handsome when rooftop signs, and fewer of them, exhorted workers to greater glory instead of better vermouth, and smaller street banners praised Lenin's unswerving vision of a Communist utopia, not shoe store discounts.
While there is much wit to be found on the boards -- a long-running cigarette campaign that takes wry pokes at American power comes to mind -- taste is not a long suit. A prominent ad for dental services relies on a racist caricature.
So many boards use sex to rise above the clutter that the latest groundbreaking attempt, in which healthy young men and women seem to have literally and completely leapt out of their color-coordinated outfits, barely draws a glance.
In a way, Mr. Beryozkin said, the Soviet Union has itself to blame. "The landscape of Soviet city planners is ideal for advertising," he said. "There aren't that many major cities with a street system so well suited for placing billboards. The major highways are pretty wide, and there's room for boards."
By comparison, he said, most West European cities are rats' nests of narrow lanes suited largely for small signs, and advertising on freeways and other major suburban roads is tightly constrained.
But geography is only one of several forces driving the billboard's inexorable rise. Money, handed over and under the table, is another. Russian city governments own many buildings outright and license the placement of signs on the rest.
Billboard licensing fees net Moscow's cash-hungry government at least $25 million a year that federal powers cannot control. Both they and billboard companies have every incentive to open that spigot more.
In parts of Russia the licensing process is so greased by bribery that it has become a big moneymaker for city officials and a magnet for violence. Last week, for example, the chief billboard licenser in Novosibirsk, under verbal fire for razing billboards in an apparent attempt to shift control of the local ad market, was shot to death during a morning drive from his country home.
Askold E. Shestunov, whose outdoor advertising company Big Board controls signs in 15 Russian cities, said Moscow's licensing process was more orderly than elsewhere. But he conceded that his workers had waged fistfights with employees of a former associate who said the city had awarded the signs to him.
"Court proceedings will start in a month," Mr. Shestunov said. "We are almost 100 percent sure that everything will be decided according to the law."
That, Mr. Beryozkin indicated, may be an exception.
"Corruption of city bureaucrats in Russia is pretty much at the same level as in Southeast Asia, Indonesia and Eastern Europe," he said. "City authorities have this resource at their disposal, and they use it. It's one of the reasons outdoor is developing so fast."
Indeed, it is developing so fast that even the billboard magnates are starting to worry about where the business is carrying them.
Moscow's surfeit of licenses and deficit of any serious aesthetic or architectural rules has had predictable results. In most cities, boards are widely spaced and set back from roads. In contrast, Moscow's signs overpopulate a relative handful of major roads, hover on buildings, loom over sidewalks, hang from overpasses and pile atop and in front of each other.
On the eight-lane-and-more Garden Ring, which circles downtown Moscow, the ordinary billboards clogging what was once a flowery median have been topped by superboards nearly 100 feet high, and scores of building walls are sheathed in seven- and eight-story pitches for beer, insurance and soap.
Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov has a plan to rein in this profusion by banning large billboards from Moscow's historic center and restricting their placement elsewhere. Many billboard companies, fearful that they are creating too much of a good thing, believe it would be a good idea to keep outdoor signs limited, modest and therefore pricey.
Whether they have the discipline is another matter. Despite Mr. Luzhkov's effort to clamp down on licensing, workers still are putting up roughly 180 standard-size boards each month, securing licenses from who knows where. 
And that does not include countless other oversized billboards, bus shelter ads, street banners and, increasingly, building-size ads like the one pitching skin cream.
"It's outrageous when these large billboard structures prevent people from seeing monuments," Mr. Shestunov, of the aptly named Big Board, complained. "It cannot be justified by any amount of money.
"On the other hand, I think it's very typical of the Russian soul, this scale in everything. People like big things here."

HEADLINE: Selection Made for Treasury Dept. Post 

 BODY:
The Bush administration acted yesterday to fill the last major slot on its economic team by naming Richard H. Clarida, chairman of the economics department at Columbia University, to be assistant secretary of the Treasury for economic policy.
 Mr. 
Clarida's research has focused on the Taylor Rule, in effect finding that the major central banks, including the Federal Reserve, adhere to the practice of adjusting interest rates in response to inflation and excessive economic growth. The rule was formulated in 1993 by John H. Taylor, a Stanford University economist. Mr. Taylor now serves as the Treasury's under secretary for international affairs. 
 The other top economic advisers in the Bush Administration, in addition to Mr. Taylor, are Lawrence B. Lindsey, head of the National Economic Council, and R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Mr. Hubbard is also a Columbia economics professor. Mr. Clarida's nomination is subject to approval by the Senate.
Mr. Clarida, 44, who describes himself as a mainstream macro-economist, has been a Columbia professor since 1988. Before that, he taught at Yale University and served for a while as a staff economist on President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers. He earned a Bachelor of Science degree in economics from the University of Illinois in 1979 and a Ph.D. from Harvard in 1983.

LENGTH: 1783 words

HEADLINE: She Wrote The Book 

BYLINE:  By William Norwich; William Norwich is the entertaining editor of The Times Magazine.

 BODY:
Why do people let journalists go home with them? 
 Even if, as documented in the most upstanding glossies, the intercourse is of the safest sort, what motivates the rich and famous to open their portals to ink-stained wretches? 
 It is not a mystery, really. They have to. It is a requisite of capitalism. It is a rule written in an unwritten instruction manual somewhere. Arbiters are not created in a void any more than trees can fall in a forest if no one hears them. According to Thorstein Veblen, the author of "The Theory of the Leisure Class," a proudly acquisitive meritocracy keeps the system charging ahead, like a carrot dangling in front of a donkey. Someone always has to show and tell in order to stimulate acquisitive urges. Once the decorator clears out and someone else's ancestral portraits are hanging on your walls, it would be downright unpatriotic not to bring a journalist home. Unlike cable television and health care, upward mobility is an inalienable right. 
"By wearing the newest fashions, decorating and redecorating their several houses, demanding exquisite foods from their personal chefs and indulging in a frankly symbiotic relationship with the press, they create taste in this country, giving us Thorstein Veblen's conspicuous consumer as a role model," Charlotte Curtis said in "The Rich and Other Atrocities," a compilation of articles she wrote for The Times from 1963 to 1973.
Curtis's readers understood that society used to be about who one was or, at least, whom one knew, married or consorted with. Never was it about "who" one wore until the great marriage of convenience that was forged between society and a caffeinated fashion industry after World War II. While the columnist Eugenia Sheppard and the publisher John Fairchild chronicled this marriage -- in fact, they often acted as its matchmakers -- Curtis cast a wider net.
Born in Chicago, and raised in Columbus, Ohio, she began her newspaper career as a general assignment reporter with The Columbus Citizen after she graduated from Vassar in 1950. Curtis joined The Times in 1961, became the newspaper's style and family editor in 1965, an associate editor in 1973 and the editor of the op-ed page the following year. She was the first woman to have her name listed on the newspaper's senior masthead.
Curtis said that she liked to "get inside a person's skin and crawl around a bit." In 1963, when Clifton Daniel, then The Times's assistant managing editor, asked her to cover society, she seized the opportunity. The world was changing , and, for Curtis, "society" was the entire human race -- a swim perfect for uncharted, anthropological study. 
Curtis felt that society should be written about in a lively way, just as one might cover politics and sports. She also thought that political coverage benefited from dispatches with the same lively social details she observed whenever more than two people gathered. This opinion was considered quite modern in the 1960's, when the New Journalism was first being scrutinized. Curtis defined her brand of society writing like any other kind of news coverage: who, what, why, when and where and, if there was any, the significance of what happened. "We were in the business of telling the truth," she explained. "The notion used to be that all brides are beautiful, and all brides are not beautiful! But it was as though all wedding stories were written, 'and the beautiful bride wore, etc.' Well, I'm sorry, that doesn't have anything to do with reality."
She used words like they were X-rays, like Joan Didion's sentences without the conditional. "Mrs. Jerry Ohrbach wanted what she called 'an informal country house with antiques' and, after a year and a half and several million dollars she thinks that at long last she has it," Curtis wrote in April 1969.
She rewrote tirelessly on a manual typewriter and prepared extensively before an interview or event. According to copy-desk legend at The Times, Curtis could be killed but never cut. All her words fit or else she might sue for malpractice.
Curtis's mother was a diplomat who had been the first female field officer in the Foreign Service. Her father was a surgeon who taught her how to arrange the food on her plate so it represented a diorama of the internal organs of the human body. 
Asked in 1963 how she managed to succeed in what was then a man's world of journalism, Curtis replied that "feminine charms" never figured into her success. "Honey," she told the questioner, "I don't have any, damn it."
Her first marriage, right out of Vassar, ended less than three years after it began. The gentleman -- nice enough, she said -- did not understand that newspapering is not a 9-to-5 job. When she started at The Times, first as a home-furnishings and fashion reporter, she rented a small penthouse at 40 East 10th Street. Several years later, she bought it for $25,000. According to her biographer, Marilyn S. Greenwald, it amused Curtis that the apartment originally was the servants' quarters. 
Charlotte Curtis weighed about 100 pounds, including the pen and pad she took to dinner parties and always put on the table, even at Mrs. Astor's. "I'm never confused about who I am," Curtis explained. She wore pearls, French perfume and ladylike dresses, but kept a pair of royal blue sneakers in her office in case she needed to run to get a story. 
"It is not a rapier that she conceals beneath the satin and velvet of her impeccable prose -- it is a scalpel, and when her surgery is complete the victim may not even know he or she has undergone an operation," Harrison Salisbury noted. Truman Capote observed, "She has two ears and two eyes, and nothing escapes any of them."
In 1966, Curtis covered what Capote called his "little masked ball for Kay Graham and all my friends" at the Plaza Hotel. "Henry J. Heinz 2nd, the pickle king from Pittsburgh, wore nothing more complicated than a wedge from a paper plate with a nose cut through the center for his nose," she wrote, emphasizing the pickle king's nose. Curtis positioned herself behind Capote and Graham on the receiving line, and her account of the evening, which appeared in the next day's Times, included the 540 names of the guests she had written down in longhand. 
The international jet set, fueled with post-World War II enthusiasm, changed the map of society in the 60's. Society became anything, or anyone, that wasn't nailed down. Or, as Curtis put it, "overachievers who are forever exercising their money and power."
In Acapulco in 1968, Curtis found Warren Avis, an industrialist who sold his used-car business earlier in the decade, "padding around in bright orange shorts." He wanted a house large enough so "you'd never see the servants, and you don't." Avis's house was "so big, and so intricately designed that guests in the same general area aren't necessarily visible to one another." She continued: "The nearest thing to a front door is a gate with a bell at the top of a long and involved stairway that begins up the hill -- somewhere above Mr. Avis's roof. But what you do see are terraces leading to other terraces, all of which overlook the bay, a telescope for Mr. Avis to identify his pals on the yachts that come to call, several comfortably furnished marble living rooms and a bullhorn. Mr. Avis needs the horn to call anyone who has wandered off somewhere -- say, to the beach 150 feet below. But it apparently is never used to call the gang in to dinner.
"We aren't that formal,' he said."
In Anchorage, in 1966, Curtis observed Alaska's "Airplane Society," where everyone "of consequence" had his own plane and nobody walked, because "if you did, someone would think you had a flat tire or were out of gas," Mrs. Robert B. Atwood explained.
Curtis wrote: "Mrs. Atwood, a sleek, auburn-haired lady who gave black-tie dinners beneath three French crystal chandeliers until the 1964 earthquake swallowed her $100,000 log cabin, braves the snow in high-heeled black alligator shoes." The article continued: "I don't believe in putting on airs,' she said, 'but I don't see any reason why we have to be uncouth."'
For a brief period, a political conscience bestirred the swells. In November 1970, Curtis noted that spaghetti parties for 8 were replacing black-tie dinners for 24: "Whether because of the recession, inflation, Vietnam, campus unrest, the desire to get closer to nature, a new introspection or simply boredom with the old extravagances, a new lifestyle is emerging, and emerging quickly." The decorator Chessy Rayner said: "We've all changed. That giddy racing around is gone. It's a reaction to what's happening. If you're giddy now, you're insensitive to the world's problems."
That same year, Curtis covered a fund-raiser for the Black Panthers given by Leonard Bernstein and his wife, Felicia, at their Park Avenue duplex that was later chronicled by Tom Wolfe in "Radical Chic." The party's elegant slumming outraged many readers of The Times.
Bernstein asked Donald Cox, a Black Panther field marshal, about the Panthers' goals and tactics. "If business won't give us full employment," Cox responded, "then we must take the means of production and put them in the hands of the people."
Bernstein said, "I dig absolutely."
Curtis was not a snob about the American dream. She simply preferred to see its enchantments with her eyes open: "This will to move and change, whether aboard the Mayflower, the covered wagon, the automobile or jet plane, coupled with the inventiveness of a restless people who consciously fled the traditions of the Old World while eagerly seeking the frontiers of the new, has produced a frankly neophiliac quality to American life. New and different is good. Old and familiar is boring. The safe conclusion, therefore, is that whatever society is at the moment is not what it is about to become."
Curtis championed places other than Manhattan. "The decisions that matter most happen in places like Allentown and Sacramento. I'm adamant about spending all the time I can in places like that."
Cared for by her second husband, William E. Hunt, a neurosurgeon, she returned to Ohio, where she died from cancer in 1987 at age 58. 
But the comic vanities of the rich always interested her. From 1983 to 1986, she wrote a weekly column of social commentary for The Times covering the Gettys, the Basses and others prominent in Manhattan's booming 1980's economy.
"What would we do without the rich? They are the modern Medicis," Curtis once noted. "They set the pace aesthetically. Of course, I'm enough of a Puritan myself to believe a little opulence goes a long way, but I'm not sure the world would be a better place without them. After all, then everything would be polyester." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: At The New York Times in 1976, Charlotte Curtis, the doyenne of society writing. (Beth Charney); Curtis wrote pointedly about the Black-and-White Ball (with guests Mia Farrow and Frank Sinatra) and the rent-a-car king Warren Avis. (from left: Bettmann/Corbis; William Sauro.)
