HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Hidden Barriers to Health Coverage

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE best possible method for getting health insurance under the current system, of course, is to be gainfully employed by a company that offers coverage. That is not to suggest that all care is created equal. Some employers pay all the premiums, while some pay less than half. Some offer plain-vanilla H.M.O.'s, others a fuller range of plans. And some are strong voices for employees in disputes with insurers, while others do very little to help. 
 But it is also true that some employers raise the bar enough to prevent or discourage their own workers from getting the insurance they do offer. 
 Some companies insist, for instance, that their workers foot a big portion of the monthly bills, and the only plans they offer may have high premiums, putting them out of the reach of most lower-paid workers. Others require workers to endure long waiting periods before they can enroll, while most refuse to cover part-time workers. And the employers -- who are generally fed up with having to administer benefits and fight with insurance companies -- are often low-energy advocates for their workers when they face off with the insurers over coverage.
The Commonwealth Fund, a health care research foundation based in New York, found in a study this summer that high premiums and tight restrictions played a major role in keeping many workers without coverage, even when they are employed by companies that offer insurance plans.
The problems are most acute for low-wage earners -- those earning less than $20,000 a year. The Commonwealth Fund found that companies with few such employees insure proportionately more of their work forces. Sometimes, even a small increase in the amount employees must contribute toward their insurance is enough to persuade them to change or reduce coverage. A $10 increase in monthly contributions raises the probability that a worker will switch plans to 25 percent from 5 percent, the foundation said. 
Workers may also be discouraged by an absence of choices. About 87 percent of workers in small companies have only one choice, generally an H.M.O., when it comes to health plans. Tack on obstacles like exclusions of care for pre-existing conditions and a load of other restrictions, and it becomes cheaper and more attractive for some people to take their chances and pay for medical care out of pocket when they become ill. 
Most companies have waiting periods before new workers can enroll in health insurance. But the longer the wait, the fewer become eligible, apparently because some may leave their jobs or change their schedules to part-time work. The Commonwealth study found that about 30 percent fewer people were eligible for insurance in companies with waiting periods longer than four months, compared with those in companies with short or nonexistent periods.
"Employer eligibility policies play an important role in coverage," said Jon Gabel, a vice president of the Health Research Educational Trust, which contributed to the Commonwealth study. He added that one in four employees working for companies that offer insurance are ineligible because of the waiting periods and other restrictions.
State regulations requiring shorter waiting periods could address this issue, but regulations have not been a panacea when it comes to solving many health care problems, and often do not help to contain overall care costs.
And workers may find that their employers are not their best advocates when it come to battling insurance companies. Some workers may not want their help anyway, preferring to keep their bosses out of their personal business, even if that means opting out of health insurance. 
"If a worker needs mental health services, or has a drug-addicted spouse, or a daughter who wants an abortion or a son with AIDS," wrote Greg Scandlen, in last winter's issue of Health Care News, a trade newsletter, "the employer might well be the last person an employee would confide in."
Mr. Scandlen, a senior fellow at the National Center for Policy Analysis, also said that setting the same high premium for all workers would likely force lower-paid, younger new employees to decline coverage, leaving behind older, often less healthy participants. 
Among the industries surveyed by the Commonwealth Fund, the retail sector had the lowest rate of insured employees. That may be attributed to its high percentage of part-time workers and to the fact that its employees make an average monthly contribution of $46 for their insurance premiums, well above the $29 average among industries surveyed.
Are employers best suited to solve the problems of the uninsured and underinsured? Many health care policy experts contend that they are not, and that universal health care or medical savings accounts are better solutions. But for now, the social contract between workers and the best employers still includes health benefits. Bosses could do more, sometimes at little extra cost, to increase the percentage of insured workers in their midst.

HEADLINE: CITY LIFE; 
Looking Up at Jersey City's Future . . .

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
Construction of the twin towers of the World Trade Center in 1973 not only unseated the Empire State Building as the world's tallest building and transformed the Lower Manhattan skyline. It also heightened the contrast between the squat waterfront warehouses here and the skyscrapers across the Hudson.
 The twin towers have been surpassed; the new tallest buildings are the Petronas Towers in Malaysia's capital, Kuala Lumpur, at 1,483 feet. But now the banner of "tallest" -- the tallest building in New Jersey, that is -- is again being raised on the banks of the Hudson, and another skyline will be transformed. 
 The Goldman Sachs & Company building at 30 Hudson Street is to rise 821 feet above the Jersey City waterfront when it is finished; the projected completion date is the summer of 2003. Whatever its street-level impact, experts say the building will have a big effect on the city's appearance, its prestige and even its self-image. 
"In some terms, you can say it puts you on the map," said Ron Klemensic, a Seattle-based structural engineer who is chairman of the Council on Tall Buildings, the international organization that officially doles out the superlatives. "For the community, it draws attention to what's happening there. Generally, at least those people who are in the building business -- contractors, engineers, architects -- all look at that as a positive thing."
Up to now, Goldman Sachs has played down the height of the building. Joel Brenner, the project manager, said the height "was dictated by some of the zoning parameters, which have very little do with the image statement that we wanted to make. 
"I think most of all," he added, "we were trying to create a quality work space that more or less you would find in Manhattan," which is where Goldman Sachs is based.
Whatever statement Goldman wants to make, the company hired the same architectural firms that designed the world's two tallest building projects, and preliminary renderings depict a soaring, clear glass column, tapering only near the top, refracting the daytime blues of the river and sky and the brilliant pinks and oranges of sunset. Cesar Pelli & Associates, which designed the Petronas Towers, is the project's principal architect, while Skidmore, Owings & Merrill LLP, which designed the Sears Tower, now the world's No. 2, is laying out the interior.
"So, there is some cachet," said Mr. Klemensic.
The tall world is a small world, apparently, and Mr. Klemensic's firm, Skilling Ward Magnusson Barkshire Structural Engineers, worked on the World Trade Center.
The cost of the 1.36-million-square-foot building, which will have an adjacent complex that includes a 250-room hotel, an auditorium and a glass atrium, is $361 million, according to the company's estimate.
At the moment, the Goldman Sachs building is little more than a massive concrete hole in the ground that will house a four-story underground parking deck. But a steel framework is already beginning to sprout above the river's edge, and even the construction cranes scrape the sky. When completed, the supremacy above other local buildings of what the company refers to simply as 30 Hudson Street will be dramatically apparent. Goldman's monument to its own corporate glory will be 50 percent taller than what is now the state's tallest building, which is also in Jersey City's financial district, a 550-foot structure at 101 Hudson Street, occupied largely by another financial firm, Merrill Lynch.
And with just a few structures in Lower Manhattan exceeding its height, the new Goldman building will raise Jersey City's profile.
"I think it will be a powerful symbol for that area," said Prof. Mir M. Ali, of the School of Architecture at the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana, who is chairman of the architecture group of the Tall Buildings Council. 
"You kind of feel a bit small when you compare yourself to New York, so this will boost your ego somewhat," Professor Ali added. "Tall buildings -- from my experience, I can tell you this -- some people just love them, some people just hate them. There's few people in the middle."
Take David Ruff and Sara Abbas, a young couple living in the Paulus Hook neighborhood surrounding the Goldman site, where a 38-story apartment tower is rising simultaneously next door.
"I like it," Mr. Ruff, 25, a pharmaceutical marketing supervisor, originally from Atlanta, said of the mushrooming skyline. "It's more like living in a city."
"I don't like tall buildings, actually," countered Ms. Abbas, 26, a corporate events planner, who used to live in low-rise Park Slope, Brooklyn. "It takes away from the quaintness of the area." 
The city's new mayor, Glenn Cunningham, welcomed the Goldman building.
"We're proud to see it coming here," said Mr. Cunningham, who vowed to work with the company to establish training and job placement programs for local residents. "It's going to feed both the image and the reality of Jersey City as the financial capital of New Jersey."
Mr. Cunningham's predecessor, Bret D. Schundler, who is now the Republican nominee for governor, approved a 20-year tax abatement for the building. Terms include payments equaling 10 percent of the building's annual lease payments, estimated to be worth $3.6 million to the city, said Bill Ayala, a city spokesman. 
Goldman is also receiving state incentives worth an estimated $164 million over 10 years, under the New Jersey Business Employee Incentive Program, which gives employers back up to 80 percent of their employees' state income tax. 
And in a less tangible benefit at the federal level, the company gets an old friend in high places, moving into a state whose junior United States Senator, Jon S. Corzine, a Democrat, is a former Goldman Sachs co-chairman. 
Steve Sanders, a board member of the Historic Paulus Hook Association, a community group, said it was yet to be seen whether the local revenues and economic activity generated by more than 6,000 Goldman employees at the building will be worth the projected 1,880 cars arriving there each morning peak period.
"Obviously, a project of that scale has unknowable impact," said Mr. Sanders, who noted there were several public and parochial schools, as well as many elderly residents, in the neighborhood. 
The city planning director, Robert Cotter, said the plans for the 35-acre Colgate Redevelopment Area, which includes the Goldman site, take the additional traffic into account. That plan allows a total of six million square feet of office space, one million of which is already occupied plus 100,000 square feet of retail space and 1,000 apartments. Goldman employees are expected to travel by PATH and light rail trains as well as by car. 
"The carrying capacity is there," Mr. Cotter said. 
The Goldman building can be viewed as the literal apex of the waterfront's transformation from a belching industrial outpost to a glistening financial center that has already attracted the likes of Deutsche Bank, J. P. Morgan & Company and others. As the name of the redevelopment area implies, the Goldman building is rising on what was once a sprawling complex of Colgate factories and warehouses, where Palmolive soap was a principal product.
"Come a rainy day, you'd find soap suds on the streets," recalled Dolores Jaworowski, 69, a retired librarian who has lived all her life in a three-story 1841 row house on Warren Street, a few blocks inland from the Goldman site. "I used to sit by the window and watch the ships come in. Now, all I can see is the buildings."
And she is likely to be seeing more of them.
The redevelopment plan has room for nearly five million square feet more of offices, even after the Goldman building becomes the tallest stalk in the Garden State.
"That area is growing, but the area is also very small," Professor Ali said. "So the only way things can go is up."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Jersey City waterfront will soon include a Goldman Sachs tower, which at 821 feet will be the state's tallest building. It is scheduled to be completed in the summer of 2003. (Photographs by Jim Simpson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE; 
Immature Cranberries Called to the Rescue

BYLINE:  By KIRSTY SUCATO 

 BODY:
At this time of year, Joseph W. Darlington, a cranberry farmer in Pemberton Township, normally bides his time. Like four generations of family farmers before him, Mr. Darlington waits for the fruit to ripen in the cool of autumn before the harvest in October, when the berries are at their most brilliant red. 
 But this year, Mr. Darlington, like more than a quarter of the state's cranberry growers, is preparing to flood his bogs just after Labor Day to capture a river of immature white berries. 
 An experimental beverage is turning the state's struggling cranberry industry upside down. It is white cranberry juice, a new product from Ocean Spray that is not as tart as the dark red brew. And it doesn't stain clothes. 
The drink, to be introduced nationwide in January, is part of an effort to increase consumer demand for cranberries and to lift growers out of their worst economic slump in 50 years. Ocean Spray is offering a bonus of up to 25 percent for the whitest fruit and, in the process, forcing some major changes in the cranberry industry. 
About 30 of New Jersey's 45 cranberry growers are members of the Ocean Spray Cooperative, the largest cranberry cooperative in the country. Of those, about 14 will be taking part in the program. 
"I guess it is the most changes occurring in a short period of time than any periods that have come before," said Mr. Darlington, the president of Joseph J. White Inc., the state's third-largest cranberry farm and a member of the Ocean Spray Cooperative. "This is certainly a period of more turbulence than ever before." 
He will devote about a quarter of his crop to the white berries, falling back on a second harvest of red fruit at the end of October. 
Growers are desperate for a way to increase prices, now the lowest since the 1950's. Last year, Ocean Spray growers got $11.23 for a 100-pound barrel of cranberries, compared with a high of about $60 in 1997. Production costs range from $15 to $45 to a barrel. 
Because of the hard times, Ocean Spray has laid off 40 workers at its manufacturing plant in Bordentown over recent months. Most farmers have not turned a profit in a couple of years and many did not even harvest last year because they could not afford to, said Edward V. Lipman Jr., a cranberry farmer and director of the Office of Continuing Professional Education at Rutgers University's Cook College. 
"I think the large farmers that are commercially efficient will ride this out; they see an end to it in maybe five years," he said. "If that doesn't happen, there will probably be a larger shakeout than what we're seeing right now." 
The problems date to the mid-1990's, when consumer demand was high, juice drinks were becoming fashionable, and medical studies showed that cranberry juice helped prevent urinary tract infections. Seeking to cash in on prices as high as $80 a barrel, farmers rushed to open bogs in Wisconsin and Canada. 
In New Jersey, where expansion is limited by state wetlands protection regulations, growers increased yields by introducing hardier varieties of plant, like the commonly used Stevens variety. 
But the growers soon produced more than they could sell, and in 1998, prices fell to $25 a barrel. This year, they are expecting to receive $17 to $22, with the white berries bringing an extra $1 to $6 a barrel. 
In an effort to reduce the glut, the United States Department of Agriculture ordered farmers to cut their production by 15 percent last year, and by 35 percent this year. For some, it will mean destroying hundreds of barrels of good fruit. Others will simply grow less. But it is still a painful remedy. 
"If we could have grown all of our acreage rather than setting aside, we probably would have had a record-breaking year," said Holly H. Rivera, the president of the American Cranberry Growers Association, whose family owns Haines & Haines Inc. in Chatsworth, the largest cranberry farm in the state. 
"It's kind of heartbreaking for a farmer to say 'We could have had a record-breaking year.' " 
New Jersey is the third-largest producer of cranberries in the nation after Wisconsin and Massachussetts, harvesting 3,700 of the 36,600 acres nationwide. Last year, the state's farmers produced 489,000 barrels, according to the New Jersey Agricultural Statistics Service. 
For now, farmers are hopeful that the new white cranberry juice will improve their fate. A pilot growing project in New Jersey two years ago gave Ocean Spray enough white berries to create three new cranberry juices, one a peach blend, one a strawberry blend and one a basic white cranberry. The juice tested well with consumers in California, said Marguerite Copel, Ocean Spray's vice president for corporate communications. 
But the project also revealed the danger of changing the age-old farming cycles. When farmers flooded the bogs for harvest in September, young vines died off. Farmers suspect it was the warmer water. This year, growers will flood only mature bogs early in the season, Mr. Lipman said. 
The new system, he said, is "a crap shoot." 
But farmers are willing to take the gamble. 
"We're saying, Hey, Ocean Spray is giving us really good innovation," Mrs. Rivera said. "We're willing to take that leap of faith."

GRAPHIC: Photos: With the cranberry industry in a deep slump, Ocean Spray's experimental white juice has growers harvesting early. Joseph W. Darlington, at right, will devote a quarter of his crop to the unripened white berries. (Photographs by David Hunsinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY; 
RISING HOME PRICES

BYLINE:  By Karen DeMasters 

 BODY:
 Prices for existing homes in Bergen and Passaic Counties increased by 17 percent in the second quarter of the year over the same period last year, the third largest increase in the nation, according to a survey released last week by the National Association of Realtors. 
The biggest increases were in Sacramento, Calif., and Washington, D.C. The median existing home price in the Bergen-Passaic area was $276,800, sixth highest nationally. Of the New Jersey areas studied, the Middlesex-Somerset-Hunterdon area had the second largest increase with a 12.3 percent jump and a median price of $238,900. Karen DeMasters

HEADLINE: The World; 
Workers of the World, Invest!

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI 

 BODY:
COMMUNISM hardly seems to belong anywhere anymore. 
 In its totalitarian Stalinist-Maoist form, the ideology has been dead for over a decade, and holdout nations that still call themselves Communist have almost all turned to capitalistic reforms to salvage sagging economies. Cuba's economy now relies less on sugar cane than shopping malls catering to wealthy tourists. Vietnam opened a stock market in Ho Chi Minh City last year. North Korea plans to offer American-taught business courses to a handful of students at Kim Il Sung University this fall -- though its leader, Kim Jong Il, still does a good job of playing the iconic yet enigmatic leader that the world once expected a Communist Party to produce. 
 In a final blow, the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, has said that capitalists should be welcomed into the world's largest Communist Party, of which he is chairman. An influential Marxist journal that dared to criticize the move was closed last week. 
So was all that sloganeering, sweat and slaughter over the last century for naught? 
Not necessarily. Absorbing free-market business practices does not mean communism is dead, according to Mr. Jiang. "In the past, our understanding of this issue was quite superficial and simplistic," he cautioned in a two-hour speech to honor his party's 80th birthday in Beijing's Great Hall of the People on Tiananmen Square. Human society "will inevitably move towards communism," he said. But, he added, "it is neither possible nor necessary to envisage or describe in great detail" how or when human society will get there. 
Mr. Jiang came up with this novel reading of communism from a surprising source: a 19th-century German sociologist, historian, economist and writer named Karl Marx. 
To explain the growth of capitalism in socialist economies, Communist theorists around the world are harking back to Marx's early writings, which suggest the Communist revolutions of this century may have come too soon. The "maturing" of capitalism is supposed to create an educated working class whose solidarity eventually overwhelms private ownership. 
To quote the sometimes bombastically verbose Marx directly (from the Deutsche-Brusseler-Zeitung, Nov. 11, 1847): "If the material conditions that necessarily result in the disappearance of the capitalist mode of production and with it the overthrow of the capitalist ruling class have not yet appeared in the historical process, but should happen despite this before history requires it, then the victory of the proletariat in overturning the rule of the capitalist class can only be temporary." 
In other words, communism (the lowercase, economic kind) can't be created by political movements (like uppercase Communist Parties) or social revolutions: it will arrive -- inevitably -- after capitalism burns itself out. 
Of course, Mr. Jiang didn't say exactly that. What he said was that the "advanced forces of production" in the "the primary stage of socialism" that China finds itself in does not just include workers. Calling any of them "capitalists," of course, is still politically incorrect; Mr. Jiang referred to them as "private entrepreneurs." 
The word "privatization" remains banned from his party's lexicon, though the Marxist concept of communal ownership has been conveniently expanded to include enterprises in which the state now owns a minority share. "Other forms of ownership" are also developing, Mr. Jiang noted in his speech. Reversing decades of party dogma, he said "a person's political integrity" should no longer be judged "simply by whether he owns property and how much property he or she owns." 
For China's Communist Party in particular, backpedaling is nothing new. Deng Xiaoping started by welcoming "intellectuals" back into the party in the late 1970's, reversing the anti-intellectualism of the Mao's Cultural Revolution. Party theorists have also been mining early Mao, before he tried to bypass the capitalist phase and move right into a communist economy with the disastrous Great Leap Forward of the late 1950's, the aggressive collectivization that ended up costing millions of Chinese peasants their lives.
FOR instance, in a 1940 speech, Mao envisioned coexistence with different social systems, including capitalism, during a long slow transition to socialism and later communism. The speech, "On New Democracy," was included in Mao's official "Selected Works," but it was ignored until now. 
Underlying the jargon is an attempt, common to all aging revolutionary Marxist parties that want to stay in power, to chart a future using Marxian theory that won't repudiate the Marxist ideology that put them in power in the first place.
"There are resources within the Marxist tradition, and more significantly in the writings of Mao Zedong, to let China's party leaders make the adjustments to capitalism they are clearly making while legitimately claiming to be following Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought," says Tim Cheek, a scholar of Chinese Marxism at Colorado College. "Like the Bible, it depends on which bits you quote." 
There's a strange contradiction lurking in all this revisionism: the United States is arguably farther along the road to Marx's communist Utopia. After all, the major means of production are collectively owned, thanks to the stock market and mutual funds. The country certainly boasts of an informed proletariat. And, as Mr. Cheek noted, "With our social security system and Medicare, we are far more socialized in practice than China, which has neither."
In practical terms, China's ideological adjustments, which are likely to be adopted into the Communist Party's charter at its 16th congress next year, are a perhaps inevitable attempt to co-opt the country's growing band of capitalists before they become a political force, possibly by joining one of China's other token political parties, which wield no power but at least present a legal framework in which to organize. 
Where this is heading is anybody's guess. Some China watchers say the party may eventually evolve into something akin to Europe's Social Democrats, albeit without willfully relinquishing the one-party system. And then they may follow in America's footsteps, which, if Marx was right after all, is heading toward communism. 
"The real message here is that communism is objectively where mankind is headed, but don't hold your breath and don't make the mistake of believing that we know how to map out a plan for getting there -- past experience has shown the folly that can lead to," said Ken Lieberthal, a China scholar and former senior director for Asian affairs on the National Security Council.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Capitalism is reaching deep into China, even here, in the Forbidden City. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
The Case For Buying Japanese Stocks

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
JAPAN seems adrift, a land without a plan.
 A year ago, its central bank puzzled many people when it raised short-term interest rates for the first time in a decade. This March it reversed course, and last week it said it would further loosen credit in an economy in which short-term borrowing is basically free. 
 None of this has helped. The country remains mired. 
Junichiro Koizumi, the new prime minister, is talking about shaking things up. But the Topix stock index is down about 13 percent this year. 
Todd Jacobson, co-manager of two Japan funds at Credit Suisse Asset Management, took some time last week to make a case for Japanese stocks. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Is there any reason to suppose that this effort by the central bank to flood the economy with money will have much effect?

A. The Bank of Japan was under tremendous political pressure to do something, and they buckled. Providing more liquidity into an economy that is experiencing deflation is clearly correct, but I don't think it will help much. Japan is in a recession. There is no question the economy is contracting.
What is important is that the Bank of Japan is showing they stand ready to provide sufficient liquidity to clean up the banks. Masaru Hayami, who heads the Bank of Japan, is basically telling the government that when and if it makes some structural changes which are deflationary, we will provide liquidity.

Q. What is the most critical change the government can make?

A. The focus is on cleaning up the banks. Corporations get about 90 percent of their funding from Japanese banks, compared to about 30 percent in the United States.
The capital bases of the banks have been depleted. They need more in the form of another round of public money coming into the system. 

Q. A number of Mr. Koizumi's predecessors have tried to mend the banks. What other changes is he proposing?

A. Koizumi wants to restructure government organizations that provide money for the economy. Two examples are a housing loan corporation and a highway development corporation. As a way of tackling Japan's budget deficit, which is huge, he wants to shut down some of these organizations, which take business away from the private sector.
But it will be very difficult for him to push through these reforms.

Q. How long will it take before these changes start to pay off?

A. It will take a number of years.
Koizumi has been very smart about taking his agenda to the public, building up support.
But he needs to act very quickly, because if he does implement everything he says he wants to do, it will cause a lot of economic pain. It is doubtful the Japanese really appreciate how much.

Q. What is the case for investing in Japanese stocks?

A. Japanese stocks are now at their cheapest levels since the mid-1980's. Compared to other markets in the world, it has become much more compelling. There is a lot of potential for upside surprises. But it is an uphill battle because the economy is so weak.
Japan is still a quite wealthy country, and the Japanese savings rate is very high. The exciting potential is if individuals put some of their money in financial markets. Equity ownership by individuals in Japan is under 10 percent. If they raised it to about 17 percent, which is what it is in Germany, there would be a massive move in Japanese stocks. 

Q. Your funds own 25 to 30 Japanese stocks. Which companies do you like?

A. Our style is to invest in the best companies in the country, companies that are well positioned globally and offer good value.
Historically, we have had a position in technology. In that area we like NTT DoCoMo, which is down about 13 percent so far this year and is very reasonably valued. We also like Sega, the game company, even though the stock is up 70 percent. And we like Nintendo.
We have some exposure to the banks. They were oversold and not owned by foreigners at all. We bought the highest-quality banks in the sector: Sumitomo Mitsui, UJF and Mitsubishi Tokyo. Mitsui Fudosan is a real estate company we own.

Q. Let's say the American economy is bottoming in the third quarter, and then starts to recover. Will that help Japan?

A. Stabilization in the U.S. would be great, but the technology sector there is still declining. You need the personal computer and cell phone market to recover. It is the key driver.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Fighting For the Check, Or Not

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I WAS all set to a write a grand feminist treatise on why young professional women don't care if men pay the check on dates. My thesis was this: Because women now make their own money -- and sometimes a lot of it -- being wooed financially is not as important anymore.
 And then I went out with a fledgling photographer who was counting his pennies. We ate at a fancy sushi restaurant (his choice) and had a fine time. Then the bill came. He picked it up. He hemmed. He hawed. 
 "What should we do?" he asked. "I'd like to get it, but I'm kind of broke."
"Me too," I said.
"But you're a journalist. You must have money."
"That," I said, "is an oxymoron."
We decided to split the check, which, I must acknowledge, was a big turn-off. I wanted to be taken out. I wanted him to pay. But he clearly didn't have his finances in order, and after a certain age (he was in his late 30's) that is about as appealing as milk-crate furniture. 
Still, my reaction disturbed me. Why did I care that he didn't cover my meal? Was I becoming shallow in my advancing age -- my early 30's? Had my feminist principles been tossed out the window with my Simone de Beauvoir anthologies? In college, for example, I never allowed a man to pay for me. Any woman would be doomed if she did; before long she would be ironing his shirts. So why did I care now?
"Men are supposed to pay for women," said Suzanne Lynn, 29, a friend of mine who grew up in South Carolina and is now a sales assistant at CTN Media Group in Manhattan. She is offended if a date doesn't see her to her front door. 
"But what if he makes less money than she does?" I asked. "Why can't we each pay our way?"
She looked at me as if I had two heads. "Because if a man is interested in you, he pays," she said. "Once the relationship is off the ground, the woman can kick in when she needs to. But if a guy doesn't pay for me at first, I assume he only wants friendship."
She was dead serious, and most women with whom I talked -- independent, strong, beautiful, accomplished types -- felt the same way, even in these tougher economic times, when men struggle just as much as women do.
My younger brother Ray, a stand-up comedian in Manhattan, says he always pays the bill on dates, "even if the girl asks me out."
"There's a feeling that women will think you're cheap if you don't," he added. "Plus, it's good manners. But women send mixed messages. I know some women who refuse to go out on a second date if the guy doesn't treat them the first time. They say they're their own person and can do whatever a guy can do, so why does it all boil down to the check?"
Theoretically, if equality is our goal, we should be thrilled to pay our way. For some reason, we are not. There is always the 75 cents-to-the-dollar argument -- that woman still don't earn as much as men, so men should pay -- but I think that more than economics is at work here. 
For one thing, traditional courtship has pretty much gone the way of dowries and arranged marriages. Most men no longer undergo formal familial grilling about their credit ratings. So what other options do modern suitors have? Paying for a date is a fairly safe way of indicating, and gauging, intentions, or at least future viability.
"There are so few rituals left -- why negate one of the last ones out there?" asked Gisela Williams, 30, a travel writer in New York. "It's nice for a guy to pull out your chair, or hold open the door or pour your wine. Paying for a date is right up there."
It also signifies desire and effort. When a man pays the check, he is saying, in effect, that she is worth the price of that tuna tartare, that he is willing to sacrifice for her.
Then there is the so-called macho factor. Many men I know like to pick up the bill; it makes them feel powerful and masculine. 
"I always pay for the woman," said Patricio Forno, 32, a civil engineer from Santiago, Chile. "No matter who earns more money, I pay. It's part of my culture, but it also makes me feel good." 
OF course, some sensitive men of the new millennium would rather split the bill or let the woman pay. And some women truly don't want men to pay, perhaps because they want to prove their own financial viability.
Andrea Schnoor, 32, isn't one of them. "I used to only pay my way, but now I let my date pay, especially at first," said Ms. Schnoor, a publicist in Manhattan. "When you get older you have a greater sense of self, and you realize that even if they do expect something in return you don't have to give it." 
One could argue that letting men pay empowers women. Sure, we can pay for ourselves; we're just smart enough not to.
If a man grabs a check, should a woman reciprocate by doing the same at a future time? Absolutely, assuming that she likes him. Should a woman pay if she has invited the man out? Definitely. And creativity -- finding other, nonmonetary ways to express affection and interest -- goes a long way on both sides.
Ultimately, of course, a successful relationship is about a million different things beyond the size of one's wallet. Still, a little well-placed wooing never hurts.

LENGTH: 1528 words

HEADLINE: Ms. Perfect Opts Out 

BYLINE:  By NELSON MUI 

 BODY:
TISH JOHNSON traces her secession from the rigors of day-to-day fashion maintenance to an evening at an Upper East Side restaurant, where an acquaintance asked how she was doing. 
 In the millisecond before Ms. Johnson replied, the woman eyed her up and down, studying both outfit and body with cool precision. "Oh, you're soooo thin," the woman trilled, scarcely concealing the enmity inside the compliment. 
 The encounter triggered a little epiphany for Ms. Johnson, 28, who has had a career as a junior fashion editor at W magazine and as a publicist. After years of swirling around the Manhattan merry-go-round of benefits, store parties and club nights that are the social life of choice for women in this set, Ms. Johnson decided she wanted off the ride. The pressure and expense of looking perfectly pulled together at work and on the town had sapped the fun from it. 
"I've opted out," said Ms. Johnson, who has left her job at a fashion publicity company to freelance as a marketing consultant. "I sent my designer clothes to the consignment shop." 
Instead of dressing to kill in just the right low-cut Chloe top and $400 sling-back heels, she reports part time to a Nike office on West 18th Street in khakis and running shoes. For evenings, she prefers a simple camisole, linen pants and low kitten heels.
For a number of New Yorkers like Ms. Johnson -- career women with the income and youth to pull off fashion's seasonal looks -- the increased stakes and the attention to appearances are proving overwhelming. These women are dedicated readers of the style bibles, up to speed on trends endorsed by the wardrobe-centric "Sex and the City." They might cheekily have accepted the label "fashion victim." But lately they have been feeling battle fatigue. They are waging a quiet revolt against luxury labels and regimes of hair coloring, eyebrow plucking, laser peels and waxing from underarms to legs. 
"People are so polished here, and I find it totally soulless, that slick New York career woman," said Amely Greeven, 27, a contributing writer for Harper's Bazaar. "Where has feminism got us? That world of the very high-profile woman, who's totally polished, it's fake and phony. It's all a myth we created working in fashion." 
Ms. Greeven is rare in publicly bemoaning the pressure placed on women by her industry. She recalled that when she worked at Vogue, "I used to go to work in what I thought was a cute outfit in the morning, but by the afternoon, I would have doubts and start to feel very nasty and grungy." Now she shuttles between a Midtown office and her home in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in jeans and T-shirts. 
Stacy Kelner, a corporate lawyer in her 30's, wants to reclaim her Saturdays for herself, not feel pressured to squeeze in a hair appointment. "You look around and you keep thinking there's always more you can do, but you have to draw a line," she said. "You start putting in streaks or color your hair. Then you keep having to do it regularly."
"It becomes a job," she added. "I've definitely opted out, and I'm not looking forward to opting back in." 
It is too early to know whether such dissenters are leading a trend destined to ripple through the ranks of working women, bringing gloom to $200-a-session hair colorists and the luxury merchants of Madison Avenue. Department store sales have been depressed all year, but that seems mainly a function of the slack economy and the failure of spring trends, like a 1980's revival, to excite customers. 
But there are signs that a reaction against the polished, high-maintenance look of the last few years could pick up converts. Many of the clothes in stores for fall represent a turn away from glittering, late-90's opulence and the often crass display of wealth worn on the back. Gone are the conspicuous logos and expensive reptile skins like crocodile and python. There are less pretentious looks, like military and equestrian chic. And denim, that most dressed down of fabrics, is expected to be very big this season, from Miu Miu shirtdresses to pantsuits that can go to the office. 
"Our theme for fall is contrast," said Jacqui Lividini, the senior vice president for fashion merchandising at Saks Fifth Avenue. "There's the option for the customer who wants to do the high-maintenance look, and there are other types of styles you can choose that are less extreme and still look pulled together. You don't have to put on a pantsuit with stiletto heels. You can opt out of high maintenance." She suggested a "novelty, dressy flip-flop" as an alternative to heels that still looks dressed up. 
And how is this for a shift in the wind? To some devoted viewers, even Carrie Bradshaw, Sarah Jessica Parker's character on "Sex and the City," looked this season like a parody of fashion direction. "They've gone over the top and unrealistic," said Kate Loudoun-Shand, who owns a textile design company that supplies Marc Jacobs and others. "It started out as the stylized glamour-girl look, but nowadays, maybe because of all the product placement, she's become this label junkie who probably wears things straight off the runway."
Since Eve bit into the apple and decided to clothe herself, women have grappled with the dressing problem. But the last decade has increasingly focused on high-fashion labels and expensive beauty treatments among women and girls, if not always men and boys, who have been allowed to slack off into everyday casual. 
A culture of assessing the best and worst dressed spread outside the usual ZIP codes and exclusive parties. Magazines like In Style and television shows like "Full Frontal Fashion" encouraged the masses to play red-carpet critic and try to imitate celebrities. Every ad, music video and television show is styled to the nines these days. 
"I think things have escalated," said Julie Krumholz, a vice president for marketing at Newsweek. "How many profiles have we all read about people who manage their schedules around their beauty and salon visits? You sort of roll your eyes, but then you see in certain circles it's true. You look at somebody like Katie Couric on the "Today" show, and she's had a transformation, she's wearing tighter clothes, heels. But you know Katie's highlights and other accouterments require a high level of maintenance." 
Valerie Steele, the fashion historian and museum curator at the Fashion Institute of Technology, pointed out that the beauty and fashion standards of celebrities, once remote, have filtered down, with many women feeling the pressure to live up to them. 
"The very polished, stylish, soignee look was once for a minority of celebrities and socialites," she said. "But now that's spread to a lot more women, who feel they have to look that way. America's traditionally been an antifashion country, but everyone's become so much more visually literate that women are a lot more visually aware. Just the other day at a party, everyone was talking about how everyone was doing Botox. It's like you start to feel you're a Neanderthal if you don't do it."
Some single women say the pressure derives from the widespread impression that there are fewer available men than women in the big city. "There are all these incredibly toned, accomplished, well-educated women competing for a limited pool of men," said Kathy Reilly, a marketing consultant in her mid-30's. "My friends are Harvard and Wharton M.B.A.'s, and we're all striving to better and better ourselves, while these men have their pick." 
Lately, Ms. Reilly is having less of the game. She has been wearing pressed designer jeans to her job as vice president for marketing for the Equinox Fitness Centers. On dates, she favors jeans, flats and hair pulled back rather than blown out. 
"For me it's all about finding the happy medium, about doing the full day of beauty when it's warranted and going out in a ponytail and jeans and being confident," she said. "I'm happier with it. Hopefully, with the economy having a correction, the over-the-top manias will subside somewhat."
She said that her dressed-down look goes over well with men. "Often it's only the women who notice all the effort anyway," she said. "With some guys, I think the appeal diminishes when they think of having to live with the high maintenance of it all."
To some, the fatigue with showy looks is reminiscent of the early 90's, when fashion reacted to 80's excess by donning minimalist sackcloth in shades of gray and beige from the Gap. Ms. Greeven, the fashion writer, is even predicting a return to grunge. "But even when you're doing a grungy thing, you have this moment when you still feel you have to do it right," she added somewhat ruefully.
Ms. Steele offered this caveat: Even if the fashion pendulum swings away from soignee looks, appearances will still matter. The status game will continue, as it did in the early 90's with minimal fashions made with extremely luxe fabrics that discreetly announced to those in the know the high price tag." 
She added: "All those homeless people probably felt just as bad being stepped on by somebody in a gray Armani suit, as opposed to a hot pink Lacroix dress. I don't think the priorities of showing off will ever change."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Some Funds Try to Read Your Mind

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH HARRIS 

 BODY:
THE developing field of behavioral economics, which blends economics and psychology, has attracted much attention recently, as many people hope that it will lead to insights that can help investors avoid falling prey to fads like the Internet bubble that popped last year.
 But so far, attempts have failed to fully harness for investment the work of academics like Richard H. Thaler, a professor of economics and behavioral science at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business and the field's leading figure. 
 The handful of mutual funds using the theory have a decidedly mixed record.
But Mr. Thaler says research by him and others holds practical promise, even if Wall Street peregrinations cannot be fully fathomed just yet. 
"There's been more progress on the individual cognitive psychology over the last 20 years than on mass psychology," Mr. Thaler said. "If we had a model that would have been able to tell us when the Internet bubble would break, believe me, we would have used it. So it's easy to say in hindsight that there was some sort of euphoria for two or three years and that euphoria has died. But nobody has the tools, at least as far as I know, that allow you to forecast these changes in these moods."
Still, he is trying to capitalize on developments when possible. Fuller & Thaler Asset Management in San Mateo, Calif., the firm of which he is a principal, has been investing privately for nine years, trying to put the academic theories to work using real money. And it has been quite successful. It says it has produced a 21 percent annualized return for the growth style of investing, about double the gain of its benchmark, the Russell 2500 Growth index. Over the same period, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has risen an average of 14 percent a year.
But while the strategy may be working for the firm's separate accounts, one of the two public funds that Mr. Thaler helps to advise has not distinguished itself during its shorter life span. The two are the Undiscovered Managers Behavioral Growth fund, managed by Frederick W. Stanske, 43, and the Undiscovered Managers Behavioral Value fund, managed by Brendan S. MacMillan, 33. Both funds require $250,000 investment minimums. 
The growth fund, with $120 million in assets, returned an annualized 2 percent from July 1998 through last Thursday, compared with 7.5 percent for the average mid-cap growth fund, according to Morningstar Inc., and 3 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500. In 1999, the fund led its category with a 65 percent return, but a year later, it fell behind, dropping 27 percent. As with most growth funds, the returns "stink now," Mr. Stanske said.
"Obviously," he added, "we had too much tech exposure, even at the beginning of the year."
The value portfolio, by contrast, which Morningstar classifies as a small-blend fund, has done well during the market downturn, along with other value investments. The $35 million mutual fund has gained an average of 25.2 percent a year from its inception in December 1998 through Thursday, according to Morningstar. This year, it is ahead by 15.5 percent through Thursday, beating its peer group, which rose 5.5 percent on average.
Both funds operate on the theory that people bring biases to their investment analysis and that these are reflected in prices. And because most people are unaware of their biases, they usually do not adjust their investing. Mr. Stanske and Mr. MacMillan try to find such patterns in the market, and to exploit them. 
Terrance Odean, an assistant professor at the University of California at Berkeley, who also specializes in behavioral finance, said, "As long as a large-enough majority of people are making these little mistakes, there's probably an opportunity to make money by being on the other side." 
But in practice, the funds share some stock-picking similarities with other growth and value portfolios, even if they are rooted in Mr. Thaler's work. For example, Mr. Stanske seeks "underreaction" when considering stocks for the growth fund. That occurs when analysts and investors believe too firmly in their estimates of what companies will earn in a given quarter and overlook signs to the contrary.
Mr. Stanske cites his finding that analysts dismissed strong earnings from Coach Inc., a maker of handbags and briefcases, when concern rose about leather prices. But he observed that investors appeared not to notice that Coach was relying less on leather than it had in the past. Mr. Stanske said he bought the stock at the beginning of the year "in the 20's." It closed at $33.65 on Friday.
As for the value strategy, Mr. MacMillan said he tried to identify "overreaction" to companies that had experienced a long period of underperformance by looking for signs that they were beginning to improve.
He pointed to Sola International Inc., a maker of eyeglass lenses, whose shares were unduly depressed, he said, by the emergence of laser surgery. Investors had largely ignored a new management's efforts to correct longstanding corporate problems. Mr. MacMillan said he bought shares in the $5-to-$6 range last summer; the stock closed at $14.22 on Friday.
FULLER & THALER is not alone in developing investments based on behavioral concepts. ABN AMRO Asset Management runs two such funds, with assets totaling 160 million euros, or $146.9 million, focused on European markets; it also has one for Japan. The European funds are ABN AMRO Ratio Invest, which began in April 1999, and the ABN AMRO Behavioural Finance, which opened to new investors in May 2000.
The Ratio fund gained 3.1 percent from inception through July, lagging behind its European benchmark, which returned 8.4 percent, according to Arjen B. Pasma, the ABN AMRO Ratio portfolio manager.
The funds follow neither growth nor value investing styles, Mr. Pasma said. Rather, he uses a model that identifies stocks out of favor or undervalued because of emotional or psychological factors.
"If you want to exploit irrationalities, you should use something that is rational or emotionless like a model," he said.
But nobody in the field pretends to have found the key to easy riches. "The problem with investing is you can't be just a psychologist," said Robert J. Shiller of Yale University and a proponent of behavioral economics. He said that all successful investors become involved in the industry to which they commit money and become aware of how other investors might overlook some developments and overemphasize others. "People like Dick Thaler are so rare in the investment world that he probably has a niche, an advantage that he can exploit," he said.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
These Days, Layoffs Compete With Loyalty

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE Harvard Business Review, in its current issue, displays a glaring contradiction. One author argues passionately that American companies require loyal employees to operate efficiently, and that means shunning layoffs. Turn the page, and the next article, titled "The Right Way to be Fired," argues that in today's world, only chumps fall into the loyalty trap.
 No attempt is made -- by the authors or the magazine's editors -- to resolve this contradiction, or even to recognize it. "I don't see the conflict," Suzy Wetlaufer, the editor in chief, said in an interview. "Human beings have complex minds and they can grasp the idea that organizations need to build trust, but the possibility of layoffs is always there." 
 Loyalty and layoffs. These are indeed two realities in uneasy coexistence today. By all the traditions of the American workplace, the loyalty of a company to its employees, and vice versa, is still valued as a source of mutual trust, greater effort and rising profits. But in the 21st century downturn, loyalty's enemy -- the layoff -- is also winning acceptance as standard business practice, even among the reluctant victims. Reflecting this new respectability, the prestigious Harvard Business Review gives layoffs and loyalty equal status in its summer issue, but without debating or mentioning the consequences. Many hope there will not be any.
"We have decided to rely on layoffs, to fold them into the corporate culture, and we are trying to minimize the impact on profits and performance," said Kathryn Shaw, an economist at Carnegie Mellon University.
The issue is simple. What is the best way to get people to work as hard as they can, and in doing so, raise output, revenue and profits? Loyalty generates the necessary trust and commitment, says Frederick F. Reichheld, a management consultant and the author of the other Harvard Business Review article, "Lead for Loyalty," as well as two books on the subject. His research, he said in an interview, shows that if a counter clerk, for example, increases his attention to customers by 5 percent, "you will kick up profits by a shocking amount." That extra effort requires commitment to an employer. The commitment comes when employees feel comfortable. And comfort requires, among other things, no layoffs or very few.
But layoffs are no longer minimized; they are often the first response to a corporate setback. The employee who ignores this fact of life is in for a shock, in the view of Laurence J. Stybel and Maryanne Peabody, authors of the Business Review article in support of layoffs and partners at Stybel Peabody Lincolnshire, a consulting firm. Their advice: Do not allow yourself to develop the view that you are indispensable to your company or that company is family. Prepare for the next job and watch for "exit" signals. "Being terminated should not come as a surprise," Mr. Stybel and Ms. Peabody write.
They are essentially in the "free agent" camp, which argues that a company's productivity and profits will rise if its employees are motivated not by loyalty but by their own needs. They will work hard not out of commitment to their employer but to develop their skills and thus their value in the job market, or because the work itself interests them, or to impress their co-workers and others in their field. This "network" will then help them land the next job. 
"If you put out less effort per hour, then productivity is undermined," said Daniel Yankelovich, chairman of DYG, a polling firm. "But suppose you expect something better to come along. You give a lot until it comes along."
There is even the view that fear of layoffs -- job insecurity -- works as well as loyalty in motivating workers. That is the conclusion that Paul Osterman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, draws from his research in the workplace. "Companies are finding that they can achieve their goals by maintaining a certain level of fear in the work force and that leads people to work hard," Mr. Osterman said.
So what is the answer? A back-of-the-envelope calculation, based on interviews with a dozen experts, suggests that loyalty -- undiminished by layoffs -- is the more profitable approach. That is particularly the case at companies with long-term goals that require commitment and continuity. Oil exploration is an example. So is pharmaceutical research. "Exxon talks of 20-year projects and they need people to hang around for 20 years," said Peter Capelli, a management professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. "You are hurt if they leave and you lose their experience."
But these are all preliminary findings. Layoffs have only recently matched loyalty in social status. Corporate America is freer than at any time since World War II to fire people at will, and the consequences are as yet unexplored. This column is an appeal to fire up the exploration. For starters, the Harvard Business Review might try to fill in the blank in the summer issue.

HEADLINE: Let the Surplus Go 

BYLINE:  By Robert M. Dunn Jr.; Robert M. Dunn Jr. is a professor of economics at George Washington University.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
An absurd debate is going on in Washington over who is to blame for the horrors of a declining federal budget surplus. The truth is that the fall in the surplus should be welcomed, given the current state of the economy, and politicians should be trying to take credit for it.
 The evidence is now overwhelming that the American economy started to slow in the early summer of 2000 and that we are now in, or close to, a recession. The percentage of the nation's manufacturing, mining and construction potential that is actually in use started dropping sharply in mid-2000 and, at 77 percent, is now at its lowest level since 1983. Corporate profits are plummeting. The unemployment rate has increased only to 4.5 percent from a low during the recent boom of 3.9 percent, but several companies have announced new layoffs that will worsen it. Preliminary numbers showed very slow growth in our country's output of products and services in the spring, and The Wall Street Journal reported Aug. 14 that the final figure is likely to show that output actually fell. If so, and if the July-to-September numbers show another drop, we will officially be in recession. 
 A federal budget surplus should decline in an economic downturn like this one, and attempts to "protect the surplus" by cutting expenditures, as some Republicans wish, or by increasing taxes, as Democratic leaders in Congress have suggested, are madness.
The federal budget automatically moves toward smaller surpluses or to a deficit in a recession because as tax receipts are declining, transfer payments, like unemployment benefits and food stamps, increase. This pattern is actually a good thing. The transfer payments and even that part of the lost revenue that is attributable to taxpayers falling into lower brackets are so-called "automatic stabilizers." And the existence of those stabilizers is the dominant reason the American economy has been less volatile since World War II than it was in the 19th and early 20th centuries.
Our system of progressive taxes and financial help for the poor, as introduced in Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal during the 1930's, assures that in a recession, disposable personal income declines by much less than gross domestic product does. That not only supports the standard of living of the unemployed, but also sustains demand for consumer goods and services. This, in turn, helps maintain employment and sales in the industries that produce consumer items. Employees in those industries keep drawing incomes that they can spend, further supporting the economy.
Companies' investments in plants and equipment typically fall sharply in a recession, but consumers' spending declines only slightly. People may delay buying new cars and major appliances, but producers of most things that people buy usually get through recessions with only modest harm. The system of automatic stabilizers is critical, and any attempt to tamper with it in hope of restoring the surpluses would be worse than futile.
Personal consumption is now the only source of strength in the American economy, and it may be shaken by stock market losses that make families feel poorer. This gives particular importance to maintaining the public's disposable income at a fairly high level. While no one is proposing direct cuts to the automatic stabilizers, some Republicans have proposed other cuts -- in military spending and help for farmers, for example -- that would offset the stabilizers' calming effect.
The timing of the recent tax cut, with its $300 rebate for anyone who paid that much in income taxes last year, now looks smart. Both the current rebate and the promise of additional tax cuts in the future will encourage Americans to spend more now. The timing may have been accidental. The Bush campaign did not know when he first proposed the cut that a recession was on the way, and Congress may have been similarly unaware when it decided to include the rebate. But many clever political moves are more luck than planning.
Some Democratic senators risk becoming reincarnations of Herbert Hoover (who raised taxes in 1932 to balance the budget) by arguing that we must increase taxes to protect Social Security from problems that will emerge after 2020. Are they really suggesting that we prolong and deepen a recession in 2001-2002 to deal with problems of retirees in 2020-2030? Even by Washington standards that is nutty. The way to protect Social Security is to return quickly to a booming economy that will produce larger tax receipts in a year or two. Suggestions by Democrats that the recent tax cut should be reversed after the 2002 elections could frighten Americans into spending less now, which is certainly not the route to recovery.
Let the automatic stabilizers, aided by a well-timed tax cut, do their job. This is not the time to worry about a declining surplus or even a modest deficit. Get the economy rolling again, and big surpluses will return. To paraphrase Richard Nixon, we should all be Keynesians now. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/David G. Herro And Michael J. Welsh; 
Oakmark International Small Cap Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
TO value companies for their $110 million Oakmark International Small Cap fund, David G. Herro and Michael J. Welsh, the co-managers, use complementary approaches.
 "I view the valuation process almost as an academic exercise," said Mr. Herro, who was trained as a theoretical economist. Mr. Welsh is a certified public accountant with experience in valuing privately held businesses or small pieces of big, publicly traded ones. The fund's companies are bigger, Mr. Welsh said, "but the process is the same." 
 Together, they look for high-quality businesses outside the United States that sell for bargain prices. A low stock price "is insufficient for us," Mr. Welsh said from their offices in downtown Chicago. "Companies have to possess a management team that's actively involved in building shareholder value."
The fund returned 20.6 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 1.6 percent for its peers in the foreign stock category, according to Morningstar Inc. It returned 3.3 percent for the 12 months ended Thursday, putting it in the first percentile among the 733 foreign stock funds in the category; on average, those funds lost 25.5 percent.
Mr. Herro, 40, and Mr. Welsh, 38, work for Harris Associates, the fund's adviser. They also run the $900 million Oakmark International fund.
For the small-cap fund, the managers use a bottom-up investment approach to look for overseas candidates with market capitalizations of $100 million to $1 billion. The fund avoids countries like Russia and China because it cannot effectively apply its criteria to them.
"Not only is corporate governance nonexistent in Russia," Mr. Herro said, "but audited accounting standards are not really prevalent." In China, he added, corporate boards typically represent the government, not shareholders.
To find value, the managers screen companies based on ratios of total capitalization -- market capitalization plus long-term debt -- to earnings before interest and taxes, or EBIT. The ratio compares the price of the business to the cash flow it generates, Mr. Herro said.
Unlike many other money managers, they do not eliminate depreciation from their calculation of operating profit. "In most cases, depreciation represents an ongoing capital expenditure, which is needed for the company to keep growing," Mr. Herro said.
The valuation screens reduce the pool to 300 to 400 companies. To pick their 75 to 100 stocks, the managers work with four analysts who dig into how each company is run.
Mr. Herro and Mr. Welsh spend about 40 percent of their time on the road, meeting with companies' managers. "We visit with the sole purpose of assessing how and why they invest their free cash flow," Mr. Herro said. "That's more important to us than their sales growth or whether they'll make their earnings projections."
Companies that can earn more than 15 percent above their cost of capital should reinvest free cash flow in operations, he added, or otherwise use it to pay down debt, buy back stock or pay dividends.
That is why they have about 8 percent of the fund's assets in Japan versus 20-plus percent for their benchmark, the Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe Australasia Far East index.
"Japanese companies have accumulated huge amounts of cash on their balance sheets," Mr. Herro said, "but their return on equity is only in the high single digits."
The fund has 6 percent of its assets in South Korea. 
"They've opened up their economy and started to clean up their corporate governance problems," Mr. Welsh said, "but stocks are still priced as if they were in a crisis."
One South Korean favorite is Hite Brewery, whose stock they began buying in July 1997 at 20,000 won; the shares now trade at 43,500 won. Hite, based in Seoul, has nearly doubled its market share for beer in South Korea over the last six years, to about 60 percent, Mr. Welsh said, adding that declining Korean alcohol taxes would increase consumption. "Beer drinking is not as saturated an industry as it is in the West," and a new brewing plant has already increased profitability, he said.
Another favorite is Kone, a Finnish maker of elevators and escalators. "They generate good cash flow, which they're putting into R&D to develop new competitive products," Mr. Herro said. The business is attractive because it generates steady service revenue from equipment it has already installed, he added. 
The managers originally bought shares at the equivalent of 29 euros in April 1995; on Friday the shares closed at 87 euros.
In December, the managers bought shares of Meitec, a Japanese temporary employment agency for engineers. "They're in an industry that should explode as Japan restructures and reforms its labor practices and lets companies become more efficient over the next three to five years," Mr. Herro said. He added that Meitec's percentage return on capital was in the high teens and that management was using cash flow wisely to hire more engineers and buy back stock. The fund paid 3,500 yen for the shares; they are now at 3,550 yen.
