HEADLINE: Insurance Cost To Homeowner Climbs Sharply 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Across the country, the cost of insuring a home is climbing sharply and is expected to continue doing so for several years. Prices are rising at more than twice the 3 percent average of recent years, and by more than 10 percent in many states.
 Allstate, the second-largest home insurer, has been leading the way, with increases of 10 percent to 25 percent in several states. State Farm, the largest home insurer, has been more reluctant to raise prices, lifting premiums 6 percent to 10 percent in a handful of states. Safeco, the eighth largest, says it expects increases to average more than 25 percent for its 1.5 million customers this year. 
 Though other companies are more circumspect than Safeco about overall insurance rates, analysts say higher prices are almost certain to spread. "These are shock increases," said J. Robert Hunter, the director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America. 
Insurance companies, which set their own rates, state by state, and zone by zone within each state, are responding to profit pressures. The companies are earning less on their investments and on certain types of personal policies while reeling from a surge in weather-related claims in the last few years. In addition to raising rates, some companies are also forcing homeowners to pay more out of pocket after they file claims.
Rising home values compound the situation for some people, since higher rates come as the values of their policies increase. And the average increases often mask outright price surges for those living in areas singled out by insurers.
In Texas, for example, Tricia Beaugh wound up with sticker shock on the renewal of her policy. In May, Allstate raised the cost of the $94,000 policy on her three-bedroom brick veneer house in Humble, near Houston, to $670, up 56 percent, from $430 the previous year.
"It was like 'Oh, my God,' " said Mrs. Beaugh, who sells advertising in the Yellow Pages. "We had pretty much figured out to the penny what we could afford for the mortgage, maintenance, insurance and taxes. We ended up having to finance the insurance, pay by the month."
Insurers have long tried to keep prices low on homeowners' policies as a way to lure customers into their profitable auto insurance business. But the profits on auto policies have shrunk, leading companies to raise auto rates last year and now to insist that home insurance be profitable.
"Now that auto insurance profits are slipping, the auto business can no longer afford to, in effect, subsidize homeowners' coverage," said Robert Hartwig, chief economist for the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group in New York. "That's why, along with the rising cost of building materials and an increase in weather-related claims, these rates are going up today and are likely to keep going up for the next several years."
Insurers are also very dependent on the returns on their investments, which have dwindled. They invest their customers' premiums until they have to pay out claims. When those investments are doing well, said Jay Angoff, a former insurance commissioner in Missouri, companies are more apt to keep their prices low than when returns are weak.
Mr. Hartwig said he expected prices for home insurance to rise by an average of 6 percent this year, double the average annual increase for the last decade. That would mean an increase of about $30 on the policy of about $500. But that average obscures some sharp moves, like Mrs. Beaugh's. In Texas, Allstate says rate increases have averaged 25 percent, bringing the average cost of coverage to $950, up $190.
The industry says the last few years have brought far more than the usual run of hurricanes, tornadoes, hailstorms and flooding rains. This has led to a rise in claims as prices of building supplies have increased. Insurers also are seeing a jump in claims in Texas and other coastal states for toxic mold, which can contaminate houses after water damage.
But Texas is not the only state where Allstate is moving aggressively. It is raising its rates by an average of 10 percent in Illinois and Wisconsin, 15 percent in Oklahoma, and, soon, 15 percent in Missouri and 17 percent in Iowa. 
"We clearly see an increase in the overall costs of the business, and we're moving to address those profit issues," said Frederick Cripe, the senior executive for pricing at Allstate.
In New York, Nationwide, the state's third-largest home insurer, is raising rates 9.9 percent in September, while Safeco has raised rates 15.7 percent.
In Connecticut, Royal Sun Alliance has raised rates 8.3 percent this year; CGU, 9.5 percent; and a dozen other companies are up an average of 5 percent.
In New Jersey, State Farm, which says it intends to abandon auto insurance in the state because it cannot make a profit, has applied for a 6 percent increase on homeowners' policies. 
Several insurers -- including Nationwide, the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company and the Farmers Insurance Group -- refused to provide information on rate changes. But regulators in Missouri said that Farmers, operating through its Mid-Century Insurance Company unit, raised prices there by 16.2 percent in June.
Insurance companies are said to be trying to cut costs as well as raise rates. Agents say they have noticed a trend toward discouraging and rejecting homeowners' claims. "We're under tremendous pressure to produce profit," said an agent in a Western state, who did not want his name used for fear of angering his employer.
Insurance executives say they are not making it harder for customers to collect claims, but some companies acknowledge that they are cutting back on claims' handlers to save money. Fewer people may mean delays in settling claims, analysts say, giving insurers more time to hold and invest customer premiums.
Over the last few years, before the new wave of price increases, insurers quietly chipped away at the benefits in their home policies. Only a few years ago, if a house insured for its full value of, say, $100,000 was destroyed, the insurance company would replace it, even if the cost ran to more than $100,000. Now the payout is usually limited to, say, 25 percent more than the insured value.
Instead of applying deductibles of $250 or $500, once standard, many companies now impose a deductible of up to 5 percent of the value of houses in the hurricane-prone Atlantic and Gulf coasts. On a home insured for $100,000, the owner would pay the first $5,000 in damages.
In Florida and some other coastal states, insurers have persuaded regulators to let them drop hurricane coverage from their home insurance policies and sell it separately.
Though most insurers seem to be pushing to make their homeowners' policies more profitable, State Farm remains something of a holdout. The company, which covers one of every five homes, is raising rates most on the East Coast and in Southern states where hurricanes and tropical storms are a threat. Its rates have risen 9 percent in South Carolina this year, 7 percent in Louisiana, 6.5 percent in Florida and 6.4 percent in Mississippi.
But it has been keeping homeowners' rates steady in many states, and even cutting them in others in hopes of keeping customers. Undercut by smaller carriers offering auto insurance at lower prices, State Farm is gambling that it will rebound from its losses by gaining market share, insurance analysts say.
Phil Supple, a spokesman for State Farm, said the company was simply playing to its strengths and taking a longer view. As a mutual company without public shareholders, it does not feel Wall Street pressure for short-term profits.
Ira L. Zuckerman, an insurance industry analyst at Nutmeg Securities in Fairfield, Conn., said that underpricing had been widespread in homeowners' insurance and that Safeco's increases would lead to others. 
"If you are a competitor of Safeco, and Safeco is raising prices 25 percent," Mr. Zuckerman said, "maybe you can raise your prices 15 percent and still be competitive."

HEADLINE: In a Competitive Race, Family Ties Can Have Both Benefits and Drawbacks 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Between dance numbers at a talent show at a youth center in the Bronx two days ago, Helen Diane Foster was introduced to about 100 young people and their parents. In a short greeting, Ms. Foster, a candidate for a City Council seat, discussed the need for students to master their education and to take pride in themselves.
 But some of the evening's most telling words came just before Ms. Foster spoke. She was introduced by City Councilman Wendell Foster, the incumbent who has spent 24 years at City Hall, and who is her father. He applauded his daughter's quest to become "the first black woman elected to the City Council in the history of Bronx County," and said that if a child following in the political footsteps of the parent is "good enough for the Bushes and the Kennedys, it is good enough for the Fosters." 
 Mr. Foster's words underscored how his career has been both a plus and a minus for his daughter's campaign, giving it its very potency while creating some difficulties. Ms. Foster, 35, the assistant vice president of legal affairs at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx, enjoys significant name recognition by being the daughter of a politician with longstanding tenure. On the other hand, it has also made her the object of criticism by some politicians who suggest that she is seeking to capitalize on her family name.
 Ms. Foster is running in one of the most competitive races in a season of highly charged contests. One of her opponents in the race is Michael Benjamin, who has a history as an aide to several Bronx politicians, including Assemblywoman Aurelia Greene, Councilman Adolfo Carrion Jr. and United States Representative Jose E. Serrano. Mr. Benjamin, 43, a member of the executive committee of the Bronx Democratic Party, has been endorsed by a wide range of labor groups and Democratic elected officials in the Bronx, including Fernando Ferrer, the borough president.
 The third candidate in the Democratic primary is Anthony Curry, 41, a staff member at the city's Human Resources Administration who previously ran shelters for homeless people.
Mr. Curry has been endorsed by State Senator Pedro Espada Jr., who is running for borough president.
 In their campaign appearances, each of the candidates extol their ability to understand the concerns of the residents of the 16th Council District, which extends from Highbridge on its western side, through the Claremont, Morrisania and Concourse Village to the east.
 Mr. Benjamin says that he has become familiar with the issues in the district from his years of working with elected officials. "I have worked in the offices of many of the people who have served this community and the Bronx," he said. "And I have been involved even at the most local level, having served as a chairman on a local community board."
 Mr. Curry said that one of his priorities would be to seek ways to develop the waterfront area in the western border of the district, along the Hudson River, for recreation and commercial use. He said his work with neighborhood youth and civic groups offered him a better perspective of the area's needs. "I have lived in the Bronx all of my life, and I know this area better than any of the others," Mr. Curry said.
 He derides Mr. Benjamin, saying that his opponent's candidacy represents nothing more than the handiwork of party bosses. He criticizes Ms. Foster even more sharply, accusing her of operating a "leisurely campaign," saying that a weeklong trip she took to the Caribbean a month before the primary "indicates that she doesn't have enough respect for the voters to even get out there and talk to them. She is only running on her father's name. They want this to be a coronation."
 The district, which is largely black and Hispanic, includes some attractive, middle class apartment buildings, including the Art Deco complexes along the Grand Concourse and in Claremont and Highbridge. But the district also includes some of the city's poorest residents, high rates of asthma and high unemployment.
 All three candidates have made education reform the centerpiece of their campaign discussions. Mr. Benjamin, for example, has advocated enhanced professional development training for teachers and principals. Ms. Foster has called for a program under which repayment of student loans would be waived for teachers who volunteer to work in low-performing schools and improve that performance.
 In addition, all three have emphasized the need to develop better relationships between the police and the residents in the district, who, they insist, have an abiding fear of officers.
 Ms. Foster raised the most money in outright contributions, $81,258. But she has so far failed to qualify for public matching funds. Mr. Benjamin has raised about $44,000, but has received another $75,280 under the city's campaign finance program. Mr. Curry has raised about $13,000, but has also failed to receive any matching funds.
 Mr. Benjamin said he rarely discussed the issue of family succession, preferring instead to talk about education and low property taxes. "But, if voters ask me my view about it," he said, "I just ask them: should any one family control a district for more than 25 years?"
 Ms. Foster, a former assistant district attorney in Manhattan, said she was unfazed by such criticism. "If the voters think I have nothing to offer, then they will cast their votes appropriately on Sept. 11," she said. "But in the meantime, I think that once they hear my views and my background, they will realize that I have something to offer."

HEADLINE: Zimbabwe Fund for AIDS Patients Is Frozen in Bureaucracy 

BYLINE:  By HENRI E. CAUVIN

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe 

 BODY:
In the battle against AIDS, it was considered a bold step. Zimbabwe would impose a 3 percent tax on personal and corporate income to pay for a national AIDS trust, which would help care for the country's thousands and thousands of citizens infected with the virus that causes AIDS.
 But more than a year after the government began collecting the tax, most of the millions of dollars raised so far sit unspent, mired in a bureaucracy that has frustrated many people who welcomed the trust's creation. 
 Even as the tax passed into law in January 2000, some people wondered about the government's stewardship of such money. The country was in the early stages of an economic crisis that has only worsened, and then, as now, there were many demands on the government. 
Still, advocates for AIDS care hoped that the enormous suffering caused by the crisis would ensure that the money reached the country's poor people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and the families struggling to care for them.
"People in principle liked it, liked the idea of sharing the burden, of looking after the people who are infected," said Chiedza Musengezi, the director of the Women and AIDS Support Network in Harare, the capital.
But so far, it has seldom worked out that way. 
Instead, the board of the National AIDS Council, a government agency that coordinates AIDS policy and was in charge of distributing the money, was dissolved in March after the Health Ministry decided that the council did not have the legal authority to manage the trust. Some critics accused the ministry of playing politics, saying that the board was dissolved because its chairman was a supporter of the Movement for Democratic Change, the leading opposition party. 
Whatever the motives, when the operations of the national AIDS trust were effectively halted, only about $4 million had been distributed, and right now at least $25 million is waiting to be spent, Dr. P. David Parirenyatwa, the deputy health minister, said in an interview.
Like its neighbors in southern Africa, Zimbabwe has been hit hard by the AIDS epidemic. At least 25 percent of the country's adults are estimated to be H.I.V. positive, according to Unaids, the United Nations AIDS agency. 
A new study looking at more recent statistics, conducted by the Health Ministry and the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, reports that about 35 percent of the country's adults are now infected, Dr. Parirenyatwa said. He said the study had not been released because the ministry was not sure the numbers were accurate and wanted to re-examine the study's epidemiology. 
If the numbers are true, Zimbabwe's percentage of adults with H.I.V. would be roughly equal to Botswana's, which is the highest in the world, and that would increase pressure on Zimbabwe to find a way to distribute the money from the AIDS trust.
Dr. Parirenyatwa acknowledged the problem of disbursing the money and "doing it quickly enough," and he promised that it would soon be flowing steadily. But he said the Health Ministry simply wanted to make sure the money reached the right people.
"It's a no-win situation, really," he said. "When we started disbursing, we did it very quickly, but then people started complaining that you are giving to people who are not deserving, so now we are very careful."
Dr. Sunanda Ray, the director of the Southern Africa AIDS Information Dissemination Service in Harare, said many of Zimbabwe's problems in distributing the money could have been avoided and should have been corrected by now.
"People are trying to provide the services on a shoestring," Dr. Ray said, "and they are feeling the urgency, and it just seems outrageous that the bureaucrats are not able to respond." 
Whatever the source of the money, distributing it quickly and fairly is emerging as a crucial challenge for many African countries as more AIDS money comes their way, Robert Hecht, an associate director of Unaids, said in an interview from Geneva.
No other country has an AIDS tax like Zimbabwe's, but some, like Cameroon, are using debt relief savings to expand their AIDS budgets, while others, like Botswana, have been able to allocate more of their own budgets to fight AIDS. 
With its deepening economic and political turmoil, Zimbabwe faces an even more dire predicament. Hunger and unemployment are rising, making it harder for families to care for their dying relatives. More than ever, people with AIDS need the sort of basic support that the national AIDS trust was set up to provide, things like blankets and pain relievers.
Last month, in a display of frustration, hundreds of people staged a demonstration to protest the problems with the trust fund. 
"If every person sees it on their pay slips, they feel they're contributing to this national cause," Mr. Hecht said, "but if nothing is happening and they don't see any movement, people become cynical. They say, 'What's happening to the money that I'm contributing?' "
Indeed, the frustration at the pace of distribution has fed suspicion among ordinary people. Some worry that the money will become a tool in the pre-election patronage machine of the ruling party, which must contend with national elections next year and a serious challenge from the opposition. 
Others suspect that the money is somehow being manipulated by the cash-strapped government to pay for other needs like fuel imports or military expenses in the Congo. 
Dr. Parirenyatwa denied such rumors. "If the money is for H.I.V., then it must be used for H.I.V.," and it must not go to Congo or to offset any other costs, he said. "Some of us are doctors. How could we do that?"
In the coming weeks and months, Dr. Parirenyatwa said, the National AIDS Council will resume distributing money, with hundreds of thousands of dollars now set to go to each of the country's 81 local district governments, which now will have a central role in how the money is spent in their communities.

HEADLINE: Sunday Q & A 

 BODY:
 Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

Early Swimming Lessons

Q. Is it is safe to teach babies to swim?

A. Linda Villarosa, who writes about health and fitness for Science Times, responds:
 In the last decade, there has been a proliferation of infant and toddler aquatic instruction programs. Most of this instruction does not focus on teaching these children to swim, however, but is intended to get them used to being in and around water. For example, the Y.M.C.A. of the U.S.A. notes that 60 percent of Y's offer infant-parent aquatics classes for children 6 months to 3 years old. These classes teach aquatic readiness to encourage babies and toddlers to become more comfortable in the water. 
Even without training, a child can perform rudimentary swimming movements in the water at about 1 year old. But, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics, children are not usually developmentally ready for swimming lessons until after their fourth birthdays.
Research shows that most children under 4 lack the neuromuscular coordination to master traditional swimming strokes. Although some children learn to swim earlier, younger children generally require longer instructional periods to learn the skills than children who have turned 4 or even 5. Having children begin lessons before 4 does not mean they will eventually be better swimmers than those who take lessons later.
More important, experts warn that infant and toddler programs cannot prevent children from drowning. Some experts say they worry that early swimming classes can give a false sense of security to parents, who might let their guard down in and around water. Drowning is the leading cause of unintentional injury and death among children under 5. 
Even if a child has been enrolled in an aquatics program, parents should still remain within arm's length, said Dr. Gary A. Smith, director of the Center for Injury Research and Policy at Children's Hospital in Columbus, Ohio. A child younger than 5 who has some competence in swimming should still be supervised closely.
If parents put their infant, toddler or preschooler in an aquatics class, Dr. Smith said, they should avoid any program promoted as a way to decrease the risk of drowning. There is no doubt that aquatics can help children develop water skills, he said, but such programs do not make children drown-proof.

The Economics of Recycling

Q. In New York City, for recycling purposes, we assiduously sort our trash: paper, metal, plastic. And then the proper truck picks it up in a special load. Aside from the environmental benefit, is there any economic benefit to New York City?

A. Kirk Johnson, who covers the environment for the metropolitan desk, responds:
The immediate economic benefits to New York City from its recycling program are not huge. And they are not easily measured. About 1,000 mostly low-wage jobs have been created in the private sector -- doing work like sorting kinds of glass -- along with several hundred public-sector jobs. An unknown number of additional labor hours are paid out by the city's big apartment buildings, where maintenance employees sort the categories of glass, metal and paper. And the city will earn about $4 million this year selling into the waste-paper market, where prices can fluctuate wildly. 
Officials at New York City's Department of Sanitation are also the first to admit that by pure utilitarian standards -- taking into account only the taxpayers' money with no thought for the environment -- recycling is inefficient. Scooping up all the city's millions of tons of rubbish with no time or labor wasted in sorting or in specialized pickups would save pots of money in the short term. 
There is a myth that recycling will eventually cover its cost, said Robert Lange, director of the Bureau of Waste Prevention, Reuse and Recycling at the Department of Sanitation. But that will never happen, he said. The best the city can hope for, he said, is that revenue from selling recyclable material pays for a small part. The larger goal, he said, is to cut the city's waste, and to the degree that recycling helps do that, its ultimate benefit could be huge.
Send questions by e-mail to sundayq&a@nytimes.com, or by mail to Sunday Q & A, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Those of widest interest will be selected, but unpublished questions cannot be answered individually. Previous Sunday Q & A's are available at www.nytimes.com/pages /national/columns/.

HEADLINE: Street Theater and Graffiti: Belarus Dissidents Make News by Making Noise 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: BORISOV, Belarus, Aug. 17 

 BODY:
It was just outside this fraying and thoroughly Soviet city, residents note with some pride, that guerrilla forces handed the French dictator Napoleon his final defeat in 1812, during his army's disastrous winter retreat from Russia.
 But that was 189 years ago. What is more interesting is what guerrillas are doing here to Belarus's own quirky dictator, President Aleksandr Lukashenko, right now. 
 Mr. Lukashenko, who was democratically elected in 1994 and two years later extended his term in a referendum that outsiders say was rigged, has spent his time casting Belarus in a Soviet mold, with disastrous results. 
The economy is a shell, and the population has been nearly cowed by a vast security network and the disappearances of a succession of political opponents and former cronies of the president who fell from favor. 
But now, three weeks before a presidential election that could actually test the durability of Mr. Lukashenko's one-man rule, stickers proclaiming "Time to clean out!" have begun popping up on office-building walls. 
Last Wednesday, the police seized eight people after 100 demonstrators abruptly appeared and linked arms in the asphalt-covered town square, almost in the shadow of Lenin's statue. Four more dissidents were arrested Thursday, eight more today -- indeed, roughly 100 since March.
Such sustained, guerrilla-style protest is new to Belarus, but not to Europe. A similar protest movement, called Otpor, or Resistance, was crucial in unseating the Serbian dictator Slobodan Milosevic last October. 
In Belarus, once a Soviet republic, the movement is called Zubr, the word for a bison that is to Belarus what the bear is to Russia and the eagle is to the United States. Proponents of Zubr say it is the country's fastest-growing youth movement, with thousands enrolled in 60 towns and cities since its founding in January. 
The movement's overriding goal is to show Belarus's legendarily passive population by vivid example that it is possible to challenge authority. The gamble is that Zubr can rouse enough people, and rattle enough of Mr. Lukashenko's enforcers, to make it impossible for Mr. Lukashenko to rig the results of the elections, on Sept. 9. 
"Most of the population is against the present regime, but they think the regime will win anyway," Dmitri Borodko, the 26-year-old coordinator in the Minsk region for Zubr, said during a chat in one of Borisov's spartan cafes. "People just don't see signs of struggle. But if they see someone struggle against Lukashenko, they will begin to believe." 
Some Western diplomats and veterans of Belarus's democratic opposition believe that Mr. Lukashenko is already in deep trouble. "What is most important is the percentage of people who want to see Lukashenko re-elected" -- only 36 percent in one recent poll, said Andrei Sannikov, coordinator of the human rights group Charter '97.
"Our main concern is whether people will turn out for the election. He'll definitely lose if the turnout rate is 70 percent. If it's 80 percent, he'll be simply demolished."
But within Belarus's democratic opposition, there is disagreement over whether Zubr's street theater and graffiti will backfire in a conservative population, and grumbling about the group's mysterious and easy access to computers, slick protest materials and even the black T-shirts its members wear as a symbol of dissent.
The Serbian group Otpor was sustained with American money. It is assumed that the United States or some other Western nation or group is backing Zubr, hoping to repeat Serbia's success. 
Conversations with dissidents and journalists here and in the capital, Minsk, suggest that success against Mr. Lukashenko may be difficult in any case. 
True enough, Belarus's splintered political opposition has managed this time to choose a single candidate, a national union leader, Vladimir Goncharik, to face Mr. Lukashenko. Mr. Goncharik, like most politicians, is a middle-aged former Communist apparatchik. He is not even marginally charismatic, and his campaign seems to be barely breathing. 
Mr. Goncharik effectively has no access to radio or television, and he is mostly ignored by all but a handful of independent newspapers. In Borisov, a city of 150,000 barely 50 miles east of the opposition's Minsk headquarters, the proprietors of one large independent newspaper said they had yet to hear from the Goncharik campaign, while city officials are already are making speeches for Mr. Lukashenko and dispatching canvassers. 
That many here give the opposition even a shot at beating Mr. Lukashenko is testament to the president's deep-seated and apparently spreading unpopularity.
Mr. Lukashenko has so blackened his record with economic and political disasters that his support has dived in recent polls. Inflation has run in triple digits, farm production has sunk; airline flights shriveled from 35,000 in 1995 to just 5,700 in 1998; the percentage of paved roads is dropping. A growing share of the nation's tax revenues has gone into a presidential fund that is not publicly accounted for. 
The president has been especially crippled by credible accusations this summer that his personal security force engineered the disappearance and apparently the execution of some of Mr. Lukashenko's political and personal enemies.
Attacks on political and social critics have risen sharply in the last two years. Last week alone, at least five independent newspapers and political or civic groups lost computers and other equipment in break-ins. Since 1999, a number of opposition leaders, including Mr. Sannikov, of Charter '97, have fled Belarus either temporarily or for good after death threats.
What is most chilling, however, is the disappearances: Mr. Lukashenko's former interior minister, Yuri Zakharenko, in May 1999; the opposition leader Viktor Gonchar and a friend, Yuri Krasovsky, in September 1999; Mr. Lukashenko's onetime personal photographer, Dmitri Zavadsky, who fell from grace for his television reporting on smuggling, in July 2000.
In June, two investigators from the prosecutor general's office fled to the United States, where they accused some of the government's top security aides of setting up a death squad that had murdered up to 30 critics. 
The State Department has deemed the accusations credible; Mr. Lukashenko has called them an election-year provocation by his political foes. On July 20, as the Minsk-based independent newspaper Den prepared a special issue on the missing men, its offices were broken into and hard drives containing the issue's copy were taken from three computers. 
It is this climate of fear, says Mr. Borodko, Zubr's coordinator in Borisov, that his movement is combatting, by staging regular, open protests against Mr. Lukashenko's rule.
Zubr's origins are perhaps intentionally mysterious. Mr. Borodko said only that it was formed last January when some 40 leaders of youth group were summoned to Belavezh Preserve, a vast park where Soviet leaders met in 1991 to dissolve the Soviet Union -- and not coincidentally, the Belarus home where the Zubr roam. 
Like the Serbian group Otpor, Zubr's rules are simple. 
"The first principle is that there is no violence," Mr. Borodko said. "We reject violence in this struggle. The second is to show strength -- not to be afraid of wearing these T-shirts. There are cases where people have been beaten up because of that." 
Some fellow opposition members bristle at such boasts. In an interview, one called Zubr a "corrupted" opposition that had crafted its message and tactics to attract Western money. 
Mr. Borodko, who says he has been a dissident since leaving the army in 1997, takes that as an insult. He was forced from his job as an accountant in 1999, he says, after working with democratic forces to stage a vote on a shadow parliament. He now supports his wife and daughter by working for the human-rights group Vesna -- and is summoned to militia and K.G.B. offices roughly twice a month for interrogations.
After taking over Zubr's operations in Minsk, he said, his office was broken into in May and a computer and fax were stolen.
"The militia hunts down guys in these T-shirts to arrest them," he said, asking of Zubr's critics: "What do they call a serious organization?"
As for money, "I don't know where the central office gets it," he said. "I can only say where we get it. There are a lot of patriots in Borisov. They can't wear the T-shirts because their businesses would be dead. The T-shirts, stickers and computers we get form the central office. The rest we get here." 
Dissidents have protested against Mr. Lukashenko's rule before, of course -- 50,000 marched in Minsk last spring, by generous estimates -- but Zubr's tactics are both broader and more audacious.
One goal is to take protest outside Minsk, where antipathy toward Mr. Lukashenko is widespread, into the country, where his support is strongest. Zubr members have been walking across Belarus this summer, trailed by a K.G.B. car, visiting collective farms to stump for the opposition.
Another apparent goal is to stand out. Earlier this summer, Zubr members were arrested after they staged a play in which men in white coats chased a raving man wearing a hockey mask and carrying a hockey stick.
The joke was not lost on Belarussians: Mr. Lukashenko, a big hockey fan, is prone to public rants and displays of excess -- like closing a highway so he can Rollerblade -- that have earned him a reputation for kookiness, and worse.
The protesters got off scot free. Because their play did not mention Mr. Lukashenko by name, they argued, it must have been the police and prosecutors who judged the crazy, stick-waving actor to be Belarus's president.
But Mr. Lukashenko had the last word. Not much later, he issued a decree that banned wearing masks in public.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dmitri Borodko, center left, whose black T-shirt marks him as a political dissident, passes the Soviet-era statue of Lenin in Borisov, Belarus. (Yuri Ivanov for The New York Times) Map of Belarus highlighting Borisov: Odd things are happening in Borisov, like street protests.

HEADLINE: The Watch For Whales Is Outpacing The Hunts 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: VICTORIA, British Columbia 

 BODY:
Hour after hour this summer, high-powered inflatable boats roar out of the harbor here, loaded with tourists dressed in orange safety suits scanning the waves of the Salish Sea for an orca, or killer whale.
 On the water, the orca pods, or families, are easily located from a mile away -- not for their distinctive dorsal fins, but for clusters of up to 40 tourist boats, from companies like Seafun Safaris and Prince of Whales. 
 Whale watching has mushroomed from one company on Vancouver Island in 1980 to 50 companies plying the Canadian-American waters here. Using a tracking network of underwater microphones and human spotters on land, air and sea, companies now tell visitors that they have a 98 percent success rate for whale-watching expeditions. 
The explosion of whale watching here in the Pacific Northwest is part of a surge worldwide. Today watching whales generates far more money than harpooning them. 
During the 1990's, the number of people going on whale-watching tours nearly tripled, hitting 10 million to 11 million in 2000, according to a report by the International Fund for Animal Welfare, a nonprofit group devoted to protecting whales, the world's largest mammals.
"We've always maintained these magnificent creatures are worth far more alive than dead," Fred O'Regan, the group's president, said on releasing the report in late July. "Now we can prove it."
Whale watchers paid more than $300 million for tour tickets last year and far more for land-based costs surrounding the tours, the report says. In contrast, the wholesale value of whale meat sold last year in Japan, one of the last major whaling nations, was put at $32 million. 
While a dead whale provides a one-time value, a live one can provide more lasting economic benefits by returning to shore communities where whale-watching tours are offered. In the 1990's, the number of communities around the world offering such tours roughly doubled to 492, according to Erich Hoyt, author of the Animal Welfare report.
Growing at 12 percent a year in the 1990's, or triple the annual rate of international tourism, whale watching attracts more than a million people a year in the United States, Canada and Spain. South Africa and Australia are fast behind. "In late 1980's whale watching just took off," Mr. Hoyt said in a phone interview from Edinburgh. "Now it is starting to translate into a political impact."
In Iceland, one of the last countries to give up whaling, the number of whale watchers was 30,330 in 1998, up from 200 in 1994. Whale watching is also growing in Norway and Japan, the two major nations that still hunt whales. In Japan, 100,000 people are estimated to take the tours. 
"The Japanese and Taiwanese are some of our best customers," Anton Roberts, co-owner of Seafun Safaris, said at the docks. 
Japan, a nation that largely feeds itself from the sea, says that each year it needs to catch about 500 whales, mostly minkes, to study their impact on fish. With Japan's whale catch today less than 10 percent the 6,000 level of the 1960's, Masayuki Komatsu, head of the Japan's Fisheries Agency, maintained a hard stance, calling minke whales "cockroaches of the sea."
In Washington, Shunji Yanai, Japan's ambassador to the United States, said recently that the whaling debate should be based "not on emotion, but on scientific reasoning" He added, "Some people say that whales eat more fish than mankind."
Here in the Pacific Northwest, some people complain that whale watching is too much of a good thing.
"People who are watching whales from shore are appalled by it," said Kari L. Koski, coordinator of Soundwatch, a boater education program run by the Whale Museum of San Juan Island, in Washington. "We see high speed and erratic behavior -- zooming in front of them and stopping in front of them."
Studies have been inconclusive about the impact of tour boats on whales. What is known is that in the last five years, the three pods of killer whales around here have declined about 20 percent, to 78 this summer. 
While noise pollution from motorboats may contribute, the main culprits are a sharp drop in salmon, their favorite food; the one-time practice of capturing whales here for aquariums; and man-made toxins.
"We are the visible thing," Mr. Roberts, of the tour company, said. "What can't be seen are the PCB's, the whales taken into captivity, the salmon disappearing."

HEADLINE: After a Decade, Scars Linger In a Healing Crown Heights 

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIFNER and FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
Ten years after Crown Heights exploded in New York's ugliest spasm of racial violence in decades, the neighborhood's black and Jewish residents conduct joint picnics and ice-skating parties, even a police-supervised Halloween parade. There is a storefront mediation center, a black and Jewish mothers group, and an effort to add black youngsters to the private Jewish security patrols.
 Black and Jewish leaders have one another's beeper and cell phone numbers. 
 Prominent members of the Hasidim like Rabbi Jacob Goldstein and Rabbi Shea Hecht can ask Edison Jackson, the black president of Medgar Evers College at the City University of New York, for help and facilities for a computer training program and summer swimming. The area's black politicians, particularly Democratic Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., once at odds with the Lubavitchers, a Hasidic sect, have made their peace and in turn can rely on their solid bloc of something over 3,000 votes. 
In the years since the chaos of August 1991, blacks and Jews in this densely populated, economically distressed Brooklyn neighborhood have made major efforts to create institutional and informal ties. But despite the efforts of the leaders, the elected officials and lots of the neighborhood's ordinary residents, many of the old differences and distrusts remain, buried just beneath the surface. These are communities that, almost by definition, lead separate lives even as they live side by side.
There are still strong emotions surrounding the night exactly 10 years ago when a car in the entourage of the Lubavitcher rebbe spun out of control, crushing 7-year-old Gavin Cato as he played with his bicycle. Yankel Rosenbaum, a 29-year-old Hasidic scholar from Australia, was fatally stabbed three hours later, caught by a mob racing through the streets shouting "Jew, Jew."
For two more days and nights hundreds of black teenagers rampaged unchecked, burning police cars, looting, hurling bottles and beating people. Blacks and Jews clashed as the police stood by.
"I wish we had all these beeper and phone numbers for each other back then," said Chanina Sperlin, executive vice chairman of the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council. "There seems to be little tension; it's not a crisis anymore," said Jesse Hamilton, executive director of the Crown Heights Service Center, who is black. "Everybody is much more in tune," said Assistant Chief Joseph Fox, the Brooklyn South police commander.
Crown Heights, a neighborhood of 134,140 people, is a quiet place these days. Like much of the city, it has less crime and more construction, although the city's decade of boom times has not produced appreciable economic gains for either blacks or Jews. On the blocks at the epicenter of the rioting, there are now fewer blacks and more Hasidim, and at the neighborhood's fringes, more affluent whites from adjacent neighborhoods have begun to make inroads.
Ten years of immigration, too, have infused the neighborhood with Koreans and Nigerians, many of them illegal immigrants. And the police, who a decade ago were the source of disgruntlement for blacks and Jews, are now praised by both. 
On a recent hot August evening, near the corner of Utica Avenue and President Street, where the riot began, teenagers played raucous basketball. There was nothing to mark the spot nearby where Gavin Cato died. The makeshift memorials are long gone. A girl swooped from sidewalk to street on a fancy bike.
"There is a little healing so far, but not much," said Clemsford David, born in Guyana, a nurse at Kings County Hospital who lived through the rioting. "There are really two cultures that are different."
Today, there is to be a kind of ceremony -- celebration would hardly be the word -- marking the anniversary with a street fair for children and a banquet at the Brooklyn Museum. It is sponsored by Project CARE, for Community Alliance Revitalization Effort, a three-year-old group of dozens of black churches, Lubavitcher organizations, police precincts and government agencies.
And so while the neighborhood remains largely poor, with everyone struggling over scarce resources for housing, education and medical care, not every issue is viewed reflexively through the prism of race. When blacks met with commanders of the 71st Precinct to complain about the extra protection given to Jewish religious leaders and synagogues, they were offered the same accommodations, but realized they were not needed, said Owen Augustin, bishop of St. Augustine's A.O.C. Church.
The leaders are vigilant for possible friction points. Last year, for example, the Jewish Community Council won a housing rehabilitation grant in a traditionally black area. In the past, that might have spurred fears the Lubavitchers were about to jump the informal border. Instead, meetings produced assurances to black leaders that the housing would be preserved for the black residents.
But the new alliances also have their limits. Some blacks are still angry because they think Jews wield undue influence. Some see Hasidim buying the stately houses on President Street and sitting on the local school board even though they have their own school system. There are still grumblings that they are taking over the neighborhood and that the police are in their pockets.
Nowhere are the enduring differences more stark than the way blacks and Jews view the two deaths from 1991.
Many blacks feel that the driver of the car that killed the youth escaped justice; he is now living in Israel. "There is a segment of the black community that continues to grieve and feels that an injustice was done and there was not equal treatment," said Dr. Jackson.
Jews angrily reject any such equating of the deaths. "It's a tragedy what happened to the Cato family. But what happened to Yankel Rosenbaum was a murder," said Mr. Sperlin. "There are still murderers out there. The two incidents are very different."
Certainly, Carmel Cato, the father of Gavin, feels the sense of injustice most deeply. Mr. Cato still insisted that Gavin and his cousin Angela, 7, who survived being hit by the car in the rebbe's entourage, lay mangled and burned on the ground for at least 20 minutes while a Jewish ambulance whisked away the car's driver.
That version of events, contradicted by official city accounts, spread through the neighborhood that night.
"Every day I think about it," Mr. Cato, a hospital worker who has since moved out of Crown Heights, said of that night. "I cannot heal. I don't know how all these people can go around and say there is healing. They never reach for me."
The differences bubbled up, too, the other night, as a group of neighborhood women gathered at the mediation center to talk about a decade of change. They were proud of the roles that women played in groups like Mothers to Mothers, which since 1992 has brought together black and Jewish mothers to talk about their fears and dreams.
As a latecomer arrived, some women cooed congratulations for her new grandchild. Others ticked off the times they had exchanged family photographs and enjoyed interracial outings.
But then Carol Meltz, a black mother of four who is a retired social worker, spoke up. A 30-year neighborhood resident, she said the riots showed a rage among young blacks that too many still overlook or portray as the work of outsiders. 
"The riots broke out because of frustration and despair," Mrs. Meltz said, her voice trembling. "I know how people felt. You had no power. Political power. Things don't happen in a vacuum."
"So why did they have to take it out on the Jews?" snapped Rivka Katzen, a Jewish woman.
"Because they were there," Mrs. Meltz snapped back.
The women's exchange was quickly smoothed over. But it showed how close to the surface and how raw the feelings can still be. Mindful of the power of language, many community leaders simply call what happened in 1991 "the incident." Most others do not talk about 1991 at all.
But the rage among young black men with no jobs and few prospects is the same now as it was 10 years ago, says Richard Green, executive director of the Crown Heights Youth Collective. They are not the ones taking part in the new interracial coalitions. Mr. Green said he knew many of the young rioters from the neighborhood. He called them society's ghosts because they do not vote, work or attend school. Their children and their younger siblings, he said, often share their fate.
"Their anger is an outgrowth of idleness, a lack of feeling accomplished as human beings," Mr. Green said. "When it's compounded, it goes into rage. We have to be able to go after what caused these youths to do what they did."
If anything, the flow of mostly illegal immigrants from Nigeria, Korea and the Middle East into Crown Heights has created new possibilities for conflict, he said.
"From Utica to Atlantic Avenue, do you have any idea of how many villages you travel through?" Mr. Green said. "And we don't have any ambassadors to these enclaves. They all carry their own nationalistic attitudes." He added, "At least now the Hasidic village is talking to the African village. What about the Korean village?"
When the No. 3 train disgorges at the Kingston Avenue station in the evening rush hour it is a stunning sight: bearded Lubavitcher men in black suits and hats climb the stairs alongside Rastafarians with dreadlocks.
"Even though we live together, we don't know much about each other," said Yossi Stern, one of the leaders of the Lubavitcher security patrol. Steve King, 29, who is black and works on Franklin Avenue as a barber, concurred: "Things are so-so. Everybody goes their own way."
Actually, of all the changes that have occurred in Crown Heights since 1991, one of the more significant happened within the Lubavitchers themselves. Menachem M. Schneerson, the charismatic rebbe, died without an heir at the age of 91 seven years ago. One side effect was that the huge crowds who gathered for his appearances -- or even a rumor he might be at a window -- no longer filled the surrounding streets, with the attendant police attention.
Outsiders thought the Lubavitchers might fall apart. Instead, despite some internal political and spiritual wrangling, they have thrived, sending thousands more emissaries abroad in their worldwide Chabad outreach movement. And their numbers are growing within the neighborhood.
"They can't build quick enough to cope with the growth in the community," said Rabbi Yehuda Krinsky, Rabbi Schneerson's longtime secretary and assistant who functions as a kind of chief executive of the international movement. "We are building schools, our synagogues are overflowing. I'm very upbeat about it."
But the Lubavitchers' intense inward looking spirituality -- some in Crown Heights still believe the rebbe may yet return as a Messiah -- their devotion to family and religious ritual largely ensures they live separately from their black neighbors.
"The melting pot, it just doesn't exist. You're not going to have that social dynamic," said Rabbi Goldstein, the chairman of Community Board 9 since 1980. "People say to me, 'You're living in a ghetto.' Well, I like my ghetto."
Mr. Hamilton, the director of a social services center, agreed, saying, "The Hasidic community is a very closed community. They don't socialize with the rest of the community that much." But, like some other black leaders, he expressed admiration for their ability to organize, saying "they do their homework better." He added, "They don't leave any stone unturned."
Dr. Robert Feldman, a Lubavitcher doctor who lives and practices at Kingston Avenue and President Street, where many of the clashes took place, thought back to the riots late one night, recalling his fear as he stitched up victims while a mob raged outside. "We didn't have any problems before. It was racially mixed, but it was nice," he mused.
What was it like in Crown Heights right before the riot, he was asked.
"The atmosphere just before this happened was very calm," Dr. Feldman said. "Just like now."

HEADLINE: Why Risk Our Social Insurance? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Thomas R. Saving, a member of President Bush's Social Security reform commission, revealed that he has no case in his Aug. 12 Op-Ed article arguing for privatization of Social Security accounts. 
 Mr. 
Saving asserts that Social Security costs will be 25 percent higher than today in 2016, 54 percent higher in 2025 and 69 percent higher in 2050. If most people had a clear understanding of how much Social Security costs today, this would be a responsible way to present future cost projections.
It would be more normal to express the projected cost increases as a share of gross domestic product. For 2015 it would be 0.86 percentage points higher than today; for 2025, 2.06 percentage points; and for 2050, 2.39 percentage points. This projected rate of increase in Social Security spending is actually smaller than what we saw in the last 50 years.

DEAN BAKER
Co-director, Center for
Economic and Policy Research
Washington, Aug. 12, 2001

HEADLINE: Between Hotel and Home 

BYLINE:  By JANET PIORKO 

 BODY:
THE name Ritz-Carlton, synonymous since 1927 with a hotel in Boston, is now associated with another kind of lodging there: the Residential Suites at the Ritz-Carlton Towers, apartments for stays of 15 days or more. With a "soft opening" in June, they are part of a complex still under construction that will include the Ritz-Carlton, Boston Common, the company's second hotel in the city, set to open in early September with 193 rooms and suites; a 100,000-square-foot athletic club, Sports Club/LA, also opening in early September; a 19-screen theater (now open), and 309 condominiums.
 The Residential Suites have cable TV, VCR, DVD, stereo, in-room safes and dedicated fax machines, as well as housekeeping, concierge, access to the health club and room service. 
 The project -- the first such venture associated with Ritz-Carlton -- is one of the more luxurious examples of extended-stay accommodations, which make up the fastest growing segment in the lodging business, according to Mark Skinner, a partner in the Highland Group, a consulting and research company in Atlanta specializing in the field.
Their number has grown from 52,000 such units in the United States in 1995 to 212,000 last year, Mr. Skinner said. Although around a third are what he calls upscale, such as the properties of Residence Inn by Marriott, only a few are deluxe.
Four Seasons also has its name associated with such units; there are 50 short-term serviced apartments on top of the Four Seasons Hotel Houston and 16 at the Four Seasons Hotel Chicago.
Typical guests are executives relocating, lawyers trying a case and film crews. "We have the lion's share of the film and entertainment industry in Vancouver," said Judy Ahola, a spokeswoman for the 397-room Sutton Place Hotel in Vancouver, which has a 164-suite tower called La Grande Residence for minimum three-night stays.
Extended-stay lodgings cost less than comparable hotels, said Mr. Skinner. At the Residential Suites, based on a 15-day stay, a one-bedroom apartment, ranging from 700 to 1,300 square feet, costs $235 to $310 a night. The Ritz-Carlton, Boston Common will charge $495 for a 350-square-foot room.
New York City has been fertile ground for this lodging. Millennium Partners, the developer of the new Ritz-Carlton Boston project, has owned the Phillips Club near Lincoln Center since 1996; it has 96 extended-stay units and 92 units for short-term stays and ownership through a residential club. The Envoy Club, which opened in 1998 with 57 units on East 33rd Street, plans to open a property on the Upper East Side of Manhattan this year; another, at 425 Fifth Avenue, at 38th Street, is planned for next year. Manhattan East Suite Hotels, with 10 properties, is spending $12 million to renovate its Dumont Plaza, with 248 suites at 34th Street and Lexington Avenue.
Because extended-stay lodgings offer value, Mr. Skinner expects they will hold their own even in a softening market. He said that statistics for the first half of the year show that this type of accommodation is weathering the economic downturn better than the overall lodging industry.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
A New Car Phone (No Strings Attached)

BYLINE:  By MINDY SINK 

DATELINE: BOULDER, Colo. 

 BODY:
FOR most of the past decade, Cellport Systems has been researching and developing a safer way for motorists to talk on their wireless phones while on the road. Sure, there are headsets and other devices on the market that allow people to talk and keep both hands on the wheel, but critics say that those, too, can pose safety problems.
 Now, as public sentiment grows against the use of hand-held cellular phones while driving, Cellport finds itself in the spotlight with its next generation of hands-free, headset-free technology. Drivers use simple voice commands to operate the phone, while the sound is channeled through the car's speakers. And Cellport's system is compatible with most major brands of cell phones. 
 Last month, Cellport, which is privately held, signed a $48 million, two-year contract to provide its voice-activated cell phone system, known as the Cellport 3000 with Voice Command, to the Ford Motor Company. Ford will offer the option through dealers this fall in the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable sedans and the Ford Windstar minivan, and early next year in the Lincoln Town Car. 
"So the stars aligned, and thank God we lived long enough to see them align," said Pat Kennedy, the chief executive and a founder of Cellport. "We were, oddly enough, way ahead of our time."
Mr. Kennedy, 48, uses phrases like "so one thing led to another" and words like "magically" to describe the business connections that led to seven patents, global partners and the contract with Ford.
Mr. Kennedy has always been drawn to the telecommunications industry even though he received a degree in international economics from the University of Buffalo. Just out of college in 1978, he began working for Hatfield Associates, a telecommunications consulting firm in Boulder, then started Cellular Solutions Inc., a cell phone accessories business. He and his former boss, Dale N. Hatfield, worked together again in the early 1990's, along with three other colleagues in the industry -- Hiroshi Sakurai, Michael Braitberg and Richard Chandler -- to eventually form Cellport. Before Cellport was founded in 1993, the partners began developing and patenting their wireless technology.
In their first year of business, Cellport's founders lived rather modestly, driving old cars and eating plenty of pizza for dinner. Their fortunes began to change later that year, when a phone company industry group agreed to provide $500,000 to finance research. That money kept the company going until 1995, when AT&T Wireless provided a cash infusion of $2 million. In exchange for financing, Cellport agreed to share research results and to allow John Thompson, then the chief financial officer at AT&T Wireless, to serve on its board. Mr. Thompson helped Cellport secure more than $3 million in additional financing from other industry sources.
BUT the streak of good news came to an abrupt end in 1998, when the company presented its first product to investors and received a lukewarm reception. "They said, 'kudos because your core concept of universality is spot on, but it's a little big and clumsy,' " Mr. Kennedy said. Soon after, Mr. Braitberg left the company, although he remains a stockholder.
FLV Fund, an investment firm based in Belgium, helped Cellport back on its feet in 1999 with a $7 million investment. Philippe Vercruyssen, senior investment manager at FLV Management USA, a subsidiary, now also serves on Cellport's board. But Cellport's biggest break came last year, when it received a $22 million investment from Cisco Systems. That enabled the company to add offices in Tokyo and Detroit and to expand its work force to 100, from 27 just a year ago.
Dressed casually on a recent Wednesday morning in a brightly colored shirt, khaki shorts and black loafers, Mr. Kennedy offered a demonstration of the Cellport 3000. As he drove through the office parking lot in Boulder, he kept both hands on the steering wheel and his eyes on the road as he "dialed" the phone with spoken commands. He then repeated the process with several different cell phone models, rapidly attaching and detaching them from pocket adapters that fit a phone into the system's cradle, known as the docking station. The phone sits snugly in the cradle, where the phone battery is also recharged, and will not become a flying object if there is a sudden stop, he said.
The Cellport kit is wired to the car's electrical system. It has a small microphone, mounted on the rearview mirror, that can be wired through the stereo speakers and is intended to pick up even soft voices. It is activated only when the user says, "Cellport, dial" in English. The system, which can be programmed for speed dialing, cannot be activated accidentally by singing along with the radio, for example, though loud noices like those from a nearby lawnmower or from screaming children in the back seat of the car could interrupt an outgoing call.
"Then you've got a user-functionality problem," Mr. Kennedy said.
Incoming calls mute the car's audio system, and an external antenna improves signal strength and reduces the problem of dropped calls. 
While other companies -- most notably Motorola and Nokia -- already have relationships with Mercedes-Benz, Jaguar and BMW to provide voice-activated phone systems as dealer options, Cellport's advantage is the near universality of the pocket adapters. Cellport said it had designed them to accommodate 70 percent of cell phones on the market. 
The Cellport 3000 system sells for around $250 at retail outlets, although installation could run an additional $100 to $200 and individual adapters costs $60 to $100.
Mr. Kennedy said his company was constantly updating software as new cell phones were created. "Even though it looks like a hardware appliance company, the reality is we're really a software company," he said.
This year, Cellport says it expects to earn a profit of $4 million to $5 million, compared with barely break-even results in previous years. Earnings could grow as the market for hand-held alternatives increases. About 15 million hands-free phone units are expected to be sold next year worldwide, generating $3 billion in revenue, according to Cellport. The company said it had sold almost 20,000 of its hands-free units this year.
"It's the simple stuff in life that sells, and it's just inevitable that universal hands-free is going to become as common as the cup holder," said Douglas M. Daniels, Cellport's vice president for business development, who helped sell the product to Ford.
Mr. Daniels said a large fleet customer of Ford, which neither Cellport nor the automaker would identify, had approached Ford with a problem: It had a hands-free policy for all company cars. "Our main motivation was customer demand," said Kurt Kaiser, North American manager for vehicle personalization at Ford.
Ford officials said they were unsure of the exact price of the Cellport option for customers, although Mr. Daniels said it would probably be under $400 on most cars. The kit can also be retrofitted to many older-model Fords.
CELLPORT began manufacturing under contract in Mexico at the start of the year and the deal with Ford began to take shape this spring. "It was catalyzed in a sense of crisis by the New York state law," Mr. Kennedy said.
This summer, New York became the first state to enact a law banning motorists from using hand-held cell phones while driving. It takes effect on Nov. 1.
Other states may follow suit. Since 1995, legislators in at least 45 states have proposed banning or restricting the use of cell phones while driving, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. More than 300 cities and towns also have laws prohibiting the practice, along with 20 countries worldwide.
A New England Journal of Medicine study in 1997 concluded that phone use in a motor vehicle quadrupled the risk of an accident. An estimated 3 percent of drivers nationwide use hand-held phones, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
While he was impressed with the Cellport technology, Felix W. Ortiz, a New York State assemblyman who spent years advocating legislation to prohibit drivers from using hand-held cell phones, said he did not think that the company's product solved the safety issues. "People should not be driving and talking at all," said Mr. Ortiz, a Brooklyn Democrat.
Bill Johnston, a psychology professor at the University of Utah who has studied how cell phones affect driving performance, agreed. "It's like a filter tip on a cigarette in that it might help a little bit," he said. "The problem is diversion from driving, just the conversation itself."
Mr. Kennedy said he was not lobbying to ban hand-held phones in cars. "We take the position with the cellular industry that, yes, consumers need to be responsible for their own behavior," he said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Why Investors May Find Arbitrators on Their Side

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
AS investors watch their portfolios wizen, complaints of broker misdeeds rise at the National Association of Securities Dealers. The group, which runs the nation's largest arbitration system handling investor grievances, reports that through July, 3,950 cases had been filed, 25 percent more than at the same point in 2000. 
 But how many disgruntled investors will succeed in their cases? Will arbitrators view them, as many in the securities industry do, as greedy opportunists trying to recover losses of their own making by picking the deepest pocket around? 
 One authority on securities arbitration says that for several reasons, many investors will fare well. Lewis D. Lowenfels, at the New York law firm Tolins & Lowenfels, said stock investors' immense losses since last year and the troubling conflicts of interest coming to light among research analysts and other brokerage firm employees will encourage arbitrators to give plaintiffs at least some of what they are seeking. 
"The tech stock bubble and conflicts at brokerage firms will be central to their decisions," Mr. Lowenfels said. "And given the unpredictability of panels, brokerage firms are going to be more inclined to settle."
Not every case will be a winner for the plaintiff, of course. But Mr. Lowenfels' argument is borne out by Merrill Lynch's recent payment of $400,000 to settle a case brought against it and its high-profile Internet analyst, Henry Blodget.
A Supreme Court case in 1987 confirmed that investors cannot file claims against brokers in court if they had agreed to bring them to arbitration, as most are required to do in order to open brokerage accounts. So investors have little choice about where they air their grievances. Surprisingly, Mr. Lowenfels said, arbitration may be kinder to beleaguered investors today than courts would be. 
To win a federal fraud case, for example, an investor must prove intent on the broker's part. Not so in arbitration, where many panels have ruled against firms for recommending unsuitable investments to clients or for failing to supervise brokers. Intent to defraud was never at issue. 
Arbitration may be more fruitful for investors, especially those suing over losses in stocks recommended by biased analysts, because in federal court, investors can bring a fraud case only if they bought or sold based on the recommendation. Arbitration, on the other hand, allows for cases in which an investor already owned the stock and simply held on because of the analyst's call. 
Finally, Mr. Lowenfels argued that in some arbitration opinions, panelists have said they were concerned about treating plaintiffs equitably even if it meant appearing to go beyond the law to do it. "In these cases, plaintiffs receive at least some portion of their demands," he said. "But in a court of law, the same claimants would probably have received nothing." 
Investors are in the midst of the worst bear market since arbitration was mandated. If throngs of them prevail, it will come as an unpleasant surprise to brokers who cheered when they won the right to compel investors to arbitration rather than the courts. They felt that arbitration panels -- made up of industry executives, lawyers and business people -- would be more conservative than juries of people unfamiliar with investing. 
But now, Mr. Lowenfels said, "in a number of important areas, arbitration panels seem to have reached beyond existing legal authorities to expand the rights and protections accorded to the investing public." 
Wonder which brokerage will be first to stop forcing its clients into arbitration?

PERSON: Pamela Conover 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Restoring the Queens' Glamour

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN 

 BODY:
THE Queen Elizabeth 2 was recently docked at Pier 90 in Manhattan, at the start of a cruise up the Northeast coast, in all her regal glory and internal contradiction.
 Plaques commemorating royal visits lined a wall near the slot machines. Mementos from the glory years of trans-Atlantic travel filled a display case, looking forlorn compared with the shiny goods for sale in the on-board mall. 
 A larger anomaly is less apparent on the ship. Carnival Cruise Lines, a Miami-based company that grew rich promoting cruises for the masses, now owns Cunard Line Ltd. and with it this icon of British seafaring tradition. 
Fittingly, the recently appointed president and chief operating officer of Cunard, Pamela Conover, also reflects this complexity. Her accent is properly British, her speech carefully measured and her demeanor reserved. But underneath that is a woman who never attended college, who rose from bank teller to company president and who now must oversee both the largest ocean liner building project ever undertaken and the huge marketing effort to help it succeed.
Despite such pressure, there is not a single crack in the facade. "You could think of it as a challenge," she said over lunch in the Princess Grill aboard the QE2. "I prefer to think of it as an opportunity."
Opportunities appeared to come up in regular progression in Ms. Conover's successful, but not flashy, career. Her greatest claim to fame was a a 1992 speech at a cruise industry convention in which she correctly predicted that the industry would consolidate from 24 companies to just a handful. 
Ms. Conover, who is 45 and now lives in Key Biscayne, Fla., was born in Thailand to a British family. Her father worked for an international trading company. She went to high school in England and was preparing to study geography and anthropology at the University of London. "I couldn't face it, so I put it off for a year," she said, and took a bank teller's job at a Wells Fargo branch in London.
She passed through a series of clerical positions and took courses in credit analysis and accounting. Wells Fargo sent her to New York as a loan officer in 1979. When she asked a former Wells boss who worked at United States Lines, a container ship company, for a reference, he mentioned a job there -- assistant treasurer. She was hired in 1981.
Contacts with Citibank led the bank to hire her four years later for its ship finance division. Carnival was a customer, and then a suitor. She joined the cruise line in 1994. "Part of it is being in the right place at the right time," she said. "Part of it is hard work. Drive."
Her first assignment for Carnival was not a success. She was president of the Epirotiki Cruise Line, in which Carnival had invested. The Greek family that had controlled the company resented her attempt to exercise control, Ms. Conover said. "My job was to get in there and run the company and take over, and there were inevitably differences," she said.
Carnival pulled out after a year and made Ms. Conover vice president of the strategic planning department before moving her to Cunard, newly acquired, as chief operating officer in 1998. The title of president was added in February. 
Cunard, established in 1839 to carry mail between Britain and North America, grew into a storied line, launching ships like the Lusitania, Mauretania, Aquitania and the queens -- the Mary and the Elizabeths, first and second. 
But several changes of ownership over recent decades left it money-losing and demoralized. The signature event was a disastrous 1994 cruise in which pipes exploded and toilets erupted on the QE2, causing a passenger uproar.
Carnival bought the line from Kvaerner A.S.A., a Norwegian shipbuilder, in May 1998 and merged it with its Seabourn Cruise Line, which runs small, expensive vacation cruises. 
The next month, Carnival announced plans for the Queen Mary 2, the largest ocean liner ever; it is scheduled for its maiden voyage at the end of 2003. It will take over regular Atlantic runs from the QE2, which will stay in service for regional cruises.
But soon after the Cunard acquisition, the luxury segment of the cruise industry, which includes Cunard, weakened sharply because of the downturn in the economy. Under Ms. Conover, Cunard's Web site (www.cunard.com) now offers a sweepstakes to win a free trans-Atlantic trip, and advertises a low trans-Atlantic fare of $1,225, including a return economy-fare plane ticket. 
The Seabourn-Cunard marriage, meanwhile, has floundered. Each line lost focus under combined management and marketing, Ms. Conover said. She has created separate managements and is selling three of Seabourn's six vessels.
Along with those problems, Ms. Conover has to oversee the building of the $800 million QM2 in a French yard; the project has faced unexpected expenses from new safety regulations -- which, for example, require Cunard to build not only the hull but also the superstructure out of steel. Some analysts view the project as folly, given the weakness in the market and what they regard as the fading appeal of trans-Atlantic ship travel.
"I think that's a dumb move," said Jason N. Ader, leisure analyst at Bear Stearns. "They're never going to get the returns on that."
Ms. Conover's tone stiffens slightly when asked about the criticism. "One, we have one of the most famous brand names," she said. "Two, we have the backing of the one of the largest and most successful cruise companies in the world. And three, we have assembled one of the finest management teams in the business."
Demographics are on Cunard's side, Ms. Conover contended. Older baby boomers are edging toward retirement. Younger ones are receiving inheritances. The number of North American cruise passengers has risen steadily. 
HENCE the urgency in relaunching Cunard's image, one of Ms. Conover's priorities. In July, Cunard gave its advertising account to the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day and hired a New York public relations firm, M. Silver Associates.
The aims will be to recall the Cunard Line's aristocratic British associations while portraying it as a floating resort, with theater productions, convention facilities, course offerings, concerts and the trappings of luxury. 
Do the images clash? Not to Ms. Conover. Passengers want both the modern amenities and the trappings of a bygone era, she contended. Ultimately, she said, a trans-Atlantic cruise is about "giving people the ability to step back."
