HEADLINE: Debate Over National Monument Emphasizes Old West-New West Divide 

BYLINE:  By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: LOMA, Mont., Aug. 14 

 BODY:
On a treeless, sun-baked hill near here where two rivers flow together, the explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark came to a critical decision in 1805: they would follow the Missouri River and not the Marias in their quest for the Northwest Passage. The call was the right one, for the Missouri led to the headwaters they sought.
 Decision Point is just one of the sites included in a proclamation signed by President Bill Clinton in January that turned this rugged, sparsely settled region dotted with cattle and nuclear missile silos into the Missouri Breaks National Monument, one of several such monuments Mr. Clinton created at the end of his term. 
 Now, Montanans are squaring off over efforts to roll back Mr. Clinton's decision, which created the new Missouri Breaks National Monument around the 90,000-acre Wild and Scenic River corridor, which encompasses more than 495,000 acres, including 82,000 acres of private land.
The monument designation did not need Congressional approval, which many in the West see as an abuse of federal power. Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton, concerned that local residents did not have enough say in the process, has asked states to come up with ways to reduce the size of the monuments or relax restrictions. On Tuesday a committee appointed by Gov. Judy Martz, a Republican, voted to recommend that the federal government shrink the national monument to 90,000 acres.
Supporters of the new monument in Montana contend that Governor Martz stacked the committee with monument opponents. 
"Committee members held proponents who testified in complete disdain," said Hugo Tureck, a rancher near Coffee Creek, outside the monument, and a director of a group called Friends of the Missouri Breaks. "It was very transparent." 
This is a familiar battleground in the West, where the agriculture, mining and drilling of the Old West economy go up against the environmental enthusiasm of the New West economy, based on tourism, hunting and fishing. 
And with the bicentennial of the Lewis and Clark expedition in 2004 expected to attract thousands of tourists, the monument is seen as "a golden goose that can lay eggs into perpetuity," said Marv Hoffer, a Lewistown city commissioner. 
"This is one of the few areas in the country where you can experience the West as Lewis and Clark saw it," said Stephen E. Ambrose, the historian and author of "Undaunted Courage," a book about the expedition.
"It's the most pristine part of the Lewis and Clark Trail," said Mr. Ambrose, who is working to keep the present boundaries. "It is precious to all Americans and it needs to be protected."
Meriwether Lewis was especially taken with the breaks, which are jagged white, dun and red sandstone cliffs that have been sculptured by wind and water into strangely shaped spires and hoodoos. "As we passed on," Lewis wrote in his famous, and often misspelled, journal, "it seemed those seens of visionary inchantment would never have an end."
In a sign of how the battle lines have been drawn over the breaks, the city commission of Lewistown, the hub of central Montana's ranch country, voted 5 to 0 in July for a resolution to protect the Missouri Breaks "to the greatest extent possible."
David Byerly, the former publisher of The Lewistown News-Argus and a Fergus County school board member, said that in Lewistown, a town of 5,800, 135 children graduated this year. The class of 2013 will have 85 members. "The rural way of life is a precious thing," said Mr. Byerly, who supports the monument. "But if you look at the numbers out there they're scary. We might want to freeze it in 1950 here, but it's not going to happen. The monument won't replace agriculture, but it's a ray of hope and we should grab it."
But some ranchers are infuriated because, they say, too much private land was included in the monument boundary. 
Matt Knox, a rancher near Winifred, Mont., and founder of a group called Missouri River Stewards, said the government had promised to acquire private land for the monument only on a "willing seller" basis.
"But if they want it bad enough, they can make us willing sellers by changing regulations and making things difficult," Mr. Knox said. "It's a scary process."
Craig Flentie, a spokesman for the Bureau of Land Management in Lewistown, said that while private lands lie within the boundaries of the monument, they would not be affected by monument regulations.
Monument status does not allow new leases for such uses as mining or oil and gas drilling, but allows existing uses, like ranching, to continue if they do not conflict with the goal of the momuent. The government is still working out details of its plan for the monument, with public participation.
There is a deep and abiding mistrust of the federal government in some communities in the West. At Tuesday's meeting ranchers posted a sign that said "U.S. Government, stop stealing private land," and a small boy carried a sign that read, "Don't let the feds take my daddy's farm." But despite some outbursts, the issue has simmered, not boiled. 
Some argue that it is a mistake for ranchers, many of whom use cheap federal grazing land and receive crop support payments, to fight the designation. 
"These ranchers are bringing the public to focus on the idea of subsidies, and we are cutting our own throat," said Mr. Tureck, who leases public land well below market cost, as do many in the breaks. "It makes the ranchers look extremely selfish. They don't want to share public lands with the public."

HEADLINE: TALKING POLITICS: Greenwich Village and SoHo; 
Concerns About Maintaining Successes of the Giuliani Era

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Richard Fitzgerald, a 49-year-old chauffeur who lives in Greenwich Village, was settled on a bench on a hot and muggy morning in Washington Square Park the other day. A police officer on a horse clip-clopped up a path to the side. Children crowded a playground, while dog owners ran their unleashed pets through a fenced-in field.
 And there was barely a drug dealer or homeless person in sight, an absence that Mr. Fitzgerald, who has been spending afternoons in the park since he was a teenager, noted with fresh approval and lingering astonishment. 
 "Oh, God, there is almost no way to measure how much improvement he has done," Mr. Fitzgerald said, the unnamed "he" being the city's soon-to-depart mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani. "I've lived here for 30 years, and I've hung out in this park for 30 years, and I feel so much better than I did 10 years ago," he said. "This park has really turned around. It's gotten cleaner, it's gotten safer." 
In the view of advisers to the mayoral candidates, there are few neighborhoods in New York where the quality-of-life improvements of the past eight years can be better measured than in the 66th Assembly District. It is a middle-class, mostly low-rise downtown patchwork that includes some of New York's most picturesque neighborhoods: Greenwich Village, SoHo, TriBeCa, Chelsea and Battery Park City among them. Its residents voted overwhelmingly against Mr. Giuliani when he was first elected mayor in 1993, and then voted to re-elect him in 1997. It was a Democratic district settling in behind a Republican mayor, in one sign of how politics in New York were changed over those eight years.
These days, voters in the 66th are pleased about the health of their city and the vibrancy of their neighborhoods, a reflection of the sentiment found in much of New York in a poll taken last week by The New York Times. They talk of tranquil parks, anxiety-free strolls at night, a bustling local economy, cleaner streets and a city that they seek to enjoy, rather than escape on summer weekends. 
And while Washington Square Park may still have its ragged edges, many of the residents who use it say the improvements over the past eight years are striking.
But with three weeks to go until the mayoral primary, there are signs of anxiety as voters begin to consider the imminent departure of a mayor whose interest seemed so closely tied to middle-class neighborhoods like these. 
"I am worried about the future," said Steven Man, 55, an optometrist who is a registered Democrat. "I don't know what will happen from here. It could go back to the way it was. I'm really not sure, and that troubles me."
And there is some concern about whether the next mayor -- who will come from what remains, for most people, an unfamiliar cast -- will, by choice or ability, continue the priorities that Mr. Giuliani has embraced. "None of the guys out there are qualified to do it; everybody out there is scary," said Andrew Nathan, 37, the former owner of a restaurant on Prince Street, Frontiere, which he closed a month ago as he prepared to move out of the city. (Mr. Nathan, a strong Giuliani supporter and a Republican, said the timing of his own departure had nothing to do with the change at City Hall.)
There are more than a few people like Marianne Salerno, 60, a medical assistant who lives in the West Village, who said they would vote for Mr. Giuliani again, were he not barred from seeking re-election by term limits. "I'm a little apprehensive," she said.
Still, this is the part of New York where the Reform Democrat movement came alive, and that produced Edward I. Koch (he still lives just off Washington Square Park), Bella S. Abzug, and the birth of the modern gay rights movement, at the Stonewall Inn on Christopher Street. Thus, if there is something approaching an approving consensus on some of Mr. Giuliani's policies, the mayor himself is another matter: many people do not seem unhappy that the city's first Republican mayor in 20 years is about to leave the stage.
"I think the city is a little bit safer -- and that's good," said Ilsa Gilbert, a writer of librettos, poetry and short stories, who lives in the West Village. "But I'm wondering at what cost. So I'm going to be glad that someone else is going to be mayor."
And if some voters are not upset at Mr. Giuliani's departure, they are nonetheless judging his successors by the benchmarks that he set for his government.
When asked the problems they wanted the next mayor to focus on, voters more often than not pointed to the kind of second-tier governmental functions that implicitly suggest an overall satisfaction with the way New York is delivering such basic services as police protection and garbage pickup. 
They talked about the park system -- which Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker and a Democratic mayoral candidate, recently identified as the one governmental department he would never cut as mayor -- or noise on the street, or municipal recreation programs, or cleaning up graffiti, or widening the new bicycle path along the Hudson River.
In a part of the city that has historically been identified with activist government, there was distress that parts of the city that had been of great concern to past Democratic administrations -- in particular, poorer New York -- had been neglected by Mr. Giuliani. 
Brian Herlihy, 28, who works for a fiber optics company, said the next mayor had to "focus a bit more on distributing the wealth, as opposed to getting New York back on its feet. I think Giuliani has done that."
Anita Fay, a writer who lives in Chelsea, said: "Housing issues really bother me. It's the chief issue. There are so many people that can afford good housing, and others get forced out. It's the issue of the next decade. For most people, housing is terrible; not for me, but for others. Rent is too high, and no one has a solution."
Similarly, the perceived deterioration of the public school system was a repeated concern. 
"Education -- that's all I want to hear," said Ronat Cooper, who was taking a break from her job at a publishing house to eat lunch at the park. "And more funding for your kids, and get them off the street, by offering programs to them." 
Ronald Barnes, 28, who works at Gap Kids and lives in Greenwich Village, also said education should be a top priority of the next mayor. "My son is 7, and he gets no help," he said. "They cut the summer youth programs."
Although there is little sign that the mayoral contest has stirred much interest, perceptions about the candidates, if indistinct ones, are beginning to come together. Not surprisingly, most people have taken notice of Michael R. Bloomberg, the heavy-spending Republican mayoral candidate. 
"Bloomberg is the only one you are hearing about right now," said Mr. Herlihy.
But in this case, attention is not necessarily a good thing. There are clearly reservations about Mr. Bloomberg's qualifications to go directly to the top job in City Hall, as well as some resentment about his heavy spending of his own money on the campaign.
"Bloomberg is just a rich guy running for mayor," said Paul Monahan, 41, a Democrat, and an independent contractor. Nino Condasta, 75, a Democrat, said: "Bloomberg I've heard bad things about. I've heard he's rich, pushy, and can afford to buy an election."
Mr. Fitzgerald said: "His money got him on the ticket. I don't think he's earned a place in politics."
And there is resistance to him because of his party affiliation, notwithstanding the fact that Mr. Bloomberg is a lifelong Democrat who switched his registration principally so that he would have a relatively clear field in which to run for mayor. "I wouldn't vote at this point for a Republican," said Ms. Gilbert. "I am so disgusted with everything that is going on there." 
On the other side, the impressions of the Democratic candidates -- Mark Green, the public advocate; Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller; Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president; and Mr. Vallone -- are much less formed, suggesting potential for change in the weeks ahead. "Right now, I think we've got a lot of good Democratic candidates," said Susan Morrow, a freelance designer. "I like Mark Green, I really do. And I like Hevesi; I think right now he's probably the best man. I mean, he doesn't have the glamour of some of the other candidates."
Matt Bodie, 32, a law instructor at New York University, said: "I guess I like Mark Green. His politics are similar to mine. I usually vote Democratic, but I'm a little worried about his ability to be mayor, a good executive. I like his policies on more of a national level."
Mr. Man said: "I know Hevesi is comptroller and smart about money. I think he'd be a better administrator than Green. Green doesn't seem to have the right personality for mayor. Ferrer is using racial things to win, and I think that it's terrible. I would never vote for him. He should be accentuating the things that are positive, the good things. Instead, he keeps talking about things that are bad."
Ms. Salerno said she had been put off when Mr. Hevesi turned up on television the other night campaigning with Abner Louima, the victim of an assault in a Brooklyn precinct house, who has endorsed Mr. Hevesi. "That has nothing to do with anything," she said. "I don't even know why they brought that as an up-front issue. Who cares? I thought that was in poor taste, and I don't think he should have done that." 
(But take heart, Mr. Hevesi: Mr. Monahan said, "I heard that Louima backed Hevesi, which would make me take another look.")
Ms. Salerno went on to say that she was uncomfortable about Mr. Ferrer because of the company he keeps. "May I be honest?" she asked. "He's a friend of Al Sharpton's. And I don't like Al Sharpton."

HEADLINE: Nasser Says Reductions in Jobs Won't BeLast Cutbacks at Ford 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Calif., Aug. 19 

 BODY:
Jacques Nasser, the chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, said late Saturday that the automaker would have to take steps beyond its announced job cuts to reduce costs.
 Mr. Nasser said Ford might cut production capacity if the United States economy shows no signs soon of rebounding over the next 12 to 18 months, which is the current outlook. Cutting production usually includes eliminating more jobs and could even involve closing a plant. 
 "This is an initial action," Mr. Nasser said of the job cuts announced on Friday. "There will be other actions that we need to take in other areas of the company. It will be how can we do things more efficiently, how can we make decisions more quickly," he told reporters here at the Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance, a celebration of luxury cars.
"We'll take the next three or four months to think it through, see what other actions are needed," he added.
Ford said on Friday that it would offer up to 5,000 white-collar employees in North America, or 10 percent of its salaried work force, a voluntary severance package. The company expects the plan would save $300 million to $400 million annually. Ford also lowered its earnings expectations for the year by more than 40 percent and said it would take a $900 million after-tax charge, mostly to cover the job cuts.
Nasser said the layoffs were necessary because of the halting economy, heated competition in the industry, and the costs associated with the massive recall of Firestone tires.
"We don't see any factor that's going to restore the robustness of the economy" in the next 12 to 18 months, he said. "We keep asking ourselves what will it be, what action will happen in the economy that will stimulate confidence in buying again, and we just don't see it."
Mr. Nasser said Ford would evaluate its global operations, which include the Mazda Motor Corporation of Japan and the foreign brands Volvo, Jaguar, Land Rover and Aston Martin, to see where other cost-cutting measures might be needed.

HEADLINE: Sell Peace, Not Arms 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Global Arms Sales Rise Again, and the U.S. Leads the Pack" (news article, Aug. 20): 
 The $18.6 billion in United States arms contracts to developing countries will undoubtedly fuel further conflicts and costs to human security in this decade and in decades to come. 
The underlying causes of security failures in developing countries lie in poverty, which can be eliminated through growth in trade, education, health and economic investments.
Selling weapons to countries in conflict will only increase the level of threat and risk to the United States' domestic and international security. It is also immoral to exploit global conflict in developing countries.

RONALD B. BRINN
Great Neck, N.Y., Aug. 20, 2001

The writer is a nongovernment representative at the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Fabricating A Crisis

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Last week the International Monetary Fund, which has no political stake in the debate over Social Security, told the prosaic truth: "the long-term financing problems of Social Security are not large" and "could be addressed through relatively small adjustments in the program's parameters." 
 But the Bush administration's hand-picked commission on Social Security reform -- which will meet behind closed doors tomorrow, violating the spirit if not the letter of the law -- wants you to believe that we must destroy the program in order to save it. To do this it must fabricate a crisis. 
 For example, the commission warns ominously about future financial shortfalls. It points out that in the year 2025 Social Security will pay $419 billion more in benefits than it collects in payroll taxes. It would spoil the effect to mention that this will be only 1 percent of G.D.P. A real party-pooper would point out that the provisions of the Bush tax cut -- which the administration insists is easily affordable -- will reduce revenue in 2025 by $700 billion. 
The commission's analysis also somehow ignores the $6 trillion in surpluses that the Social Security system, which currently collects much more in payroll taxes than it pays in benefits, will run between now and 2025. Where will the money go? Of course, one interpretation of that mysterious disappearance is that the commission believes the surpluses will be used not to pay future benefits to retirees, but to cover the revenue lost because of the tax cut -- a revenue loss that the I.M.F. says will be almost twice as large as the administration admits.
It's true that the Social Security system will eventually have to change the way it invests its surpluses -- but only because it will face an embarrassment of riches. At the moment, Social Security surpluses are being used to pay off federal debt, a perfectly sound way to use the money. But because federal debt to the public is only $3 trillion, Social Security will eventually have to start buying private stocks and bonds. That is, unless big deficits reappear -- a project on which the Bush administration has made a good start. 
The commission claims that letting Social Security buy private assets would be a disaster, that unless retirees' money is placed into private accounts it will be squandered to serve political ends. But the I.M.F. argues that "such investments could be managed in a manner that would minimize the risk of political interference." That argument rests on hard evidence. State and local government pension funds own more than $2 trillion in private-sector assets, and after some highly publicized incidents of politicization in the early 1980's the record has been extremely clean. In fact, government-run pension funds have earned the same rate of return as private funds. 
Meanwhile, a system of private accounts would create a cash crisis, because baby boomers, whose payroll taxes help pay benefits to today's retirees, couldn't count on younger workers to do the same for them. Private accounts would also expose workers to a lot of risk, and managing millions of small individual accounts would be very expensive. 
That last point is important. A forthcoming study from the Congressional Budget Office suggests that as much as 30 percent of the value of private accounts would end up consumed by administrative costs. This compares with costs that are less than 1 percent of benefits in today's Social Security system.
The outlines of a plan that would sustain Social Security without destroying it are clear: Allow the system to invest some of its surplus in private assets, and close the system's modest long-run financial shortfall by making minor adjustments to benefits and rescinding part of the recent tax cut. After all, a recent study by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities found that the revenue lost because of the Bush tax cut will be more than twice the sum needed to secure Social Security without any reform at all for the next 75 years. The administration tried to refute that calculation, playing its usual game of statistical three-card monte -- "Look, honey, I just found $4 billion under the cushion, and 60 lines of stem cells too!" -- but the center's estimate matches those of the I.M.F. and other independent organizations. 
The truth is that the only serious threat to Social Security comes from those who want to panic us into junking the system, when all it needs are minor repairs.

HEADLINE: For Fall, Some Swash, Some Buckle and a Tougher Look 

BYLINE:  By CATHY HORYN 

 BODY:
Reflected in the windows of Saks Fifth Avenue and Bergdorf Goodman last week were pedestrians in summertime straw and linen inspecting the latest crop of equestrian gear and racy peasant chic -- a reflection that if it's August in New York, it must be deep fall among the fashion peddlers.
 In the September issue of Vogue, 10 pages of Nadja Auermann throwing out rebel looks in thigh-high boots and furry Russian toques ("She'll lead you on with toques to die for," trills a caption for a fox) somehow jibe with what Anne Slowey, writing in Elle, found out about Russian women. They can't fill up fast enough on fashion's gaudy treats. And now, apparently, a lot of other women want to look like the Russians. They want the diamonds and killer boots. They want the naughty pink Gucci peasant blouse, the savage Dior furs, the pushiness of skintight Dolce & Gabbana flares. Above all, they want to look tough . . . She'll lead you on with toques to die for. 
 Even the model sitting poolside in this season's Versace advertisements, with a mansion rising up behind her like a cardboard Tara, has that grave and hungry look of Ms. Filler Up. 
So what gives with all this hard extravagance with the economy in a soft slump? Just fashion changing direction, looking for a fresh hit. Retail sales have been off since the end of last year, and nobody's hiding that fact. "It's tough out there," said Kal Ruttenstein, the fashion director of Bloomingdale's. "Our trunk shows haven't been doing as well as in previous seasons, and purse strings are tighter."
High on Mr. Ruttenstein's probable list of fall hits is the peasant look fueled by Tom Ford's collection for Yves Saint Laurent. This consists of nothing more than a ruched blouse made (preferably) of gauzy fabric and worn with a slim skirt or, better, tight, low-slung jeans in a vintage wash. Mr. Ruttenstein has such tops for as low as $98. To get the mother of these blouses, from Saint Laurent, with nicely done ruching, you add a zero and multiply by two.
A few blocks away, at Bergdorf Goodman, the windows had a Russian-peasant-bohemian theme going, with a souped-up Roberto Cavalli fur coat and more of Mr. Ford's modern Carmen collection. "If I had to pick one collection that expresses the season for us, it's without a doubt Saint Laurent," said Robert Burke, the fashion director of Bergdorf. "It appeals to a wide age group. It can be happy Gypsy or hippy bohemian." Such buzzy phrases aside, Mr. Burke said he thought the freewheeling Saint Laurent Gypsy story (with ankle-laced sandals, which now have a waiting list of customers) offered fashion seekers a respite from last fall's ladylike chic. "It leaves room for more self-expression," he said.
The clothes that are being pushed in stores and magazines first appeared on the runways six months ago, before anyone knew exactly what would fly. And in retrospect, those collections were like the biggest sneeze you ever saw -- a real head-clearer. Gone was the congestion of Park Avenue suits and prim coats reeking of the Colony, circa 1969. In its place came a slightly tougher chic, boy meets girl, with flat or low-heel boots; distressed leather or roughed-up shearling; minimal tops with funky couture embellishments; pinstripe or muddy plaid pants ($35 at H&M); the odd, scampering debutante in jodhpurs and a blanket cape closed with a snaffle-bit buckle. 
Both Michael Kors and Ralph Lauren chose last February to go that safe, secure horsy route. And, last week, store executives from Saks to Neiman Marcus said that these have been among their best-selling collections among early deliveries.
"The Kors riding pants have been selling out," said Joan Kaner, the fashion director of Neiman, adding that other strong sellers have been leather and suede jackets in dusky colors like whiskey and cognac and fur hats, especially those toques. "And we've been getting people who want to know when the Balenciaga shaped pantsuit is coming in," Ms. Kaner said. She was referring to Nicolas Ghesquiere's boned, nearly hourglass-shape jacket, which stood out as one of the more distinct silhouettes for fall. In fact, almost every store that carries Balenciaga, including Jeffrey and Barneys New York, has already sold much of what it has received, including a $900 satchel bag, which went quickly at Barneys.
Not everybody has gone horse crazy. "I can tell you, we don't have a single customer coming in the store saying, 'I want equestrian,' " Julie Gilhart, vice president for fashion merchandising at Barneys, said with a laugh. Which is not to say that Barneys isn't selling those Kors jodhpurs or Prada riding boots. Ms. Gilhart said that what sells is something unique, whether or not it falls into a broad buzz trend. Lace is an example. "It might be Victorian lace or mod lace, it doesn't matter -- it's selling," she said. "People want something that says to everyone else, 'This is mine, not yours.' They don't want to share."
And, in that spirit, one of the best-selling collections has been that of Comme des Garcons, based on corsets and lingerie lace, with accessories like strap-on conical bras to be worn over a jacket. Linda Dresner, the boutique on Park Avenue, keeps selling the same style of Comme des Garcons shoes right out of the window. Black and long of toe, with a jaunty rhinestone buckle, they look like something the offspring of a pilgrim and a rocker might wear.
Though people talk about self-expression, there is, not surprisingly, more consensus in what the leading magazines are showing than solidly individual points of view. Vogue has Linda Evangelista on its cover. And inside, for many pages, she gives the clothes she wears a real spark, an easy naturalness, that younger, blander models just can't pull off. But then it has Ms. Auermann sporting rocker raccoon in "The Wild Bunch," which is not too far from the "Call of the Wild" in Harper's Bazaar. 
Elle has toques, too -- piled with jewels, surrounded by lace and finished off with that familiar "From Russia With Love" opulence. But Elle also gives weight to a fall style that most other magazines ignored or overlooked: athletic-inspired clothes, from Dior to Chanel, and photographed for the magazine by Karl Lagerfeld.
While it remains to be seen how many souffle-size toques and capacious Elmer Fudd trapper hats will actually materialize on the streets this winter, one thing is certain: people will be walking a little closer to the ground. Flat boots are ubiquitous and selling -- including Gucci's over-the-knee boot, based on a 1960's Saint Laurent style, and Manolo Blahnik's midcalf biker boot.
As Ms. Kaner said, "It's boots, boots, boots."
Jeffrey Kalinsky, owner of Jeffrey, agreed: "The new shoe for fall is the boot. Last spring, the new pump was the mule."
As this was sinking in, Mr. Kalinsky was asked what the new pump for fall might be.
He paused, as if mentally running through his entire shoe inventory, which must be considerable, then said: "The boot is the new pump."

HEADLINE: Kalkan Journal; 
Come to Me, All You Big Spenders

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: KALKAN, Turkey, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
The village rises gently from the bright brimming bay on the Mediterranean, its whitewashed houses climbing the folds of the hills in a more or less orderly fashion.
 The place was once quiet and unchanging, a balance of fishermen and olive farmers where the brilliant sun and royal blue sea were the fortune. Today the measure is more conventional -- tourist dollars and real estate values. 
 "Kalkan is not spoiled, but some things could go wrong if we are not smart," Hakan Basoz, who traded teaching for running a tour company, said as he navigated his minivan along the road above the sea and pointed out the new houses and small hotels under construction.
Kalkan, with a year-round population of 1,500, is still peaceful. The only congestion is the occasional overflow of yachts in the marina. A few thousand tourists a season visit the shops and stay in the small hotels or at Club Patara, an elegant upscale resort. 
But Turkey is on the cusp of what many in the field predict will be phenomenal growth in tourism, and the people here along the Mediterranean in southwestern Turkey and in hundreds of other towns and cities are eager to share in the anticipated prosperity.
Expectations are especially high because as Turkey endures the worst economic crisis in its modern history tourism is the only sector that is thriving. The number of visitors is 20 percent ahead of last year, with a record 12.5 million tourists expected and revenues estimated at $10 billion.
Government officials portray tourism as the country's salvation, predicting a doubling of visitors and revenue in the next four to five years. Even more modest estimates forecast steady double-digit growth.
"For next year and after we aim at better figures with a better capacity for high-quality tourism," said Cengiz Yucel, head of research and development for the Association of Turkish Travel Agencies in Istanbul.
The demographics of tourism provide clues for where the country is today and where its travel industry and government hope it will be tomorrow.
Europeans see Turkey as a sun-drenched bargain, particularly with this year's devaluation of the Turkish currency. They tend to come on bargain tours and spend their time on the beaches of the Aegean and Mediterranean.
Germans are the most common tourists. Bypassing Istanbul and the historic sites, they flock to the all-inclusive vacation villages dotting the Mediterranean coast of southern Turkey. Russians and the British are next, followed by the Dutch and French.
Americans rank sixth, with about 500,000 visitors last year. They usually travel individually or in small groups and visit Istanbul and places of historic interest. Americans spend more money than other people -- an average of $1,268 per person compared with $769 by Germans and $502 by Russians, according to the Central Bank of Turkey.
With an international promotion budget of $30 million this year, the government is trying to keep the bargain tourists while making new appeals to bigger spenders from the United States, Japan and other more distant countries. Much of the new development is aimed at upscale tourists, with an emphasis on historic sites as well as the dazzling coastline.
The tourism industry was built up in the 1980's by the government through cheap loans and tax breaks for private investors. The way the government and developers handle the new push for growth will determine how places like Kalkan fare in the future.
Skimming across crystal clear water in his speedboat, Turhan Kaso pointed out the new road being carved into the hillside cupping the southern end of Kalkan Bay. "That is a monstrous mistake," he said. "They will ruin the view for many just to build houses for a few."
Mr. Kaso, an Istanbul architect and builder, first visited Kalkan in the 1970's. Though the area contains stunning Lycian tombs carved into cliffs and other ancient sites, he was in search of new places to dive. He found wonderful spots among the small islands outside the bay and returned many times.
For years, he dreamed of building a vacation house here. By the time he started work in the late 1980's the dream had grown a bit. The result was Club Patara, a honeycomb of 200 villas and a 60-room hotel nestled on a hillside across the bay from the village.
The development is a sharp contrast to the overbuilt and crowded vacation villages farther south toward Antalya. Mr. Kaso used natural stone, abundant greenery and earth tones on his gently rounded buildings to fit the resort with the environment. Trees and winding pathways conceal the houses. 
"I had no desire to destroy what brought me here in the first place," said Mr. Kaso, maneuvering his boat toward the dock. "I have a house here, too."
In the decade since Club Patara opened, Kalkan has undergone a slow, steady transition from rural village to tourist town. The ground floors of village houses that once held goats and sheep were cleaned up and turned into restaurants and carpet shops. Many larger homes became small hotels, all of which seem to have rooftop restaurants and menus in English. Instead of commercial fishing, boats are used for sport fishing or scuba diving.
As the growth pushed beyond the village boundaries, some people grew anxious. Mr. Basoz cited a larger village 20 miles away where uncontrolled building has damaged its character and charm.
He and others formed a foundation to limit growth in Kalkan. The mayor and other civic leaders were sympathetic and restrictions were approved. But the lure of tourist dollars is proving a difficult force to counter.
"My uncle owns 300,000 square meters of land" -- about 75 acres -- "on the far end of the bay and he wants to sell to a developer," Mr. Basoz said. "I tell him he needs to wait and we need orderly growth. But it's hard to wait."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Turhan Kaso, who developed Club Patara outside the Turkish village of Kalkan, surveying his domain. (Douglas Frantz/The New York Times) Map of Turkey highlighting Kalkan: Turkey is hoping to attract affluent tourists to places like Kalkan.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
MajorGauges Move Higher in a Day of Careful Trading

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks were higher yesterday after an optimistic outlook from the home-improvement retailer Lowe's raised hopes that consumer spending would bolster the slowing economy. But activity was subdued in advance of an expected cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
 The Fed is expected to reduce interest rates for a seventh time this year to try to jump-start the economy, but money managers said they were more interested in whether the Fed thought the economy was picking up. 
 "Everyone's waiting for the Fed to see what it says," said Mark Coffelt, who helps manage Texas Capital's Value and Growth portfolio. "The key is their attitude. Hopefully, they'll say, ' The economy is recovering, but if it's not, we'll lower interest rates more.' " 
The Conference Board, a business research group, said its index of leading economic indicators scored a fourth consecutive month of gains in July, hinting that the economy could show signs of recovery in the months ahead.
Lowe's bright outlook also helped increase retailing stocks on optimism that consumer spending might remain strong.
"Consumer spending is the linchpin right now, and comments from Lowe's this morning suggest consumers are O.K.," said Crit Thomas, head of growth equities at National City Investment Management. "If consumers can tread water through the end of the year, we'll feel a lot more comfortable about the stock market."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 79.29 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 10,320.07. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 9.44 points, or 0.8 percent, to finish at 1,171.41. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index gained 14.34 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,881.35.
About 890 million shares traded on the Big Board while 1.16 billion traded on the Nasdaq, making it the fourth-lightest session of the year.
Investors' focus was squarely on the Fed's next move. A poll of 25 primary dealers of United States government securities last Thursday found that they all expected the Federal Open Market Committee to cut the federal funds rate a quarter point today.
The Fed has already brought the federal funds rate on overnight bank lending down to 3.75 percent.
"People are just watching and waiting to find out what happens tomorrow," said Jack Shaughnessy, chief investment strategist at the brokerage firm Advest. "There's a possibility they may cut rates by as much as 50 basis points, because the stock market has been languishing."
Lowe's climbed $2.80, to $37.84, after reporting that earnings rose 18 percent, as the homebuilding and remodeling markets remained healthy despite the slowing economy. The company also said income tax rebate checks had helped fuel some of a sales increase.
Among other retail building stocks, Home Depot rose 57 cents, to $49.80.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Decline
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as traders worried about the Federal Reserve would signal that today's expected cut in interest rates might be the last for the year as the economy picks up.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 17/32, to a price of 100 25/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.90 percent from 4.83 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 15/32, to 98 28/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.45 percent from 5.42 percent on Friday.

SECTION: Section C; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 342 words

HEADLINE: Economic Indicators Rose For the 4th Month in July 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators rose in July for a fourth consecutive month, suggesting that the economy will strengthen by the end of the year, a private research firm said today.
 The Conference Board's index, a gauge of economic activity over the next three to six months, rose 0.3 percent. That matched the increase in June and reflected a rise in the money supply and a drop in first-time claims for unemployment benefits. 
 The index is "flashing a signal that the economy will be doing better as we head into the second half of the year" after the weakest 12 months of growth since the last recession, said Joshua Shapiro, chief United States economist at Maria Fiorini Ramirez Inc. in New York.
The index of coincident indicators, a gauge of current economic activity, rose 0.1 percent in July after falling 0.1 percent in June. The index of lagging indicators dropped 0.7 percent last month, compared with a 0.9 percent decrease the previous month.
A combination of lower interest rates and advance tax refund checks that the government started mailing last month may spur the economy by enticing consumers to spend more at retailers.
The four-month string of gains in the leading indicators index is the first since October 1999 to January 2000. The Conference Board compiles the index from eight previously reported economic statistics and estimates of two others.
Still, corporate profits fell more than 16 percent in the second quarter, the worst performance since the third quarter of 1991, based on reports from 424 companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Thomson Financial/ First Call.
Weak profits and sluggish growth help explain why Federal Reserve policy makers, at their meeting on Tuesday, are expected to lower the overnight lending rate between banks for a seventh time this year.
By lowering interest rates, the Fed "has moved to support demand and, we trust, help lay the groundwork for the economy to achieve maximum sustainable growth," Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told Congress last month.

HEADLINE: A Messenger to China Business; 
U.S.-Trained Telecom Chief Builds a New, Hybrid Model

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING 

 BODY:
Edward Tian says he is on a mission to bring Western-style business practices to China. But what lured him back to his native land from Texas in 1995 was less a spirit of patriotism than a sense of insecurity.
 "I concluded there was very little chance I would become a successful entrepreneur like Jerry Yang," said Mr. Tian, comparing himself with the Chinese-American founder of Yahoo. "I was too old and my English wasn't good enough." 
 That's setting the bar pretty high. Mr. Tian, 38, is no slouch: he speaks rapid-fire English and holds a Ph.D. from Texas Tech University. And after starting a successful technology venture in Dallas, he was chosen by the Chinese government to run a pioneering state-owned company. 
Perhaps because of his credentials and his keen ambition, Mr. Tian has faced sky-high expectations ever since he became chief executive of the company, China Netcom, in 1999. And as the fledgling telecommunications company has hit some bumps, managing those expectations has become an unavoidable part of his job.
China Netcom was started at the urging of Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, who hoped to create a class of state-owned, but Western-style companies able to take on the hulking state monopolies. Netcom's main business is delivering high-speed data communications; its chief rival is China Telecom, the leviathan that dominates voice and data traffic.
With Mr. Zhu's blessing and four other powerful backers -- the Chinese Academy of Sciences, the ministry of railways, the Shanghai municipal government and the State Administration of Radio, Film and Television -- Netcom seemed destined to be at the vanguard of the nation's economic transformation.
It has not worked out that way, at least not yet. The sluggish pace of deregulation, China's murky political environment, the drying up of capital markets and the woes of the global telecommunications industry have conspired against China Netcom's efforts to build a franchise. Far from defining the future, Mr. Tian is being carried along by events largely out of his control.
"Edward is the poster child for the opening of China's corporate sector," said Duncan Clark, managing director of BDA China Ltd., a consulting firm in Beijing. "But he wants to be more than a catalyst. And Netcom is having trouble adjusting to the massive shifts in the industry."
Few experts are ready to dismiss Mr. Tian. His strategic vision remains compelling and his political connections are golden. (Netcom's investors include Jiang Mianheng, the son of President Jiang Zemin.) But Mr. Tian's troubles are a case study in how hard it is to compete in China, where each step forward can be thwarted by arbitrary regulations and baffling politics.
"If there is anyone who can take on the bureaucracy and make an impact, it is him," said Henry Lee, managing director of Hendale Asset Management in Hong Kong. "Will the bureaucrats let him? Only time will tell."
Mr. Tian professes to be unfazed by the hurdles. Sitting in his elegantly appointed office in Netcom's headquarters here, and flanked by an antique statue of a Chinese warrior, he offers his views on why China is the world's most promising market for data communications services.
In part, it is the familiar argument that size matters: China already has 25 million Internet users who represent just 2 percent of the population. In five years, Mr. Tian says, China will have 300 million Internet devices of one kind or another: laptop computers, hand-held electronic organizers, mobile phones.
In contrast to the United States, where the Internet developed in an anarchic manner, in China the government has tightly regulated companies that can provide Internet access and other data services. China Telecom has the bulk of the business while Netcom and a handful of smaller companies fight for the rest.
The lack of competition, Mr. Tian said, means that a company with the right licenses and political connections can build up a valuable franchise. By regulating the number of new entrants, he said, China can avoid the surplus of fiber optic networks in the United States and Europe.
"You can learn from the mistakes of other countries," Mr. Tian said. "Since we have a clean sheet of paper, we can do it right."
To serve this virgin market, China Netcom has laid a 5,300-mile fiber optic network, known as an Internet backbone, through 17 cities from Beijing in the north to Guangzhou in the south. The first phase of the network, completed last October, soaked up much of the company's initial financing of $300 million.
All this is a remarkable feat for the son of two scientists, who a decade ago was in Lubbock, Tex., researching a thesis on a type of poisonous weed that grows in Texas. After earning his Ph.D., Mr. Tian moved in 1993 to Dallas, where he and a partner, James Ding, searched the Chinese-American community, trying to attract investors for a venture that was to provide online information about China.
Among those they approached was Henry Lee, then a money manager for the Bass brothers. Mr. Lee recalls Mr. Tian as a fountain of ideas, brimming with enthusiasm. Still, Mr. Lee turned him down, in part because a China venture seemed too far afield for his employers who were known for real estate investments. He also questioned how Mr. Tian's online service could compete against media giants like Reuters.
Mr. Tian and Mr. Ding retooled the venture into a systems integration company, AsiaInfo Holdings. They moved the company to Beijing in 1995, and it was listed that way on the Nasdaq stock market last year. Mr. Ding remains its chief executive.
Given Mr. Tian's ambition, his friends said it was no surprise that he would leap at the chance to do something grander. But there was another motive. Even in Texas, where Mr. Tian said he acquired a taste for country music, barbecue and square dancing, his homeland always beckoned.
"He's got a patriotic fervor that sets him apart from other Chinese capitalists, who are purely profit-driven," Mr. Lee said.
At the same time, Mr. Tian wants to build a money-making enterprise. And he does not have the necessary tools yet.
While his network is as sophisticated as that of China Telecom, Netcom lacks local connections to hundreds of millions of customers. Mr. Tian's business model requires that the government break China Telecom's stranglehold on the nation's local and long-distance phone service.
Beijing has taken some steps in that direction. It detached China Telecom's mobile phone operation and set it up as a separate, publicly traded company, China Mobile. It took the company's paging network and handed it to a rival cellular company, China Unicom, which also trades in New York and Hong Kong.
And it has announced vague plans to carve up the rump China Telecom and take all or part of it public. But a stock offering has been shelved while competing ministries haggle over how to divide the company's assets. These include the local and long-distance networks, as well as the data network, which carries more than 80 percent of the country's traffic.
"Deregulation is going to happen, but it's going to take time," said X. D. Yang, a managing director for Asia at the Carlyle Group, a private investment firm. Mr. Yang, in his previous job as a banker at Goldman, Sachs, negotiated the firm's $60 million investment in China Netcom.
While the politicking continues in Beijing, China Telecom maintains its dominance in Mr. Tian's market. So Netcom must make do by pushing into ancillary markets, where it can find opportunities. These businesses range from Internet data centers to prepaid Internet telephone cards.
Originally, Netcom was to be a Chinese version of Qwest or Level 3, a wholesaler of capacity on its network. It has turned into an eclectic purveyor of telecommunications services. For all that, analysts estimate that Netcom generated just $36.5 million in sales last year.
Now, the company is changing course again, focusing on providing data services to big corporate customers. By the end of the year, Netcom plans to wire 700 office buildings in 33 cities with broadband connections. It will then link the buildings to its fiber optic network and Internet data centers, covering what it estimates to be 70 percent of China's corporate market.
"This company has undergone one of the biggest restructurings I've ever seen in the last six months," said Peter Lovelock, an analyst at MadeforChina.com, a technology consulting company in Beijing.
Mr. Tian acknowledges that his protean business plan has confused some investors. "I still face a lot of difficulty explaining the opportunity of the Chinese market to the outside world, especially the investor community," he said.
In addition to Goldman, Sachs, others who have invested in Netcom -- $325 million in total -- include Dell Computer, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, the Bank of China and the China Construction Bank.
The financing was an endorsement of Mr. Tian's vision. But it imposes an extra layer of scrutiny. Mr. Tian submits a financial report to his investors each month. He said Netcom was losing money -- he would not say how much -- but he predicted that it would break even in two years.
Goldman, Sachs, for one, is not anxious about Netcom's bottom line. "We take a very long-term view on China," said S. Shirley Lin, managing director of Goldman's direct investment arm in Asia.
Mr. Tian said the investors help by offering him advice on how to build and run a commercial enterprise. He said this was his toughest challenge -- tougher even than navigating the Chinese bureaucracy.
Netcom has almost 3,000 employees, and is adding 200 a month. Mr. Tian recruited Western-educated Chinese from companies like Microsoft, Oracle and McKinsey, the consulting firm, as top executives. Now, he must hire middle managers able to run a fiber optic network and sell advanced services.
Mr. Tian has devised a performance-based compensation plan for his managers. He says Netcom is one of the few state-owned Chinese enterprises that draws a distinction between shareholders, directors and executives.
Still, in a country that believes one man can make history, China Netcom remains inextricably linked to Edward Tian. Mr. Tian is not only aware of this, but he seems to relish the idea that he is a legend in the making -- perhaps even some day achieving the status inside China that technology industry icons like William H. Gates or Steven P. Jobs hold in the United States.
"My hero is Steve Jobs," he said. "I always wanted to become like him. I wanted to go to the Wild West -- and the Wild West is China."

HEADLINE: Survey Indicates Business Travel May Pick Up 

BYLINE:  By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
The sharp drop in business travel may be beginning to bottom out, a survey of travel managers indicated yesterday, but experts in the $185-billion-a-year industry warned that strong growth is unlikely to return for quite a while to airlines and hotels that cater to the corporate market.
 The National Business Travel Association released a survey of travel managers at 200 domestic companies that found increased optimism about sending more people on the road. The survey, conducted from Aug. 9 to Aug. 14, indicated that 16 percent of the travel managers plan on spending more on business trips next year, while 57 percent said they would spend at the same level as this year. 
 "Corporations are going to begin resuming business travel, but they're going to continue being cautious," said Marianne McInerney, executive director of the group. 
"This is the first time this year that we've seen a signal that the cutbacks are ending," she said. But it is "a yellow light," she added, "not a green light."
As a result, airlines in particular are facing further intense competition for the corporate traveler.
This year, as the business travel market plunged, corporate managers took the opportunity to negotiate lower-priced contracts with airlines and other suppliers. Even when more normal times resume, Ms. McInerney said, airlines and hotels will need to "show a willingness to pare back" some of the highly optimistic revenue projections they made in recent years based on dependable, sharp annual rises in air fares and hotel room rates.
In the survey, slightly over half of the travel managers said they negotiated discounts of up to 10 percent this year as airlines and hotels scrambled to hang on to a share of the smaller number of business customers, who account for about two-thirds of revenue for domestic airlines.
Travel industry analysts warned that projections that business travel would double over the next five years should be treated cautiously. Instead, some said, tighter corporate travel policies widely adopted in the last six months requiring more use of lower-fare advance-purchase air tickets, and less expensive hotel chains, are likely to curtail big gains.
"We're not going to get back to the normal routine," said Michael Boyd, president of the Boyd Group, an airline consulting firm. "The economics of air travel have changed. While business travel is not going to decline, it's not going to grow anything like some people say it will."
This year, Mr. Boyd said, airlines stung by declining revenues from corporate travel have rapidly shifted to smaller planes on many popular business routes, in new strategies to extract more yield per flight from the highest-paying customers.
On such routes, "you might cut your costs in half, but you keep those 40 key business passengers that you want to keep," he said.
Airlines will be intent on renewing their appeals to their most prized passengers once a more normal business climate returns, analysts said. Many of those passengers are business travelers whose schedules and preferences make them less likely than leisure travelers to accept the restrictions of the cheapest coach fares, even if they are traveling on less expensive tickets than before. But at the top of the industry's food chain are the most frequent travelers, who are more likely to expect the comforts of business-class or first-class travel, either through upgrades or by paying premium fares.
Especially on long-haul flights, many airlines are anticipating greater competition for those passengers, even though business travelers in general are notably resistant to competitive lures because they are bonded by frequent-flier bonus programs to certain carriers.
"Without question the biggest driver in the corporate traveler's airline choice is frequent-flier miles," said Martin Mosley, the marketing director for North America, Central America and Asia for LanChile, the Chilean airlines. "But I think convenience and comfort is right up there these days." 
For frequent fliers on domestic flights, one of the more striking experiences in recent months has been the easy availability of upgrades from coach to first-class seats.
Today, especially on domestic airlines, "first class is full of frequent-flier upgrades," Mr. Mosley said. "What used to be prestigious is no longer."
Like many other airlines that regard the premium-cabin passenger as their main profit center, LanChile has expanded business-class seating on its long-haul flights. But LanChile, like other international carriers that depend heavily on passengers paying premium fares, tries to keep the front-of-the-plane seats for customers paying full freight.
On LanChile, Mr. Mosley said, "we'll let seats go empty versus upgrading somebody just for the sake of it."
"We feel that the people who paid for a first-class or business-class seat feel that they should be sitting next to other people who paid for a first-class or business-class seat. They don't want to sit next to someone who's upgraded their way in. We're very strong on not devaluing the product."
In general, airlines, and especially domestic carriers in the United States, do not like talking directly about such class distinctions. But once business travel again hits its stride, many carriers can be expected to market more aggressively the service, the comfort and the status associated with premium-class seating at premium fares.
Last year, in moves that were later imitated by other carriers, British Airways and Virgin Atlantic, two competitors on the lucrative trans-Atlantic routes, completed expensive outlays on expanded business-class cabins, with seats that fold down into beds and amenities like preflight meals in private airport lounges and, on Virgin, in-flight massages.
Despite the current recession in business travel, that trend appears to be slowly continuing, even as revenues have dropped and passenger load fallen.
For example, Singapore Airlines announced last week that it is spending $100 million to expand its business-class cabins, including adding flat-bed seats, on its 45 long-haul 747 and 777 aircraft. The same day, Cathay Pacific Airways, noting British Airway's success with its new premium services, said it was planning to expand its own long-haul business-class cabins.
British Airway's strategy has been "to reduce overall capacity and really focus on the front of the airplane," said John Lampl, a spokesman for the carrier.
"They're all going to be doing it," Mr. Boyd said. Whatever their loyalties from frequent-flier programs, airlines will need to work harder to put a greater percentage of premium passengers in their seats, he continued. "That's where the money is. The money is that business traveler."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Evaporating Budget Surplus Sets Up a Political Battle
Both the White House and Congress are set to confirm that the budget surplus outside of Social Security has all but evaporated for the next few years, and Democrats are planning to intensify their attacks on President Bush's fiscal management.
 The combination of the administration's tax cut and the slowing economy has shaved roughly $120 billion from the surplus for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, administration officials and Congressional budget analysts said. That should leave the surplus for the year at about $160 billion. Page A1. 

U.S. Slump Drags Down Mexico
Mexico has been dragged into recession by the faltering United States economy, taking a toll on millions of Mexicans. A3.

Condit to Be Interviewed on ABC
ABC said that the correspondent Connie Chung would interview Representative Gary A. Condit of California on Thursday in one of the most sought-after news interviews in recent years. The interview with Mr. Condit, who has been at the center of widespread media coverage of the disappearance of Chandra Levy, a federal government intern, is expected to be among the most-watched television programs of the summer. C8.

Investment Bank Hires Counsel
Credit Suisse First Boston, which is at the center of investigations into how new stocks were sold on Wall Street in the late 1990's, hired Gary G. Lynch, a former director of enforcement for the Securities and Exchange Commission, as its general counsel. C2.

Fujitsu to Cut 10% of Employees
Fujitsu, one of Japan's leading makers of personal computers, semiconductors and communication equipment, said that it would eliminate 16,400 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, as it struggles with the slump in technology spending. World Business, Section W.

Stocks Climb in a Modest Rally
Stocks rose after an optimistic outlook from the home-improvement retailer Lowe's raised hopes that consumer spending would bolster the slowing economy. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 79.29 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,320.07. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 9.44 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,171.41. The Nasdaq composite index gained 14.34 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,881.35. C9.

The index of leading economic indicators rose 0.3 percent in July, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, suggesting that the economy will strengthen by the end of the year, the Conference Board said. C2.

Toys 'R' Us Reports a Loss
Toys "R" Us reported a fiscal second-quarter loss as it spent money to renovate stores to win back customers from Wal-Mart. The loss met analysts' lowered estimates. John Eyler, the company's chief executive, is remodeling stores, retraining staff and adding exclusive items to win back customers. Shares of Toys "R" Us rose $1.62, to $24.02. C7.

Ames Department Stores sought bankruptcy protection as competition with Wal-Mart has left it struggling to pay its debts. C7.

Baycol Shows Communication Lapse
Experts say the story of Baycol, the cholesterol-lowering drug that Bayer withdrew after it was linked to 31 deaths, shows the communication failure that has occurred before and may occur again with other drugs. F1.

Many Opting for Generic Prozac
Merck's health benefits unit said that most of its customers who take the antidepressant Prozac had opted for the generic version that became available this month. C9.

Reality Show Not Entirely Real
The Paramount Television Group confirmed that some of the scenes in the reality show "Manhunt" -- which purports to show events in Hawaii -- were actually shot in a Los Angeles park after filming was completed. C8.

HEADLINE: U.S. BALKS ON PLAN TO GET PLUTONIUM OUT OF WARHEADS 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 

 BODY:
A program conceived by the Clinton administration to rid the world of 100 tons of American and Russian weapons-grade plutonium is likely to be abandoned by the Bush administration, according to people who have been briefed about the project.
 Under the plan, which was first proposed in the mid-90's, 50 tons of American plutonium and 50 tons of Russian plutonium would be taken out of nuclear weapons and either converted into fuel for nuclear reactors or rendered useless for weapons by mixing it with with highly radioactive nuclear waste, a process known as immobilization. 
 When the plan was drafted, Clinton administration officials said the program would reduce the risk that the plutonium would fall into the wrong hands, where it could easily be turned into weapons.
By reducing the availability of weapons-grade plutonium, the project had the added benefit of bolstering treaties between the United States and Russia to cut the number of nuclear warheads deployed by each side, by making it harder to turn plutonium from decommissioned weapons back into warheads. 
Bush administration officials deny that the program is dead, but acknowledge that it has difficulties, primarily financial ones.
"The issue is under review," said an administration official who would speak only if not identified. "We've made no secret of that. But no decisions have been made."
But the official continued, "It's no secret that there are a lot of equities to balance here."
One major equity, he said, is money. Early this year the Energy Department predicted a cost of $6.6 billion, about triple the initial estimates, to convert the American stocks to fuel for civilian nuclear reactors. It put Russia's cost at $1.76 billion, which is money Russia does not have.
The expectation under the Clinton administration was that the United States and other rich countries would help pay, but no concrete pledges were ever made.
In 1999 the Clinton administration did agree to pay a consortium of power companies $130 million to use plutonium that the government would convert into fuel. But the conversion factories are not yet built, and the conversion itself was contingent on an agreement with the Russians to take similar steps to dispose of plutonium from their weapons.
Despite the program's expected benefits, the Bush administration's proposed Energy Department budget this spring did not include the money needed to mix some of the plutonium with nuclear waste. 
The second path -- converting it to fuel for American nuclear reactors, the strategy the Clinton administration hoped would induce the Russians to do the same -- also appears likely to be dropped soon.
"There is no enthusiasm for it whatsoever," said a Congressional aide who was briefed by officials of the National Security Council, referring both to the current strategy of immobilization and to conversion to reactor fuel. 
The issue of what to do with plutonium from decommissioned nuclear weapons has haunted policy makers for years. 
One particular fear is that the material from Russian weapons would be bought or stolen by terrorists or a "rogue" government who could construct a nuclear bomb. In recent years, the security of bomb materials in Russia has been improved markedly by joint Russian-American efforts, administration experts say.
Bush administration officials insist that they share the goal of disposing of American and Russian plutonium. 
"There's no philosphical shift that says suddenly we're perfectly fine with surplus plutonium laying around -- we're not," said an administration official familiar with the Clinton-era program. But, he added, conversion to fuel for existing reactors or mixing with waste are "not the only options for disposing of it safely." 
As an alternative, the Bush administration appears to be considering a variety of untested technical options, including a new generation of nuclear reactors that could burn plutonium more thoroughly.
"They're trying to improve on it by giving up on getting started any time soon," said Matthew G. Bunn, a nuclear expert at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, who was an adviser to the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy in the Clinton administration.
He and other experts are skeptical that a new generation of reactors, which was also mentioned in President Bush's energy plan as a way to dispose of nuclear waste, would ever be built. Construction on the last nuclear plants built in the United States country was begun more than 25 years ago.
"We're back at Square 1 with the program, and they're looking at imaginary options, like advanced reactors," said Tom Clements, executive director the Nuclear Control Institute, a nonprofit group that opposes the use of plutonium for reactor fuel. "For financial reasons, it's not going to be viable."
Though the administration is considering dropping the program to convert or immobilize weapons-grade plutonium, a separate Russian-American program to reduce the inventory of another Russian bomb fuel, highly enriched uranium, is continuing. In fact, uranium that was intended for Russian bombs now meets more than half the needs of American power reactors. 
But diluting uranium to the type used in power plants is technically far simpler and cheaper than the process required for plutonium, which must be converted from the metal form used in weapons to a plutonium-uranium ceramic used in American power plants. 
In fact, enriched uranium has economic value as reactor fuel, while converting plutonium appears to be a money-losing proposition.
Even so, Russian officials have said repeatedly that they view plutonium as an asset and would like to build new breeder reactors, so named because they produce plutonium faster than they consume the other main reactor fuel, uranium.
The end of the plutonium program would be mixed news for groups concerned with proliferation. 
For example, the Nuclear Control Institute has pushed vigorously for immobilization and against converting plutonium to reactor fuel, which is known as mixed oxide, or MOx.
Officials of the institute say conversion to MOx is very expensive and would encourage international commerce in weapons material. 
"We think their assessment of MOx is correct," said Mr. Clements, referring to the administration. "The problem is, it appears they've also rejected the cheaper alternative, which is immobilization."

HEADLINE: On California's Urban Border, Praise for Immigration Curbs 

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: IMPERIAL BEACH, Calif. 

 BODY:
Not too long ago in this coastal city south of San Diego and a stone's throw from Mexico, residents said they felt under siege.
 Rick B'Tello, who manages the beachfront Seacoast Inn, said Border Patrol agents routinely chased illegal immigrants up the beach, each time prompting about half of his horrified guests to check out of the hotel. At the Tijuana Estuary, a national wildlife refuge, Brian Collins, a biologist, said illegal crossers trampled rare plants and the nests of endangered birds on their furtive way north, sometimes even eating the birds' eggs for breakfast. 
 Worse, Imperial Beach officials said, the hordes passing through -- the Border Patrol said it once arrested more than 2,000 immigrants here in one 24-hour period -- gave this city with a population of about 26,000 a negative image that kept families and visitors away.
These days, though, the wildlife refuge is peaceful, tourists are coming in droves, and more people are moving in than out. Residents here mostly credit Operation Gatekeeper, the federal government's seven-year-old effort to strictly guard the westernmost 66 miles of the California-Mexico border. 
The Border Patrol's tighter enforcement, which has been spreading east to Arizona and Texas as well, has been widely condemned by human rights advocates for channeling immigrants into remote mountains and deserts, where hundreds of them have died of exposure. But in urban areas like Imperial Beach that took the brunt of the illegal traffic, grateful residents say the stepped-up vigilance has all but sealed the once popular smuggling routes across their beaches, parks and backyards and helped revive the area's economy and improve the quality of life.
Among the signs of prosperity in this working-class bedroom community are higher occupancy rates at hotels and record attendance for beach events like the U.S. Open Sandcastle competition, a 28 percent increase in home prices this year and neighborhoods no longer disturbed by large groups of illegal immigrants and the armed federal agents who trailed them.
"When I hear comments that Operation Gatekeeper doesn't work, well, it's worked for us," said Imperial Beach's mayor, Diane Rose. "Suddenly, people feel comfortable walking along the beach with their children in the evening. Your evenings are not disrupted anymore. People want to live here."
The quality-of-life problems of border communities are not well publicized, and they are not the kind of issue that makes or breaks government policy. But some immigration experts say these problems add another point of view to a national debate that has lately focused on the risks to the illegal immigrants. A General Accounting Office report released in August said that other communities where border enforcement had increased had experienced economic improvement and lower rates of crimes like theft.
In Nogales, Ariz., officials reported that as crossings declined, many small convenience stores that catered to illegal immigrants went out of business and large retailers took their place, attracting legal shoppers from both sides of the border. In Brownsville, Tex., shoplifting incidents dropped and a park near the Rio Grande is used again by families, the accounting office reported.
"This isn't just a matter of whether the neighborhood is messy," said Mark S. Krikorian, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies in Washington, which advocates immigration controls. "People have a right to expect that their neighborhood isn't going to host this kind of civic disorder. It affects how secure people feel."
The heavy use of urban areas like Imperial Beach for illegal crossings, Border Patrol officials say, stemmed from the relatively easy access the western end of the border afforded immigrants looking for work in places like Los Angeles. At one point, it was estimated that 25 percent of all crossings along the 2,000-mile Southwestern border came through the westernmost five miles starting at the Pacific Ocean.
But a turnaround began in 1994 when the Immigration and Naturalization Service focused resources along its San Diego sector -- installing lights and ground sensors; more than doubling the number of Border Patrol agents, to 2,000; completing fencing along 47 miles of the border and starting a new secondary fence as reinforcement.
Johnny N. Williams, director of the service's western regional office, said the San Diego sector of the border was now under control, with a 30-year low in immigrant arrests and drug seizures also sharply down. 
A recent tour along the first few miles of the border attests to the transformation -- once a wild stretch populated by border crossers, smugglers, bandits and federal agents in pursuit, the area was deserted except for the occasional Border Patrol vehicle. Only six men were seen biding their time on the Tijuana side of the corrugated steel fence that serves as the international boundary. 
But while San Diego was calming down, the illegal traffic shifted elsewhere, and arrests of illegal immigrants rose in other border areas, like Douglas, Ariz. In those places, the G.A.O. found, residents now complain of loss of business, destruction of private property and environmental degradation.
More troubling, by moving eastward to more dangerous terrain, many illegal immigrants have died from exposure to extreme heat or cold while trying to cross. The high death toll -- more than 1,000 known deaths in the last four years alone, according to Border Patrol figures -- and the increased illegal flow through other points of the border have led to criticism by civil rights advocates that Operation Gatekeeper is not only ineffective but inhumane.
"This is not about quality of life but life itself," said William Aceves, a spokesman for the American Civil Liberties Union of San Diego and Imperial Counties, one of the groups that have taken their complaints to the human rights commissions of the Organization of American States and the United Nations.
Many border residents said they had mixed feelings about the immigrants themselves, but not about relaxing their end of the border. 
Some residents noted that many crossers had also died here, drowned in lagoons or run over by cars in mad dashes across the freeway. Even today, parts of I-5 south of San Clemente have chain-link fencing on medians and "Caution" signs with the silhouettes of a man, a woman and a child in pigtails hurrying along.
Even those torn about the plight of the illegal immigrants, like Melissa Espinosa, 24, a second-generation Mexican-American, said they supported Operation Gatekeeper. Ms. Espinosa said she was not allowed to play in certain areas while growing up in the San Diego section of San Ysidro to avoid encounters with crossers. When she was a teenager, she said, federal agents stopped her on the street regularly, asking her to name the governor of California to check her citizenship status.
But her exasperation with the immigrants often gave way to compassion. She used to give directions to some who were mistakenly headed back to Mexico, she said, and sometimes alerted them to Border Patrol agents nearby. "I felt sorry for them, but it was very invasive," said Ms. Espinosa, a waitress.
Bud Harbin, 64, a former member of the Imperial Beach City Council who said he could count as many as 70 illegal immigrants passing through his neighborhood most nights, said the trespassers had stolen four of his cars, crouched down in his bushes and once hid in a room of his house. On many nights, he said, women in the neighborhood who lived alone or whose husbands were out would call on him to check on a noise or a prowler.
Not all border residents are delighted with the enforcement. A few miles east, in San Ysidro and Otay Mesa in the southern part of the city of San Diego, views of the illegal immigrants are tempered by economic ties that draw millions of crossers from Mexico to the area legally, many to shop. 
In those parts, people say they are more troubled that the government is using resources to curb the illegal traffic that could go to paying for more inspectors so that legal crossers do not have to wait for hours to have their documents checked. 
"We could be using the money to open up legal gates," said Alejandra Mier y Teran, executive director of the Otay Mesa Chamber of Commerce. "I view it as an opportunity cost. Our businesses are losing money because of this."
But in Imperial Beach, residents worry about how long the enforcement will be maintained. The immigration agency's strategy is to increase control of the border in phases, but attrition within the Border Patrol is a big concern, as is the question of whether the agency will continue to receive adequate financing to stem the flow of illegal immigrants. 
"We would never allow it to go back to what it was before," Mayor Rose said. "We couldn't afford it economically. We have to make sure the resources we need happen."
