HEADLINE: Citing Drop in Surplus, Democrats Plan to Portray Bush as Reckless 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 

 BODY:
With both the White House and Congress set to confirm that the budget surplus outside of Social Security has all but evaporated for the next few years, Democrats are planning to intensify their attacks on President Bush's fiscal management and to pin blame for the weakened economy on the White House.
 Following up on their arguments of earlier this year that Mr. Bush's tax cut would prove unaffordable, Democrats said they were confident that the administration would pay a political price for breaching informal agreements between the two parties not to spend any of the excess tax revenue generated by Medicare and Social Security. 
 White House officials said the tax cut would ultimately restore the economy's health and drive the surplus up again. In linking the declining surplus to Social Security and Medicare, the officials said, Democrats were engaging in scare tactics. But they said they were resigned to a political battle throughout the fall over who lost the surplus and what to do about it. 
In a sign of the rising political stakes, Mr. Bush is scheduled to speak about the budget outlook in Missouri on Tuesday. Administration officials said his theme would be that the real threat to the surplus was not the tax cut but excessive spending by Congress.
The combination of the tax cut and the slowing economy has shaved roughly $120 billion from the surplus for the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30, administration officials and Congressional budget analysts said. 
That should leave the surplus for the year at about $160 billion, all or nearly all of which would be accounted for by Social Security receipts.
The White House will release its updated budget projections on Wednesday. The Congressional Budget Office will publish its figures next week. The White House version is likely to show that the government used up most of the $30 billion Medicare surplus this year but barely avoided dipping into the Social Security surplus, in part because of a last-minute accounting change disclosed by the administration last week.
The Congressional analysis is likely to vary somewhat from the White House projection. 
In economic terms, it makes little or no difference whether the government spends a few billion dollars of the Social Security surplus in a given year. But the political ramifications could be enormous, given that both parties have worked hard in recent years to establish the Social Security surplus as an unbreachable bulwark against fiscal irresponsibility and as a vehicle to pay off the national debt.
White House officials said the government was still in sound fiscal condition, that the economy would improve next year and that Democrats were being irresponsible by suggesting to voters that the diminished surplus could imperil Social Security benefits.
"We would like to get beyond the politics of trust funds and Social Security and figure out a solution to reinvigorating economic growth," said Chris Ullman, a spokesman for the White House Office of Management and Budget. "That should be our joint endeavor."
To draw attention to their argument that the tax cut was excessive and will imperil the surplus for years to come, Democrats intend to run television commercials in some cities starting on Tuesday saying that Mr. Bush has proven to be reckless in managing the surplus.
"This is a much broader issue than just the budget," said Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "This goes to the total mismanagement of our economy."
Democratic leaders are using the diminishing surplus figures to bolster their argument that the administration does not have the money to pursue its plan to create private investment accounts in Social Security, to finance its national missile defense or to make good on its pledge to increase spending on education.
And when Congress returns to Washington after Labor Day to begin working in earnest on next year's spending bills, Democrats said they would go all out to make clear to voters that the painful budget trade-offs now faced by Congress were a result of Mr. Bush's overreaching with his tax cut.
"He inherited the strongest economy in a generation and the largest surpluses in history," said Thomas S. Kahn, staff director for the Democrats on the House Budget Committee, "and in a few months we've seen those surpluses slip through our fingers." 
"The administration," Mr. Kahn added, "is going to have to do some explaining."
But beyond casting blame and saying "I told you so," Democrats have no clear strategy. For one thing, 12 Democrats in the Senate and 28 in the House voted for the tax cut, so the party cannot claim united opposition to Mr. Bush on the issue.
Moreover, with memories of the drubbing the party took at the polls after supporting President Bill Clinton's tax increase in 1993 still fresh, Democrats have expressed little enthusiasm for rolling back Mr. Bush's tax cut to build a bigger fiscal buffer, especially while the economy remains weak.
Having worked hard for years to establish themselves as guardians of fiscal responsibility, Democrats are also loath to risk giving up the high ground in the fiscal debate by voting for spending bills this fall that would eat up more of the Medicare and Social Security surpluses. At the same time, they want the blame for any unpopular spending cuts to rest with the administration.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader in the House, said on the NBC program "Meet the Press" on Sunday that the administration should propose a new budget that would detail the spending cuts necessary to keep the budget from dipping into Social Security money. And he raised the possibility that provisions of the tax cut that are not scheduled to take effect for a number of years could be delayed if the surplus disappeared.
But he suggested that Democrats, in the end, might feel compelled to go along with restrictive spending bills, precisely the response White House officials have said all along that they wanted the tax cut to demand of both parties in Congress.
"Let's look at where we are," Mr. Gephardt said. "Given what's happened in this economy, given that we're now going into the Social Security and Medicare trust funds, we've got to review everything that we've done."
Both parties have found that fiscal responsibility and paying off the national debt are concepts that resonate with voters. Yet neither party is sure how politically powerful those policies are, especially when the economy is weak and most people are more concerned about jobs and incomes than the nuances of fiscal policy.
Strategists from both parties said the administration was clearly betting that the economy would turn around relatively quickly, and that any political peril regarding the surplus would be paved over by renewed growth and job creation before the midterm Congressional elections next year. In its budget update, the administration will project economic growth next year of 3.2 percent, a more robust projection than most private economists are making.
"What you've got going on here is a high-level game of budget chicken, in which both sides are waiting to see who's going to screw up and be blamed for having crossed that line," said Leon E. Panetta, who was budget chief and chief of staff in the Clinton administration.

HEADLINE: A Growth Industry Cools As New York Prisons Thin 

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
With the number of inmates in state prisons across the country either stabilizing or dropping after decades of explosive growth, New York is taking early steps to reduce its prison staffing significantly. 
 The Department of Correctional Services has frozen hiring at 36 prisons across the state, and hopes to eliminate 614 prison jobs through attrition by March, forcing corrections officers to begin to grapple with something they never imagined possible. New York City's plummeting crime rate might cost them their jobs if the goal is not met through attrition and might deliver a further blow to communities already braving a slowing economy. 
 The change in New York, where officials project the decrease in the inmate population to be about 9 percent, is threatening the livelihoods of people like Alan Ada.
In the mid-1980's, he surveyed his options in Cape Vincent, N.Y., a tiny resort town on the Canadian border, and decided to follow the calling of thousands of other young people upstate. Children of laid-off paper-mill workers and struggling dairy farmers, they chose a booming field that most never dreamed of, but that offered a steady salary, a pension and health insurance. Like them, he became a corrections officer. 
New York City quickly proved him wise. Desperate to ease overcrowding in its jails, the city built a $90 million jail in Cape Vincent in 1988 near the banks of the St. Lawrence River and began flying inmates north on twice-weekly jet shuttles nicknamed "Con Air." 
The new prison allowed Mr. Ada to get a steady job in the place where he was born and raised, a rare feat in Cape Vincent, a town of 2,400 in the Thousand Islands wilderness that falls silent when the leaves turn and the summer tourists depart. 
As the number of inmates in New York soared in the 1990's, the state took over the prison, doubling its population and work force. Across upstate New York, shrinking rural communities and their legislators clamored and competed for prisons, a seemingly recession-proof industry. But the boom times are coming to a jarring end. 
"Who ever thought crime would go down?" asked Tim Munroe, a corrections officer who has worked in the Cape Vincent Correctional Facility for 12 years. "Who ever thought we would run out of inmates?" 
Officials in Massachusetts, New Jersey and Texas -- states also experiencing declines in their prison population -- said they had no plans to reduce their prison work forces. Experts caution that it is not yet known whether the nationwide prison population is dropping or simply stabilizing. But if the decline becomes a clear trend, hundreds of small, rural prison towns across the country could find themselves confronted by the same unnerving news as Cape Vincent.
"Regions and towns that have based their whole economies on prisons are going to be confronted with some really serious problems," said Michael Jacobson, a professor of criminology at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. "This is going to be a problem for the governor and Legislature. In the same way towns lobbied to open prisons, they are going to lobby against closing them."
In New York, a continued drop would bring a halt to what has served as a de facto economic development program in the state's isolated corners -- prison growth. Assailed by critics as a shortsighted use of state resources and defended by supporters as necessary for public safety, New York's sprawling 70-facility, $2.4-billion-a-year prison system pours hundreds of millions of dollars into the upstate economy each year.
The dependence bred by nearly 30 years of unchecked prison growth is evident in isolated Cape Vincent, where deer nibble on grass near the prison, wild turkeys wander the roads and Canadian radio stations dot the airwaves. Prison employees expressed fear, anger and suspicion about the state's plan and complained of low morale and management problems. A group of corrections officers met with H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and a candidate for governor, this month to express concerns about cutbacks.
The vast majority of officers interviewed asked not to have their names published because they feared losing their jobs. Corrections officers' salaries start at $33,000 and rise to $48,000 in 20 years.
"When they say the crime rate is down, it's just a political thing," scoffed Mr. Ada, one of several officers who questioned whether the rates are actually dropping. "I think it's just something for the politicians to make them look good." 
Mr. Ada, who is also the local fire chief, complained that proposed changes in the so-called Rockefeller drug laws would further reduce the prison population, and he was convinced that crime continues unabated downstate. "All you have to do is look at the New York City news," he said.
The supervisor in Cape Vincent, Tom Rienbeck, said that the prison is the community's second-largest employer after its public schools, and that the state's goal of cutting 168 of the prison's 528 jobs through attrition would hurt.
"Anytime you lose that many jobs, it's something to worry about," Mr. Rienbeck said, adding that he, too, never dreamed the prison population would drop. "You always figure you're going to have criminals. It's like being a doctor, you figure there are always going to be sick people."
Mr. Rienbeck and corrections officers expressed worry that the state would not reach its goal through attrition and that layoffs would be necessary. "There are maybe a handful of people close to retirement," Mr. Ada said. 
James B. Flateau, a spokesman for the Department of Correctional Services, said the Cape Vincent's prison has lost 26 officers, for example, through attrition since April 2000. The state's goal is to lose 117 officers and 51 civilian employees by next March, but Mr. Flateau emphasized that the figures are only targets. He said that the department expects to meet its goal statewide and that higher attrition in other prisons could make up for less in an area like Cape Vincent. 
Groups that criticized explosive prison growth in the past are using the slowdown to again call for change. Jennifer Wynn, director of the Prison Visiting Project for the Correctional Association of New York, questioned the wisdom of making prisons such a large economic force in upstate New York.
"Since 1982, New York has opened 38 new prisons, every one of them in a rural upstate community that relies on prisoners -- mostly poor people of color from New York City -- to fuel the local economy," she said. "Maybe it's time to invest in more positive and sustainable industries than warehousing people."
Several upstate county governments may also have miscalculated. For the last decade, state prison overcrowding resulted in thousands of inmates serving their sentences in county jails instead of state prisons. After years of legal battles, the state now reimburses the counties for housing the inmates.
Some rural counties, seeking to make the arrangement profitable, built large jails with excess capacity. But with the prison population dropping, some sheriff's departments that run county jails are stuck with oversized centers with empty bunks.
"There are jails that overbuilt in anticipation of needing additional space for themselves and in anticipation of taking advantage of some extra dollars from the state," said Peter Kehoe, executive director of the New York State Sheriffs' Association. "Those people are beginning to worry."
The worry is palpable in Jefferson County, home to Cape Vincent, and neighboring St. Lawrence County. Hiring freezes are in effect in four of the five prisons, some of which are known as "cookie cutters," a reference to the speed and identical designs desperate corrections officials used as they scrambled to build them in the 1980's and 1990's.
Besides the hiring halt, 350 officers temporarily assigned to prisons in the two counties fear being moved to downstate prisons where their jobs are permanently assigned, according to Mr. Munroe, a former union leader in Cape Vincent who believes the drop in crime is real and good for society over all. He added that he did not believe anyone considered what would happen if the crime rate dropped. "There wasn't much forethought," he said.
Dozens of local men are already making the commute to downstate prisons. One corrections officer who spoke on the condition of anonymity said the hiring freeze put off his hopes of being able to work in a nearby prison. "Cape Vincent is my No. 1 jail," he said. "It's two miles from my house."
He drives two hours to a maximum security prison in central New York. There, he works double shifts for two to four days, sleeping in an apartment he shares with 12 other officers. He returns to Cape Vincent and works odd construction jobs during his days off.
But he and other local prison employees all enthusiastically endorsed theirs as a "clean industry" that produced steady employment and little pollution. No guards have been seriously injured since Cape Vincent's prison opened, they said, and no inmates have escaped. 
With mills and other area businesses continuing to close, Mr. Ada regrets that his town did not agree to house more prisons in the boom times, saying, "It's supposed to be one of the more secure state jobs."

HEADLINE: California Governor Sees an End to Freeway Building 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: FONTANA, Calif., Aug. 20 

 BODY:
Standing atop eight lanes of grooved pavement and pristine yellow stripes in the kind of distant Los Angeles suburb made possible by endless highway construction, Gov. Gray Davis today dedicated the latest section of freeway to be built in California and declared that the project would be the last.
 California is identified more closely with freeways and the automobile than any other state -- it has slightly more than 15,000 miles of roads. But like other states, it long ago abandoned the hope that highways alone would solve growing urban transportation problems. 
 Mr. Davis used today's ribbon-cutting ceremony on a broiling, smoggy afternoon to underscore this fundamental shift, saying that the primacy of the automobile in transportation planning was over.
While the state will be spending much more money on transportation in coming years, Mr. Davis, a Democrat, said it would be mostly for mass transit like trains and buses. It is a shift that some experts say rests on troubling economics, because the state will be serving fewer people with sharply increased expenditures.
Even one of the most ardent supporters of new highways over the years, the Automobile Club of Southern California, has accepted the shift. "That's what the reality is now," said Jeffrey Spring, a spokesman for the association. "We have to look at alternative methods of moving people around." 
Mr. Davis said that even after the 28-mile stretch of the Foothill Freeway was completed here in San Bernardino County, serving booming suburbs about 50 miles east of downtown Los Angeles, the state would still spend large amounts on highways -- but to improve existing roadways, not add to them.
His remarks lent a bittersweet edge to the hoopla atop the freeway here. While few policy planners and politicians today would be eager to celebrate creeping suburbanization and the other side effects of America's car culture, this ceremony did -- whether intentionally or not. 
A high school band played near displays that included race cars and Fontana's original 1952 Ford police cruiser, in mint condition.
A construction company had a booth advertising the new homes it is building in one of the dozens of new subdivisions blanketing an old farming and warehousing region. A man dressed in a foam-rubber suit that looked like a smiling suburban house danced about the highway lanes handing out sales brochures.
The ceremony today was for the opening of a six-mile portion of the Foothill Freeway, which will link the cities of La Verne, Rancho Cucamonga and Fontana. The cities, which lie at the western end of the largest county in the country, are now served by densely traveled, frequently backed-up freeways. Trains run from here to downtown Los Angeles, but they carry a fraction of the number of people who cram the roads at rush hour.
No one expects that to change. Norman King, the executive director of the San Bernardino Associated Governments, a regional planning group, began the ceremony by noting that the cars parked on the freeway today were just a prelude to the traffic jams that were sure to follow.
He added that while freeways were indeed expensive, they were a lot cheaper than the other forms of transit that would increasingly suck up tax dollars in the future.
To support the shift, Mr. Davis said he was backing a proposal to have Californians vote in March on a proposition that would dedicate all revenues from state gasoline taxes -- $36 billion over 20 years -- to transportation projects. Currently, those revenues go into the state government's general funds.
Transportation experts are generally critical of the policy shift, not because they believe in more highway construction, but because they tend to believe that the government does too little to encourage Californians to use the public transit it plans to spend so much money building.
Driving, they complain, is becoming cheaper, while building new transit systems is becoming significantly more expensive.
"What we have is a goofy policy that doesn't really make sense, except in politics," said Peter Gordon, a professor of urban economics at the University of Southern California. He added that he believed the state should make public transit more attractive by making driving more expensive, by raising tolls, parking costs and gasoline taxes.
"The bottom line here is that transit use is not increasing nearly as fast as transit expenditures," said Brian Taylor, director of the Institute for Transportation Studies at the University of California at Los Angeles. "We haven't seen any big shift in travel because we don't ask drivers to pay the costs of their driving. Things like gas and parking are actually getting cheaper in inflation-adjusted terms, so it's no surprise people are driving more and more."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 30, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 21 about the opening of a section of the Foothill Freeway in Los Angeles referred incorrectly to a California ballot proposition. The proposal would dedicate all state sales tax on gasoline to transportation projects. It would not stipulate that separate gas taxes be used for such projects; gas taxes are already used solely for transportation.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
TBWA Acquires Two Agencies

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
TBWA Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that it had acquired two agencies, Weiss Stagliano Partners in New York and O'Malley & Hogan in Dublin, and merged them to form Brand Architecture International, which will specialize in branding services. Terms of the cash deal were not disclosed. 
 Brand Architecture has 50 employees and revenue estimated at $8 million to $10 million from clients like Bass Ale, The Economist and Tumi. It will operate as an autonomous unit of TBWA from offices in Dublin and New York as well as from a new office in London and continue to serve clients from brand consulting to creative. 
 Top executives at the two agencies become directors and principal brand architects at Brand Architecture, including Adam Stagliano, 46, president and chief strategic officer at Weiss Stagliano; Marty Weiss, 47, chief creative officer at Weiss Stagliano; and Damian O'Malley, 45, a partner at O'Malley & Hogan.
Last summer, Weiss Stagliano and O'Malley & Hogan formed a brand consulting company, Weiss Stagliano O'Malley Hogan International Brand Architecture.
Weiss Stagliano began as Carroll Raj Stagliano in 1989, then merged with Weiss, Whitten in 1991 to form Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano. The name changed in 1993, when Tom Carroll left, and again in 1997, when Nat Whitten left. The new branding unit brings some agency relationships full circle as Mr. Carroll is now president for the Americas at TBWA in Playa del Rey, Calif.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: South Korea: Growth Data Due 

BYLINE:  By Don Kirk (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Economists expect the Bank of Korea to report a disappointing number today when it releases its report on the country's gross domestic product for the second quarter. 
The central bank had earlier estimated a growth rate of 3.3 percent for the quarter and 3.8 percent for the year. Now, because of the slowdown in Japan and the United States, Korea's two largest trading partners, economists expect a growth rate of less then 0.5 percent for the quarter and less than 3 percent for the year. Don Kirk (NYT)

HEADLINE: Ferrer Trails Fund-Raising In Manhattan 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Fernando Ferrer's main campaign appeal is to "the other New York," the city residents who have been left behind in good economic times, or at least have not been a part of the Giuliani-era establishment. So even his supporters are not surprised that the Bronx borough president lags far behind his three main Democratic rivals in collecting donations from Manhattan, the city's richest borough.
 But Manhattan is again the biggest source of campaign dollars for the mayoral candidates, with borough residents already giving the Democrats collectively $8.6 million -- almost twice as much as the other boroughs put together. Of that total, $3 million has gone to Public Advocate Mark Green, the top fund-raiser in Manhattan, while only $1.25 million has gone to Mr. Ferrer. 
 The result is that he is far behind Mr. Green in fund-raising, even though Mr. Ferrer has raised more money in Queens, Staten Island and the Bronx. 
In fact, counting matching money, Mr. Green and Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi have already raised enough to ensure they can spend the maximum allowed by law in both the Sept. 11 primary and a Sept. 25 runoff election, which may be necessary to pick the party's nominee. Mr. Ferrer, by comparison, still had to raise about $1 million to hit that ceiling, while Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, was about $650,000 short, as of the Aug. 6 campaign finance reports.
If one of the four Democrats wins at least 40 percent of the vote on Sept. 11, he will go directly to the general election in November, making a runoff of the top two candidates unnecessary. But most polls have shown none of the four candidates as having the magic 40 percent.
Given that there is only two weeks between the primary and the runoff, each of the candidates has no choice but to prepare ahead of time. That means all four want to have all of the money they need in hand before the runoff would start.
Mr. Ferrer, who like the other Democrats already has enough money raised to spend the maximum $5.5 million for the primary, said yesterday that he was confident he would raise the remaining money he would need for a possible runoff, money that for the most part would be spent on television commercials. City rules cap spending in the runoff at $2.6 million.
"It does not concern me in the least," he said yesterday, after holding a news conference in front of City Hall. "I will have enough."
But Mr. Ferrer's spokesman acknowledged that with a base in the Bronx, and with a message that focused on the city's disadvantaged residents more than his rivals' did, he has perhaps had a harder time raising money than his opponents.
"We have many, many contributors who are far from wealthy," his spokesman, John Del Cecato, said. "That speaks to how we are seeking to represent all New Yorkers."
Mr. Ferrer added, "Maybe I need wealthier relatives and wealthier friends."
Money, of course, does not necessarily translate into votes. But as the election approaches, the amount and source of the money raised provides insight into the different mayoral campaigns and the difference audiences they, at least financially, are attracting.
To date, Mr. Hevesi still has the overall lead, having collected $7.1 million in donations, while Mr. Green has $5.8 million, Mr. Vallone has $4.5 million and Mr. Ferrer has $4.0 million. Each of these figures accounts for any money that has been refunded by the candidates, but they do not include city matching money, or interest or balances transferred from previous campaigns.
Mr. Ferrer, through early August, had 5,489 contributors, averaging $764 apiece before any refunds, according to city campaign finance data. That puts him in third place out of four in terms of number of contributors, with Mr. Vallone trailing. Mr Ferrer is in last place in terms of the average size of the contributions. Mr. Green's average contribution, by comparison, has been worth $912, the highest.
What really matters, in terms of fund-raising for the candidates, is not just how popular candidates are in Manhattan in general, but how popular they are in certain particularly affluent neighborhoods, as an examination of giving by ZIP codes shows.
In 10021, which covers the East Side of Manhattan from 61st Street to 80th Street, residents have donated a total of $1.9 million to mayoral candidates, the most of any ZIP code in the city. Of that total, $605,666 went to Mr. Green, who lives just north of the area, while Mr. Ferrer drew $268,490. 
But just up the way in 10029, which stretches from East 97th Street to East 116th Street, residents have sent in a total of just $39,240 to the four Democrats. Mr. Ferrer has beaten out all of his rivals in this ZIP code. But the resulting $12,490 he has collected in total from the Spanish Harlem ZIP code has not been not much of a financial boon.
The pace of fund-raising, particularly in the last seven months, has varied widely for the four Democrats.
Since mid January, Mr. Green's fund-raising effort has taken off, while Mr. Vallone's has increased only slightly and Mr. Ferrer's and Mr. Hevesi's have declined. That means Mr. Green has been cutting the large fund-raising lead once held by Mr. Hevesi, who started the year far ahead of the other candidates.
In the most recent filing period -- a 25-day stretch from July 12 to Aug. 6th -- Mr. Green raised an average of $23,064 a day, compared with $6,480 a day for Mr. Vallone, $2,508 a day for Mr. Ferrer, and $1,238 a day for Mr. Hevesi, the records show.
Much of the recent surge in fund-raising by Mr. Green has to do with his perceived status as the front-runner in the campaign, both Mr. Green and his rivals said. Polls have repeatedly shown him with a small but statistically significant lead over the other three Democrats.
"Apparently, people who were waiting and watching the mayor's race are now voting with their dollars by helping my candidacy," Mr. Green said yesterday, adding that he considers a runoff "all but certain."
The particularly small average daily amount that Mr. Hevesi has raised in recent weeks is in part because he continues to return much more money than any of his rivals, a total of $408,000 so far during the campaign -- money that was given back because contributions exceeded legal limits or because other questions were raised about the appropriateness of the donation.
Spokesmen for Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Ferrer also said that the candidates had spent much less time during the first half of this year focusing on raising money, in part because they already knew they had raised enough to spend as much as is allowed by law in the Sept. 11 primary.
Matching money from the city Campaign Finance Board helps to even out the candidates' differences.
To date, a total of $9.8 million in matching money has been given to the four Democrats, which represents $4 for each $1 they have collected in small contributions -- those less than $250.Anyone who gets into the runoff election will be entitled to as much as $720,000 more in matching money, meaning each candidate must raise at least $1.9 million of his own money for a runoff.
But what is clear is that if Mr. Ferrer, in particular, is going to meet his fund-raising goal to prepare for a runoff election, he must pick up the pace in fund-raising in the next several weeks.
Both Mr. Vallone and Mr. Ferrer have already planned a series of fund-raising events to do just that. Mr. Ferrer, for example, has invited Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., the lawyer, Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee, the actors, Earl Graves Jr., the president of Black Enterprise magazine, and Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan borough president, among others, to headline a fund-raising event on Sept. 5.
Mr. Vallone, meanwhile, will be at Tavern on the Green on Sept. 5 at a fund-raiser hosted by a group of prominent female supporters.
But Mr. Green is showing no sign of slowing down in his own fund-raising effort. He has 18 fund-raising events scheduled between now and Sept. 11. And he has his own Sept. 5 event planned: a concert at Town Hall on West 43rd Street featuring performances by Jon Bon Jovi, Jewel and Mandy Patinkin that is scheduled to be hosted by Warren Beatty and Annette Bening, among others. He hopes to raise as much as $400,000 at this concert alone.
The rules will all change in the general election if Michael R. Bloomberg is the Republican nominee. Because he is not participating in the campaign finance system, the spending cap will also be lifted for the Democratic nominee, who will get an extra amount of city matching money.
The Democratic nominee should be able to draw a large amount of money, given the predominance of Democrats in the city. But if Mr. Bloomberg keeps up his spending at a rate similar to what he has already begun -- he has already spent at least $16 million, more than all the other candidates combined -- it will be virtually impossible for the Democratic nominee to match his spending.

HEADLINE: Slight Progress on Budget As Leaders Talk Compromise 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 20 

 BODY:
Legislative leaders met with Gov. George E. Pataki early today and made some minor progress toward an accord on a supplemental budget that would patch the holes in the austere spending plan passed two weeks ago.
 For the first time, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said publicly that he was willing to reduce his demand for $1.7 billion in additional school aid and $400 million in other additions in order to reach a compromise with the governor. 
 The governor, meanwhile, signaled a willingness to raise spending above the $83.6 billion he proposed in January, so long as the Legislature approved new streams of revenue to support the expanded programs in the future, people familiar with the talks said. Among the revenue sources being considered is a new multistate lottery game. 
Mr. Silver and the Republican leader of the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, left the hourlong meeting with the governor this morning without reaching a deal, and aides to all three men said the negotiations were fragile and fluid. Still, for the first time this year, the Republican governor and the Democratic Assembly leader seemed to soften their positions. Some aides said an agreement on an overall amount of spending might be possible this week.
"I am willing to compromise in the interest of doing a budget," Mr. Silver said as he emerged from the meeting. 
"I am willing to compromise from the larger numbers in education and health care in order to do a budget."
Two weeks ago, Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno put aside their partisan differences and passed a skeletal version of the governor's budget that stripped out $4 billion in spending as well as new Medicaid and school-aid formulas the governor wanted.
The two leaders calculated that a painful budget would bring the governor to the negotiating table. For months, Mr. Pataki had maintained he had finished his job when he submitted his budget and that the Legislature must act upon it. As the economy slowed, the governor also maintained that tax revenues would flatten out or drop this year, a prediction the Assembly and Senate regard as too pessimistic.
When the Legislature passed the stripped-down plan, however, the governor changed his stance on what his role should be. He sued the Legislature, arguing that the State Constitution forbids changes to language in his appropriations bills without his consent. 
The governor's strategy this year had political advantages. Polls suggested most voters blamed the Legislature rather than the governor for the late budget.
The longer the impasse lasts, the longer the state spends money at last year's pace, building up a surplus for 2002, an election year. For both political and fiscal reasons, the governor wants to avoid cutbacks next year, his aides said.
The main obstacle to an accord had not changed in today's meeting. Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno argued that revenues would grow somewhat this year and that the governor would have $4 billion to $5 billion in reserves. They noted that $1.8 billion more than Mr. Pataki had foreseen had come in since January. 
The governor stuck to his gloomy revenue outlook, predicting those revenues would vanish next year. He said all the reserves were earmarked for special purposes, including $2.25 billion to hedge against a recession.
Mr. Pataki asked the Legislature to find new revenue to offset any spending increases, legislative aides said.
"I think there are still real differences on the economic condition of the country and the revenues," he said after the meeting. 
"There has not been any economic news across the country or globally that would suggest we should raise our projections at all."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing Bonds Up In The Catskills 

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton (NYT) 

 BODY:
 A financial recovery in Sullivan County has led a Wall Street bond-rating agency to upgrade the county's debt rating to A, from A-minus.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Sears to Focus on Variety Not Price

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company, which spends $600 million to $1 billion annually on advertising, is overhauling its pitches to emphasize the variety of name-brand merchandise sold by its 860 stores rather than trying to compete on pricing with discounters like Wal-Mart Stores and Target.
 The idea behind the high-stakes new campaign for Sears is simple enough: Let Sears be Sears. 
 Sears executives hope the humorous campaign will stimulate flagging sales amid the soft economic climate by playing up its strengths, primarily the broad assortments of branded goods, and playing down its weaknesses, primarily an inability to pursue the so-called everyday-low-price strategy of the discount chains.
The stakes for the campaign, to begin appearing on Sept. 6, could not be higher for Sears, the nation's fourth-largest retailer. The company is hard-pressed in grappling with skeptical, belt-tightening shoppers who have grown reluctant to buy much of anything and increasingly open their wallets and purses only when the goods are on sale. 
"Sears, like all retailers, is operating in a difficult consumer-spending environment," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, an analyst at Lehman Brothers who follows retailing.
"Relatively speaking, Sears is holding its own," he added, "but that's still not as much as investors would like."
Investors were also not too keen on the Sears results for July, which showed a 2.5 percent decline in total sales and a 3 percent decline in sales at stores open for more than a year, known in the industry as same-store sales. That figure is considered a crucial indicator of retail vitality.
And in the second quarter, Sears revenue from retailing, its mainstay money maker, fell 1.1 percent from the corresponding period of 2000.
"We're very aware of the economic conditions," said David Selby, senior vice president for marketing at Sears in Hoffman Estates, Ill., who offered a preview of the campaign yesterday in a telephone interview.
"What we're going to do here is tell our story very clearly and very aggressively," he added.
The campaign, a result of a creative shootout between the two big principal Sears agencies, will include everything from television commercials to signs in stores to ad banners on Web sites. The campaign carries the theme "Sears. Where else?," a question meant to be part rhetorical, part revelatory, not unlike the old slogan for Kellogg's Corn Flakes, "Taste them again for the first time."
The switch in Sears strategies came after Alan J. Lacy, chairman and chief executive of Sears, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting that he wanted to improve marketing efforts by refocusing them from pricing to the extent of brand-name products, whether proprietary (Craftsman, Kenmore) or national (Levi's, Maytag).
That set the clock ticking on the Sears ad theme since August 1999, "The good life at a great price. Guaranteed," which was the product of a previous creative shootout between the retailer's two principal agencies. They were, and are, the Chicago offices of Ogilvy & Mather and Young & Rubicam, both now owned by the WPP Group, which typically divide the general advertising assignments for Sears by categories like apparel (Y.& R.) and automotive (Ogilvy).
Mr. Lacy's reorientation set off the second shootout, which ended last month with a decision to proceed with a strategy developed by the Chicago office of Y.& R. That agency also created "Come see the softer side of Sears," the theme that ran from 1993 to 1999.
"The goal is to articulate what the brand is all about and serve it up in a fresh way," Mr. Selby said. "We want to cut through the fog of familiarity, if you will."
"At the heart of what we're doing is to play our own game, 'Only Sears can do that,' because that's who we are," he added. "Rather than be embarrassed or vague, we want to celebrate the breadth of merchandise Sears has."
The variety of goods Sears sells is represented in the campaign by shopping lists of disparate items consumers typically buy, augmented by paeans to Sears service, employees and product guarantees. But in keeping with the desired freshness, there's typically a twist.
For instance, one commercial shows a woman in a chic autumn outfit as a breeze stirs, causing a trickle of leaves to fall. The breeze becomes a windstorm and the leaves start flying. The cause? A man with a Craftsman leaf blower. In another spot, a baby keeps crying as its mother tries offering distractions like a Sears infant blanket, but the wails turn to gurgles only when dad trips and falls as he tries to capture the child on a Sony video camera.
The print ads are similarly skewed. One displays an overweight man in a bathroom and offers this shopping list: "Fieldcrest bath towels. Whole Home accent rugs. NordicTrack treadmill." Another shows the shopping list for a boy named Tim, who is decked out in Nike shoes, Levi's jeans and a Champion jersey he "had to have" because his friends Billy, Danny and Derek wear them. The final item on the list is a membership in the Sears KidVantage Club, which offers the "savings you had to have to keep up with Billy, Danny and Derek."
The humor "is important," said Mark Figliulo, executive vice president and chief creative officer at Y.& R. Chicago, because "we want to bring a lightheartedness to Sears."
"Shopping should be fun; it shouldn't be a chore," he added, "and when you accomplish things, you feel good."
Target has had much success with breezy, cheerful print and television ads by Peterson Milla Hooks in Minneapolis that celebrate the wide variety of brand-name products it peddles. Though it is not implicit in the campaign, Sears is in effect saying, been there, done that.
"Our research shows our customer is a 'mission shopper' and we know how busy her life is, how crazy her life is," Mr. Selby said.
"We're not everything for everyone," he added, "but the reality is, we can help her complete more of her mission."
As for concerns the campaign might make Sears seem as if there is too much under one roof, that's why several commercials show the sales staff, Mr. Figliulo said, "who are there to help you accomplish your mission." (There will be internal communications, with training involved, aimed at helping employees cross-sell merchandise between departments, as in commercials where appliance shoppers are sent to the jewelry department and jewelry shoppers are sent to home electronics.)
Besides, "as soon as you think you've got it all," Mr. Figliulo said, referring to the typical shopping list, "there's usually one more thing you need."
The "Sears. Where else?" theme is being used by all Sears agencies, which in addition to Y.& R. Chicago and Ogilvy Chicago include the Burrell Communications Group in Chicago, 49 percent owned by the Publicis Groupe, for ads aimed at black consumers; Mendoza Dillon & Asociados in Newport Beach, Calif., for ads aimed at Hispanic consumers; and the Los Angeles and New York offices of Kang & Lee, part of Young & Rubicam, for ads aimed at Asian-Americans.
Sears joins a list of retailers revamping their campaigns, among them Kmart, with new work by the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/ Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, and J. C. Penney, with new work by DDB Worldwide, part of Omnicom.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sears's new campaign begins next month. It carries the theme, "Sears. Where else?"

HEADLINE: An Unresponsive Economy 

 BODY:
All of a sudden, the light at the end of the economic tunnel doesn't seem to be getting any closer. For much of this year, analysts expected the Federal Reserve Board's half-dozen cuts in interest rates to shift the economy out of neutral by the fourth quarter. Now, as autumn nears, medium- and long-term interest rates remain prohibitively high, and each day brings news of more layoffs. Pundits seize upon any sign of a turnaround, such as last month's growth in new home construction. Clearly, however, companies are finding few reasons to increase their investments. One obvious problem is that the Fed and the Bush administration are working at cross purposes. 
 The Fed has been steadily lowering the federal funds rate -- the rate at which banks lend reserves to each other on a day-to-day basis -- with the hope that other lending rates will follow suit. Since January, short-term rates have fallen by almost three percentage points. A drop in inflation, driven mainly by lower energy costs, has given the Fed room to make another cut at its meeting today. But rates on loans and mortgages with terms of five years and longer have barely responded. 
 One cause of the stickiness in long-term rates is the widespread belief that the economy will resume its productivity-driven boom in the next few years. Another cause is more troubling -- uncertainty about the federal government's finances. Corporate tax revenues have slackened, and declining business confidence suggests slim prospects for an uptick anytime soon. Forthcoming estimates from the White House and the Congressional Budget Office will almost definitely show drops in the projected budget surpluses. President Bush has already hamstrung the coming years' federal budgets with his tax cut and his unrealistic allowances for discretionary spending. Smaller surpluses will force Congress to spend money that would otherwise have extended the solvency of Medicare and Social Security.
Congress has aggravated the problem by showing a disturbing lack of commitment to making these programs more sound. Given members' disagreements on a prescription drug benefit for Medicare, chances for comprehensive reform look slim. The White House favors a flawed, politically unfeasible reform of Social Security and has dismissed the worsening budget forecasts. The specter of a ballooning federal debt, accompanied by high interest rates, looms larger by the day.
Investors have also signaled their worries about the American economy through the dollar's cascading fall against the euro, yen and British pound. The weaker dollar hurts American companies that depend on foreign financing because of scant domestic saving. Upward pressure on prices, and even higher interest rates, could result as well.
At the moment, robust consumer spending is keeping the economy growing, if extremely slowly. This lifeline is likely to disappear, though, when the slews of layoffs -- 5,000 at Ford Motor Company being the most dramatic in recent days -- begin to bite. After consumers' spending is finally overtaken by their mounting debts, investment by businesses will have to drive economic growth. Yet thanks to Congress and the White House, the Fed's efforts to promote investment have yet to take hold.
Europe and Japan are sputtering, too. Their problems will limit the positive impact the lower dollar might otherwise have on American exporters. On the bright side, though, the dollar will offer some succor to struggling Argentina, whose currency is linked to ours. While fighting to escape its own economic slump, Argentina has learned the lesson Washington must now heed: To promote investment for the long term, the government must keep its own house in order.

HEADLINE: Slump in U.S. Drags Mexico, and Fox's Agenda, Down 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 20 

 BODY:
Mexico has been dragged into recession by the faltering American economy, taking a toll on millions of Mexicans and the political aspirations of President Vicente Fox.
 Mr. Fox took office on Dec. 1 promising to create 1.4 million new jobs. That has proved a mirage. Instead, hundreds of thousands of people -- perhaps as many as half a million, by some estimates -- have lost their jobs since then. 
 The economic pain is hard to calculate, but in a country where nearly half of the population is poor by any standard, it is likely that several million people have less money and perhaps less to eat today than a year ago. Mexico, unlike the United States, does not offer unemployment benefits.
Mr. Fox said last year that he could sustain the economic growth that peaked at 7.7 percent during the early part of 2000. That, too, was an illusion. With luck, the gross domestic product might grow somewhere between 1.8 percent and 2.5 percent by the end of this year. 
But private analysts say the country, which does not measure its economy quarterly, remains for now in a recession based on the American standard of two consecutive quarters of no growth.
Mexico has been selling 80 to 90 percent of its exports to the United States since the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect in 1994. So a slowdown in the American economy spells shutdowns and layoffs in Mexico as companies dismiss workers to cut their costs.
"The correlation of manufacturing job losses in Mexico to the deceleration of the U.S. economy is about one to one," said Alfredo Thorne, chief Latin American economist at J. P. Morgan Chase in Mexico City.
This morning, at the Almeda plaza in the heart of Mexico City, close to 100 people like Julian Gonzales sat on park benches reading the want ads with weary resignation. Mr. Gonzales, once an administrator at a heavy-equipment manufacturer, has been out of work for months.
"The sad reality is that it is incredibly difficult to get a job" in Mexico these days, he said.
Down the rows of benches, Paulo Cesar Jimenez, 20, a communications student at Del Valle University, said he had been looking all summer for work without success.
"I see people, even those who have college degrees, who are now driving taxis or selling things on the street," he said. "Supposedly Vicente Fox was going to give young people opportunities. Look at me, sitting here, waiting for my opportunity."
As many as 20 percent of Mexicans have no jobs or are underemployed, meaning they work less than 35 hours a week, which may not be enough to get by, private economists say.
Mr. Fox remains remarkably upbeat despite those harsh facts and grim faces. But he now acknowledges the undeniable: Mexico has been in a recession for months, and its deep dependence on trade with the United States is the primary cause.
Mr. Fox said on Saturday that Mexico was "not anticipating a crisis or a domino effect" from weakened economies in the United States and Latin America. "But simply there is no dynamism now in the American economy, and therefore there is no growth."
Many economists agree with him that Mexico's economic foundation is stable; some predict that its fortunes will soon improve. "Yes, we are in a recession," Mr. Thorne said. "We are in the worst part of the cycle. But we are very close to the bottom. The rate of decline is slowing."
Interest rates are less than 10 percent, about half as high as a year ago. Foreign direct investment in Mexico is likely to reach $27 billion this year, about twice what it was last year. Mr. Fox has been pursuing that money on nearly every one of his many foreign trips to the United States, Europe and Asia.
Inflation is down and the peso is strong -- so strong that Mexico has now seized Brazil's title as the biggest economy in Latin America, measured in dollars.
But a stronger peso -- it has appreciated 6 percent against the dollar this year -- also means costlier Mexican exports, aggravating Mexico's pain when the American economy weakens. That fact alone has cost thousands of jobs at assembly plants near the United States border, a cornerstone of the free-trade economy, along with technology businesses, car and auto-parts makers and consumer electronics companies.
All of which suggests to Rogelio Ramirez del la O, one of Mexico's most respected economists, that "we have not hit bottom yet." Mr. Fox's predicted 7 percent growth, he said, may wind up approaching 0.7 percent, if that, forcing many more Mexicans to live hand to mouth before a North American economic revival.
And a sputtering economy may make a mess of many of Mr. Fox political plans. He has already announced cuts in government spending by hundreds of millions of dollars, though where those cuts are coming from remains murky. Some ambitious projects, like one to spur development in Mexico's rural south, could be delayed or derailed.
Oil, one of the government's biggest sources of income, is also stalling the economy. This year, Mexico has seen revenues from its state-run energy company, Pemex, drop 41 percent. Oil prices and exports are down; the costs of financing sales of natural gas to Mexican companies are up.
Pemex, like many another state-run industry, is not a model of modern efficiency. But the regulation and competition that could reform the energy industry typify the many expected changes yet to occur in Mr. Fox's nine-month-old administration. And without the economic growth on which he stakes much of his political fortune, much of the optimism that his election brought to Mexico's middle class has never trickled down to Mexico's poor.
Luis Ochoa, 44, was also in the Almeda plaza looking for carpentry work. When he does have a job, he makes less than $100 a week and sleeps at the construction site where he works.
He and his seven children picked coffee beans for years in the town of Cordoba, in the southern state of Veracruz. But free trade has pounded Mexico's coffee industry. Exports from as far away as Vietnam have glutted the United States market and sent prices plummeting. 
At home, he said, he makes the equivalent of five cents for a pound of coffee beans. So he comes here to try to help feed his family.
"It's harder to find jobs today," he said. "For two years I've been coming to Mexico City, and it's more difficult now. The government is telling pure lies, because they haven't followed through on their word. Everything is the same."

HEADLINE: Bush Warns Against Delay In Acting on Military Budget 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 20 

 BODY:
President Bush told veterans at a convention here today that he would hold fast to his request for more money for the military in the next fiscal year and warned Congress not to delay action on the Pentagon budget until the end of the appropriations process. 
 "I have a better idea," said Mr. Bush, who has proposed spending about $33 billion more on the Pentagon in the next fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1, than was originally appropriated for the 2001 fiscal year, administration officials said. 
 "Let us keep our priorities straight and start with the things that matter most to our country's security and our country's future," Mr. Bush said at the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention here. "This year, let us have responsible spending from Day 1 and put the national security and education of our children first in line when it comes to the appropriations process." 
Mr. Bush was in part telling more than 10,000 men and women at the veterans meeting what they wanted to hear, including a promise to clear what he described as an unacceptable backlog in veterans' unpaid benefits claims.
The president was also girding for the appropriations war that will heat up when Congress returns from its August recess and Mr. Bush heads back to Washington after four weeks at his ranch near Crawford, Tex.
Leading Senate Democrats maintain that a military increase on the scale that Mr. Bush has proposed is unaffordable without substantial cuts in other areas, and they say Mr. Bush has yet to identify such potential savings.
But beyond those specifics, the appropriations process will be a tug of war between Mr. Bush and Congressional Democrats over who can make the strongest claim to fiscal prudence at a time of shrinking surpluses and a sluggish economy.
With his remarks today, Mr. Bush was giving the rope a vigorous yank, and he was once again presenting himself as a Washington outsider who had come to bring a dose of sanity to an insiders' crazy game.
"As we enter the appropriations process," Mr. Bush said, "I have great hopes, but no illusions. Washington has its own way of doing things, especially around the time of year when final appropriations are made."
He later added, "When it is time to pass the last bill, they are just about to go over the budget. And often, and sadly, the final bill has been the defense appropriations bill."
Mr. Bush vowed that this was "the old way of doing business."
In fact, military spending has often come late in the process not because lawmakers have been trying to choke it off, but because the Pentagon's spending bill is more complicated than many others. Additionally, Mr. Bush's fellow Republicans controlled both chambers of Congress -- and the appropriations process -- from 1995 until this year.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush had requested about $329 billion in discretionary military spending for the next fiscal year, up from what they said was about $296 billion in the original 2001 budget. After Mr. Bush took office, he signed a supplemental military appropriation of close to $6 billion for 2001.
Mr. Bush alluded to these figures to assert his commitment to the military. He also cited a "top-to-bottom review" of the process for paying veterans' health care and pension claims that is being conducted by the secretary of veterans affairs, Anthony J. Principi. The president estimated the backlog to be about 600,000 unpaid claims.
"When the draft board got your file," Mr. Bush told the veterans, "it worked efficiently. But now, when you need health care, forms get lost and answers come late. That is no way to treat America's veterans, and that is going to change."
Mr. Principi later told reporters that his goal was to cut the total backlog of cases to 200,000 by 2003 and to reduce the average time to process a claim to three months from nine or more.
As Mr. Bush used his words to try to portray himself as someone high above political pettiness, he used his actions to try to portray himself as someone at eye level with working-class people.
After his speech to veterans, he visited a Harley-Davidson factory in Menomonee Falls, just outside Milwaukee, where motorcycle engines are manufactured.
First on an assembly line and then in the cafeteria, Mr. Bush mingled with many of the factory's roughly 1,000 employees.
The president's advisers would like to improve his standing with organized labor, a potent political force in closely contested Midwestern states like Wisconsin, which Mr. Bush narrowly lost last year.
But the president's conversations veered away from politics and policy.
"How's your golf game?" one man asked him.
"It stinks," Mr. Bush replied.
He left after about an hour and 20 minutes with parting gifts, including a helmet of many colors and a coat of black leather bearing the Harley-Davidson logo.
Mr. Bush's visit to Wisconsin, to be followed on Tuesday by a visit to Missouri, took him away from a sustained break in Crawford that he has described as an important respite from Washington and that has prompted considerable scrutiny and ribbing.
He slyly acknowledged all of that in his remarks to the veterans today.
"It is important for a president never to become isolated in the seat of power," Mr. Bush said. "As great and influential as that city is, sometimes the president just has to get out of Crawford, Tex."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-9

Yemen Stalls F.B.I. Pursuit Of bin Laden in Cole Blast
An F.B.I. investigation into the deadly suicide bombing of the American destroyer Cole in Yemen last year has virtually ground to a halt because Yemeni authorities have refused to widen the inquiry to include Islamic militant groups in Yemen. The decision has frustrated American efforts to link the bombing conclusively to Osama bin Laden. A1

Militants Vow More Bombings
Muslim militants vowed to avenge the killing of a Palestinian fighter, Samir Abu Zeid, and his two children with more suicide bombings in Israel. The Israeli Army denied accusations that they had assassinated Mr. Abu Zeid and said he had killed himself and his children when a bomb he was making exploded. A9

Plutonium Plan Under Review
A program conceived by the Clinton administration to rid the world of 100 tons of American and Russian weapons-grade plutonium is likely to be abandoned by the Bush administration, according to people who have been briefed about it. Bush administration officials deny that the program is dead, but acknowledge that the future of the program has difficulties, primarily financial ones. A1

Slump in U.S., Slump in Mexico
Mexico has been dragged into recession by the faltering American economy, taking a toll on millions of Mexicans and the political aspirations of President Vicente Fox. Promises that he made when he took office on Dec. 1, including the creation of 1.4 million jobs, have gone unfulfilled. A3

Khmer Rouge Trials More Likely
A new law that establishes the framework for an international tribunal in Cambodia, and a show of support from Prime Minister Hun Sen last week, have enhanced prospects that several Khmer Rouge leaders will eventually go on trial. A9

Charges in Fatal Hotel Fire
Philippine officials filed criminal charges against William Genato, owner of a hotel that caught fire last weekend, leaving 73 people dead. A3

NATO Studies Macedonia Truce
NATO's top commander, Gen. Joseph Ralston, met with alliance officers and Macedonian security chiefs in Skopje to determine whether a government cease-fire with ethnic Albanian guerrillas had improved enough to begin a NATO mission. A4

World Briefing A8

NATIONAL A10-15

Democrats Plan to Fault Bush for Shrinking Surplus
President Bush is to speak about the budget outlook today, and both the White House and Congress are set to confirm that the surplus outside of Social Security has all but evaporated for the next few years. Democrats are planning to intensify their attacks on Mr. Bush's fiscal management and to pin blame for the weakened economy on the White House. A1

HEADLINE: Countdown to the Great Labor Shortage 

BYLINE:  By WELD ROYAL 

 BODY:
The daily flurry of layoffs is bringing major changes to the workplace as companies struggle with the economic downturn. But if government predictions play out as expected, soon there will be an equally big and opposite shift as baby boomers retire and the nation experiences one of its most severe labor shortages.
 In its most recent study, released in November 1999, the Bureau of Labor Statistics projected that the gap between the number of jobs available and the number of people to fill them would grow to six million in 2008. And this is just the start of a shortage that will peak from 2015 to 2025, when the bulk of workers born between 1946 and 1964, as many as 60 million, reach retirement age. 
 Occupations with large numbers of older workers like construction inspection and teaching in secondary schools are expected to suffer. So are fields creating jobs at a fast pace, like computer engineering.
Of course, there are always unexpected developments that can radically change the workplace -- the women's movement, the Internet, a war. But experts say the coming demographic shift is sure to have an impact.
"As the baby boomers retire, we'll be losing the head of the proverbial python that tried to swallow the elephant," said Ross C. DeVol, director of regional and demographic studies at the Milken Institute, an economic research group in Santa Monica, Calif. "And that will have ramifications on the diversity of the work force. There will be more women and minorities in the work force, and older Americans deciding to work longer."
For workers, experts say, the imbalance means opportunities in fields like engineering or health care where the shortages will be the most acute. For companies, the shortages will mean sending more jobs overseas and turning to immigrants to do the work Americans cannot or will not do. Already, such trends are under way.
"Finding qualified workers remains a top economic development priority, even during this downturn," said Shepard Nevel, executive director of the Mayor's Office of Workforce Development in Denver.
Technological advances have allowed companies like Affiliated Computer Services, a Dallas-based information technology concern, to weave a patchwork of solutions here and overseas. ACS generates half its $1.96 billion in revenue from business service. In one operation, employees in Lexington, Ky., retrieve their client companies' correspondence from a local post office, scan it and send it by satellite to a data processing center in Ghana, in West Africa. There, 500 workers -- mostly young women -- enter the information into a database. They can earn about 80 cents an hour plus benefits, amazingly cheap by American standards but well beyond Ghana's minimum wage of about 80 cents a day.
ACS first set up such outposts abroad to lower costs, but expanded further as it struggled to find enough workers in America willing to handle data processing. "When we opened our office in Guatemala City, we had 500 people on the first day looking for a job," said Jeffrey A. Rich, the chief executive. "If we had opened in Manhattan, we would have had just a few people."
In Baltimore, economic development officials say they will not be able to attract the next generation of workers with such routine data processing jobs. And they are worried because a decade from now, the city and surrounding region are expected to have 108,000 fewer people aged 25 to 44 than now. Among other steps, government officials, executives and philanthropists financed a series of recent focus groups nationwide to find out exactly what the baby boomers' children want in a job. The aim is to attract companies that have jobs that will appeal to this group.
Companies will have to grapple with changes in the work force structure, said Ronald E. Bird, chief economist for the Employment Policy Foundation, a business-oriented research group based in Washington. Thirty years ago, he said, the labor market was shaped like a pyramid topped by corporate executives and other professionals (24 percent of the work force). In the middle were the skilled crafts workers, clerks and administrators (36 percent). The remaining 40 percent, including unskilled laborers, made up the bottom. But that pyramid has been shifting, with the top and the middle making up 71 percent of jobs now and projected to make up 77 percent by 2031.
BE&K Inc. of Birmingham, Ala., which designs and builds industrial plants worldwide, has been wrestling with these changes. It says it cannot find enough skilled laborers. To address the escalating shortage, it created a task force on the future of construction work. The group foresees a more diverse labor pool, with more new immigrants and women. But attracting women is an uphill battle because of the industry's macho image.
The number of women in the work force has more than doubled, to 62 million, since 1970, but they still constitute only 10 percent of all construction industry workers, according to the National Association of Women in Construction. BE&K has managed to beat that ratio -- some 12 percent of its 10,700 employees are women -- through such initiatives as day care at job sites and networking groups.
To attract more young women, it sends role models like Mary Hodge, a 47-year-old electrical supervisor, to visit high schools. This summer, it enrolled 10 high school girls in a free construction camp, where Ms. Hodge showed them how to thread electrical wires through siding while talking up opportunities for travel and the good pay -- perhaps $80,000 a year with overtime.
John Natoli, 52, also acts like a cheerleader for his profession. Mr. Natoli, chief engineer at the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, says while unemployment statistics are inching up, they do not square with what he is already finding: a dearth of engineers. "If 15 or 25 of them walked into my office now, I could hire them," he said. The gap is so big that Mr. Natoli does not expect this to change even if the downturn persists awhile.
The unit runs help-wanted ads, sends e-mail messages to new graduates and hires from other agencies. But people leave, and Mr. Natoli cannot always replace them with American-trained engineers, who can make much more in private industry. As a result, the construction unit has become a mecca for immigrant engineers, with roughly 40 percent of the engineers educated abroad.
Despite some tensions, Mr. Natoli said, work pressures mostly trump cultural divides. "People have so much to do, they forget about everything else," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mary Hodge, right, electrical supervisor for BE&K Inc., on a job site in Decatur, Ala. (Steve Gates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Why Put Out Every Wildfire in the Forests? 

BYLINE:  By William Kittredge; William Kittredge is the author, most recently, of "The Nature of Generosity."

DATELINE: MISSOULA, Mont. 

 BODY:
A year ago, crossing the Higgins Avenue bridge into downtown Missoula, I was unable to make out the Great Northern Railroad Depot five blocks away. The air was that thick with smoke. A dark, unblinking red sun hung in a sky that was reddish gray shading to black. 
 The sun resembled the eye of a very cranky god. Great tracts of timberland in northern Idaho and western Montana were afire. Prevailing winds were blowing in our direction. 
 I was on my way to Quality Wholesale, shopping for big lawn sprinklers, the kind that throw long, revolving cascades of water. Annick Smith, my longtime love, lives in a log house 25 miles out of town, above the Big Blackfoot River, in fields surrounded by timber. We wanted to wet down the meadows around her house. We were determined to save her home. Not that it was threatened. Not yet.
For almost a century, federal agencies in charge of managing public lands in the West believed their mission was to put out fires, natural or otherwise. They were responding to public will. My neighbors, when I was in the ranch business, regarded putting out fires as an absolute government responsibility. So, a couple of years earlier, when I visited John Hyde, a ranger in Oregon, I was surprised to find that he was dismayed over what he described as overactive federal fire suppression policies.
John explained that natural wildfires had historically kept the floor of the forests clear of debris, while the big trees survived. Settlers drove wagons in what would look to us like open parks under big yellow pine. Now, after a hundred years of our putting out every fire, the woodlands are thick with combustibles. It's tough to hike across those same hills, which are brushy and cluttered with downed timber that should have burned decades ago. "One day," John said, "we're going to have an inferno." It's easy to imagine.
If he's right, who's to blame? Maybe Thomas Jefferson. He sent Lewis and Clark west to determine how the vast unknown property called the Louisiana Purchase might be converted into a pastoral homeland for settlers. Maybe Jefferson's dream placed too much emphasis on taming. Wildfires, however chaotic, are essential to forest ecologies. Before settlers arrived, Native American tribes even set fires in autumn to encourage vigorous regrowth and provide good browse and grazing for game.
But ordinary human fearfulness is probably the real culprit. A lot of people claim to love wildness, but what many really seem to love is the idea of wildness. The actual item can be dangerous. That's a reason Westerners have been so intent on killing wolves and grizzly bears. Great carnivores on the loose are bad for business -- as are wildfires, an intensely dangerous form of wildness.
Westerners are profoundly double-hearted about the realities of land and water use. The exploitation of "nature" has for generations been the primary basis for our economy -- logging and mining, grazing on public lands, pumping the aquifers dry to support irrigation for agriculture. In drought years, fire suppression itself can be a local summer industry.
A lot of people work very hard fighting fires. Some die terrifying deaths in the line of duty. But big-time fire suppression is like war -- federally financed, whatever the expense -- with bulldozers, helicopters, planes and legions of foot soldiers. Many in rural communities make their money for the year working on and supporting fire crews. 
On the other hand, "nature" also tends to be beloved by the rural people who do much of the exploiting. Many of those moving to the West in droves dream of a home in the woods, seeking what I've heard described as "lifestyle enhancement."
So, we're in a real fix: timberlands are filled with combustibles and a lot of people are building houses under the trees. What to do in fire season?
It might be sensible to support local economies through a federally financed effort to clean up the woods. I don't mean "salvage logging" by timber corporations using industrial equipment; massive machines clawing up ecosystems are part of the problem. Instead, experienced local people, using horses to assist in the heavy work, could start the process of clearing away downed timber and brush. They could pile the accumulated debris and burn it in late fall when runaway wildfire danger is minimal. Then tax dollars would be helping to prevent fires rather than suppress them, and the federal money would still stay in local economies. Top that off with public planning to discourage home building in the deep woods, and maybe we'd be getting somewhere.
Last summer Annick and I set out our sprinklers, but the effort seemed a little pathetic. We could imagine a tourist tossing a cigarette into the dry weeds along Interstate 80, a few miles away over timbered hills. What if a heavy wind happened to be blowing in our direction? In an hour or so we might confront towering flames, running treetop to treetop. We lucked out then, as we have this year. There are no fires in our vicinity even though half a million acres are burning as I write. But what about next year, and the year after that? Can we hold the line with lawn sprinklers? 

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Owen Smith)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; 
Hearst Shuts Down Magazine

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
The weak advertising economy has claimed another victim, as Hearst Magazines is closing Classic American Home.
 The magazine, published every two months, was introduced in 1975 as Colonial Homes. 
It adopted its new name last year. 
 "It is a difficult decision to cease publication of a lifestyle magazine like Classic American Home, with a following of dedicated readers," Paul Luthringer, a spokesman for Hearst Magazines in New York, said in a statement. 
A report of the closing appeared this week in the trade publication Folio First Day.
Mr. Luthringer attributed the closing to a determination that the magazine "does not have the potential to reach the circulation levels that we use as a benchmark for mass consumer magazines today."
The circulation of Classic American Home stood at 521,000, ranking it among the smallest of Hearst's publications; the circulation rate base guaranteed to advertisers was 500,000.
According to the Publishers Information Bureau, ad pages for Classic American Home for the first four issues of 2001 totaled 113, down 6.8 percent from the comparable period of 2000. The July-August magazine, now on newsstands, is the final issue.
The closing is the second for Hearst in 2001. In January, Offspring, a test quarterly introduced last year, was absorbed by SmartMoney, which is published in partnership with Dow Jones. Classic American Home was the third magazine to announce a closing in the last week, along with The Industry Standard and Working Woman. Other recent closings include Family PC and Individual Investor.
