HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Brann Worldwide is acquiring Wong Wong Boyack to add an Asian marketing capability.

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
A LARGE direct marketing agency is expanding its offerings by acquiring a smaller one that specializes in marketing to Asian and Asian-American consumers.
 The acquisition by Brann Worldwide in Wilton, Conn., of Wong Wong Boyack in San Francisco, for undisclosed terms, points to the growing interest among marketers in seeking to engage consumers in ways deemed culturally relevant rather than with "one size fits all" pitches. The trend is being fed by data from the 2000 census, showing sizable increases in minority populations, as well as by hopes that appealing to market niches or segments may be profitable in a weak economy. 
 "It's all about understanding unique consumer behavior throughout the buying process," said David Finkel, president and chief executive at Brann. "Different segments need to be communicated to differently." 
Brann, part of the Diversified Agency Group unit of Havas Advertising, the big French-owned agency company, is rebranding Wong Wong Boyack as Brann Wong Wong.
There are eight employees at Brann Wong Wong, which handles accounts with billings estimated at $10 million from clients like American Savings Bank in Honolulu, Cisco Systems and Sina.com, a Web site for Chinese communities.
Brann Wong Wong will operate from the San Francisco office of Brann, as the first unit of Brann that will be focused on marketing to consumers of specific ethnicity. The agency will work not only with Brann San Francisco but also with the 17 Brann offices in 14 cities in Europe and North America.
"We wanted to have an Asian capability," Mr. Finkel said, because that market is the fastest growing of the nation's major ethnic markets as well as highly educated and affluent.
The 2000 census showed there were 10.2 million Americans who identified themselves as "Asian," compared with 6.9 million who did so in 1990. If the people who described themselves as of two or more races are included, the "Asian" number in 2000 climbed to almost 11.9 million; the 1990 census did not include a combination-race question.
Mr. Finkel said Brann was also attracted to Wong Wong Boyack by the strengths of the agency's top executives. They are Penelope Wong, president and chief executive, and her brother, Ben Wong, chairman and chief financial officer. (The Boyack in Wong Wong Boyack referred to Lee Boyack, who had led account services before leaving the agency in 1996.)
"We are not an ethnic agency that uses direct marketing by default," said Ms. Wong, who identifies herself as Chinese-American. "We approach it as direct marketing, as target marketing, and we use all the strategic tools that are available to us."
Ms. Wong suggested several reasons for the interest in acquiring her agency, which was founded in 1991. Advertisers want larger agencies as they themselves grow larger, she said, through expansion or acquisition. And being part of Brann, she added, would give her clients access to additional resources like research.
Ms. Wong, 48, takes on the added post of executive vice president and director for strategic business and brand development at Brann San Francisco. Mr. Wong, 50, takes on the added post of executive vice president and director for strategic planning and insight at Brann San Francisco.
About two years ago, Mr. Finkel said, Brann identified ethnic marketing as a priority and also looked into expanding into direct marketing to Spanish-speaking consumers.
Brann Wong Wong works on direct marketing campaigns to mainstream consumers in this country as well as ads aimed at Asians abroad, in languages including those spoken by Chinese, Japanese, Koreans and Vietnamese. Those tasks include direct mail, online advertising and ads encouraging consumers to call a toll-free number or to visit a Web site.
Ms. Wong offered a personal perspective on the Asian-American market.
"There are so many things that Asian-Americans need but they can't find," she said. She told a story about how difficult it was for her, not so many years ago, to find eyeglasses that would fit her face -- even in San Francisco, a city with a large Asian-American population.
"My nose is a Chinese nose; I don't have much of a bridge," Ms. Wong said. "Sophia Loren has a really different nose than I do. So does Calvin Klein. These things just fall right off my face."
"Now it's pretty easy for me to go into an eyeglass store and find several styles that work," she added, "but I used to have to go to Hong Kong."
"Those are the kinds of opportunities I'm talking about," Ms. Wong concluded. "There was a need, there were plenty of consumers to serve, and it just took people a while to figure out."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "There are so many things that Asian-Americans need but they can't find," said Penelope Wong of the Brann Wong Wong agency.

HEADLINE: Franchisees On Edge; 
Some Angry Ones Sue As GNC Competes

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
A decade ago, the General Nutrition Companies was a venerable but wobbly company in the business of selling vitamins and nutritional supplements, mostly to true believers in their health benefits. Then it decided to offer franchises to entrepreneurs who dreamed of being their own boss.
 From that moment, GNC stores spread like St. John's wort, building a mass market by opening in shopping centers and along country roads. Their owners, many of them longtime GNC customers, usually prospered, selling multivitamins and muscle-building supplements, soy products and herbal remedies. 
 GNC, since 1999 a division of the Dutch company Royal Numico, became the vitamin king, with a 15 percent share of the American market and sales of $1.28 billion last year. It won plaudits as a top franchiser. 
But these days, some store owners say, they are besieged by cold-eyed competition -- not from other vitamin merchants, but from GNC itself.
At least a dozen lawsuits are pending against the company, with several more expected by next month. Last week GNC announced a settlement with some franchisees, who had sued it over what they called unfair pricing and other complaints. But the settlement stops well short of addressing all their concerns.
The central issue is how aggressive GNC has been in opening its own stores, which benefit from lower wholesale prices on many products. Often these stores are not far from existing franchises. And two years ago the company struck a deal with the Rite-Aid Corporation to open at least 1,000 GNC centers inside its drugstores. So far, 605 Rite-Aids have the centers, with 220 more expected this year. GNC is also manufacturing private-label products for Rite-Aid.
"Our worst competition," said Daniel Brandt, a GNC franchisee in Silverdale, Wash., who is not a plaintiff, "is the company."
Company executives say that they have no desire to ruin their franchisees and that the dissatisfaction among a relative handful of franchisees comes from their own shortcomings.
"The franchisees are perhaps poor operators, and are running into financial difficulty," said Jim Sander, GNC's general counsel, when asked why so many lawsuits had been filed. He noted that more companies have started selling vitamins and related products, just as demand has contracted with a slowing economy.
"It makes no sense for us to drive a franchisee out of business," he said. "It would destroy the good will that a location has with its customers, and would make them look down on General Nutrition."
Nearly all the franchisees' lawsuits share a similar theme -- that GNC misled them about its pricing structure, the company-store program or the arrangement with Rite-Aid. Jeffrey Goldstein, a Washington lawyer representing some plaintiffs, recently amended several lawsuits to include racketeering claims, based on similarities among many cases. 
In last week's settlement of several lawsuits that had sought class-action status for all independent franchisees, the company said it would spend $4.2 million over two years to give franchisees credits worth $125 a store a month for two years.
It is unclear, however, how many franchisees will be interested. For it to be binding, 90 percent of them must approve it. Ed Bishop, a store owner from Indiana and legal director for an association that represents about 300 franchisees, said everyone he had talked to was planning to opt out of the settlement. Those who accept the settlement are still free to file new lawsuits against the company in the future. Calling the $125 credit "peanuts," he said he typically orders $16,000 worth of GNC products a month for each of his two stores.
But Russ Cooper, the senior vice president in charge of franchising at GNC, said he had an enthusiastic response to the settlement from around the country. "I think we'll be over the 90 percent hurdle that we need," he said.
Some plaintiffs in the lawsuits were successful before things took a turn for the worse. Kevin and Jeniffer Lee, owners of several stores in the Los Angeles area, won sales awards like the "Million Dollar Store" prize before a company-owned store opened not far away, according to documents filed in the case.
GNC has 1,430 franchised stores and 2,700 company-owned stores, Mr. Cooper said. Company stores are opened twice as fast as franchisee stores, he said, calling this "a healthy mix." Company stores are usually in indoor malls, he said, while franchisees tend to be in strip malls or by themselves.
Company stores pay less than franchisees for many of their products, Mr. Cooper said, but a few products, like vitamin E and beta carotene, are sold to franchisees at a loss or at cost.
He maintains that franchisees could profit even with dual pricing by keeping inventories high and following other recommended GNC sales practices.
GNC said a franchise typically takes in about $340,000 annually, compared with $450,000 at a company store. "The gross margin for franchisees is about 50 percent," Mr. Cooper said, while company stores' profits are declining.
The company-owned stores are part of GNC's "competition program." Executives say the program was prompted in 1998 by price-cutting at a rival, Vitamin World, a unit of Nature's Bounty.
One franchisee, Gulzar Niazi, saw a company store materialize in a mall four miles away within months of his opening his store. After complaining to GNC management in Pittsburgh, he said, he began to receive failing grades from company inspection teams. Last month, Mr. Niazi lost his store and said he would file for bankruptcy. "I am wrecked, wrecked, wrecked," he said in an interview.
Mr. Cooper said Mr. Niazi did not keep enough products on his shelves. "He was getting store report scores of 53 out of a possible 100," he said.
But the real trouble, Mr. Niazi said, was the company store in the Waterbury Mall, which was undercutting his prices. A product called Myaplex Light, for instance, which cost him $25.80 wholesale, was sold to customers for $20 in the mall store, he said. He collected dozens of receipts as evidence.
Mr. Niazi's experience is echoed by others. "I have suffered from that," said Eric Miller, who owns six stores in the Philadelphia area and otherwise calls himself a contented GNC franchisee. "You do what you can. You have to match GNC's prices in their competition program." 
Documents in the Lees' lawsuit, which speaks of a pattern of fraud by GNC's franchising arm, manufacturing division and corporate offices, include a declaration by Kevin Lee, the Los Angeles franchisee, in which he accuses the company of having a "wholesale dual-pricing structure under the competition program that has devastated my stores."
Mr. Lee is trying to force GNC to turn over internal documents that would show how it picked store sites, formed its discount programs and set up its contracts. In a similar lawsuit by a franchisee in Baltimore, the judge issued an order last month to compel GNC to turn over internal memos.
Mr. Cooper said the company planned to comply with every legal requirement in the lawsuits. He and company lawyers denied any unlawful activity. Mr. Cooper said the Lees' business fell off because a store manager left and a Vitamin World store moved in next to them. As for the Baltimore case, filed by a franchisee named Igor Rafalovich, Mr. Cooper said: "He's an individual who does not understand franchising. He's challenged by that."
Mr. Goldstein, who represents the Lees and Mr. Rafalovich, responded: "No jury is going to believe these absurd excuses."
Mr. Bishop, the store owner from Indiana, said he became legal director (even though he is not a lawyer) of the franchisees' association two years ago after encountering problems himself.
At a presentation in Pittsburgh in 1998, he said, the company promised generous margins and told of excellent prospects for franchise owners. Since then, he has battled GNC over a variety of issues, from its use of his customer list for e-mail marketing that directs them to shop on Drugstore.com, in which GNC is a stakeholder, to its sending him expired products, which Mr. Bishop had to pay for because he did not return them within two weeks. 
Franchisees pay up to $32,500 for the right to open a store, and perhaps $200,000 for the fixtures and stocking the shelves, according to the 1999 offering plan. They must pay rent to GNC, which insists on being the leaseholder for all stores, and contract with the company for accounting services, in addition to buying products from GNC. They are permitted to buy from other companies as well, as long as the products are approved by GNC.
Mr. Brandt, the Washington state franchisee, said he negotiated his own lease for his first store, at $14 a square foot. Then, he said, there was a snag. GNC wanted the lease in its name, so it "came in behind me and said, we'll give you $18 a square foot," he recalled.
"I once had more trust in this company, but once they did that, I was really surprised. At that point, I had already paid the franchise fee."
Financing is also an issue. To open stores, Mr. Cooper said, many franchisees borrow from the company. "We have competitive rates," he said, "and we don't require them to pledge their personal assets."
But one longtime franchisee who planned to open another store this year said she had looked into the GNC offer and turned it down. "The interest rate is 12 percent," said the franchisee, Blanche Green, who owns a store in Cartersville, Ga., that became a GNC store 10 years ago. "I can beat that at my local bank."
In the last two years, at least 300 franchisees have left GNC, Mr. Brandt said. Their names, locations and closing dates are listed in the offering plan distributed to prospective franchisees.
In the early 1980's, some franchisers came under fire for their treatment of franchisees, said Ann Dugan, co-author of a training manual called "Franchising 101" and an expert on small business at the University of Pittsburgh. "There are some things that GNC has come down hard on their franchisees for that seem foolish to me," she said. "Franchisees are business owners. They've got to make money." 
Robert L. Purvin, author of "The Franchise Fraud," (John Wiley & Sons, 1994) and an advocate with the American Franchisee Association, said he had contacted the Federal Trade Commission about some of the problems at GNC. But he said there had been little response. An F.T.C. lawyer, Robert Frisby, said the agency had taken three actions against GNC in the last 32 years, all for misleading claims on products, not franchises. He would not say whether any franchising complaints were being investigated.
GNC, meanwhile, plans to keep expanding. "Our growth will come primarily from international stores this year," Mr. Cooper said. "And we will open 100 stores domestically this year. Over half our openings will be done by franchisees." 
Mr. Purvin remained worried, though, about the future of GNC's franchises. The company is now "predominantly a manufacturer," he said.
"It's looking for ways to sell as many of its products as it can."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Drop Sharply on Concern Over Message From Fed

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday after the Federal Reserve lowered its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to its lowest level since spring 1994.
 The Fed's policy makers cited the possibility of continued economic weakness for their decision to cut their target for the federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks to 3.5 percent from 3.75 percent. The rate reduction, the seventh this year, was part of the aggressive effort to revive the sluggish economy. 
 Still, analysts said that investors were now more concerned about weak corporate profits than about monetary policy and that the downbeat tone from the Federal Reserve shook investors' confidence in an already volatile trading environment. Stocks, which had been modestly higher ahead of the announcement at 2:15 p.m., tumbled in a broad decline.
"It's the statement that's knocking the wind out of the market," said Peter I. Cardillo, chief strategist at Westfalia Investments. "The Fed is not convinced that we're in any sort of recovery."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 145.93 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 10,174.14. The Nasdaq composite index declined 50.05 points, or 2.7 percent, to 1,831.30, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 14.15 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,157.26.
Notable losers yesterday included semiconductor issues like Linear Technology, which fell $3.22, to $39; Altera, which lost $1.86, to $26.48; and Xilinx, which dropped $1.92, to $36.48. Intel fell $1.13, to $27.07. 
Abby Joseph Cohen, who has been perennially bullish, also weighed in yesterday with mixed signals about the future of the economy. Ms. Cohen, chief investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs, cut her forecast for the end of the year for the S.& P. 500 to 1,500 from 1,550, although she still predicted a rise of more than 28 percent in the index the rest of the year. 
Analysts and economists said the most important part of the Fed's rate decision yesterday was the central bank's tone about the future of the economy.
"It seems as though the move and the communique are a push and that the Fed is taking a wait-and-see attitude," said Bryan Piskorowski, market commentator at Prudential Securities.
"That leads to more inertia for the market for the very near term," he said. "We're going to need another strong stream of data points to really come to a better view of where the economy stands." --------------------

Treasuries Are Higher
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve lowered its target interest rate and signaled it might lower it more in coming months.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 11/32, to a price of 101 4/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.86 percent from 4.90 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 11/32, to 99 7/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.43 percent from 5.45 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
AOL Time Warner Will Cut More Jobs

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
AOL Time Warner Inc., the world's largest Internet and media company, said yesterday that it would cut more than 1,200 jobs at America Online, its Internet unit, and would take a third-quarter charge of $100 million to $125 million.
 The unit, which employs about 16,000 people, also said it would eliminate another 500 jobs as part of an alliance between its Netscape division and Sun Microsystems Inc. 
 The cost-cutting effort -- the third major round of layoffs at the company after the completion of the $106.2 billion merger of AOL and Time Warner in January -- was widely expected by analysts. 
AOL, which is based in Dulles, Va., said the reorganization aims to integrate more tightly its multiple online brands and Web properties.
As part of the reorganization, the company said it would create a new AOL Interactive Services Group that would encompass the AOL service and its local Digital City guide business. It will be led by Jonathan Sacks, the AOL president.
It will also create a new AOL Web Properties Group, led by Jim Bankoff, formerly president of the pioneering Netscape software business. 
The group will encompass Netscape, CompuServe, Moviefone, Mapquest and the popular instant messaging services ICQ and AOL.
The move follows cuts announced earlier this year.
In January, the company cut 2,400 jobs in several areas, including its 24-hour news network CNN, its publishing unit that houses People and Time magazines, and its film units, including New Line Cinema.
The company, which employs a total of about 90,000 people, also said this summer it would close its Warner Brothers Studio Stores by October, cutting 3,800 jobs.
Analysts have said the company has to cut costs to come close to meeting its aggressive financial targets for 2001, given the economic uncertainty and advertising slowdown.
While some analysts have reduced their 2001 earnings and revenue estimates for AOL Time Warner recently, most concur that the company is still one of the better-insulated media companies.
Yesterday, AOL Time Warner shares fell 31 cents, to close at $39.90.

HEADLINE: Age Limit Is Urged for Motorized Scooter Users 

BYLINE:  By JULIAN E. BARNES 

 BODY:
Concerned about rising numbers of injuries, the Consumer Product Safety Commission will warn parents today not to permit children younger than 12 to ride motorized toy scooters.
 Sleek silver scooters like the Razor, featuring thin plastic wheels and a foot brake, took off in popularity last year, and so did scooter-related injuries. This year, the commission said, motorized versions of those toys have become more common, and so have related injuries. 
 There were roughly 4,390 injuries from motorized scooters that required emergency-room treatment last year, and about 39 percent of the injuries involved children under 15, the commission said. In the first seven months of this year, the commission found, 2,250 people were taken to emergency rooms for injuries associated with motorized scooters. 
In addition, since the beginning of last year, two children and one adult have died after accidents involving motorized scooters, the commission said. Most recently, a 6-year-old boy in Orange County, Calif., died on Aug. 15 from injuries sustained six days earlier when he fell from a motorized scooter.
Ann Brown, the chairwoman of the safety commission, said the motorized scooters on the market, most of which go 9 to 14 miles an hour, travel too swiftly for young children.
"No 6-year-old should be on these things," she said. "Children under 12 do not have the manual dexterity to use them."
At the start of last year, California banned children younger than 16 from driving motorized scooters.
"We are concerned," said Sgt. Steven Doan of the Orange County Sheriff's Department. "We are seeing an increased use in an age group that is too young to use these scooters. With younger children it's a recipe for disaster."
Washington and Oregon also restrict the use of motorized scooters, and several towns and cities have passed laws prohibiting children from riding them.
Small privately held companies dominate the market for motorized scooters, which generally sell for $400 to $1,000. Patmont Motor Werks is the largest manufacturer, and made about 100,000 motorized Go-Ped scooters last year, according to the commission. Steve Patmont, the chief executive of the company, declined to confirm those sales estimates but said that sales were down slightly this year because of the slowing economy.
Other larger companies are planning to get into the market -- and focus on a younger audience. Fisher-Price, a unit of Mattel, plans to sell an electric scooter this holiday season that will travel at about 7 m.p.h. The scooter, which will sell for $250, is made for children age 6 and older.
Laurie Oravec, a spokeswoman for Fisher-Price, says her company's toy scooter, the Power Wheels Lightning Powered Action Cycle, would be safe for children because it accelerated slowly. The scooter has wide air-filled tires that can be ridden on grass, and Ms. Oravec said it was meant for backyard, not street, use.
Only a limited number, perhaps as few as 10,000, of the Lightnings will be available this holiday season. More will be shipped by next spring, she said. 
Jacqueline Elder, the deputy assistant executive director for the commission's Office of Hazard Identification and Reduction, said that although she would have to see the Fisher-Price scooter to assess its safety, its low speed might make it safe enough for young children.
Ms. Oravec said she hoped the commission would find that the Fisher-Price toy was a safe alternative to the current batch of motorized scooters.
"We are very good at taking older-age trends and bringing them down to a younger age child," Ms. Oravec said. "We are viewing the Lightning as the solution to the issues the C.P.S.C. is raising. Here is a vehicle that kids under 12 can use."
Ms. Brown said people who ride motorized scooters should wear sturdy shoes, helmets, knee pads and elbow pads. And she said the scooters should not be used at night.
Mr. Patmont said he approved of the safety commission's warning, but said that the government could have gone further.
"We feel strongly that scooters are not toys and are not for children under 16," he said. "It's absolutely not a toy; it's a serious transportation device."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Fed Cuts Interest Rates For Seventh Time This Year
Citing a persistently weak business environment at home and slowing economic growth abroad, the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point and signaled that its campaign to avert a recession is probably not yet over.
 The rate cut was the seventh this year and brought the federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks to 3.5 percent. It has been one of the most concentrated periods of monetary policy easing on record. Page A1. 

Jury Deliberates in Firestone Case
A jury began deliberating whether a tire made by Bridgestone/Firestone was responsible for a crash in March 2000 that left a woman paralyzed and brain damaged. C3.

His Many Citizenship Quests
When he was 7, Carlos M. Gutierrez, chief executive of Kellogg, and his family left Cuba for Miami as refugees and lost their citizenship. His family eventually moved to New York, where he became a citizen. Two of his three children were born in Mexico, and he made sure they both received United States citizenships. But it took his son 14 years. "When we walked out of the courthouse," he said, "I felt we'd achieved a major milestone." The Boss. C6.

I.M.F. to Provide Aid to Argentina
After nearly two weeks of negotiations, the International Monetary Fund announced that it would provide up to $8 billion in emergency aid to Argentina to stabilize the economy. A1.

Parents to Be Warned on Scooters
Concerned about a rise in injuries, the Consumer Product Safety Commission will warn parents today not to permit children younger than 12 to ride motorized toy scooters. A14.

Apple to Receive Emmy for FireWire
Apple Computer will receive an Emmy award today for FireWire, a technology for connecting peripheral devices to a computer. In TV production, it connects digital cameras and video-editing equipment to a computer and then shuttles images back and forth. C3.

The Conference Call Beast
The challenges to managing an international conference call are daunting. The leader must be alert to the cultural sensibilities of the participants and their varying states of fatigue; patient with their sometimes mangled English; and deft enough to keep the tone friendly while suppressing chatter. Management. C6.

Target and Saks Post Results
Target said that its fiscal second-quarter profit rose 5 percent as it lured consumers concerned about prices in the slowing economy, while Saks said its second-quarter loss widened because of declining sales at its Saks Fifth Avenue chain and regional department stores. Shares of Target fell $1.74, to $35.36, while Saks fell 19 cents, to $10.51. C6.

AOL to Lay Off 1,200 Employees

AT&T Reassures Excite Customers

HEADLINE: Budget War In Albany Pits Pataki Against All 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA and JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 21 

 BODY:
As summer began, the Capitol was mired in its annual budget deadlock. The battle lines were drearily familiar: Gov. George E. Pataki and the Republican-led Senate versus the Democrat-controlled Assembly.
 Today, there is nothing familiar about this fight. A partisan struggle between Republicans and Democrats has turned into an institutional one, pitting the governor against the Legislature. The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and his troops joined forces with the Assembly Democrats and, over Mr. Pataki's objections, adopted a budget shot full of holes, hoping to force the governor to the negotiating table. 
 The tactic seems to have worked, for now. The governor and legislative leaders held their third budget negotiation today, discussing new sources of revenue, like Indian casinos, video gambling machines at race tracks, or joining the multistate Powerball lottery, that could offset education spending sought by the Legislature. 
Mr. Bruno and the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, left the session today sounding optimistic that a deal could be near. Mr. Pataki did not. "I'm continuing to make it plain to them these are difficult economic times," he said.
At its core, this year's conflict is an intensification of a long-running power struggle between Mr. Pataki and the Legislature. The governor has repeatedly tried to assert greater control over the budget process and tie the hands of a Legislature that he believes has overstepped its bounds and reflexively spends too much. This year, he made his firmest stand yet, and the Legislature pushed back like never before, prompting the governor to ask the courts to settle the matter once and for all.
"The governor's lawsuit has less to do with this year's budget than with future budgets," said the leader of the Assembly's Republican minority, John J. Faso, who is close to Mr. Pataki. "A large part of the governor's motivation is to establish the authority of the office."
Even if this year's impasse is resolved, the governor's aides say the lawsuit and the more fundamental struggle it represents will continue.
Several aggravating factors helped bring the fight to a head this year, including a slowing economy that prompted Mr. Pataki to dig in his heels.
Most important, Mr. Bruno and the Senate Republicans, who had long been frustrated by dealing with the Democrats, grew equally impatient with the governor. Unlike the experience of previous years, they were unable until last week to coax Mr. Pataki into negotiation and compromise, and saw in his actions a lack of respect for the Legislature and its role.
"The governor acts as though the Senate is just there to do his bidding, he has this take-it-or-leave-it attitude, and Joe got tired of it," said a lobbyist who is close to Mr. Bruno.
Aides to Mr. Bruno said he became particularly irked when Mr. Pataki began sending the Legislature emergency spending bills to keep the government running a week at a time, rather than two or three weeks. That forced the Legislature to return to Albany every week, long after the scheduled end of this year's legislative session in June. Meanwhile, the governor was criss-crossing the state, cutting ribbons and criticizing the Legislature, but would not meet legislative leaders to discuss the budget.
Mr. Pataki took the position that his job was done when he proposed a budget in January, and that he should not negotiate budget details with the Legislature. For most of this year, Mr. Bruno agreed, joining the governor in assailing the Democrats and calling on them to begin budget conference committee meetings. The Republicans even held mock conference sessions and lectured Democrats in absentia, before an audience of reporters, for not attending.
"Joe was incredibly frustrated that the process wasn't moving," said a Republican senator. "He thought Shelly's approach was wrong, but he understood it."
Under a 1998 law passed at Mr. Pataki's insistence, legislators go unpaid after the April 1 start of the fiscal year if there is no budget. By mid-summer, irritation with the governor was running high in both houses, and lawmakers were pressuring Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver to get paychecks issued again.
August loomed as a deadline. Most school districts outside New York City have to send out their property tax bills before Sept. 1, and without the expected increase in aid from Albany, those bills would rise. It was a smaller issue to the Assembly Democrats, but Senate Republicans feared blame for higher taxes.
Ultimately, it was Mr. Bruno who proposed last month that they pass a stripped-down budget, aides in both houses said. In announcing the deal in late July, Mr. Bruno repeatedly stressed that the Legislature was "an equal partner" in the process, wording that his aides say was aimed at the governor.
From the 1970's until 1997, budgets were negotiated by governors and legislative leaders. Then, in 1998, the Assembly and Senate abandoned that method and drafted a budget in public conference committees without directly involving the governor.
Mr. Pataki, not tied to the deal, vetoed 1,300 spending items worth $1.6 billion. He also pushed the boundaries of how the line-item veto power had been used in the past, leading to a still-pending lawsuit by Mr. Silver. The Democrats concluded from 1998 that the governor had to be a party to the budget deal -- the outlines, if not the specifics -- or he would veto their pet programs at will.
But since then, Mr. Pataki has resisted negotiations. The negotiated budgets of the past, his office argues, were a legislative power grab in defiance of the state Constitution, which gives governors the most control over budgets.
Mr. Pataki and his aides insist that he was always willing to discuss broad parameters, but that the Assembly's spending demands were so high -- more than $2 billion above the governor's proposed $83.6 billion -- that there was no point in talking. They note, rightly, that the governor's call for a 5 percent spending increase was hardly austere, and that independent fiscal monitors applauded his restraint.
"When the speaker says the governor won't negotiate, what he's really saying is the governor won't cave in to my demands to spend more," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the governor.
But the gap between Mr. Silver and Mr. Pataki was less stark than it appeared. Each year, the Assembly seeks billions more than the governor, but it is a bargaining position, later abandoned. And as much as a month ago, in private talks, Mr. Silver cut his demands by more than $1 billion, leaving him at roughly the same level as the Senate.
The governor rejected even that as too much, helping push the Senate toward turning its back on Mr. Pataki. He and his aides acknowledge that the governor has been more rigid than usual this year about not increasing spending much above his proposal, but they say that is due to his fears about the economy, not to a desire to have his way.
A more basic dispute stems from the way Mr. Pataki writes his budgets, and the fact that the state Constitution puts strict limits on what the Legislature can do to his appropriations bills.
With each passing year, the governor has inserted into his appropriations bills more and more text containing changes in state law on how money is spent. He has also increasingly lumped many projects together as a few large, general line items. With those changes, he has sought to give himself the maximum power to alter state law and decide how money is used, with minimal input from the Legislature.
Legislators began complaining about this trend a few years ago, and this year they tried to reverse it by amending some of the governor's budget bills. In his suit, Mr. Pataki, said that step violated the state Constitution. Mr. Silver and others countered that the governor's bills themselves were unconstitutional. Legal experts say it is not clear who is right.
Mr. Pataki's aides say they are confident he will not be hurt politically by the mess, citing polls showing that most New Yorkers blame the Legislature. Legislators, in turn, express similar confidence, and some predict that ultimately, as state services suffer, so will the governor.
In any case, both sides argue, the stakes for control of state budgets are high enough to run those risks.

HEADLINE: Text of Federal Reserve's Statement 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee at its meeting today decided to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 3 1/2 percent. 
In a related action, the board of governors approved a 25-basis-point reduction in the discount rate, to 3 percent. Today's action by the F.O.M.C. brings the decline in the target federal funds rate since the beginning of the year to 300 basis points. 
 Household demand has been sustained, but business profits and capital spending continue to weaken, and growth abroad is slowing, weighing on the U.S. economy. The associated easing of pressures on labor and product markets is expected to keep inflation contained. 
Although long-term prospects for productivity growth and the economy remain favorable, the committee continues to believe that against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future. 
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Richmond, Chicago, Kansas City and Dallas.

HEADLINE: High Noon in Albany 

 BODY:
New York's governor is now suing the Legislature over the state budget. Meanwhile, schools are preparing to open without a clear idea of how much money they will have this year, and other important state services are in danger of running out of cash. The legal arguments must be suspended long enough to resolve the immediate crisis. 
 The standoff between the governor, George Pataki, and the Legislature began with a fight over how high next year's state revenues are likely to be. As always happens in Albany, the governor has picked a conservative figure, with the lawmakers opting for much more optimistic numbers that would allow room for additional spending. Traditionally, the two sides meet somewhere in the middle. But this year Mr. Pataki, citing the slowing economy, refused to budge. Now the governor and legislative leaders are talking again and are said to be close to an agreement. If so, it is long past time. 
 Cynics -- which Albany has in abundance -- wonder if the lawsuit is just another chip in the bargaining that Mr. Pataki would sacrifice in return for concessions from the Legislature. Certainly, the lawmakers are terrified of the prospect that the governor might go ahead with his court fight and strip them of their budget-making powers.
The suit centers on the State Constitution, written in 1927. The framers, whose opinion of the State Legislature was even lower than the public's is today, decreed that the governor had the duty to propose a detailed budget. The Legislature could only eliminate spending items or reduce spending -- two of its least-favorite occupations. The idea was to curb logrolling, the Legislature's habit of insisting that money directed at one town or district had to be duplicated for everybody else's bailiwick. But once the Constitution was ratified, Albany quickly reverted to a system of behind-the-scenes negotiation and tradeoffs that allowed the Legislature far more leeway to tinker.
Mr. Pataki has been pushing the limits of his power, particularly in his insistence that he has the authority to rewrite state laws in his budget. This year, for instance, he dramatically changed the rules on how school aid can be spent, and rewrote the reimbursement rates to nursing homes whose patients are on Medicaid. Citing the Constitution, he claimed that the Legislature, which wrote the original rules, had no right to object.
The governor's position seems like a stretch. Budgets in 1927 were generally simpler documents that did not accommodate the kind of changes in state policy that he has been trying to make. But his lawyers say his arguments are solid. The legislators feel they are now involved in what one aide called a "death-grip battle" to save their prerogatives.
It's possible that Mr. Pataki is grandstanding for the benefit of the conservative wing of his party, which has been angry about his pre-re-election drift to the left. He may also have been driven to this extreme step by frustration with the State Legislature, a syndrome familiar to anyone working for New York's government. But there is no excuse for holding the state's schools and social services hostage to his pique.

HEADLINE: The Last Freeway 

 BODY:
For at least a few minutes after it opened at 5 p.m. on Monday, the new six-mile stretch of the Foothill Freeway from Fontana to Rancho Cucamonga must have looked almost as fresh as the six-mile Arroyo Seco Parkway did when it first carried traffic from Pasadena to Los Angeles in December 1940. Together, these two stretches of concrete are the alpha and the near-omega of urban freeway construction in California. The Arroyo Seco Parkway, later renamed the Pasadena Freeway, opened just two months after the Pennsylvania Turnpike, becoming the first freeway in the West. The extension of the Foothill Freeway, which will fully link San Dimas and San Bernardino by 2006, may be the last. There are no new California freeways in the planning, a fact that gathers a lot of meaning when you consider that the Foothill Freeway was first sketched out in 1948. 
 This does not mean that the Los Angeles area freeways go everywhere commuters believe they should go. It means that the cost of adding more freeway miles -- measured in political will and environmental and social sacrifice as well as real dollars -- has grown unacceptable. But it also means that in the oscillating rhythm of housing and economic development and highway construction, some momentous stasis has been reached, at least in Southern California. It is tempting to say that the finishing of the Foothill Freeway will mark the end of an era. It is probably more accurate to say that with the completion of the Foothill Freeway inertia wins out. But then most L.A. commuters would argue that inertia threatens to win out almost every day on nearly every mile of the city's freeways. 
 The concrete grid that now enmeshes Los Angeles is beyond hyperbole. It was beyond hyperbole even in the mid-1960's, when the construction rush was still in its early days. For Reyner Banham, the influential English architectural critic writing in 1971, the freeway system was "indeed one of the greater works of Man." For the novelist Thomas Pynchon in 1967, an access road "was this hypodermic needle, inserted somewhere ahead into the vein of a freeway, a vein nourishing the mainliner L.A., keeping it happy, coherent, protected from pain, or whatever passes, with a city, for pain." 
In concept, the freeways must have looked like passage between one reality -- home -- and another -- work. But the lane stripes had hardly dried on the first of them before it became clear that the freeways were a reality unto themselves, a reality that offered a psychological freedom and a psychological burden to drivers all at once. In Joan Didion's 1970 novel, "Play It as It Lays," one character surrenders compulsively to the Los Angeles freeways. Day after day, "she drove the San Diego to the Harbor, the Harbor up to the Hollywood, the Hollywood to the Golden State, the Santa Monica, the Santa Ana, the Pasadena, the Ventura. She drove it as a riverman runs a river, every day more attuned to its currents, its deceptions." 
Those deceptions are the stuff of legend. Los Angeles is a city full of drivers who pride themselves on the subtlety with which they navigate the freeway system. The freeways are, in some sense, the most fully visualized constructs in the Los Angeles basin, watched closely by Caltrans cameras, always under some form of electronic surveillance, if only to keep the traffic flowing. They manage to be utopian and dystopian at once. Their flyovers and interchanges are monuments to power and artifacts of need. The logic of motion the freeways embody has long since overwhelmed the coherence that defines communities and neighborhoods. That logic is as simple as this: a better way to San Bernardino.

HEADLINE: Slaying Suspect Remains Free; 3-Year-Old Son Is Found Dead 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Aug. 21 

 BODY:
The 3-year-old son of a Ukrainian immigrant sought in the slayings of his wife and four relatives was found dead today in a box under a light tower in a Sacramento suburb.
 The authorities were led to the body of the boy, Sergey Soltys, by a note found on Monday night in a car owned by his father, Nikolay Soltys. 
 The boy had been stabbed to death, the police said. 
The authorities say Mr. Soltys killed his wife, an aunt and uncle, and two young cousins on Monday. The authorities posted a $10,000 reward for him today and pursued dozens of tips in a nationwide manhunt.
The note that led to the boy's body was written on the back of a photograph of the child and his mother, Lyubov Soltys, who was one of the victims. It was tucked into a pocket in the car door, Sergeant Lewis said. The car was found parked behind a store. A search of the area turned up nothing but the note.
Mr. Soltys was seen both at the scene where his wife was found stabbed to death and at the home where his aunt, uncle and cousins were killed, about 20 minutes away, the authorities say. A warrant names Mr. Soltys as the suspect in the five slayings, and Sergeant Lewis said investigators believed that he was responsible for his son's death.
Sergeant Lewis said the child was found in a rural area in Placer County, east of Sacramento, in a box large enough to hold a 36-inch television.
Sergeant Lewis said the discovery of the body was "probably the most distressing of all, because there was a great deal of hope throughout the department that we would be able to find this child safe and sound."
The authorities were investigating reports that Mr. Soltys had headed to Seattle, where he has relatives. Sergeant Lewis said Mr. Soltys also had relatives in North Carolina and New York.
Officers in the Sacramento area were stationed at bus terminals and airports. Sheriff's deputies also planned to hand out fliers in Russian and English in some neighborhoods in the Sacramento area, home to an estimated 75,000 Ukrainian and Russian immigrants.
Investigators said that they were unaware of a motive for the stabbings but that they were looking into reports that some relatives were unhappy that Mr. Soltys was unemployed and on welfare.
"He had mental problems," said Inna Yasinsky, an aunt of one of the children killed on Monday.
Investigators said Mr. Soltys had been rejected by the Ukrainian army for mental instability. He also had a history of domestic violence in Ukraine, but he had no known criminal record in the United States since his arrival more than a year ago.
His wife, who was about three months' pregnant, left Ukraine and reluctantly joined him about five months ago, said Frank Russell, the chaplain of the Sheriff's Department, whose office counseled relatives after the killings.
After reuniting with his wife, Mr. Soltys apparently began trying to refashion his life by going to college. His wife had planned to start a new job on Monday.

HEADLINE: TRENDS; 
Jilted by the New Economy, Tech Refugees Find Solace in the Old One

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
American companies have announced almost one million job cuts this year and more than one-quarter of them have come from the telecommunications and computer industries. Given those figures, it may be natural to assume that technology workers have suffered disproportionately as the economy has stumbled. 
 Uh-uh. 
 As in previous economic downturns, middle managers, sales representatives and industrial workers are bearing the brunt of the pain. But digitally gifted refugees from the new economy are finding jobs in the old economy, where their skills are very much in demand and business, while not robust, has not fallen off nearly as much as at companies that hitched their fortunes to the Internet.
 "There are still lots of opening at old economy businesses for computer-literate workers," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist at economy.com. "So people being laid off at places like Cisco are going to places like Countrywide Home Loans."
 The booming housing and health care industries have also protected their workers. But Mr. Zandi cautioned that could change if the economy continues to weaken."The next month or two will be critical," he said. "The economy is right on the edge. What happens with the tax rebate and the second quarter revision to the G.D.P. will decide the economy's direction." DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Target Reports Rise in Profit; Saks Says Its Losses Widened 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Target Corporation said yesterday that its fiscal second-quarter profit rose 5 percent as it lured consumers concerned about prices in the slowing economy, while Saks Inc. said its second-quarter loss widened because of declining sales at its Saks Fifth Avenue chain and regional department stores.
 Target's net income rose to $271 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $258 million, or 28 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales in the period ended Aug. 4 rose 8.5 percent, to $8.95 billion. 
 The results matched analysts' estimates, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
Sluggish sales at the company's department stores may keep full-year earnings below forecasts, said Doug Scovanner, the company's chief financial officer.
Third-quarter profit will probably be at the low end of forecasts, the company said. Analysts' estimates range from 25 to 31 cents, First Call said. The 68-cent average forecast for the fourth quarter probably is too low, Target said.
Target may miss full-year goals if its Marshall Field's department store chain lags sales expectations, or if sales of low-profit goods at Target discount stores drag down margins, Mr. Scovanner said.
Shares of Target, based in Minneapolis, fell $1.74, to $35.36.
At Saks, net losses widened to $58.4 million, or 41 cents a share, compared with $5.79 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales in the period ended Aug. 4 fell 8.5 percent, to $1.27 billion. Excluding a $3.8 million gain from the repurchase of bonds and $19.8 million in expenses for store closings and a reorganization of the company's catalog business, Saks said it would have lost $42.4 million, or 30 cents a share, a penny narrower than the 31 cents expected by analysts. Earlier this month, Saks said the loss would be 28 to 32 cents a share. The average forecast at the time was 14 cents.
Shares of Saks fell 19 cents, to $10.51. The results were released after the close of regular trading.

HEADLINE: Drug's Removal Exposes Holes In Europe's Net 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Aug. 21 

 BODY:
When Bayer announced earlier this month that it was withdrawing its fast-selling cholesterol-lowering drug from the market, it pleased officials at the United States Food and Drug Administration, who had become alarmed by a rising number of deaths and severe reactions linked to the drug.
 But in Europe, where Bayer is based, the move startled regulators and exposed considerable confusion. As recently as June, regulators from countries in the European Union decided that problems with the drug, sold under the brand names Lipobay and Baycol, could be handled through new warnings to doctors and patients. 
 Now, as they seek to respond to the problem, they are also trying to sort out who in Europe is responsible for dealing with such issues. Bayer is a German company, but its drug was licensed in Europe by the British authorities, with neighboring countries essentially adopting its decision. 
But Britain's regulator, the Medicines Control Agency, does not have the main responsibility for monitoring a drug's safety after it has been approved. That is supposed to be shared by each government within the European Union. 
German health officials now say that Bayer failed to give them the troubling data that it turned over to British regulators in June. The British agency, which never sent the report to its counterparts, says that was Bayer's responsibility.
And Europe's umbrella organization for drug regulation, the European Agency for the Evaluation of Medical Products, contends that it has little role to play because it was not involved in the licensing.
"There is a real problem with coordination," said Karl Lauterbach, a professor of health economics at the University of Cologne and an adviser to the German Ministry of Health. "One country like Great Britain can have responsibility for the approval process, but not for safety. The problem currently is who, exactly, is responsible on the European level for safety."
Bayer says that Baycol, also known by the generic name cerivastatin, has been linked to 52 deaths around the world, mostly in cases where patients took it in combination with another cholesterol-lowering drug, gemfibrozil, which is sold under the brand name Lopid. 
The problem is that Baycol, when used in combination with gemfibrozil, occasionally produced a disorder that caused a breakdown of muscle cells, leading to kidney failure. 
Regulators in Europe and the United States had become increasingly worried about Bayer's drug, which was approved in 1997. But their reactions differed considerably.
In the United States, Bayer was required to include warnings to doctors and patients against combining Baycol with gemfibrozil as early as 1999. European regulators did not demand a comparable warning until June, after Bayer presented them with data about harmful reactions in Europe.
Michael Diehl, a spokesman for Bayer, said the European warnings came later because fewer Europeans combined drugs and fewer problems arose.
But the F.D.A. may also have had access to more complete data. The agency collects reports from across the country, but in Europe, regulators piece together reports from each member country. 
Spanish health officials reported in June that three people had died in the previous six months from the muscle-weakening disease, known as rhabdomyolysis. 
More recently, German health officials have said that five deaths may be linked to the drug. But those are much smaller numbers than the 31 deaths recorded by the F.D.A., a fact that Dr. Lauterbach said might have impeded European officials from recognizing the severity of the problem. 
Poor sharing of information surfaced again when Bayer submitted a study to British regulators on June 15. That study was based on data compiled by an American health maintenance organization and showed that severe reactions were more common among people who combined Baycol with gemfibrozil than among people who combined other cholesterol-lowering drugs.
Last week, amid a growing public uproar and numerous class-action suits against Bayer, Germany's health ministry complained that it had never received the report. Rather than criticizing their British counterparts at the Medicines Control Agency, German officials denounced Bayer for its "unacceptable information policies."
"It isn't the job of the M.C.A. to be postman for the European Union," said Ulrich Hagemann, deputy director for pharmaceutical monitoring at Germany's Federal Institute for Medicine and Medical Products, which is the German counterpart to the F.D.A. 
Mr. Diehl of Bayer responded by saying that Bayer had satisfied its reporting obligations.
Mr. Hagemann defended Europe's decentralized system for drug regulation. Drug approvals can essentially be delegated to a single European country, and a drug manufacturer can choose the country in which it will seek approval. In theory, all countries apply the same rules and guidelines for approving products. 
But monitoring safety afterward is more complicated because no country wants to be responsible for collecting data from the entire European Union. As a result, each country has the same obligation to monitor and pass on information about results within its boundaries.
Europe does have a centralized regulatory agency, the European Agency for the Evaluation of Medical Products, which licenses drugs produced through genetic engineering. Companies with new drugs produced by conventional technology can seek approval through the agency, which is in London, but Bayer chose to seek approval through what Europeans call the process of mutual recognition.
"We did not intervene because we did not have to intervene," said Noel Walthion, head of the agency's office of post-authorization evaluation. The only pan-European group with a responsibility for discussing such safety issues is a group of experts known as the Pharmacovigilance Working Party. That group met in June, a few days before Bayer turned in its latest and most troubling study. That was when it decided to impose the warnings that had been standard in the United States for two years.
Mr. Diehl of Bayer confirmed that his company decided to withdraw the drug primarily because of reports in the United States. Now European regulators are trying to organize a review of the safety of other cholesterol-lowering drugs, and they are still considering the case of Baycol.

HEADLINE: As Prices Fall, Utilities Weigh The Economics Of New Plants 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Just months after the Bush administration painted a picture of shortages and called for building a power plant a week for the next 20 years, power prices are falling, industry analysts are warning of a surplus of electricity in parts of the country and some companies are reconsidering their plans to build new plants. 
 The dire long-term forecasts may well prove right. But power generation companies and their investors have their eyes on less distant horizons. The combination, many energy experts say, means that the construction of power plants is likely to run in boom-and-bust cycles, and that consumers -- who increasingly are being charged market prices for power -- will have to get used to electricity bills as volatile as the prices of gasoline, gold or any other commodity. 
 "Power is cyclical now, like oil and natural gas," said Raymond C. Niles, power and natural gas analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "It's going to be moving like a pendulum now between tight supplies and abundant supplies, high prices and low prices." 
Power companies have proposed adding about 350,000 megawatts of generating capacity by 2004, just under a 50 percent increase in the nation's existing power output, said Christopher R. Ellinghaus, an analyst at the Williams Capital Group, an investment bank. But it now appears, he said, that only about 100,000 megawatts of new generation will be built over that period. (A megawatt provides enough power for 800 typical homes.)
Indeed, if all the proposed plants were built, the country would have half again as big a reserve cushion as energy planners consider necessary, said Christian H. Poindexter, chief executive of the Constellation Energy Group, a power company in Baltimore. That prospect, he told stock analysts earlier this month, is helping drive electricity prices down now.
Talk of overcapacity is controversial given the dearth of power plant construction in the United States over the last decade and the near-crisis conditions that loomed in California and New York at the start of the summer. Nonetheless, a number of factors have combined to render some of the power companies' most bullish plans economically unfeasible, analysts said.
For one, the already strained transmission systems in much of the country cannot handle the addition of so many power plants. More than 90 percent of new plants, moreover, are designed to run on natural gas, and experts point out that the country lacks the supplies of gas and the network of pipelines required to fire all the proposed generators. 
The Bush plan calls for extensive investment in the grid and the pipeline system, but both projects face regulatory, political and economic challenges. 
In addition to infrastructure issues, there are signs of overbuilding in a number of regions where power plant construction over the last two years has been prolific, said Jone-Lin Wang, director of North American power at Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm. Ms. Wang thinks that by 2003 or so, there could be a surplus of power in New England and Texas; other experts add Ohio, Illinois and Indiana to that list, as well. 
The problem, many experts say, is that many generation companies have their eyes on the price of power and little else. As a result, when power prices fall, generating companies that rushed in with plans to build plants are quick to drop them. 
"Developers have a herd mentality," Ms. Wang said. 
Outright cancellations of projects have not been widespread, but there have been some.
Cogentrix, an independent power producer based in North Carolina, scrapped a 1,100 megawatt plant in West Virginia after the company concluded that prices were unlikely to justify the investment, a spokesman said. That would have included the cost of extending a pipeline from the natural gas network to feed the plant.
One of the country's largest developers of power generation, the Calpine Corporation, has long said it planned to bring 70,000 megawatts of generation on stream by late 2005. But in a conference call with analysts Monday, company officials said for the first time that they were not "locked into" that target. 
In Ohio, state regulators said they had seen a drop in interest in building "peaker" plants, the smaller generators that are turned on for those few hundred hours a year when the need is greatest. Projected power prices for next summer are so low that some generators do not expect to collect enough to make a profit on such plants.
In the Northwest, generators blame federal price caps for the cancellation of 500 to 750 megawatts of new generation. But analysts said the broader economics of the region's power market made the proposed plants unprofitable. 
"There are some power plants being delayed or canceled due to economic conditions, not federal caps," said Barry Abramson, senior power analyst at UBS Warburg. "Projecting ahead, the companies are seeing increased supply in the area and lower demand than they thought."
Nationally, only about three-fourths of the new generating capacity that was expected to become available this summer has come on line, according to RDI Consulting in Boulder, Colo., which advises energy companies. "We expected 46,000 megawatts of new generation this summer and got 35,000," said Christopher Seiple, RDI's managing director. 
Under the old regulated system, state officials and utilities projected growth in electricity demand and the number of new power plants needed. Regulators set rates that allowed the utilities to recoup the cost of construction and a return on their investment. But that process also spawned cost overruns and overbuilding.
Now, with half the country in some stage of deregulation, many utilities no longer own plants or build them. Instead, new power generation companies, called merchant generators, have stepped into the breach. But they must make complex judgments about how and where they can collect a return on their investment, and analysts say the young industry has not perfected that art.
"We would like to see more educated developers who don't just look at price, that they have a better understanding of the demand growth pattern in a region and who else is building what," said Ms. Wang of Cambridge Energy Research Associates.
A senior Bush administration official acknowledged that considerable new generating capacity was coming on line without government action, but said the investment was patchy. White House policy initiatives, he added, are focused on improving the electric grid and pipeline network.
Regulators, meanwhile, are reluctant to call all the activity overbuilding, perhaps for fear of driving away new projects. And so far, much of the new power has been used. During the heat wave in New England two weeks ago, for example, the 3,000 megawatts of new generation added over the last two years proved critical to avoiding widespread interruptions, said a spokeswoman for the New England Independent System Operator, which runs the region's transmission grid. 
Power generators and many Wall Street analysts also said wide swaths of the country -- most notably California and New York -- were far from having a surplus of capacity, and had narrow reserve margins against blackouts. Moreover, they said, many of the new plants would replace older, dirtier, less efficient ones currently in use.
Still, with power prices falling, some analysts say regulators will have the rare chance to figure out how to create market conditions that smooth the boom-and-bust cycle.
"Lower prices for now will give us the breathing room to deal with the issue of how to handle price spikes on the policy level," said Mr. Seiple, the Colorado consultant. "The danger is that people will forget that price spikes ever occurred -- until they occur again."

HEADLINE: Retailers Split Over Setting Sights on Tax Rebates 

BYLINE:  By JULIAN E. BARNES 

 BODY:
For taxpayers at loose ends over how to spend their rebates, Lowe's Home Improvement Warehouses has helpfully compiled a list of projects that cost from $300 to $600. Among the suggestions: put up a flagpole or build a playhouse.
 Not to be outdone, Home Depot is recommending that customers invest in energy-saving improvements like insulation and is offering interest-free financing to encourage people to spend their rebates before the checks arrive. 
 With billions of dollars in rebates on their way, these and other big retailers, including Wal-Mart and Travelocity, have made the miniwindfalls a central theme of their marketing plans. For many, it is a chance to extend a peak selling season that is now coming to a close. 
But many companies that usually have a strong back-to-school business, including J. C. Penney, Best Buy and Target, have remained largely silent on the tax rebate. These retailers and others are not convinced that people will spend their rebates and are sticking with traditional end-of-summer pitches to draw shoppers.
"I was a little surprised," said Scott Krugman, spokesman for the National Retail Federation. "There were a few clever promotions, and I was wondering if there would be more, but it really wasn't the case. People have been focusing on the product, not the gimmick."
The Treasury Department began sending checks of as much as $300 to individuals and $600 to families on July 20. So far it has mailed 40.7 million checks worth a total of $17.2 billion, and by the end of September, it will return $38 billion to taxpayers.
The rebates are the first part of a 10-year tax cut package that President Bush promoted to stimulate the economy. The first hard numbers with which to judge the economic impact of the rebate will not be available until next month, when retailers report August sales. Some surveys suggest retail sales at the end of July were strong, but the Redbook Retail Sales Average, a survey of retail sales, for the first two weeks of August disappointed some retail analysts, rising only 0.2 percent from July.
A telephone survey by the University of Michigan found that about 18 percent of people expect to spend their rebates, while a Gallup poll put the figure at 25 percent. But many economists note that what people say they will do and what they actually do are often two different things. Some economists predict Americans will spend as much as $20 billion of the rebate. That would add two-tenths of a percentage point to the nation's economic growth this year.
"People are funny when they say they are not going to spend the money," said Stuart Hoffman, the chief economist for PNC Financial Services. "Who are we kidding?"
Some retailers agree. Home Depot began a tax rebate ad campaign after a survey it commissioned found that about 9 percent of the people questioned said they planned to spend their rebates on home improvements, said Don Harrison, a company spokesman. When prompted, another 24 percent said they would consider spending the check to fix up their houses.
Online travel agencies have also tied marketing to the rebate. "What Uncle Sam giveth, useth to go away," says an ad from Travelocity.
Expedia, another online travel agency, has a page on its site highlighting "The Great Tax Rebate Vacation." Most of the options are long weekend getaways, and Expedia managers hope consumers will use their rebates and leftover vacation days for a last-minute trip.
"Some research we looked at showed people were excited to get their checks,' said Christina Kozloff, a product manager at Expedia. "People are looking to spend them and spend them on themselves."
Discount retailers appear divided. Target has kept all mention of tax rebates out of its ads and out of its stores, while Kmart is offering customers a 5 percent bonus if they use their checks to buy a gift card.
Wal-Mart has not offered any discounts but has told customers they can cash their checks at the store. The first customers to do so ended up spending about 25 percent of the rebate at the store, Wal-Mart said. The most popular items they bought were electronics, cameras, prepaid cell phones and air-conditioners
Not everyone is trying to persuade Americans to spend the rebate. The Vanguard Group and the Fidelity Investments unit of FMR have encouraged their clients in newsletters and e-mails to invest the rebate. Robert Corcoran, a vice president for retirement product development at Fidelity, said a number of customers had visited its retail centers with rebate checks in hand.
Many retailers that opted against promotions or advertisements based on the rebates said they doubted such an appeal would bring extra customers into their stores.
Back-to-school is a strong selling season for electronics merchants like Circuit City and Best Buy, so neither chain has done any tax-rebate related promotions. Laurie Bauer, a spokeswoman for Best Buy, which is based in Minneapolis, said that when people in Minnesota got state tax rebates last year and in 1999 it had little effect on sales there. Based on that experience, Best Buy decided to pass on any advertising related the federal rebate, she said.
Clothing retailers have also decided to pass up mention of the tax rebate in advertisements. J. C. Penney said it would increase advertising spending $80 million in the second half of the year but would not refer to the rebate checks.
"We've continued with our regular scheduled programming," said Tim Lyons, a Penney spokeman.
Macy's, a unit of Federated Department Stores, is not doing any tax rebate promotions. Nor are stores owned by Gap or Limited. Sears has added references to the tax rebate on some ads but does not expect the rebates to give sales much of a boost.
One of the first companies to make a rebate-inspired appeal was perhaps one of the last places people would think to spend the bulk of their rebates. On July 9, Pizza Hut, a unit of Tricon Global Restaurants, began a TV ad for its twisted crust pizza that said: "Almost as good as a refund, but tastes a whole lot better."
Sean Gleason, the vice president for advertising, said the promotion appeared to work because people had been calling to ask for the tax-refund special. "It's kind of funny," he said. "We are offering a $9.99 pizza when people are getting $300."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing Slow Start For Amtrak Train 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 A fast train that is critical to the future of Amtrak is off to a slow start. 
In service eight months, the Acela Express between Washington and Boston is falling short of projections in riders and revenue. And a nonstop Washington-to-New York service -- Amtrak's silver bullet in its race with air shuttles -- has been suspended because of low ridership. Amtrak officials say they have had to deal with various challenges, including the slowing economy and aging electrical wiring. "We concede that ridership fell below our forecast by about 6 percent, and revenues by about 3 percent," said Cecilia Cummings, an Amtrak spokeswoman. "But when you look at the drop in business travel in general, we're claiming victory."
