HEADLINE: In America; 
A Campaign of Caution

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The four men in gray suits took their seats at the table and waited quietly for the televised debate to begin. Reporters leaned forward -- poison pens poised -- hoping that one of these unfailingly polite men would just lose it, say something outlandish, or maybe snarl at somebody (like a certain mayor we know), and enliven a campaign that so far has been a snooze.
 Aware of the media's insatiable quest for conflict, Mark Green said, "I'll try for a contentious debate." 
 He was joking. Ahead in the polls, Mr. Green is doing all he can to sidestep the ordinary rough-and-tumble of a political campaign. 
New York mayoral races are seldom genteel affairs. Name-calling and mud-slinging are cherished traditions. Fiorello La Guardia was reported to have bragged, "I invented the low blow."
You'd think that with four major Democratic candidates you'd get a brawl that the World Wrestling Federation would envy. But not this time.
Mr. Green and the others, Peter Vallone, Fernando Ferrer and Alan Hevesi, have kept their voices low and their guards high. So at Tuesday's Democratic primary debate, sponsored by The New York Times and New York 1 News, the closest things to a conflict were a few testy exchanges between Mr. Hevesi and his "good friend" Mr. Vallone.
But at the heart of one of those exchanges was a potential problem so serious it could undermine the entire program of the next mayoral administration, whoever wins.
Mr. Hevesi, the city comptroller, expressed reservations about the recently adopted city budget. He said that over the next few years the city would face budget deficits and a ballooning debt service that could "tie our hands in the future."
He complained that there were "substantial difficulties" with the current budget that would make it more difficult to cope with the anticipated effects of a slowing economy.
Mr. Vallone, the City Council speaker, dismissed Mr. Hevesi's concerns and said he resented "the continuing implication that there is something wrong with our budget process." 
Who's right?
Most of the mayoral candidates, including Michael Bloomberg, who is seeking the Republican nomination, have expressed concerns about the downturn in the national economy and its inevitable effect on city revenues. In a recent interview with The Times, Mr. Bloomberg said, "The outlook for at least the next few years is not one that should give you comfort that the city is going to be able to do everything."
Mr. Hevesi, in a report on the recently adopted budget, said, "The city has failed to take advantage of the opportunities provided by the remarkably good recent economic times to plan and prepare for the less favorable economic climate that may lie ahead."
Mr. Green, in an interview yesterday, said that "no one is smart enough to know" how far the economy would skid. But he has already drawn up contingency plans for a targeted hiring freeze that would shrink the city's labor force through attrition. He said he would exempt teachers, cops and employees at senior centers.
Huge budget gaps, ranging from $2.7 billion to $3.2 billion, are projected for the 2003 to 2005 fiscal period. And Mr. Hevesi has said that current capital spending commitments will lead to a debt service obligation of $5.1 billion in the year 2005. 
The city will soon have to negotiate raises for police officers, teachers and other municipal employees. And a recent round of tax cuts will be phased in over the next few years.
The Citizens Budget Commission, a civic watchdog group, warned early on that the budget, "with its mixture of increased recurring costs and reduced recurring revenues," was not "prudent" -- particularly in light of "the weakening national and local economy." 
The mayoral campaign may be low-keyed, but the issues at hand are as consequential as those in prior, noisier campaigns.
Mr. Vallone said again yesterday that he wasn't worried about the city's fiscal shape. The budget is sound, he said. And if things worsen, cuts can be made without too much difficulty.
"The reality is we had it much tougher 11 years ago," he said. "I cut $2 billion in one month with David Dinkins."

HEADLINE: BUSH PROJECTIONS SHOW SHARP DROP IN BUDGET SURPLUS 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 

 BODY:
Ending a brief but giddy era of fiscal plenty, the Bush administration released projections today showing that the federal budget surpluses outside the Social Security system will dwindle to almost nothing for the next several years.
 For the current fiscal year, the administration estimated, the government would run a surplus of about $600 million outside Social Security, an almost negligible amount in a $1.9 trillion budget and a $10 trillion economy. As recently as April, the White House projected a surplus of $122 billion in the non-Social Security system for the fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30. 
 Largely because of the tax cut passed by Congress this year and the economic slowdown, the surpluses outside Social Security will remain tiny for the next three or four years before beginning to grow again, the White House said.
The government will continue to run substantial Social Security surpluses, the administration said, including $157 billion this year. But by agreement of the two parties, that money is off limits for spending or tax cuts and is reserved for reducing the national debt or shoring up the retirement system. 
The sharp turnabout comes just months after both parties were busily making plans for allocating what seemed to be an endless bounty from the prosperity of the late 1990's. It has set up a return to bitter budget battles and efforts by each party to turn the situation to its political advantage.
White House officials sought to cast the news in the best possible light. They said that the country was still in sound financial condition and that an expected economic rebound should put enough money on the table over the next decade to deal with all the nation's priorities, especially if the tighter budget encourages Congress to pare wasteful or inefficient spending.
Despite the economic slowdown, the surplus for this year, including Social Security, will still be the second largest on record, "a phenomenon that should strike all Americans as very positive," said Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director. The total surplus last year was $236.9 billion, a record.
Democrats responded that the administration had squandered the surplus by pushing through an irresponsibly large tax cut, putting the government into such a squeeze that not only Democratic initiatives but Mr. Bush's own agenda, including a big increase in military spending, would be impossible to carry out.
"I believe President Bush's campaign promises are unraveling," said Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. "He claimed we could afford his massive tax cut, a major defense buildup, more money for education, while paying down the debt and protecting Social Security and Medicare. He was wrong."
In its midyear review of the budget outlook, the White House projected that the non-Social Security surplus would be $1 billion to $6 billion for the next three years before increasing to $19 billion in 2005 and then growing steadily for the rest of the decade.
But the administration was able to show a non-Social Security surplus for the next few years only by making assumptions and policy changes that Democrats attacked as gimmicks. 
They included a shift in the way the government accounts for Social Security revenues, economic growth assumptions that Democrats said were too optimistic and a decision not to include in the calculations the cost of tax and spending decisions that Congress is all but certain to make in coming months and years.
The new projections from the White House's Office of Management and Budget showed that the government would run a total budget surplus for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 of $157.8 billion, of which $157.1 billion would come from Social Security. 
The surplus for next year, the administration projected, would be $173 billion, with $1 billion coming from outside Social Security. The total surplus in 2003 would be $195 billion, with $2 billion coming from outside Social Security.
If those figures prove correct, it will mean that the government will spend nearly all of the surplus generated by part of the Medicare system, money that Democrats and most Republicans in Congress had also sought to put off limits. The Medicare surplus this year is about $30 billion.
The administration projected a gradual improvement in the fiscal outlook over the rest of the decade. The total surplus for the next decade should be $3.1 trillion, the White House said, compared with a projection of $5.6 trillion earlier this year, before the tax cut and the economic slowdown. 
It said the non-Social Security surplus for the next decade should be $575 billion, compared with a projection of $3.1 trillion at the beginning of the year. The 10-year projection for the Social Security surplus was largely unchanged, at $2.5 trillion.
The Congressional Budget Office is scheduled to release its own updated surplus forecast next week. Members of each party said it might show the government crossing the line into spending Social Security surpluses. 
The situation holds opportunity and peril for the administration and Republicans in Congress.
To some degree, the administration's goal in pursuing the $1.35 trillion tax cut was to get as much of the surplus as possible out of Washington so that Congress could not spend it. 
Eliminating nearly all of the non-Social Security surplus limits the ability of Democrats -- or Republicans for that matter -- to propose big new spending programs. It also makes it easier for the administration to demand a re-examination of spending on programs that it opposes on policy grounds or judges to be ineffective.
"The budget is tight, and that's exactly what we designed and exactly what we wanted," said Representative Jim Nussle, Republican of Iowa, the chairman of the House Budget Committee. 
But the budget may be so tight that Mr. Bush's own plans will be among the first to suffer. Mr. Conrad and Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said they would oppose Mr. Bush's request for an $18 billion increase in military spending next year.
The president's plans for the Pentagon may also face problems in the Republican-controlled House. Mr. Nussle said he was "very troubled" by the White House's military spending request because it was not backed up by a detailed review of the Pentagon's long-term needs.
Members of each party said Mr. Bush might have trouble obtaining money for his education and energy plans and would find it more difficult to finance creation of private investment accounts within Social Security.
More broadly, the administration is at risk of being blamed for blowing the surplus, a contention that Democrats are turning into a battle cry as they prepare for the the 2002 election.
The administration is clearly aware of its political vulnerability. In calculating its new budget projections, it made several policy decisions and assumptions that had the effect of increasing the surplus and decreasing the risk of dipping into Social Security money, especially this year and next year.
It assumed that economic growth next year would rebound to 3.2 percent, at the high end of what private economists predict. It changed a longtime accounting convention in Social Security, allocating higher-than-expected payroll tax revenues to the books for previous fiscal years rather than counting them toward the results for the year in which they were discovered.
In calculating the current year's non-Social Security surplus, the administration assumed that corporations would pay $4 billion to $5 billion of taxes earlier than necessary, raising revenues for this year by that amount. 
Perhaps most important, the White House included in its budget assumptions all of the nearly $200 billion for increased military spending over the next decade that Mr. Bush has proposed, but it did not account for the costs of other programs that are moving through Congress, or for his own plans for a national missile defense. 
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group, said the cost of all the programs now in the legislative pipeline would be at least $800 billion over 10 years, more than wiping out the $575 billion non-Social Security surplus that the administration predicted would be available during that period.

HEADLINE: Turbine Maker Outlook 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Capstone Turbine lowered its third-quarter and full-year sales forecast yesterday, driving its shares down nearly 30 percent to a 52-week low. 
 The company, based in Chatsworth, Calif., said sales for its 30-kilowatt and 60-kilowatt power generators would be substantially lower than had been forecast because of the economic slowdown. 
Capstone did not provide detailed figures. 
 Capstone set a sales goal in late July of 600 units for the third quarter. 
Namrita Kapur, an analyst with Adams, Harkness & Hill, said: "The market does not like uncertainty.
"It is always better to have figures because people expect the worst. And maybe this is a signal of just how bad things are." 
Ms. Kapur added that Wall Street's revenue and earnings estimates for Capstone were still too high and should come down soon. 
Capstone's turbines, about the size of two large washing machines, are similar to jet-engine turbines and are fueled most commonly with natural gas. They provide enough energy to keep the light on at a small business or the computers operating in an office. 
The turbines cost $30,000 to $55,000, about 50 percent more than an equivalently powered diesel generator, but they emit less pollution and require less maintenance. 
The shares dropped $2.07, to $5.18. That is off from a 52-week high of $98.50 last August.

HEADLINE: Librarians Adjust Image In an Effort To Fill Jobs 

BYLINE:  By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 22 

 BODY:
Dana Garzolini frequently turns heads when she is on the job in the Chicago public libraries.
 " 'You don't look like a librarian,' " Ms. Garzolini says people tell her. " 'It doesn't fit you at all.' " 
 Ms. Garzolini does seem like a typical 26-year-old, though. 
"I like to go out to eat," she said. "I like to go to bars. I like to travel. Pretty much, I'm up for anything. I consider myself very adventurous."
That is the image library administrators want to project as they try to lure young people to fill what could soon be thousands of vacant jobs as older librarians retire and the private sector beckons.
In a Web site promoting a campaign by the American Library Association, librarians ride Harleys, surf and skateboard. They are young and hip. They wear dreadlocks and practice yoga. And like Ms. Garzolini, they are known to enjoy an occasional night at a bar. There is a cook and caterer, a "popular culture junkie" who started a hip-hop program for the Cleveland library and a "surfer dude" who owns a record company.
Colleges and universities are turning out more library and information science graduates than ever, the association says, but public libraries must compete with the growing number of higher paying jobs in the private sector, a formidable competitor even with the economy slowing.
At the same time, the need for public, school and academic librarians is growing. The association's president, John W. Berry, said that in the next 12 years, nearly half of the approximately 125,000 fully qualified librarians in the nation would retire. 
In June 2000, at the annual conference of the American Library Association, only 481 job seekers showed up for 1,000 posted openings. At an association conference in January, only 260 people showed up for 813 postings, officials said.
Already a small number of libraries have begun using recruiting videos and even a Web site. Officials at the association say their Web site is part of a five-year campaign, begun in April, that is likely to include public service advertisements. 
Even the phrases used in the promotion, called "The 21st Century Librarians," cast the profession in a new light, with librarians seen as "ambassadors," "teachers," "linguists," "technology experts" and "human search engines." 
"It's time for us to work on advocating for libraries to change the image," said one of the "21st Century Librarians," Veronda Pitchford, an African-American librarian in Chicago who wears dreadlocks, enjoys in-line skating, practices yoga and listens to eclectic music. "I want little kids to know that this is an option. I want little girls to see me."
Ms. Pitchford, 30, said that even in an age when computers may be leading children to forget the human touch of a librarian, there is no substitute. 
"When I say that we're the ultimate search engine," she said, "I'm not joking."
From New England to Los Angeles, the shortage has left scores of libraries understaffed or staffed by less-qualified workers. The library association requires that professional librarians earn a master's degree in library and information sciences, which some prospective students deem too costly for a job that pays less than other professions. The mean salary for beginning librarians is $32,891, the association says. 
Leigh Estabrook, a professor at the Graduate School of Library and Information Science at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign said about 20 percent of the school's graduates get jobs outside libraries. 
"The competition is not just financial, that business and Microsoft pays a lot better than most public libraries, for example, but also that some corporate jobs, nonlibrary jobs, offer our students opportunities to get in on the ground floor and develop new things," Professor Estabrook said.
But while the number of library and information sciences graduates continues to rise nationally, to 4,472 in 1999 from 2,975 in 1981, the association says, it is not likely to soon remedy the shortage.
"Even with more grads," Professor Estabrook said, "the demographics of people retiring does mean that for a certain period of time, there will be a real trough in libraries." 
Many libraries have been trying to recruit from their own support staffs, offering tuition vouchers and support for employees who want to become librarians. 
The hope is that they will follow in the footsteps of those like Tyrone Ward, 48, now a manager at a West Side branch of the Chicago Public Library system who began work as a literacy coordinator, then went back to school to earn a master's degree in a program partly financed by the city and the library.
As an African-American man, whose assistant is also a black man, Mr. Ward says he can influence African-American children.
"When they see the two of us, just seeing it is enough for young black males to see their place," he said. 
"The schoolmarmish librarian, with the reading glasses and the sort of long dress and long skirt with the bun hair was a wonderful lady, very loving and very devoted to her work," Mr. Ward added. "But her day is long gone. The stereotype has more life than she does."
Mr. Ward is an avid jazz fan, a book collector who enjoys traveling and jogging along the shores of Lake Michigan in the cool of a summer's evening. Still, some images die hard. 
When people learn that he is a librarian, "the response is kind of lukewarm, especially when I'm talking to ladies," Mr. Ward said. "There seems to be a gleam in their eyes, and it dims ever so slightly."
But even that is changing. Recently, Ms. Garzolini sat with co-workers in a conference room at the Harold Washington Library in downtown Chicago, chatting and pondering the new day for librarians. 
"I think that the American Library Association should run a campaign that librarians are hot," one librarian said.
They all laughed. 
"A calendar maybe?" another woman said, laughing.
Well, maybe not.

HEADLINE: Tennessee's Fiscal Troubles Grow After Futile Push for Income Tax 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Aug. 21 

 BODY:
It was only two years ago that Tennessee was considered a model of good financial management, one of only nine states whose governments had top-drawer credit ratings from all the rating agencies and the envy of Southeastern states struggling to modernize.
 But that was before a slowing economy gutted its revenue, which was vulnerable because of an almost total reliance on the volatile sales tax. Now Tennessee's fiscal reputation has fallen even further than those of the large group of other states struggling to balance their budgets, and deep rifts have been exposed among residents and legislators over the proper role of state government in lean times. 
 Two weeks ago, after yielding to large crowds at the Capitol here protesting a proposed income tax, legislators could balance the budget only by spending all the state's remaining $560 million share of the national settlement with the tobacco industry; most other states are using their settlement windfalls for health purposes and preventing tobacco use. 
Almost immediately, the rating agencies sharply downgraded the state's credit, warning that Tennessee must plot a course back to fiscal responsibility if it expects to borrow money in the future. Schools now worry about finding money for building projects, and a few districts were so short of cash they had to open several days late this year. Money for health care and mental health programs is likely to be slashed, and state colleges and universities have raised their tuition 15 percent.
"We are suddenly in a very precarious position," said C. Warren Neel, the state commissioner of finance. "The revenues of this year's budget could fall short, and our rainy-day fund needs to be much higher. If we don't change the structure of our tax system, we are going to be at the mercy of lawsuits from people who need our services, and we'll gradually lose our ability to govern ourselves. We'll be like Alabama."
Being like Alabama, frankly, is not the way Tennesseans have traditionally seen themselves. The state always had a reputation for being better educated and more economically vibrant than its neighbors farther south. But now, with dozens of states struggling to balance their budgets, it has found itself hit even harder than most, because, unlike 41 states, it cannot rely on the cushion of an income tax.
Nearly three-fourths of its revenue comes from its 6 percent sales tax. This was enough in the days when Tennessee had a mostly manufacturing and agricultural economy, with actual goods to tax. But as the state moved more heavily into untaxable services, sales tax revenue began to slip, particularly with so much commerce taking place on the Internet, where taxes cannot reach.
The slowing of the economy has magnified the effect. State sales tax collections last month were 2.6 percent lower than at the same time last year, and Mr. Neel's office said that even the current budget, patched together with tobacco-settlement money, was likely to fall short of its goals if the economy remained anemic.
Opponents of the income tax say the sales tax would be perfectly adequate if the state simply cut back on spending for social purposes, particularly the expensive TennCare health insurance program.
"I know that we can find a way to run this state and deliver services in such a way that we remain a low-tax state," said State Senator Marsha Blackburn, a Republican from the Nashville suburb of Brentwood. "All we have to do is hold the line on growth, and that will take care of our budget problems."
The state's aversion to the income tax dates from 1931, when the Tennessee Supreme Court ruled that an income tax enacted not long before was unconstitutional. The State Constitution does not specifically prohibit a personal income tax, but neither does it list one among the several taxes it says the state can levy. (It does allow a tax on interest and dividends, which is in effect.)
While a succession of five state attorneys general have said that an income tax would be legal if the legislation was properly worded to comply with the court's concerns, the decades without such a tax have created an immensely passionate popular opposition to it.
Gov. Don Sundquist, who won office in 1994 as a conservative Republican opposed to an income tax, changed his position after his re-election, citing a need to preserve high-quality education and health care programs.
"I did not run for governor to preside over Tennessee's descent into the ranks of the least, the lowest and the last of the 50 states," he said in 1999, after announcing that he would sign an income tax bill if it came to his desk.
But no such bill came, even as Tennessee slid to 48th in the nation in the average amount that residents pay in state taxes, and 48th in per-pupil spending for education.
This year the Democratic-controlled legislature seemed only a few votes shy of passing an income tax plan that would have also reduced the sales tax, but as a vote neared on July 12, Senator Blackburn's office sent an e-mail message to the hosts of a radio talk show, who were quickly able to produce a large anti-tax rally at the Capitol.
While lawmakers were in session, protesters honked horns and banged on the statehouse doors, and one woman broke a window with her fist. Negotiations on the tax fell apart, and the legislature passed a budget that required using the tobacco money.
Calling the budget bill irresponsible, Governor Sundquist vetoed it on July 26. "I believe that this bill is certain to cause our great state irreparable injury," he said, "and puts our state on the path toward disaster."
But less than two weeks later the legislature overrode his veto, and the budget took effect. Many of the protesters claimed victory. Their comments reflect a profound suspicion of those in power, and a reluctance to trust them with a new tax.
"This state has a spending problem, and the budget just keeps growing every year," said David Ivy, a resident of suburban Mount Juliet who was among the crowd at the Capitol in July. "We understand that you have to have taxes to operate this society, but there is a huge amount of waste, and all they say is, 'It's for the children,' and expect us to throw money at it."
But a recent analysis by The Commercial Appeal, the Memphis daily,showed that most of the growth in state spending was mandated by the courts or the federal government and so was outside the discretion of the state. Given that continuing pressure on the budget, many supporters of the income tax believe its adoption is only a matter of time, particularly now that there is no tobacco money left to plug holes.
"It used to be an obscenity to talk about an income tax, and now at least it's a policy choice," said Senator Bob Rochelle, a Democrat from nearby Lebanon who was a leading proponent of the tax in the legislature. "Once people understand the implications of having an unhealthy state government -- fewer people with diplomas, with health care -- I think things will change when this comes up again."

GRAPHIC: Photos: E-mail from the office of State Senator Marsha Blackburn, shown at right in legislative session this month, led to a huge statehouse protest against an income tax proposal. HEADLINE: The Reality Behind the Slogan; 
Saturn Unit, Once a Maverick, Is Looking a Lot More Like G.M

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: SPRING HILL, Tenn., 

 BODY:
General Motors created Saturn 16 years ago as a different kind of car company, a friendly, unconventional brand aimed at Americans for whom Detroit represented a failed past.
 Today, the slogan remains. But behind the scenes, Saturn is getting to be a lot more like the rest of G.M. And, paradoxically, that is proving a boon for Saturn. 
 It turns out that a giant bureaucracy like G.M.'s is a lot more nurturing of an offspring it can control that it ever was of an iconoclast. Consumers, meanwhile, seem not to notice the changes at Saturn -- or not to care -- and Saturn is the only one of G.M.'s eight divisions with a rising market share this year. 
As a quirky subsidiary, run with considerable autonomy here in the verdant rolling country of central Tennessee, Saturn languished for a decade selling the same small-car model and, in the last two years, a bland midsize car originally designed for G.M.'s European operations.
But now Saturn is run, like Chevrolet and Buick, from G.M.'s monolithic headquarters in downtown Detroit. G.M. plans to give the division an entirely new model in each of the next four years, beginning with the car-based Saturn Vue sport utility vehicle late this year. A small car, a midsize car and a minivan will follow.
"G.M. and I are personally committed to getting Saturn the resources they need to grow," said Ronald Zarrella, the company's president for North American auto operations. "The only way we can make Saturn work economically is to leverage the rest of General Motors." Translated, that means more parts are shared with other G.M. vehicles, and workers here no longer play much of a role in the design, engineering and marketing of Saturn cars. The white-collar staffs for these tasks have been moved to Detroit, and their managers now answer to G.M. executives there.
The first president of Saturn, Richard G. LeFauve, reported directly to G.M.'s president. But the current president, Annette Clayton, is little more than a factory manager, reporting to one of the most junior of G.M.'s four dozen vice presidents; the company will not allow her to be interviewed.
Yet assembly line workers continue to collaborate closely with G.M. engineers in figuring out the least expensive, least- error-prone ways to put the parts together. G.M. has also been careful to leave untouched the side of Saturn that most customers notice, like the low-pressure sales tactics at dealerships.
Two weeks ago, when J. D. Power & Associates, a quality consulting firm, released the results of a national survey of consumer satisfaction with car dealerships, Saturn was once again at the very top of the list, ahead of luxury brands like Cadillac, Lexus and Jaguar. 
Dealers tend to agree that the industrial side of the Saturn mystique is far less important. "As long as we continue to take excellent care of the customer, I think that's what the customer is looking for," said Lynn B. Kimmel, a Saturn dealer in Indianapolis. 
The changes have nonetheless upset some of Saturn's original employees. "It's the entire dismantling of the entire Saturn concept -- it's no longer a different kind of car company, and it's no longer a different kind of car," said Michael Bennett, who was the chairman of the United Auto Workers union local at Saturn from 1986 until 1999.
Some on Wall Street share Mr. Bennett's worry that G.M. may be hollowing out Saturn's powerful, if eccentric, image. "The products seem less distinctive; they seem more G.M.-like than they ever were," said John Casesa, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch.
"Without some work to define this brand, Saturn is going to have an identity crisis," he added.
Saturn is a small piece of G.M., contributing just 6 percent of overall sales, and its gain of one-tenth of a percentage point in market share among all car brands this year is a result of Saturn's sales slowing less than the rest of the industry's. Auto sales over all are down 4.7 percent this year, versus a 1.6 percent drop for Saturn.
Moreover, Saturn has been losing money, forced to offer discounted loans and leases in a glutted global market for small cars. Car-based sport utilities are in short supply, however -- and are quite profitable -- so G.M. hopes that Saturn can make money soon with the introduction of the Vue.
Some workers here are nostalgic for the days when they stood side by side with engineers, helping choose which auto parts supplier would produce spark plugs or seat springs. But union members voted out Mr. Bennett and his team in February 1999, choosing new leaders who wanted to develop more of an arms-length arrangement with management.
"Early on, we had a lot more autonomy, and that's for sure," said Ron Hankins, the union president at Saturn since 1999. "With it so challenging in the environment that we're in to build a small car in America and make a profit doing it, we just had to find better ways to do that, and be closer to the mother company."
Contributing to G.M.'s willingness to yank Saturn back into the fold has been a change in international business culture.
When Saturn was conceived in 1985, Japan was a widely admired economic power, and small cars were seen as the future of the auto industry. Saturn adopted Japanese manufacturing practices like teamwork, although the cars themselves were marketed as quintessentially American. Like Japanese automakers, Saturn committed itself to never lay off a worker, using business slowdowns, for example, as opportunities to provide extra training.
But with Japan in its second decade of an economic funk, it no longer represents such a powerful model for American manufacturers. The small-car market has shrunk precipitously since Saturn's first car came out in 1990, although it rebounded slightly with the rise in gasoline prices last spring. And the willingness of American companies to lay off workers has gone from being considered a vice to a virtue, at least among business leaders and some economists and government officials.
G.M.'s more hard-headed approach to Saturn now is evident in its dealings with government officials here in Maury County, as the automaker demands a lower tax assessment. "It just seems the new people who are there now are pushing hard," said Ed Harlan, the elected county executive. "I suspect it'll end up in court." 
General Motors is not alone in having undermined Saturn's uniqueness; national U.A.W. leaders also played a role. Before G.M. began building the Saturn L midsize car two years ago at a factory in Wilmington, Del., the automaker asked the union for the same highly flexible labor contract that it has in Spring Hill. But the U.A.W.'s leadership, which had a long-running feud with Mr. Bennett, rejected the request. 
U.A.W. officials declined to discuss Saturn publicly. A union official who insisted on anonymity said that relations between Detroit and Spring Hill had greatly improved as labor rules for Saturn have become more like those in other G.M. factories. Over all, G.M. and the union have dedicated themselves to working together more closely after strikes at G.M. factories in the summer of 1998.
Mr. LeFauve, who was the president of Saturn from 1986 to 1994 and is now retired, said many of the changes at the unit were inevitable. 
"A small company just cannot make it alone in the car industry. You need to have a big brother to help you with high fixed-cost resources like engineering, purchasing, financial and the sales end of the business," he said. "We completely separated ourselves from G.M., but in some cases we found out what we were doing at G.M. corporate was the best way to do things."
Mr. Hankin, the union president, explains the difference in factory-floor terms. G.M. employees' identity badges have blue backgrounds; Saturn workers' badges are red. "Absolutely, we're seeing more blue badges," Mr. Hankins said. "I don't know if it's a bad thing to see blue badges walking around."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook; 
What's in a Name? Today, Not Much

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
One is called Calibrus, one is called Calibra. Which one is the Internet start-up and which is the coupe made by General Motors? These days it's hard to tell. (Calibra is the car.) An entire industry of namers has sprung up to coin vaguely hip terms for the new economy's companies. The process of inventing and promoting a name can cost millions of dollars. It could also do more harm than good. 
 Invented names are nothing new. Since the turn of the 20th century, companies have picked nebulous names such as Amalgamated Holdings Limited and Consolidated Products Incorporated after undergoing mergers and reorganizations. Where today's names differ is their emphasis on mood. A somehow energetic but meaningless name like Ajilon (an information technology consulting firm) or Motiva (a joint-venture oil refiner and also, it happens, a management software package) is meant only to grab the attention of investors, consumers and corporate clients. 
 Auto makers and drug companies have used this tactic for years. If Miata and Allegra had not been a sports car and an allergy medicine, they could easily have ended up as third-generation mobile phone companies. Yet while specific products might rely on their brand names only for an edgy cachet, company names can convey a deeper meaning.
When a company bears the name of its founder, boss or creative mastermind -- such as Ford Motor, Dell Computer or Hershey Foods -- consumers can assume that a person or family's legacy ultimately stands behind the product. The inclusion of a hometown or region in a name, as in Hartford Property & Casualty or Alaska Airlines, can imply a loyalty or responsibility to that community. And it's certainly helpful for a company to have a product or service in its name, like any of the above, at least to distinguish itself from cars and drugs. 
Forthright, identity-based names have been tossed aside as too old-fashioned for the new economy. Today companies change owners and managers all the time. They're ageless, placeless and sometimes, especially when they end in .com, productless. A vague name, the namers will tell you, is a license to serve all sorts of clienteles in all sorts of ways. 
It also cuts the clearest ties to a company's community and its past. These ties have value to consumers, workers and even shareholders. As the namers will find out soon enough, building a good name takes more than just a good name. DANIEL ALTMAN

HEADLINE: The Jockeying Starts As Helms Yields to Time 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 22 

 BODY:
Speaking of the toll of time, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina announced tonight that he would not run for re-election in 2002 and would retire after a momentous 30-year career.
 Mr. Helms, a 79-year-old Republican, who is as revered by the American right as he is reviled by the left, explained his decision by quoting former Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina, a Democrat who left the Senate two years after Mr. Helms arrived. 
 "There is one inescapable reality that no man can ignore and that is that time takes a terrific toll," Mr. Helms said in an eight-minute televised address on WRAL-TV, where he first came to public notice as an editorial commentator. 
Backed by the state and national flags, and speaking deliberately, Mr. Helms seemed to choke up a bit as he concluded his remarks to the North Carolinians he has served longer than any senator in state history.
"One thing is for sure," he said, staring directly into a camera, "we will never forget you. And we shall always be grateful for all you have meant to us." 
Over the last decade, Mr. Helms has had coronary bypass surgery and prostate cancer, and he now suffers from a nerve condition in his feet that hampers his mobility and has forced him to use a motorized scooter. As a result, his departure has been anticipated and is certain to bring out several contenders for his seat.
Mr. Helms noted that he would be 88 if he ran and won in 2002 and completed a sixth term. "This," he said, "my family and I have decided unanimously I should not do and, ladies and gentlemen, I shall not."
In an interview with one of the station's anchors, Mr. Helms said that he had made his decision about three weeks ago and that it had been "very tough."
"Being part of the Senate," he said, "is not just another job, but I had to choose between that and my family and I made the right choice." 
While not unexpected, Mr. Helms's announcement was received solemnly by his admirers, who view him as a courageous captain of American conservatism, and cheered by his detractors, who see him as narrow-minded, obstinate and, in some cases, bigoted against minorities and homosexuals.
"It is a great loss," said the Rev. Jerry Falwell, a longtime Helms friend and the founder of the Moral Majority. "He's a national treasure. Of the 100 members of the United States Senate over the last 30 years, no one has been more consistent and reliable in his commitment to conservatism, America and moral and family values."
That view differed greatly from the one offered by Robert A. Pastor, an Emory University political scientist whose nomination by President Bill Clinton to be ambassador to Panama was one of many that died because of Mr. Helms's parliamentary maneuvering. 
"Nothing that Jesse Helms did in his entire career will enhance America's national security more than his retirement," Mr. Pastor said. "He's veered between the isolationist wing of his party and the unilateralist wing, but he has never accepted the tenets of cooperative multilateralism."
And yet, even some of those who battled with Mr. Helms over the years found themselves offering sentimental tributes today. Former Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., who lost a storied Senate race to Mr. Helms in 1984, spoke of the friendship they had subsequently developed and of Mr. Helms's fierceness in defense of his state.
And Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat who succeeded Mr. Helms as chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee when the Senate changed hands in June, complimented Mr. Helms as "one of the most thoughtful, considerate and gracious senators I have ever served with."
Mr. Biden also noted that Mr. Helms was capable, at times, of changing positions, as he did recently in compromising in his opposition to the payment of the nation's back dues to the United Nations. 
Mr. Helms's announcement sounded a starting gun for what may now become an intriguing race to succeed him. A crowd of potential candidates has been circling and jockeying for weeks on the assumption that this day would come. None moved immediately today, allowing Mr. Helms to take his farewell bow on an otherwise empty stage, but they are expected to make decisions soon. 
Like several other 2002 races in competitive states, the North Carolina campaign will be closely watched because of its implications for control of the Senate, where the Democrats took a one-vote majority in June after the defection of Senator James M. Jeffords from the Republican Party. But it also will say much about the politics of North Carolina, a state that, while generally conservative, is almost certainly not as conservative as its senior senator. The Republican primary, in particular, could become a battle to define the future of a party that has been identified for three decades by its conservative colossus, Mr. Helms. 
The main suspense here concerns whether Elizabeth Dole, a former presidential candidate and a two-time cabinet secretary, will enter the Republican primary. A North Carolina native who spends most of her time in Washington, Mrs. Dole, 65, has said she will give the race serious consideration if Mr. Helms retires. She made no comment today.
The prospect of a Dole candidacy has generated great enthusiasm among national party leaders, some of whom have predicted that her stature and fund-raising resources would all but clear the field of Republican competitors. But that view is not necessarily shared in North Carolina, where there are concerns about Mrs. Dole's age, her disappointing performance in the 2000 presidential campaign and her residence outside the state.
"She will face the carpetbagger label," said Theodore S. Arrington, a political scientist at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "And this is North Carolina, not New York, where we know what a carpetbagger is." 
If she runs, Mrs. Dole is likely to be perceived as firmly in the moderate camp. In her presidential campaign, for example, she supported a ban on assault weapons, a position unlikely to win friends in a Republican primary. The conservative standard, meanwhile, could be carried by former Senator Lauch Faircloth, 73, who was something of an ideological soulmate to Mr. Helms before losing his 1998 re-election campaign to John Edwards. Mr. Faircloth said tonight that he would give the race "serious consideration" in the coming weeks.
Falling somewhere between Mrs. Dole and Mr. Faircloth could be Representative Richard M. Burr, 45, of Winston-Salem. Mr. Burr, a four-term incumbent, has a generally conservative voting record but has not been as outspoken on social issues as Mr. Helms.
"He's not this sort of unyielding right-wing conservative in his public persona," said Jack D. Fleer, a political scientist at Wake Forest University.
In an interview tonight, Mr. Burr said he hoped to make a decision in the next three to four weeks, but said he would not run if Mr. Faircloth chose to do so.
Another potential candidate is a former mayor of Charlotte, Richard Vinroot, a two-time candidate for governor, who plans to meet with political advisers and fund-raisers on Thursday. Mr. Vinroot said today that there was "a great likelihood" that he would run.
On the Democratic side, Secretary of State Elaine Marshall has announced her candidacy, and State Representative Daniel T. Blue Jr., the state's first black House speaker, is considering the race. Former Governor Hunt said tonight that he would definitely not run. 
Whoever runs, politicians and political scientists said today that North Carolina politics would forever be changed. 
"We'll have a new day for us in North Carolina, and I think it will be a better one," said Harvey Gantt, the former Charlotte mayor who lost close races to Mr. Helms in 1990 and 1996. "Obviously, he was a different kind of senator, a throwback to another time."
Mr. Helms, Mr. Gantt said, succeeded by playing on the fears of white Southerners who saw their world changing at an unacceptable pace -- racially, economically and culturally.
Dan T. Carter, a historian at the University of South Carolina, said that Mr. Helms would probably be the last of his kind in Southern Republican politics, both in his rigid ideology and in his defiantly old-fashioned style.
"Today you have compassionate conservatism and a thousand points of light," Mr. Carter said. "But Helms held on to an abrasive rhetorical style of the 1950's and 60's in which the world is divided between the Satanic forces on one side and the forces of righteousness on the other."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about a decision by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina against seeking re-election to a sixth term misstated the age he would have reached by the end of that term. It is 87, not 88.

HEADLINE: State Faults Amtrak for Neglect of Tunnels 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
A state transportation report on Pennsylvania Station accuses Amtrak of neglecting costly improvements to 15 miles of potentially dangerous tunnels that serve the passenger station, the busiest in the country.
 The report suggests that Amtrak, the federally subsidized railroad that owns the tunnels, was more interested in pursuing projects like the new Acela high-speed rail service and the redevelopment of the James A. Farley Building across Eighth Avenue. It blames Amtrak for not correcting fire and safety problems in the tunnels, some of which were identified as early as 1978. 
 The report, to be released today, was prepared by the State Senate Standing Committee on Transportation and was based on a public hearing held in the spring. Among its recommendations, it calls upon United States Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton to do more to get federal money to correct the problems, which are estimated to cost $898 million over the next 10 years. 
"While we accept the sincerity of Amtrak's Northeast corridor administration's commitment to improve safety, it is clear that Amtrak has invested a great deal more effort in glamorous projects," the report says. "It is clear that Amtrak has sacrificed accelerated tunnel infrastructure improvements for these service expansion and economic development projects."
Amtrak has long complained that lack of money, not neglect, is at fault. This year, Amtrak has allocated $20 million for tunnel work, which is all officials say the railroad can afford. Amtrak is so short of funds that it had to mortgage portions of Penn Station last month to get short-term cash. 
An Amtrak spokesman, Rick Remington, said yesterday that federal funds for the $810 million Farley redevelopment project, which will convert the building into a passenger station, were assigned by Congress, not by Amtrak. As for the Acela service, he said it did not compete with the Penn Station tunnels for Amtrak's money or attention.
"It wasn't a case of either-or," Mr. Remington said. "We were progressing on both at the same time."
The tunnels were built more than 90 years ago and lack basic ventilation, adequate escape routes and even essential water standpipes for firefighting. Each of the six tunnels is about two-and-a-half miles long; four of them run under the East River and two under the Hudson River. Together they serve about 300,000 passengers a day on Amtrak, Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit trains.
Based on testimony from fire officials and other experts, the state report says the tunnels pose no imminent hazard to commuters since they are structurally sound and kept in good repair. Nonetheless, it concludes that emergency and safety facilities "are woefully inadequate to deal with a major fire, accident, terrorist act or other emergency situation."
State Senator Dean G. Skelos, one of the writers of the report, said in an interview, "All of Amtrak's projects are wonderful, but it means nothing if people are not safe." 
In the event of a fire or other emergency in the tunnels, narrow stairways and trapped smoke would make evacuating passengers so difficult that the Fire Department's contingency plans call for first towing trains from the tunnels with the passengers aboard.
A spokesman for the Fire Department, Deputy Commissioner Francis X. Gribbon, said yesterday that Amtrak recently agreed to speed up the installation of standpipes in the tunnels -- which would provide water for firefighting -- and to provide hand-powered railroad carts so that firefighters and hoses could get into the tunnels without depending upon the 90-year-old spiral staircases.
"I think they will be the old-fashioned kind, where you pump it," Mr. Gribbon said of the carts. 
The situation in the tunnels is so serious, the state report suggests, that if the federal government does not provide the money soon, the state should move to take control of the two East River tunnels that are exclusively used by the Long Island Rail Road.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that runs the commuter railroad, has been rebuffed by Amtrak in previous attempts to gain control of the tunnels, but state officials said the urgency of the situation might persuade federal officials to back a state effort. In its current five-year capital plan, the transportation authority has committed $125 million for tunnel safety work, an indication, authority officials say, of how serious it is about correcting the problems.
Richard R. Kelly, a consultant hired by Amtrak, said that he had not seen the state report but that he welcomed any effort, even if critical, that would draw attention to the tunnel problems.
"I never regretted or resented the inquiries because that was all part of bringing the message out as to what the need is," Mr. Kelly said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An East River rail tunnel. A state report says Amtrak is not correcting fire and safety problems in all six tunnels into Pennsylvania Station. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: From No Aid To a Bailout 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 

 BODY:
Despite negotiations that covered 12 days and several midnight bargaining sessions, many of the people involved in emergency talks to bail out Argentina's floundering economy went to lunch on Tuesday believing that the United States would say no to new aid.
 Bush administration officials had taken office declaring their intention to end President Clinton's repeated bailouts of chronically ailing economies like Argentina's. And Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill lamented in negotiating sessions over the past week that nobody seemed to be thinking creatively about ways of alleviating the country's debt problems without more loans. Publicly, he fretted about American "plumbers and carpenters" who pay taxes and "wonder what in the world we're doing with their money." 
 But by late Tuesday afternoon, Mr. O'Neill appeared to have changed his mind, and the administration voted to support the International Monetary Fund's plan to provide $8 billion in new loans for Argentina on top of a $13.7 billion package the country received just eight months ago. 
Ostensibly the administration's shift occurred because Argentina agreed to restructure its debt. The new I.M.F. loan program also pressures private lenders to help Argentina reschedule some loans.
But while those are novel provisions for an international bailout, they represent a 30-degree tack, rather than the 180-degree turn-around that the Bush administration had once indicated it preferred when it came to repeat borrowers at the financial bailout window.
The decision underscored that even at times when the United States holds most of the cards -- it is the largest single shareholder in the I.M.F. and is generally thought to have veto power over new loans -- it finds it difficult to deny an urgent request from an ally. It also cannot simply walk away from the interventionist financial diplomacy of the Clinton administration. That is, at least in part, because after a decade of fast-paced economic integration it is hard to separate financial rescues from other foreign policy priorities the Bush administration puts higher on its agenda, like free trade, open stock and bond markets, even democracy.
"You have to worry about collateral damage to the global financial situation, free trade, and open economies," said Edwin M. Truman, a former Treasury and Federal Reserve official who worked on many international financial rescues. "It's not like you can just categorically turn off the bailout switch."
President Bush has stressed the need to expand ties with Latin American leaders and has pushed a plan to create a hemispheric free trade zone modeled on Nafta. That goal would likely have receded had Argentina collapsed after its leaders got a polite no to their aid request from the United States, people involved in the talks said today.
It is no coincidence that Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, today invited Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay to join the United States in reviving the so-called Four-Plus-One trade group that pushed for trade expansion in the first Bush administration. Mr. Zoellick called free trade an engine of economic growth for Argentina and the region that would supplement the I.M.F. rescue package.
The Bush administration also has come under repeated fire, especially from European allies, for abandoning international commitments made during the Clinton years, including agreements to reduce global warming, control germ warfare and to crack down on tax evasion. White House officials have recently been scrambling to demonstrate that they value cooperative relations with major allies. Scuttling a rescue for Argentina could have undermined that.
Interestingly, many economists agree with Mr. O'Neill's skeptical approach. Argentina's problems have become severe enough that new loans are seen as having no more chance of success -- and maybe less chance -- than the last round agreed to during the final months of the Clinton administration. Argentina's economy has been shrinking for three years. Falling exports and capital flight has threatened its ability to repay some $128 billion in dollar-denominated foreign loans.
But while it is hardly a model for economic development among emerging markets, Argentina has often followed the advice of the I.M.F. In the early 1990's it committed itself to keeping its peso equal to a dollar in an effort to tame inflation, and overhauled its banking system, which was mired in mismanagement. 
Moreover, political support for fiscal austerity and open markets is shaky, both in Argentina and neighboring Brazil. Some fear a popular backlash if the experiments fails.
"If these talks had not had a positive result, we would definitely have had effects -- political, economic and in other areas -- that we all definitely wanted to avoid," Daniel Marx, Argentina's finance secretary, said today. Mr. Marx led his country's negotiating team.
For days, Mr. O'Neill pressed I.M.F. officials, Mr. Marx and his staff to find a way to solve Argentina's problem without new loans. Mr. O'Neill explored the idea of an Argentine-led debt restructuring backed by the I.M.F. or another multinational lending agency that would not require up-front loan commitments, for example, people involved in the talks said.
To the extent Mr. O'Neill and others countenanced new lending, they wanted assurances that the loans would resolve Argentina's woes long-term. Given market uncertainties, I.M.F. and Argentine officials were unable to provide the hard, multi-year projections Mr. O'Neill demanded, the people said.
Timing also worked against the administration. Argentine officials had made clear they were seeking up to $9 billion in new loans. As negotiations dragged on, investors lost faith in new aid.
Mr. O'Neill's scathing public assessment of Argentina's dependence on foreign aid -- he referred to a 70-year record of borrowing with poor results -- also struck at confidence. Argentine stocks plummeted and the bond market soured. 
Ultimately, the administration was backed into supporting new aid just to control matters. The aid buys time for Argentina and the I.M.F. to pursue the creative long-term solution that Mr. O'Neill sought.
"The reason the talks took so long is that O'Neill really wanted to do something creative and longer lasting," said William R. Rhodes, a Citigroup vice chairman who tracked the talks for his bank. "But ultimately to get that done you need calm and tranquillity in the markets."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Art May Not Be All Fun and Games, but Some of It Certainly Is

BYLINE:  By GRACE GLUECK 

DATELINE: NORTH ADAMS, Mass. 

 BODY:
Taking cues from the Surrealists and Grandpa Duchamp, the foxiest player of them all, more than a few artists are incorporating games and game themes into their work. They are prompted, too, by current video and computer pastimes, and maybe the slots at Las Vegas.
 Intrigued by the effects of chance, rules, competition, challenge and foolery that games engender, they devise obstacle courses, puzzles and word and video constructs that invite viewer participation on, well, a different wavelength from more traditional art. 
 To play Uri Tzaig's marble game, "Trance," two or more people sit at a square table topped by a pebbly silicon board and move the colored marbles on it in ways of their own improvising. Perry Hoberman's "Cathartic User Interface" presents a giant panel of computer keyboards that viewers activate by throwing balls whose random hits produce irritating messages: System Failure. The operation has failed. Would you like to try again? It will only fail again. 
Both works are in "Game Show," one of three related exhibitions at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art here that deal with artists whose work makes use of game structures and themes. It's a hodgepodge of a group, some of whose participants seem a little dragged in, but the result is not without entertainment value.
Of the two other shows, "Oyvind Fahlstrom: Another Space for Painting," brings back a gamester well known in the 60's and 70's whose work faded out with his untimely death; Fahlstrom (1928-76) was a Brazilian-born Swedish activist and social activist. 
"Fluxus Games From the Gilbert and Lila Silverman Fluxus Collection Foundation" displays work by artists who belonged to the fluid and playfully subversive Fluxus movement of the 1960's and 70's. Lively as it is, it's a familiar group of pieces that have often been seen, and it offers no surprises.
Taking up a sizable chunk of "Game Show" is Kay Rosen's "Sight and Sound of Music," a humongous wall drawing in a gallery to match. The work comprises two graphlike lines of peaks and valleys -- a green one soaring high, a blue one lying low -- on a grid, flanked at each end by a vertical alphabet, each letter aligned with one of the grid's horizontal lines. 
What looks like a chart of, say, the gross national product, turns out, when properly read, to be a musical text and notes. Aside from billboard messages, it's not too often that a small, sweet idea has the chance to expand in such a space.
Another space-grabber -- and there's plenty of space here to grab -- is Sophie Calle's "Double Game," somewhat abbreviated from its New York appearance last season at the Paula Cooper Gallery. In it, through texts and photos, Ms. Calle depicts the game of double lives she has played, as a chambermaid, stalker, character in a novel and street performer in SoHo.
Christoph Draeger's catastrophe photographs -- some made up, some for real -- become games by virtue of their translation into jigsaw puzzles. His "found" color photographs of disasters, some of which are very big, are glued to cardboard backings and die-cut into puzzle pieces, like "TWA 800 No. 4," showing the reassembling of the plane's carcass in a hangar after its explosion in 1996. 
This and his other disaster puzzles could be read, I suppose, on a literal level, as the riddle of accidents in general. More to the point, the breakup of the photos into a jigsaw play pattern gives the viewer an ironic distance from the events. Still, in this show explanations violate the rules of the game.
The game as a con job is seen in Christian Jankowski's "Telemistica," created on the spot at the 1999 Venice Biennale. He asked unwitting Venetian tarot card readers to comment on his yet-unborn work, which would be a video of their responses to his questions about its success. And here is the video, showing the readers' forecasts -- favorable, of course -- for its prospects and Mr. Jankow ski's happiness with it.
The work that involves the most physical labor is Chris Finley's four-part "Level One," which puts the viewer through a set of optical exercises. The first step is lining up a sassy three-part painting of a spaced-out pig while straddling a gutter in which a rolling ball oinks at your feet. In the fourth and last step, you are jumping up and down on a trampoline to see over a wall that half conceals Mr. Finley's hyperactive painting "Boing Splat Flat With Yellow Jacket Bat." And is it worth it? Never mind; it's the process that counts in his kid-pleasing marathon.
Who was it who said, "A few artists at play go a very long way"?
Much more impressive is the Fahlstrom exhibition, which occupies another level of this vast, Rube Goldbergian warren of buildings and corridors that is a big game in itself. "Oyvind Fahlstrom: Another Space for Painting" is a smaller version of a show organized by the Museu d'Art Contemporani de Barcelona, and it is making its only United States appearance at Mass MOCA. The two museums have produced a meaty catalog.
Fahlstrom, a painter, poet, performer, cultural critic and provocateur, regarded all of his work as a crusade for peace and social justice. But unlike most crusaders, he had a sense of humor. His use of Pop imagery tended to confuse those who slotted his garrulous work as Conceptual, but it stoutly resisted classification, having been culled from sources that ranged from Surrealism to John Cage, Mad magazine and Robert Crumb. (Fahlstrom was one of the first artists to use comic strips as inspiration.)
Games (some of them precursors of video play), maps, performances and installations were his preferred mediums. One of his inventions was "variable paintings" using cutouts on springs or magnets that could be moved around, like "Packing the Hard Potatoes (Chile I: Last Months of Allende Regime)" from 1974. A wall work with phantasmagoric cutouts on springs, each of its elements bears lines of poetry by Sylvia Plath and Federico Garcia Lorca.
The show's most arresting installation is "Meatball Curtain (for R. Crumb)," from 1969, inspired by a Crumb comic strip. Its raucous, brightly colored life-size figures of animals, humanoids and other phenomena form a sprawling tableau, flat forms translated into a 3-D setup. Meatballs, suspended on wires, drop down on the figures, "transfiguring the people and threatening the world order," in the artist's words.
A more participatory experience is offered by "The Little General (Pinball Machine)," from 1967, presumably a comment on the political and moral confusions of the 1960's. In a shallow waist-high pool, 9 by 16 feet, float silhouettes, cut out from magazine images and mounted on Styrofoam -- a typical Fahlstrom medley of figures that includes de Gaulle, Che Guevara, Moshe Dayan, a woman exposing herself, a penis, coffins, a head of Bob Hope -- that move if you even breathe on them. Their collisions and changes of position reflect the chance actions that daily invent and reinvent the world.
There is enough here from Fahlstrom's richly imaginative inventory of images and concepts to make his the most important of these three exhibitions. It speaks to a new audience even 25 years after his death.
"Game Show" remains on view through April, "Oyvind Fahlstrom: Another Space for Painting" through Nov. 1 and "Fluxus Games From the Gilbert and Lila Silverman Fluxus Collection Foundation" through Jan. 14 at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, 87 Marshall Street, North Adams, Mass., (413) 664-4481.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In "Trance" by Uri Tzaig, museumgoers play with marbles.; Chris Finley's "One-Eyed Galactic Gutterball Pig Mantra," a game-art installation at Mass MOCA. (Photographs by Nicholas Whitman/Mass MOCA)

HEADLINE: Insurer Says Hyundai Deal Could Falter 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
The American International Group, the world's largest insurer, warned today that a $1.16 billion deal to take over the financial units of the crumbling Hyundai empire could collapse, just hours after a preliminary agreement with the South Korean government was signed.
 Under the deal announced here today -- which came after nearly a year of negotiations -- a consortium led by A.I.G. would take 55 percent of Hyundai Investment Trust and Securities, nearly 30 percent of Hyundai Trust Management and a stake in Hyundai Securities. 
 But later in the day, the company said that the agreement would fall apart if Hyundai Securities priced its shares at 8,940 won, or $6.80. A.I.G. said the price "is unacceptable and will impede completion of A.I.G.'s proposed investment" in the other two Hyundai companies. 
"A.I.G. does not believe the transaction will be consummated, unless this or other aspects of the transaction are promptly modified," the company said in a statement from its headquarters in New York. A.I.G. is said to have expected a share price of 7,000 won for Hyundai Securities.
Despite the optimism with which Korean leaders greeted the deal, the A.I.G. statement illustrates the difficulties foreign companies have faced in negotiations for Korean businesses as the Seoul government tries to restructure the conglomerate-dominated economy.
The investment by A.I.G. and the consortium, which includes W. L. Ross & Company, would be the largest foreign investment ever in the Korean financial services industry. Korean regulators said that under the deal, A.I.G. would invest $840 million to $850 million while a Korean government company would invest $700 million.
The signing of the memorandum today came as a relief to Korean leaders, after recent signs that the economic recovery was flagging. Indeed, the deal came as officials celebrated the last payment on $19.5 billion in loans extended by the International Monetary Fund. In late 1997, the fund put together a $58.5 billion rescue package to cover debts piled up by Korean conglomerates.
Kim Yong Duk, deputy finance minister, said the A.I.G. deal was evidence of South Korea's ability to fight its way through the current slump. "Definitely this deal will improve the confidence of the market," Mr. Kim said. "It will remove uncertainties."
Some analysts, however, said the celebration was premature. "The economy is slowing precipitously and publicly," said Richard Samuelson, managing director of UBS Warburg here.

HEADLINE: De Beers, With Net Off 15%, Will Curb Its Diamond Buying 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
As the economic slowdown blunts American appetites for costly baubles, De Beers Investment, the diamond giant, said today that its first-half profit fell 15 percent.
 De Beers also backed away from an earlier forecast that its sales of rough diamonds would reach $4.8 billion this year. And it said it would introduce quotas for the number of stones it was prepared to buy from diamond mines. It last introduced quotas in 1998 when sales slumped. 
 De Beers controls about two-thirds of the world's mining and marketing of rough diamonds, as the stones are called before they are cut and polished. The United States accounts for half the $60 billion retail market for jewelry and gems.
In the first half of the year, De Beers said net income fell to $744 million from $877 million a year earlier. The report was the company's first since it was taken private in May in a leveraged buyout led by the Oppenheimer family of South Africa and the Anglo American mining colossus, both of which hold 45 percent of the new De Beers Investment.
In a conference call, Gary Ralfe, De Beers' managing director, acknowledged that the company faced a difficult market and regulatory problems in Europe relating to a new marketing strategy called Supplier of Choice. The strategy aims to encourage competition among its wholesale customers to increase demand.
Mr. Ralfe said the market slowdown, particularly in the United States, where diamond retailers had not been able to sell surplus stocks, meant that De Beers was not going to meet its forecast of $4.8 billion in sales. "We're going to undershoot it by some distance," he said.
He also said that European Union regulators in Brussels had objected to its new marketing strategy, forcing De Beers to delay its introduction planned for last month.
Even without that regulatory hurdle, however, the De Beers plan to introduce quotas for its own mines and other suppliers in Russia and Canada represents an about-face, as the company falls back on the manipulation of diamond supplies through which it has controlled the world diamond trade for decades. Its new strategy is supposed to end the practice of controlling supplies in favor of promoting demand for diamonds as the main force in the diamond business.
Mr. Ralfe said the quotas would be modest, representing less than 10 percent of current supplies.
De Beers executives said there had been no change in the company's long-running regulatory problems in the United States, where it has long faced antitrust challenges because of its cartel-like grip on the world diamond trade.

HEADLINE: First Voting In East Timor Gives a Taste Of New Rights 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
Exactly two years after the people of East Timor voted, at great cost, to break away from Indonesia, they are tasting the fruits of their freedom with the first democratic election in their history.
 On Aug. 30, the anniversary of their referendum for independence, East Timorese are to vote for a constituent assembly that will draw up a constitution in preparation for full nationhood some time next year. 
 This vote, like the referendum in 1999, is being organized by the United Nations, which has continued to administer East Timor, a former Portuguese colony annexed by Indonesia, as it struggles to its feet economically and politically.
The assessment this week by United Nations officials and East Timorese reached by telephone: so far, so good. 
"People seem to be very much aware that this is a momentous event for them," said Colin Stewart, the United Nations official in charge of civic education. 
"For the first time, they will have their own democratically elected legislature and a cabinet that reflects the result of their vote," Mr. Stewart said. "Timorese will be taking the reins of power, even though technical independence is still a step away."
Tens of thousands of people have given their views in public meetings on the kind of nation they would like to see embodied in a new constitution. And about 80 percent of the 380,000 eligible residents have registered to vote.
They are to choose 88 members of an assembly from among 1,138 candidates representing 16 parties. The assembly is to convene two weeks later to begin to shape the outlines of the newest nation. A presidential election is likely to follow a few months later.
Almost everybody expects Jose Alexandre Gusmao, East Timor's independence leader and its most popular public figure, to be elected president. For the moment he is standing aside from the campaign, pursuing his avocation as a photographer and joining foreign reporters in covering the rallies.
The campaign has been largely peaceful, although acts of intimidation by the largest party, Fretilin, have been reported.
"There is an undercurrent of tension," said Johanna Kao, who has been helping organize political parties as a representative of the International Republican Institute, an American civic-education organization. "They are a little worried about what the election might bring in terms of new violence or conflicts."
The tension is not surprising, given East Timor's recent experience. When it voted overwhelmingly for independence, ending 25 years of Indonesian occupation, the vote was followed by a rampage by Indonesian-backed militias that took hundreds of lives and destroyed 80 percent of the territory's buildings.
"So many people have had so much trauma," said Rosa Garcia, a reporter for The Timor Post, a local daily. "They anticipate that if Fretilin does not win, it will be like a civil war. Some people say they have already been threatened."
East Timor's recovery is still only beginning. Most ruined buildings have not been rebuilt, many people remain unemployed and small outbreaks of violence are common.
Some 50,000 East Timorese still live in refugee camps in neighboring West Timor, which is still part of Indonesia. Militia members continue to clash with United Nations peacekeepers along the border.
East Timor remains heavily dependent on foreign aid, with just $25 million of its annual budget of $305 million coming from taxes and fees.
A multibillion-dollar windfall is expected in the coming decades from offshore oil. But apart from that, coffee is East Timor's only significant export. The foreign investment that Mr. Gusmao said would fuel recovery has not materialized in any significant way.
Even before the wave of devastation in 1999, East Timor had few resources with which to build a nation. The territory was run essentially by its Indonesian occupiers.
The United Nations and private foreign agencies are working to create a police force, a court system, a new military force, an education system and a health care system. Much of this is paid for from a $170 million trust fund administered by the World Bank.
On its face the capital, Dili, appears to be bustling, but most restaurants, hotels, vehicles and apartment rentals are part of a bubble economy fed by the huge foreign presence. One test for East Timor will come when that presence begins to scale down next year.
Another concern is that troublemakers from across the border are biding their time until the United Nations withdraws, hoping to prove Indonesia's prediction that East Timor cannot survive alone. Secretary General Kofi Annan says some foreign troops will be needed even after full independence.
The election next week will be only one of the early steps toward creat ing a nation that can stand on its own.

HEADLINE: Some on Fed Panel Saw June's Rate Cut as Enough 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's interest-rate-setting panel voted to cut borrowing costs at its June meeting, but some members thought that the Fed was nearing the end of the current cycle of looser monetary policy, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
 The panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, voted 9 to 1 to reduce short-term rates by one-quarter of a percentage point at the meeting on June 26-27, with William H. Poole, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, casting the negative vote. 
 "Mr. Poole dissented because he believed that F.O.M.C. actions this year had already established a highly stimulative monetary policy stance," the minutes said, adding that he thought another rate cut "raised an undue risk of fostering higher inflation in the future."
While Mr. Poole was the only formal dissenter, some other members apparently shared his concern. "In the view of a number of members," the minutes said, "the committee might well be near the end of its easing cycle."
Still, on Tuesday, the Federal Open Market Committee again cut short-term rates by a quarter-point, the seventh reduction this year in an attempt to stave off recession -- which, as economists define it, is two consecutive quarters of contraction in the broad economy.
The cut in June, the sixth, was the first one of only a quarter-point. Before June there had been five cuts of a half-percent each.
Mr. Poole's dissent was the second time this year that a member of the Fed's policy panel chose to vote against a rate decision. At the meeting on May 15, Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, voted against a half-point cut, favoring a smaller move instead. At the time, analysts were surprised by Mr. Hoenig's dissent and the disclosure that two other unidentified committee members said they "could have accepted" a smaller reduction.
Most Fed committee members in June saw the easing as posing little risk of inflation and thought it was necessary, given the lack of evidence that the economic slowdown was over. At the time of the meeting, the economy was performing more poorly than had been expected and inflation was subdued.
In addition to the decision to lower rates again, Mr. Poole disagreed with the "balance of risks" statement issued after the meeting, which said there was a greater risk of recession than inflation. The minutes said Mr. Poole was worried that the statement would be viewed as a sign the Fed was likely to cut rates further.
Still, in reflecting the overall view, the minutes said, "With greater slack in labor and product markets, and with inflation expectations contained, an added easing ran very little risk of exacerbating price pressures, provided the committee was prepared to firm the stance of policy promptly if and when demand pressures threatened to intensify."
