HEADLINE: California Home Prices Up 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: LA JOLLA, Calif., Aug. 23 

 BODY:
Prices for homes in Southern California rose in July at their fastest rate since 1989 and sales surged, helped by low mortgage rates and pent-up demand for lower-cost homes, a new report said. 
 The median price rose to a record $234,000 last month, a 14 percent increase from July 2000, according to the report, by DataQuick Information Systems. A total of 28,944 homes were sold in Los Angeles, Riverside, San Diego, Ventura, San Bernardino and Orange Counties, up more than 19 percent from July 2000 but down 3.7 percent from June 2000. 
 Entry-level and midlevel homes were selling at a faster rate than more expensive homes, reversing a seven-year trend.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; 
2 Big Booksellers' Results Beat Wall St. Expectations

BYLINE:  By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK 

 BODY:
Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookstore chain, posted fiscal second-quarter results yesterday that easily surpassed Wall Street expectations. The second-largest chain, Borders Group, modestly topped forecasts.
 In a crucial barometer of how the book industry is faring during the economic slowdown, both companies also projected an improvement over last year's lackluster holidays, the season that usually accounts for more than 40 percent of the book industry's annual sales. 
 Barnes & Noble said it expected sales at its superstores open at least a year to increase about 4 percent through the holiday quarter. By comparison, Barnes & Noble's same-store sales rose about 2 percent during last year's weak holidays after rising about 6 percent in 1999.
Ed Wilhelm, Borders' chief financial officer, said he also expected sales growth better than last year, but not as good as 1999.
Both companies noted that comparisons with last year reflected the anomalous burst of book sales last summer after the release of the fourth Harry Potter book.
For the quarter ended Aug. 4, Barnes & Noble reported a loss of $1.7 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with a loss of $8.6 million, or 13 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier, partly reflecting a 62.6 percent increase in sales in its Game-Stop video game division.
Excluding certain costs like losses in some investments and stock payments to executives, Barnes & Noble said it would have broken even on a per-share basis, compared with a loss of 11 cents a share in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected the company to lose 12 cents a share on that basis.
Barnes & Noble, based in New York, said its revenue rose to $1.05 billion from $924.3 million. Sales at its superstores rose 8.3 percent, to $772.5 million. Sales at its superstores open at least a year rose 3 percent. 
Barnes & Noble also operates B. Dalton bookstores, which account for about 8 percent of its bookstore revenue; it also owns a 40 percent stake in the online store Barnesandnoble.com. Losses from its stake in Barnesandnoble.com, which declined to $11.3 million from $15.7 million, and from the cost of acquiring GameStop lowered its earnings to break-even.
Barnes & Noble said sales at GameStop, previously called Babbage's, rose to $206.8 million from $127.3 million, reflecting the popularity of new video game platforms.
The company also said it planned to make preliminary filings to spin off GameStop by selling a minority stake to the public.
Shares of Barnes & Noble rose $1.21 each, to $41.97.
After the market closed, Borders, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., reported earnings for the quarter ended July 29 of about $100,000, up from a loss of $1.6 million in the period a year earlier. The company said its per-share earnings, excluding discontinued operations and certain one-time charges, rose to break-even from a loss of 2 cents a share. Analysts had expected the company to lose a penny a share, according to First Call.
Borders, which also operates Waldenbooks, said its sales rose 5.9 percent, to $739.8 million, from $698.4 million. In its Borders superstores in the United States, which account for the bulk of its revenue, sales rose 10.1 percent, to $511.1 million from $464.1 million. Sales at store open more than one year rose 2 percent in the quarter.

HEADLINE: CHINA NOW FACING AN AIDS EPIDEMIC, A TOP AIDE ADMITS 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
Departing from the Chinese government's general reticence on the subject of AIDS, a senior official openly admitted today that China was facing an epidemic that threatened to outpace government efforts to control it.
 The official, Deputy Health Minister Yin Dakui, also conceded the government's failure to develop effective education programs and the tendency of some local officials to cover up the extent of infection in their jurisdictions, allowing the disease to spread unchecked. 
 "Like many other countries we are also facing a very serious epidemic of H.I.V.-AIDS," Mr. Yin said, adding that the government had "not effectively stemmed the epidemic."
Mr. Yin's 90-minute news conference -- the first by a top Chinese official on the topic -- was the latest in a series of small steps suggesting that China is ready to address more openly a topic that has been mostly taboo. 
At today's news conference, Mr. Yin insisted that China's epidemic of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, was still relatively small -- but he also released some alarming new statistics. Reported H.I.V. infections rose 67.4 percent in the first six months of 2001 compared with the same period last year, he said. And about 5 percent of drug users in China are now infected with H.I.V., up from less than 0.5 percent in 1995.
In response, the government has decided to spend about $12 million annually for AIDS prevention and control, he said, as well as more than $117 million this year to improve blood safety. (By comparison, the United States government has budgeted $744 million for H.I.V. prevention in fiscal year 2001, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.)
More important, though, Mr. Yin addressed some of the politically sensitive aspects of the AIDS problem, touching on China's shortcomings in dealing with the crisis forcefully and in time. "In some regions, leaders and the general public have not fully realized the hidden dangers of a large-scale epidemic," he said. 
He also discussed, for the first time, an AIDS epidemic covered up in Henan Province, where tens of thousands of poor farmers have contracted AIDS by selling their blood using unsterilized practices.
Just last week, Mr. Yin held a widely publicized meeting with AIDS patients in the village of Wenlou, in Henan Province. It was the first time that such a high-level delegation had visited the area and the first time the situation had been featured in the mainstream state press.
Today's news conference was a milestone of sorts, although it also underscored the gulf between the government and its critics both in and outside China who remain at least somewhat skeptical, feeling that the government has been far too slow in confronting a burgeoning AIDS problem.
"In the past I may have believed things, but now I'm not sure about what I'm told, so I must observe and judge," said Dr. Gao Yaojie, a retired gynecologist who earned international praise and the enmity of local officials by creating her own H.I.V.-education program in Henan.
And the government's apparent commitment to greater openness about AIDS was undercut by the fact that reports on today's lengthy news conference in the state-controlled press were brief and statistical, leaving out the Mr. Yin's judgment that China faced a "serious epidemic" and not mentioning Henan Province by name at all.
Also, despite acknowledging a rapid increase in the number of people testing positive for H.I.V., Mr. Yin staunchly defended previous ministry estimates that 600,000 Chinese were infected with the virus at the end of 2000. And he repeated the goal, set by the central government this May, that China should contain the total number of H.I.V. cases to less than 1.5 million in 2010.
But a recent United Nations report estimated that already "above one million" Chinese had H.I.V. at the start of 2001, and that if current trends continue there could be 20 million by the end of 2010.
According to government data, almost 70 percent of those infected with H.I.V. are intravenous drug-users, although critics say that statistic may be partly a result of intensive testing in that group.
Even those who welcomed the government's new approach said that it was too little, too late for the thousands of people who had been needlessly infected in recent years -- while health officials failed to take decisive action. 
The United Nations report noted that China was experiencing local H.I.V. epidemics that could have been prevented with simple education programs.
For example, government research found that the rate of needle-sharing among drug users in Jiangxi Province increased sharply in the 1990's, reaching 93 percent in 1999. Because health officials made inadequate efforts to stem the practice, H.I.V. spread quickly among addicts when the virus entered the population. Seventeen percent of drug users at one surveillance site are now infected.
"Education is extremely important especially at the grass-roots level," said Dr. Gao, who is currently distributing 120,000 copies of a book she recently wrote and printed on the topic. "Education is essential," she said, "and so is a proper attitude toward people with AIDS -- an attitude of support and understanding."
Mr. Yin disputed accusations that the government had been previously unconcerned, noting that the government has had an office charged with overseeing sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS since 1996 and a plan for H.I.V. prevention and containment since 1998. 
But until the new infusions of money announced this month, that plan was underfinanced. In recent years, China, the world's most populous country, has spent only a fraction of the money spent on H.I.V. education and prevention by Thailand, for example. 
Mr. Yin became testy on the question of why the Health Ministry had not been more forceful in dealing with the epidemic among blood sellers in rural Henan Province. 
The bulk of H.I.V. cases there were contracted in the 1990's when poor farmers sold their blood at blood stations that, Mr. Yin admitted today, used unsanitary procedures.
Blood from farmers of the same blood type would be pooled and centrifuged to separate out the plasma, which was sold to make medicines like gamma globulin and albumin. The remainder of the pooled blood, mostly red cells, was reinjected into the farmers. This was to allow them to give blood more frequently, which many did several times a month for a fee of about $5.
While Mr. Yin blamed "underground and illegal plasma collection stations" for H.I.V.'s spread, he did not mention that many of these stations were owned or operated in collaboration with government bureaus, including the Chinese military.
The practice tailed off in the second half of the 1990's, in part because of a government ban on blood sales and in part because the farmers realized that it had infected them with a fatal disease.
But data on infection rates in the area remain sketchy, in large part because provincial officials have generally refused to let outside researchers conduct independent surveys, often forcing them to work undercover. Some Chinese journalists who have tried to report on the problem have been fired. Foreign journalists who have tried to visit the villages have been detained. 
Mr. Yin denied that Health Ministry officials were in any way responsible, saying that "it is not appropriate to blame the Chinese government for the suppression." 
"We have all along encouraged people on the local level to confront the issue rather than to suppress it," he said. 
"Our experts have made efforts to change the way of thinking of the leaders and the people at the grass roots," he said. "But they are worried that once the problem is revealed it will harm their social and economic development."
Indeed, because of widespread ignorance, people with AIDS generally face severe discrimination. Once a village gains the reputation of having an AIDS problem, its residents often have trouble selling their produce or even traveling on buses out of town. 
Still, even as some village officials have tried to suppress information, many AIDS patients have made desperate efforts to get their story out -- even traveling to Beijing to petition central leaders and meet with journalists.
Reached by phone, one AIDS patient in Wenlou who would give only his surname, Cheng, said that while villagers generally appreciated the deputy minister's recent visit, they felt he offered no solution. 
Mr. Cheng said that 12 people in the village of several thousand had died of AIDS this summer and that several more were close to death. He said that although health authorities had now set up a free clinic, it only dispensed simple medicines for headaches, diarrhea and fevers. 
During the visit of the deputy minister and his entourage, Mr. Cheng said, the village was surrounded by the police. "He didn't say what would happen to us," Mr. Cheng said. "He encouraged us, and warned us not to talk to foreign reporters." 
In villages like Wenlou, a majority of adults sold blood, and many now have H.I.V. Mr. Yin estimated that between 30,000 and 50,000 former blood sellers in Henan Province were infected. Other estimates put the number as high as a million.
Last April, the Henan provincial health department -- together with the Health Ministry -- tried to conduct a comprehensive survey of the village, although several people refused to participate. Of more than 1,600 people questioned, 568 reported that they had sold blood before 1995 and, of those, 244, about 42 percent, tested positive for H.I.V. Some previous studies had suggested rates as high as 60 percent for the village as a whole.
But the April study probably understates the impact of the virus on the village because it included people of all ages up to 65, and few people under 20 could have sold blood. It also does not include the many villagers who have already died. 
Ministry officials say they are continuing their efforts to understand the magnitude of the problem.
"It is important to get an accurate estimate of carriers so we can establish the future costs of their medical care, because the villagers are poor and can't afford their own treatment," said Dr. Shen Jie, an H.I.V. expert at the Health Ministry.
At the news conference, Mr. Yin also addressed the government's plans for AIDS education, confessing that official efforts had so far failed in many respects. "We still have a poor record of education on how to prevent H.I.V.," he said. 
He noted that in surveys, only about 9 percent of prostitutes regularly have their clients use condoms and only 30 to 40 percent of intravenous drug addicts understood how to protect themselves from contracting H.I.V. "That number is even lower among people in impoverished or remote areas," he said, where many people have still never even heard of AIDS.
That lack of knowledge is especially worrisome because H.I.V. infection has now been found in all 31 provinces. 
Dr. Gao said she had been deluged with requests for copies of her new education book, which she printed in part with the proceeds from the Jonathan Mann Award, a prestigious international public health prize, with which she was honored this year. Local officials blocked her from traveling to Washington to accept it from United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan. 
"Of course education should be the government's job," she said. "There's so much to be done."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Uncertain Economy Spurs Interest in Law Degrees
A growing number of relatively recent college graduates have decided that a law degree is the best ticket to a safe perch in the new economy of uncertainty.
 Nearly 24,000 people took the Law School Admissions Test in June, an increase of 18.6 percent from the same month the previous year, according to the Law School Admission Council. The organization, which administers the exam, expects a similar or even larger increase in the number of people taking the next test in early October. Page A1. 

2 Bookstore Chains Top Estimates
Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookstore chain, narrowed its fiscal second-quarter loss, surpassing estimates, while the second largest, Borders Group, modestly topped forecasts with its profit. Both companies projected continued improvement over last year's lackluster results through the holiday season, which usually accounts for more than 40 percent of the book industry's annual sales. Shares of Barnes & Noble rose $1.21, to $41.97, while Borders rose 13 cents, to $23.28. C6.

Dispute Over AIDS Drug Intensifies
The dispute between Brazil and Roche, the Swiss drug maker, intensified as the company asked to meet with the nation's health minister, who repeated his threat to authorize generic copies of a Roche AIDS medicine. C2.

Waning Surplus Poses Political Test
For the last few years, Republicans and Democrats have agreed not to touch the portion of the federal budget surplus coming from Social Security. But now that the surplus outside of Social Security has dwindled, their resolve is about to be tested. News Analysis. A1.

Stocks Finish Session Mostly Lower
Stocks fell as skittish investors saw little reason to buy. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 47.75 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,229.15. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 17.04 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,842.97, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 3.22 points, to 1,162.09. C7.

Hasbro Streamlines Operations
Hasbro, the nation's second-largest toy maker after said that it was integrating the last of its semi-independent divisions. C4.

Fed Minutes Show Debate in June
The Federal Reserve's interest-rate-setting panel voted to cut borrowing costs by a quarter-point at its June meeting, but some members thought that the Fed was nearing the end of the current cycle of looser monetary policy, according to minutes of the meeting. William H. Poole, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, dissented. C7.

Russia Raises Its Oil Output
Russia, the world's second-largest oil exporter, is increasing its production and export of oil, just as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is seeking to cut back output. World Business, Section W.

A.I.G. Says Hyundai Deal May Falter
The American International Group, the big insurer, warned that a $1.16 billion deal to take over the financial units of Hyundai could collapse. World Business, Section W.

Profit Decreases 15% at De Beers
As the economic slowdown blunts appetites for costly baubles, De Beers Investment, the diamond giant, said that its first-half profit fell 15 percent. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: LAW SCHOOL CALLS AS ECONOMY SLOWS 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
When Kevin Haeberle graduated from Georgetown University with a degree in English literature two years ago, the last thing on his mind was law school.
 He caught the dot-com wave and rode it well until he was laid off last month. But now he is one of a growing number of relatively recent college graduates who have decided that a law degree, after all, is the best ticket to a safe perch in the new economy of uncertainty. 
 "I want something meaningful to me, and I want something that is more of a stable, organized environment," said Mr. Haeberle, 24, who is collecting unemployment benefits while taking a course to prepare for the Law School Admissions Test this fall. "Not someplace where 25 percent of your co-workers are there one day and gone the next." 
Nearly 24,000 people took the L.S.A.T. in June, an increase of 18.6 percent from June in the previous year, according to the Law School Admission Council. The organization, which administers the exam, expects a similar or even larger increase in the number of people taking the next test in early October.
Reflecting decisions mostly made late last year, when the first signs of economic distress were just emerging, applications to enter law school this fall rose as well, up 5.6 percent, to almost 79,000. That is the largest increase in a decade and the highest number of applicants since 1995, when over 84,000 people applied. It remains well below the nearly 100,000 who sought entry to law school at the depths of the last recession in 1991, but it is expected to increase even more sharply for those applying for next year's class.
Tom Matos, director of admissions at New York Law School, said, "As the economy gets softer, for those who are recent graduates of undergraduate schools and who don't have job security and who have had in the back of their mind an escape route, law school is fairly high up on the list." 
In the boom years of the 1990's, interest in law school waned as college graduates, many attracted by tales of instant dot-com millionaires, sought opportunities elsewhere.
In the meantime, while business schools initially attracted more students in the 1990's as entrepreneurial success stories spread, they also lost applicants at the height of the Internet fever. Applications fell because it seemed to many young adults that an M.B.A. was an unnecessary way station before jumping on the gravy train.
Now, as the job market deteriorates, both law and business schools are drawing more attention, with law, which appears to be the most sensitive to changes in the economy, showing the sharpest increase.
Many students applying to law school, of course, are the kind of people who have always gone: those drawn to the glamour of the courtroom by dramas like "Law and Order," those pursuing careers in politics or promoting social causes and those following in a family tradition.
But the recent surge of interest suggests that economic concerns are also playing a significant role in the decisions being made by many young people applying to law schools this fall.
For one thing, the biggest increases in the number of people taking preparatory classes for the L.S.A.T. offered by Kaplan Inc., the largest test-preparation company, have been in San Francisco, Austin, New York, Boston and Washington -- all places where the collapse of the "new economy" has crushed more than a few Generation Y dot-com dreams.
Kaplan, a unit of the Washington Post Company, reports that the number of people taking its L.S.A.T. courses has increased nearly 20 percent this year, which should translate into a similar increase in actual applicants.
"We've seen this several times," said Stephen Schreiber, vice president at the Law School Admission Council. "We saw that in the mid- to late 80's. There was a big surge in test takers."
Business schools have also begun to attract more attention from young college grads. The Graduate Management Admission Council reports that 195,027 people took its test last year, up nearly 7 percent from the previous year. As of June 30, 111,203 people had taken the G.M.A.T. this year, up 12 percent over the same period last year.
For different reasons, the number of people applying to medical school has fallen steadily since 1996. Some experts see signs, however, that this decline is beginning to level off.
Still, law school applications appear to be the most affected by changes in the economic climate. Between 1991 and 1998, as the economy got better and better, the number of people applying to law school fell steadily, from 99,327 to 71,726, according to the Law School Admission Council.
In 1999, even before the economy weakened, the number of applicants climbed slightly but it stayed almost level for 2000. Now it is on the rise again.
Some schools experienced even greater gains and a few were surprised to find that more students accepted offers of admission than expected, perhaps because they found other prospects dimming.
"We didn't accept any more than we ordinarily do," said Alan D. Hornstein, associate dean at the University of Maryland School of Law in Baltimore, which has 312 students starting this fall instead of the 200 it expected. "Our yield went through the roof."
The increase in the popularity of law school has causes beyond the dot-com meltdown, said Jeffrey S. Lehman, dean of the law school at the University of Michigan. "We're seeing the echo of the baby boom generation hit law school now," he said. However, up to now, the number of people graduating from college each year has barely changed.
He said that law also appeals to more idealistic impulses, not just to materialistic ones. "The country goes through cycles in the prevalence of a public-spiritedness," he said. "Most people who are applying to law schools are motivated in significant part by a desire to make society a better place."
He acknowledged that more than 90 percent of law school graduates go on to jobs at private law firms, where many will spend at least a few years buried in piles of paper and dealing with mind-numbing details, rather than in government or with nonprofit organizations.
"Many more of our graduates would accept a public interest opportunity if it were available," Mr. Lehman said. "But the truth is that those opportunities are very scarce for those people who are just graduating from law school."
Mr. Haeberle, the laid-off dot-commer, said helping improve society was certainly one of his motivations for going to law school. "What I'm interested in more is the conceptual side of health care, in fighting to make sure that our health resources are well allocated," he said.
He started questioning his job working for a start-up that designed Web pages for television networks early this year, he said, and began to study other career options in earnest when the company -- he would not give the name because it is still hoping to raise more money -- reduced its work force by 25 percent in March.
His experience is not unusual.
Shannon Carl, a 1997 graduate of the University of Texas at Austin, was also laid off by a dot-com and is enrolled in a law school test-preparation course.
"It's really good that I did take some time off before I went back to school, because I think I'll appreciate it more," she said. "My generation was not necessarily brainwashed but further education -- you didn't have to go. It wasn't a necessity because there were all those dot-coms and there was all this opportunity out there."
But Ms. Carl, who is 26, said law school had always been a goal. So when she was laid off in April, she decided to apply. Although economic security was not her primary motivation, she said: "Law school takes care of you. If you get out of it what you put into it, then after law school you're going to get a job."
Not everybody intending to go to law school is a refugee from the Internet economy, of course. Hallie L. Parsons did not go to a dot-com, did not get laid off and knows exactly what she wants to do after law school. Ms. Parsons, 29, a property manager in San Francisco and a graduate of the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque, read her fortune after eating take-out Chinese food at her apartment in March. "In your 20's you are driven by will," the fortune read, "in your 30's by wit, and in your 40's by wisdom."
"I'm almost 30, so it's time to get some more wit," Ms. Parsons said. She had always wanted to go to law school at some point, but became involved in commercial real estate by accident, she said. Reading her fortune rekindled her interest in law and now she is busy taking Kaplan's L.S.A.T. course.
"I want to go for more knowledge, not for the career change," she said, adding that she plans to return to real estate once she has her law degree.
Even a law degree, though, is no guarantee of a good job these days. Current second- and third-year law students, many already in the midst of interviews for internships next summer or full-time jobs after graduation, say that it is much harder going right now than it was the year before. And some leading law firms have announced layoffs, suggesting that the profession is not immune to the downturn.
Business school students say the job climate has grown much darker for them, too. According to students who are just now beginning to interview as they return to campus for the fall, big consulting firms and investment banking firms that last year showered them with offers this year are being much more selective.
No doubt the new crop of law students are counting on the economy to be better when they graduate. But not everybody seeking a seat in a good law school is going to get one.
"An increase in applications will lead, probably, to a decrease in acceptance rates overall for most law schools," said Genita C. Robinson, assistant dean for admissions at the University of Chicago Law School.
And law school is not for everyone, she warned. "Law isn't just a job; it's a commitment," Ms. Robinson said. "A law degree can be a very useful tool, but you should think about what you actually want to do with it."

HEADLINE: Human Genome Appears More Complicated 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS WADE 

 BODY:
After a humiliating deflation this February, human dignity is on the recovery path, at least as measured by the number of genes in the human genome.
 Two new estimates put the likely number of human genes at around 40,000, up by a third from the estimate of about 30,000 in February by the two teams of scientists who decoded the human genome. The low estimate still has its defenders. 
 The 30,000 number suggested that evolution had not found the design, operation and maintenance of a person much more complicated than the job of running the microscopic round worm (19,000 genes), the fruit fly (13,000 genes) or the mustard cress plant (25,000 genes), the three other multicellular organisms whose genomes have been analyzed. 
Until the human genome was decoded, the textbook figure for the number of human genes had been 100,000, putting a safe distance between people and the little creatures on which the genome decoding methods were first tested.
But 100,000 was just a guess. When the 3.2 billion letters of the human genome were decoded, computer programs set to analyze the sequence found that 1 percent of the DNA consisted of genes. Both the government-financed consortium of academic centers and its rival, Celera Genomics of Rockville, Md., concluded there were 30,000 or so well-documented genes, though both allowed that the number might grow.
Dr. Michael P. Cooke, Dr. John B. Hogenesch and colleagues at the Genomics Institute of the Novartis Research Foundation in San Diego have now compared the two sets of human genes from Celera and the consortium, finding that 15,000 genes are common to both. The fact that the two sets do not entirely overlap has not been generally known. 
Based on a test of their own, the Novartis biologists believe that most of the genes found by Celera alone, and by the consortium alone, are real. If all the human genes found by only one of these groups are added to the 15,000 found by both, the total comes to around 40,000.
Dr. Cooke said his next project was to test whether all 40,000 of these predicted human genes were real.
Separately, Dr. Christopher Burge of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said he had an article in the journal Genomics suggesting that the total number of human genes was around 40,000. Dr. Burge is the author of Genscan, one of the principal programs for predicting which regions of the genome contain genes.
Dr. Cooke and Dr. Hogenesch said they were less interested in the precise number of human genes than in making sure they had the full set, however many it might be, since researchers trying to understand some aspect of the body's function could be led astray if some vital gene was missing from the catalog.
The importance of cataloging every human gene is to understand how human cells work in health and disease and to devise gene-based remedies for many ailments.
The number of genes dictates the size of that task, since it would presumably take longer to understand the roles of 40,000 than of 30,000. Obtaining the precise number is also a test of how well biologists understand the human genome.
Now that the number may be ascertainable, biologists are being more cautious in their predictions.
"People were throwing numbers around, and now there is complete silence on the subject," said Dr. Burge, suggesting there was a fear of looking foolish with the wrong estimate.
In May last year, with estimates of the number of human genes ranging all over the lot, scientists meeting at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory on Long Island organized a sweepstakes for bets on the exact tally, with the winner to be chosen in 2003.
It is now not so clear that the real number of human genes will be known any time soon. With all the estimates out there, "it has to be becoming clear to people it must not be simple," said Dr. J. Craig Venter, the president of Celera Genomics. 
Dr. Venter said that the Novartis scientists were the first to point out publicly that Celera's predicted set of human genes and that of the public consortium did not overlap much, a fact that means the consortium "has missed a lot."
Dr. Eric Lander, chief author of the consortium's report, was traveling and unavailable for comment.
Dr. Venter said he disagreed with the Novartis scientists' method and did not plan to revise his tally of 26,000 well-documented human genes. He also found other more doubtful ones, and with further research his number could go up or down by 5,000 genes.
"It will probably take 5 or 10 years to have a really accurate count plus or minus 100 genes," he said.

HEADLINE: A Political Straitjacket 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
For the last few years, across two presidents' administrations and an increasingly bitter partisan divide in Congress, Republicans and Democrats have agreed not to touch the portion of the federal budget surplus coming from the Social Security system. 
 The two parties drew that line not from a bedrock belief in the virtues of austerity but from a desire to keep the other side from getting its hands on the money and a well-grounded political fear of meddling with Social Security. 
 But it seemed to work, at least while the total budget surplus was getting bigger each year, allowing the nation to make plans to pay off its debt while still allowing consideration of tax cuts and ambitious spending programs.
Now, with the surplus outside of Social Security gobbled up by the combination of President Bush's tax cut and the ailing economy -- and with Democrats and Republicans continuing to pursue expensive and clashing agendas -- their resolve is about to be tested. 
Neither side wants to be the first to retreat from its pledge not to touch the Social Security surplus, and each seems willing to go to great lengths to avoid doing so. But people in both parties are beginning to acknowledge that the policy has left them in a quandary and that a further downturn in the economy could soon force the White House and Congress to rethink it.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, said today that the administration intended to keep the budget in balance without using any of the Social Security surplus. The bipartisan agreement to wall off that money, Mr. Lindsey said in an interview, reflects a valuable political constraint that, among other things, limits the growth of government spending.
But Mr. Lindsey said Mr. Bush had always had in mind two exceptions to his support for staying out of the Social Security surplus. One is if the country were at war. The other is if it were in a recession.
The administration is predicting a rebound in the economy next year. Should that forecast prove wrong and the economic slowdown degenerate into a downturn, Mr. Lindsey said, he would advise the president to put stimulating the economy ahead of maintaining the inviolability of the Social Security surplus.
In other words, Mr. Bush might be willing to use Social Security revenues to pay for more tax cuts if the economic situation became bleak enough.
The president is "saying the value of respecting this political constraint is very high and is more important than your run-of-the-mill spending program -- war obviously being an exception, or the need to stimulate the economy being an exception," Mr. Lindsey said. 
At the other end of the political spectrum, liberal Democrats have become increasingly uncomfortable with the straitjacket their party has put itself in. Worried that spending on education, health, the environment and other social needs will be the first to suffer if Congress and the administration begin trimming the budget to protect the Social Security surplus, they say the nation could benefit from some flexibility in budget policy.
Robert B. Reich, who was labor secretary under President Bill Clinton, said both parties "have created a fiscal trap for themselves."
"When they hear both parties talk about the importance of balancing the budget at any cost, the public naturally comes to assume that is a goal that must not be tampered with," Mr. Reich said. "Hence, we are back in the land of Calvin Coolidge."
Starting in Mr. Clinton's first term, when they voted for a tax increase to help wipe out the huge deficits that had plagued the government since the early 1980's, Democrats have worked hard to shed their tax-and-spend image and to recast themselves as guardians of fiscal responsibility and prosperity.
But unless Democrats are willing to back off somewhat from their adherence to austerity, Mr. Reich said, they risk having to sacrifice much of everything else the party stands for.
In releasing new budget projections on Wednesday, the administration forecast a Social Security surplus for the next decade of $2.5 trillion, including $171 billion next year. But it said it expected the surplus outside of Social Security to total only $575 billion over the next 10 years, down from $3.1 trillion earlier this year before passage of the tax cut and before the dimensions of the economic slowdown were clear. 
The non-Social Security surplus next year would be $1 billion, the administration said, and $2 billion in 2003. That is real money in any other context but not a very large amount when it comes to the $1.9 trillion federal budget.
The Congressional Budget Office will release its forecast next week, and it may show that the government is already dipping into Social Security money.
Some Republicans, especially those who are strong proponents of tax cuts, have always regarded the wall around the Social Security surplus as a trap set by Mr. Clinton.
In early 1998, faced with mounting demands from the Republican Congress to use the emerging surplus for tax cuts, Mr. Clinton challenged both parties to "save Social Security first." In doing so, he implied that an excessive tax cut would endanger the future of the retirement system, a politically powerful link that has bedeviled Republicans ever since, even though the government routinely spent the entire Social Security surplus for decades before that.
In economic terms, Mr. Clinton's stance was built on a belief, backed most notably by Robert E. Rubin when he was Treasury secretary, that eliminating deficits and reducing the national debt would bring down interest rates and provide a powerful stimulus to the economy.
The strategy seemed to work in the late 1990's. But as the economy has swooned, some economists have warned against sticking resolutely to austerity. And as a political matter, austerity will no doubt become less attractive to the parties as they face painful decisions about scaling back.
Mr. Bush's agenda includes costly proposals important to his party's right wing, like a buildup in military spending and the development of a missile defense. It also encompasses issues crucial to his efforts to win support from moderate voters, like increased spending on education.
In the long run, the president could have difficulty finding money to pay for his plan to add private investment accounts to Social Security.
Democrats are wondering where they will find the money for a prescription drug benefit for retirees. They could find themselves battling against cutbacks or slower growth rates in other programs as well, especially as Mr. Bush seeks savings to finance his priorities.
"It is going to be incumbent upon Congress to make sure they don't overspend," Mr. Bush told reporters today in Texas. "I will use the veto to make sure that Congress stays within the budget."

HEADLINE: A Mixed Field for a Mixed District Expected to Gain in Political Strength 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
It is a district made up of Brooklyn neighborhoods with different personalities. There is Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, with their immense population of black, middle-class residents and trendy restaurants and shops. There is Crown Heights, with its Orthodox Jewish enclave in a largely Caribbean neighborhood. There is also the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the adjacent area with its growing populations of middle-income transplants from Manhattan, both black and white.
 The 35th Council District is also the scene of one of the most hard-fought City Council campaigns of this election season, where seven candidates are battling for the Democratic nomination and the opportunity to succeed Councilwoman Mary Pinkett, who has represented this district since 1973. 
 The candidates' resumes could hardly be more divergent.
Letitia James, 41, the endorsed candidate of the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn, has worked for several Democratic officials, from Assemblyman Albert Vann to Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer. Peter M. Williams, 42, the director of Housing and Economic Development for the National Urban League, served his political apprenticeship as a technician in the mayoral campaigns of David N. Dinkins. James E. Davis, a police officer, minister and Democratic district leader, came close to beating the Brooklyn Democratic Party chairman in an Assembly race three years ago.
The race also includes Sidique Wai, the president of the United African Congress and a longtime community organizer on health concerns; William Saunders, another Democratic district leader and a long-term aide to State Senator Velmanette Montgomery; and Robert Hunter, a former investment banker and Vietnam veteran who serves on several community boards.
And then there is Abraham Wasserman, a real estate developer and the first member of the Lubavitch Hasidim community to run for a City Council seat.
Ms. James has been endorsed by many unions and Democratic officials in Brooklyn, most notably Clarence Norman Jr., the party chairman, but several of the others are well known to voters. Mr. Davis, 39, who beat the party candidate for the district leader position last year, ran twice for the Assembly and also ran against Ms. Pinkett in 1997, as did Mr. Williams in 1991.
Mr. Wai, 53, who moved to New York from Sierra Leone nearly 30 years ago, has been involved in a number of local organizing activities, including opposition to police abuse. Mr. Saunders has dealt with constituents in Senator Montgomery's office for years and has been endorsed by two members of Congress -- Major R. Owens and Edolphus Towns -- in addition to Ms. Montgomery. (Mr. Saunders refused to disclose his age except to say, "I'm a senior citizen.")
Mr. Wasserman, 51, has never run for elective office but has been a committee chairman in Community Board 9. He was elected to the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council and estimates that there are at least 2,000 registered Democrats among the Lubavitch community, which serves as his political base. "But I'm not just the Hasidic candidate," he said. "I'm reaching out to all of this district."
Like many City Council races in this year when term limits have opened many seats, the race in the 35th Council District is intriguing because no one candidate is assured of winning and each can cite circumstances that could assure a victory. It is a race in which a few thousand votes could mean victory. Moreover, to many the race is significant because it will establish a new face of leadership in an area that has become an increasingly important economic and political part of Brooklyn.
A central theme for most of the candidates is affordable housing. The arrival of newcomers from Manhattan and elsewhere causes many longtime residents, particularly in Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, to fear they will be priced out of the area. 
Mr. Williams has endorsed a proposal that the city develop a trust fund to help build housing for low- and moderate-income people. Ms. James has supported a similar plan under which proceeds from the sale of the World Trade Center would be used to construct 100,000 new housing units throughout the city. Mr. Saunders said it was important for the city to develop ways to make it easier for people to own homes. 
Mr. Hunter, who said he was in his 50's, said the Brooklyn Navy Yard would be an ideal area to be redeveloped for new low- and moderate income apartments.
Mr. Davis has made health care and public safety his central themes, saying the city should check its hospitals and clinics more carefully to ensure that they are more efficient.
The candidates have had different levels of fund-raising success. Ms. James has raised the most in outright contributions so far -- nearly $38,000 -- and $64,000 in public matching funds puts her over $100,000. Mr. Davis has the next largest total, as $55,000 in matching funds put his total at about $75,000. The only other candidate to secure matching funds so far has been Mr. Wasserman, who received $33,500 in addition to nearly $9,000 in contributions.
Mr. Williams reported nearly $30,000 in contributions, Mr. Saunders $17,000, Mr. Wai $15,500 and Mr. Hunter $7,600.
While the race has largely been a cordial one, there has been some sniping. In particular, some of the candidates have expressed displeasure with Ms. James, the only woman in the race, because of her success in challenging the nominating petitions of two women and forcing them off the ballot.
Who will ultimately prevail remains unclear to most Brooklyn politicians. "The person who works the hardest and has the best field operation is the candidate who will win this," Mr. Williams said. "And right now, it's a very open race."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Bonds Makes This Year's Run For the Books

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Perhaps the most intriguing aspect of Barry Bonds's prolific home run production this season is that no one has focused on how close he is to 60 or 61, for years and years the yardstick by which home run hitters were measured. The 1927 season of Babe Ruth and the 1961 season of Roger Maris already seem like obscure, irrelevant history.
 Mark McGwire wiped out those measuring sticks when he unleashed 70 home runs three years ago. Make that only three years ago. Ruth's record, once thought unbreakable, stood for 34 years. Maris's record, viewed by some critics as a fluke, remained in place for 37 years. Now Bonds threatens to eradicate McGwire's name from the record books only three years after it was put there. 
 Bonds, who brings his pursuit of the McGwire record to Shea Stadium for a four-game series beginning tonight, has 55 home runs. He hit his latest last night as a pinch-hitter in Montreal. He is only the ninth player to reach that number (the nine players have done it 14 times), but he is the fourth to do it (and it is the eighth time it has been done) in the last five years.
Until 1998, Ruth and Maris were the only players to hit 60 home runs, and they each did it once. In successive seasons, '98 and '99, another pair of players, McGwire and Sammy Sosa, each surpassed 60 twice. Now Bonds and Sosa are poised to do it as a duet this season.
In this era of offensive inflation, people talk about bigger and stronger players, smaller parks, inferior pitchers and juiced balls. Some whisper about the substance that is so taboo people dare not speak its name: steroids.
Two major league officials yesterday expressed concern about the possible use of steroids to build greater muscle mass, which in turn would produce more home runs.
The officials, who spoke on condition that they would not be identified, did not cite specific players.
"Look at all these guys," one official said, speaking of players generally. "Look at their arms, their upper bodies, their thighs. All of a sudden they're huge. They talk about players being bigger and stronger. Where are they getting bigger and stronger? Not in a gym. You can't do it in the gym." 
Neither official offered any evidence that any player uses any illegal or questionable substance. Because there is no evidence, the home run explosion remains untainted.
In spring training last year, Bonds talked about the explosion.
"They're just stronger and bigger," he said of the home run hitters. "That's what it comes down to. Guys are bigger and stronger."
He was asked about Sosa, who had hit a total of 129 home runs the previous two seasons after having hit a total of 170 the five seasons before that. "He's always had the ability," Bonds said. "He just came into his own. Is that supposed to shock everyone?"
Bonds, who at the age of 37 has shocked everyone, then was asked if he could hit 50 home runs in a season. Not 60, but 50.
"I never hit 50, so I'll never say I can hit 50," he replied. "If I had done it before, I'd say yes, but I've never hit 50. I'm not going to."
Bonds proved to be a prophet. He slugged a career-high 49. This season he hit No. 49 on Aug. 9 in the Giants' 115th game, then joined the 50 circle two days and two games later.
With a pair of three-homer games in the last two weeks, Sosa has sent a resounding signal that he is prepared to turn the rest of the season into the kind of stirring record chase that he engaged in with McGwire in 1998. Before the first of those explosive games, Bonds led Sosa by 49 to 37. They are only six home runs apart, 55-49.
Sosa proved what an explosive home run hitter he could be in 1998, hitting 21 in a 30-day span, the most during any 30-day period in history. Then along came Bonds this season, matching Sosa with 21 in a 30-day span, from May 17 through June 15. In the early part of that tear, Bonds hit nine home runs in six games, then expanded his run to 14 in the first 15 games of that stretch and 17 in 21. 
But Bonds has had his rough stretches as well. Not long after his 30-day eruption, he went 14 games without a home run and managed to hit only three in a 28-game span. Just when it seemed as though his run at the record might be over, he burst to life and connected for 12 home runs in 21 games, bringing him to 54.
Bonds has one difference in his pursuit of McGwire's record than McGwire did in chasing Maris's mark. With an unbalanced schedule, Bonds will face pitchers in his division more than McGwire did in his. Of the Giants' remaining 35 games, 25 are with National League West teams.
Three of the four teams against which Bonds has hit the most home runs this season are in the N.L. West. He has hit seven home runs each against Arizona and San Diego and has six games left with each. He has hit five home runs against Colorado, which plays the Giants seven times.
His favorite pitches this season have come from one of the best pitchers in the league, Curt Schilling of Arizona. Bonds has hit three home runs against Schilling, including two in a July 26 game. Just eight days earlier, Bonds socked two against Mike Hampton of Colorado.
Based on the Rockies' rotation, Hampton will pitch against the Giants Sept. 1 but miss the second series with them. If the Diamondbacks maintain their rotation, Schilling will miss the first series with the Giants but pitch in the second Sept. 5. In all, the Giants will play teams with 12 pitchers who are among the 21 in the N.L. best noted for their home run largesse. Schilling and Hampton are among those dozen, as are Kevin Jarvis and Bobby Jones of San Diego, Wade Miller and Pedro Astacio of Houston and Steve Trachsel of the Mets, who is scheduled to face Bonds tomorrow night.
Trachsel gave up Bonds's 15th home run May 11, but he is better known for the home run McGwire hit against him in 1998 when he pitched for the Cubs. It was No. 62, the record-breaker. Trachsel said earlier this week that McGwire's home run wasn't the worst thing that has ever happened to him. In fact, he said, it was "kinda cool" to be in the record books as the pitcher who threw the historic pitch. A pitcher's perspective can change with the years.
The key to Bonds's chances of putting a pitcher in the record books with him could be the approach teams take -- pitch to him or walk him. McGwire walked 162 times in 155 games in 1998. Bonds has walked 128 times in the 118 games he has played.
"I don't track every game that Barry plays," said Tony La Russa, the St. Louis manager, "but with Mark nobody ever said, 'Here, I'm going to challenge you.' That was one of the most incredible parts of '98. If he normally walks 100 times, he gets 60 extra at-bats. He was pitched so carefully he had to keep expanding his zone. The Giants are in the heat of the race. They're going to be playing important games. It depends on how aggressive guys are with him, how aggressive Barry is. A lot of times Mark was trotting to first base when we needed him to swing."
An umpire who has watched Bonds for years said he is a very picky hitter.
"He doesn't swing at a lot of bad pitches where McGwire will swing at bad pitches," the umpire said. "He has a strike zone that he monitors. He works pitchers. He's not lunging to get home runs. He's not going off the plate."
Bonds walked five times in the first two games in Montreal this week. In '98, the Cardinals played the Expos the last four games of the season and McGwire walked three times. He also hit five home runs.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Germany: Economy Stalls 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The German economy stagnated in the second quarter in yet more proof that Europe has not been immune from the economic slowdown in the United States. 
The federal statistics office said gross domestic product in the second quarter had grown 0.6 percent from a year earlier, the lowest level in more than four years, from 1.4 percent in the first quarter. However, the office said, investment, particularly in construction, was stagnant and exports declined. Analysts said, however, that one positive number was the 0.9 percent increase in consumer spending.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: The Netherlands: ING'S Profit Grows 

BYLINE:  By Suzanne Kapner (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The Dutch financial services company ING Groep said second-quarter profit rose 21 percent, helped by acquisitions and lending income. 
Despite an "uncertain" economic outlook, ING said it still expected full-year earnings to rise 17 percent. Last year, ING spent $13.8 billion to increase its presence in the United States life insurance industry, buying ReliaStar Financial and two units from Aetna. Profit, excluding one-time gains, rose to 1.27 billion euros ($1.15 billion), or 65 cents a share, compared with 1.05 billion euros, or 54 cents a share, last year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing Hotels To Be Replaced 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 A powerful New Jersey casino development agency plans to spend up to $10 million to buy and raze a stretch of shabby $30-a-night hotels along Route 40, replacing them with a big hotel, an office building or both. Built mostly in the 1950's, these squat roadside motels -- with names like Sea Breeze, Hi Ho and Santa Maria -- have increasingly become home to low-rolling gamblers, prostitution and illegal drug use. 
Under a partnership with Egg Harbor Township, the state agency, the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, plans to acquire 27 properties on the north side of the road, known to generations of seashore-bound travelers as the Black Horse Pike, over the next five years and then raze them, assembling enough land for a bigger new development. Not all are motels. Some vacant properties and at least one auto repair shop are among them.
